<td width="100%">
<p><img src="biohead.gif" width=561 height=26 align=BOTTOM border=0 naturalsizeflag=3></p>
<p><b><font color="#000060" face="Arial">Public Service<br>
</font></b><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Wingdings">s</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial">Two-term <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Mayor of Anchorage<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>
(1982-1987)<br>
</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Wingdings">s</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial">Anchorage Assembly (1975-1979)<br>
</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Wingdings">s</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial">Child Advocate of the
Year awarded by the National Child Welfare League (1998)<br>
</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Wingdings">s</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial">Interstate Oil &amp;
Gas Compact Commission (1999-2000)<br>
</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Wingdings">s</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial"><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of Alaska<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>: First
Term <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>-1998<br>
</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Wingdings">s</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial"><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of Alaska<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>: Second
Term <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>-2002</font></p>
<p><b><font color="#000060" face="Arial">Business</font></b><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Wingdings"><br>
s</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial"><TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Restaurant
partnership<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> (1969-present) - <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Downtown Deli<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/><br>
</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Wingdings">s</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial"><TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Alaskan oilfield work<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>
(1968-1969) - North Slope, Cook Inlet</font></p>
<p><b><font color="#000060" face="Arial">Personal</font></b><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Wingdings"><br>
s</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial">Born, <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Tulsa,
Oklahoma<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>January 1, 1943<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/><br>
</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Wingdings">s</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial"><TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>U.S. Army<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> (1962-1965);
82nd Airborne (1963-1964), Vietnam (1964-1965)<br>
</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Wingdings">s</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial"><TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Yale University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>BA Economics<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>
(1968)<br>
</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Wingdings">s</font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial">Married <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Susan Morris<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>
(<TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1968<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/>); three children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Devon<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Luke<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Sara<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/></font></p>
<p><center><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial"><hr><br>
</font><table width=450 border=0 cellspacing=2 cellpadding=0>
<tr>
<td width="100%">
<p><center><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial"><img src="photographs/tk-construction_work.jpg" width=109 height=87 align=LEFT border=0 naturalsizeflag=3><img src="photographs/tk-computer_kids.jpg" width=108 height=87 align=RIGHT border=0 naturalsizeflag=3></font>&nbsp;</center></p>
<p><center><b><font color="#000060" size="+1" face="Arial">Administration
Focus:<br>
Jobs, Family, Kids</font></b></center></td>
</tr>
</table></center></p>
<p><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial"><img src="bullets/family.jpg" width=24 height=23 align=BOTTOM border=0 naturalsizeflag=3>
Committed to building a healthy, growing private sector economy
through partnership with industry. Emphasis on &quot;doing it
right&quot; by concentrating on jobs for Alaskans, using <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
businesses, and protecting the environment.</font></p>
<p><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial"><img src="bullets/family.jpg" width=24 height=23 align=BOTTOM border=0 naturalsizeflag=3>
Create excellence in education where failure is not an option.
Started the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> </font><font size="-1" face="Arial"><a href="http://www.educ.state.ak.us/QSchools/home.html">&quot;Quality
Schools Initiative&quot;</a></font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial">to make <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s schools better by combining mandatory
standards, comprehensive testing, and remedial action when appropriate
with increased financial support for our schools.</font></p>
<p><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial"><img src="bullets/family.jpg" width=24 height=23 align=BOTTOM border=0 naturalsizeflag=3>
Help build healthy families through the </font><font size="-1" face="Arial"><a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/smartstart/smstrt1.html">&quot;Smart
Start&quot;</a></font><font color="#000000" size="-1" face="Arial">
program for <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s children which ensures health care to all
children, strengthens prevention programs like Headstart and
day care assistance, and insists on zero tolerance for child
abuse and neglect.</font></p>
<p align=RIGHT><a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/gallery/index.html"><i>On
to Governor Knowles' Photo Gallery</i></a>&nbsp;<img src="arrow.GIF" width=22 height=12 align=BOTTOM border=0 naturalsizeflag=3></td>
</tr>
</table></center></p>

<html>
<head>




<title>franbio</title>
</head>
<body link="#0000FF" vlink="#800080">
&nbsp;
<center><table border=0 cellspacing=10 cols=2 width=600>
<tr>
<td><img src="paper.jpg" hspace=20 vspace=5 height=173 width=254 align=LEFT></td>
<td><b><font size=+2><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lt. Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Fran Ulmer<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></font></b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b><font size=+1>A little bit of history...</font></b>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=-1><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lt. Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Fran Ulmer<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> started
her career in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> politics and government almost as soon as she arrived
in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> in 1973. She was soon hired by <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>former Governor Jay Hammond<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> as
one of his key political advisors, serving first as his <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>legislative liaison<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>
and then as the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>director of Policy Development<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. At the same time, she was
an active volunteer in many local community organizations such as Big Brothers/Big
Sisters, the Salvation Army and the March of Dimes, and served as chair
of the local Planning Commission. In 1983, Fran was elected <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Mayor of<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> <a href="http://www.juneau.com/"><TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Juneau<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/></a>
and was subsequently elected the first chair of the U.S. Conference of
Women Mayors.</font></font>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=-1>Following her tenure as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Juneau's
mayor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, the Lt. Governor was elected to the first of four (two-year) terms
in the
<a href="http://www.legis.state.ak.us/">House of Representatives</a>
where she successfully sponsored dozens of bills on a wide variety of issues.&nbsp;</font></font></td>
<td><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=-1>Twice named Kids Champion
of the Year by KIDPAC, and Child Advocate of the Year by the National Association
for the Education of Young Children for her advocacy in support of education,
child care, and the prevention of child abuse and neglect, Fran sponsored
hallmark legislation securing new rights for the adult survivors of child
abuse.&nbsp;</font></font>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=-1>She was also recognized as
Legislator of the Year by the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Cancer Society for her accomplishments
in the field of health, particularly for legislation requiring insurance
providers to include coverage for routine mammograms.&nbsp; In her final
term, she served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Minority Leader of the House of Representatives<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.&nbsp;
In <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> she made history by becoming the first woman to be elected to statewide
office and to the office of the <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>. She and <a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/">Governor
Tony Knowles</a>were elected to a second term and
<a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/ltgov/speech/inaug.html">inaugurated
on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>December 7, 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/></a>.</font></font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign=CENTER><b><font size=+1>Official duties...</font></b>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=-1>The Lt. Governor's statutory
duties include supervision of the <a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/ltgov/elections/homepage.html">Division
of Elections</a>, <a href="http://www.legis.state.ak.us/cgi-bin/folioisa.dll/aac">signing
and filing of regulations</a>; production of the
<a href="http://notes.state.ak.us/pn/pubnotic.nsf/aaj?OpenView">Administrative
Journal</a>, central registration and supervision of <a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/ltgov/misc/notarymanual.html">notaries</a>,
all matters related to use of the official state seal; and serving as chair
of the <a href="http://www.dnr.state.ak.us/parks/oha_web/ahc.htm"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
Historical Commission</a>. Lt. Governor Ulmer is also a member of the Executive
Clemency Advisory Committee, the state's designee to the Arctic Winter
Games, RuralCap, the Governor's <a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/protecting_children/index.html">Children's
Cabinet</a>, the <a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/salmon/">Salmon Cabinet,
</a>served
as chair of the Bering Sea Task Force<a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/ltgov/press/bseatask.html">,
</a>the
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s Land Manager's Forum, and chair of the <a href="http://www.eed.state.ak.us/earlydev/americorps/home.html"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
State Community Service Commission</a>.&nbsp;</font></font></td>
<td><img src="Futurekids1.JPG" hspace=10 vspace=10 height=159 width=288 align=ABSBOTTOM>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=-1>In 1997 she was the Governor's
delegate to the President's Summit on Volunteerism in Philadelphia, which
reignited her desire to help young adults understand government processes.&nbsp;
In addition to fostering volunteerism through <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s Promise, Lt. Governor
Ulmer launched <i><a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/ltgov/photos/2000/lvaphotos.html">Let's
Vote! <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> - New Voters for the New Millennium </a></i>in February 2000.&nbsp;
The non-partisan effort was successful in increasing the youth voter turnout
by 48 percent for the 2000 General Election.&nbsp; Building on the <a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/ltgov/Letsvote/lvaBrochure.pdf">success
of <i>Let's Vote! <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></i></a>Lt. Governor Ulmer has turned her attention
to improving <a href="http://www.state.ak.us/itg/civic_survey/home.html">Civics
Education in the schools.</a></font></font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=+1>Working for <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>...</font></font></b>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=-1>Of particular interest to
the Lieutenant Governor is her work on the <a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/ltgov/TIC/tichome.html">Telecommunications
Information Council</a>(TIC), which she chairs. The TIC is responsible
for establishing policies and standards for voice, video and data systems
in state government.&nbsp; Lt. Governor Ulmer has also been appointed by
the Governor to serve on the <a href="http://www.astf.org/"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Science
and Technology Foundation</a>Board and the <a href="http://www.labor.state.ak.us/commish/ahric/home.htm"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
Human Resources Investment Council</a>. Lt. Governor Ulmer enjoys a close
working relationship with Governor Tony Knowles and frequently represents
the Governor and the Admnistration at statewide, national and international
functions. The Governor appointed her an as ex-officio member of the <a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/PRESS/01113.html">Governor's
Commission on Tolerance in May of 2001.</a></font></font></td>
<td><img src="victory.jpg" hspace=20 vspace=20 height=162 width=248 align=RIGHT>
<br>&nbsp;
<br>&nbsp;
<br>&nbsp;</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><img src="Autographed.jpg" hspace=10 vspace=10 height=215 width=279 align=LEFT></td>
<td>I<font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=-1>n addition to state duties,
Lt. Governor Ulmer serves on federally appointed boards and commissions:
as a member of the local and state advisory committee to the
<a href="http://www.fec.gov/">Federal
Elections Commission</a>; as one of three U.S. members (and only woman
commissioner) to the <a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/ltgov/speech/1999/npafcsymp.html">North
Pacific Anadromous Fish Commission </a>to which she was<a href="http://www.gov.state.ak.us/ltgov/press/1999/npafcpress.html">
appointed president for two years.&nbsp;</a>As a member of the local and
state government advisory committee of the <a href="http://www.fcc.gov/">Federal
Communications Commission </a>she has advocated for universal service for
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> and has helped educate the FCC on the state's need for greater access
to affordable telecommunications services.&nbsp; Fran also serves as the
Governor's designee to co-chair the
<a href="http://www.denali.gov/">Denali
Commission.&nbsp;</a>Introduced by Congress in 1998, the Denali Commissionis
an innovative federal-state partnership designed to provide critical utilities,
infrastructure, and economic support throughout <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.&nbsp; Fran also
serves on the Federal Elections Commission Advisory Panel and the <a href="http://www.aerostates.org">Aerospace
States Association</a>.</font></font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=+1>Personal interests...</font></font></b>
<center>
<p><img src="widefran1.jpg" height=225 width=300></center>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=-1>Fran is an adopted <a href="http://www.geocities.com/Athens/Atlantis/4513/">Tlingit</a>
Kaagwaantaan. She was given Annie Johnson's Tlingit name Kinzei and was
sponsored by Agnes Bellinger of Juneau. She is a member of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alaska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Native
Sisterhood, Juneau Camp Number 2.&nbsp;</font></font>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=-1>Among her many activities,
Fran continues to mentor her Little Sister Whitney through the Big Brothers/Big
Sisters program in Juneau.</font></font>
<center>
<p><img src="shakingsm.jpg" height=198 width=250></center>
</td>
<td valign=TOP><b><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=+1>Family...</font></font></b>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=-1>Fran Ulmer grew up in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>a small
town in<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> <a href="http://dir.yahoo.com/Regional/U_S__States/Wisconsin/Cities/Horicon/"><TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Wisconsin<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/></a>
where she learned to love the outdoors. After graduating from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University
of Wisconsin<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor's degree in economics and political science<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>,
Fran continued at the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Wisconsin School of Law<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> where she collected honors
with her <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>. Alaska's first woman <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> brings a
close family circle to her job. Fran is married to Juneau attorney, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Bill
Council<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> and is the mother of two college-aged children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Amy<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Louis<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.</font></font>
<center>
<p><img src="family1999.jpg" height=191 width=255>
<br>&nbsp;
<br>&nbsp;
<br>&nbsp;

</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td align=left bgcolor="#000000"><a href="http://www.governor.state.al.us/index2.htm" target=_top onmouseover="window.status='Click to Return Home'; return true"><img src="../images/new/nav-1-capitol.gif" alt="click for Flash Intro" border=0 width=90 height=127></a></td>

<td valign=top width="100%"><div align=center><center><table border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 width="100%">
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#000000" valign=top><font size=1><a name=TOP></a></font><img src="../images/dot_clear.gif" width=1 height=25 alt></td>

<td valign=top nowrap></td>
<td valign=top width=500><u><strong><font face="arial,helvetica" size=4><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Don
Siegelman<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></font></strong></u><br>
<br>
<img name=slideshow src="../images/bio/gov-sch-01.jpg" border=1 align=right alt width=300 height=200><font face="arial,helvetica" size=2><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Don Siegelman<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is noted for his work in improving education, children&#146;s services, economic development and promoting anticrime initiatives including drunk driving and domestic violence prevention. Governor Siegelman is committed to changing education in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> for the better and changing education forever.  Siegelman&#146;s first act as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> was to sign an executive order to eliminate portable classrooms in public schools and to build safe new classrooms for school children. He also signed a bill into law to raise teacher salaries to the national average and removed tenure for principals.  He has implemented the nationally recognized <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Reading Initiative in 429 schools and has provided rewards for schools that meet and exceed <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#146;s standards for education. The Fordham Foundation has recognized <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> for being among the top five states in the nation with academic and accountability standards. Governor Siegelman proved his commitment to children by appointing the state&#146;s first children&#146;s commissioner and children&#146;s cabinet.  Additionally, the governor created the Office of School Readiness to begin providing early learning opportunities to four-year olds throughout the state. Governor Siegelman believes in making <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#146;s homes, streets and schools safer, and has signed a number of domestic violence bills into law including one making domestic violence a crime in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>. Siegelman has continued to push for tougher DUI laws including increasing penalties for adults driving drunk with a child in the car. Since becoming governor, Siegelman has expanded industry across the state by announcing the location of businesses including Honda, Navistar, Fiat and Boeing and expansion of Mercedes in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.  Siegelman was also instrumental in enacting tort reform, including caps on punitive damages and established a task force charged with developing the State&#146;s first long-term strategic plan for economic growth.  Governor Siegelman was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Mobile, Alabama<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>1946<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>.  He graduated from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Alabama<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1968, <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Georgetown University School of Law<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1972 and studied International Law at <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Oxford University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Oxford, England from 1972 to 1973.  He and his wife <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Lori<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> live in Montgomery with their two children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Dana<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Joseph<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.</font></td>
<td valign=top nowrap></td>
<td valign=top nowrap>

<tr>
<td height=26 valign=top width=50>&nbsp;</td>
<td valign=top colspan=2 width=266 align=left height=26></td>
<td height=26 valign=top width=30>&nbsp;</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width=50 valign=top height=14></td>
<td colspan=2 valign=top width=266 align=left height=14>
</td>
<td width=30 valign=top height=14></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width=50 valign=top height=544></td>
<td colspan=2 valign=top width=266 align=left height=544>
<div align=left style="width: 365; height: 873"><font color="#162D4F"><br>
<br>
<font size=3 face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><b>Lt. Governor
Windom and His Family</b></font>
<b><font size=3 face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><br>
<br>
</font></b></font><img src="swearingin1.jpg" align=left><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial"><font size=2>On
<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 3, 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Steve Windom<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> of Theodore was elected <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant
Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> to become the first <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> to hold the
office in 124 years.<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial"><font size=2>Lt.
Gov. Windom represented the Mobile area in the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> State
Senate from 1989-98.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial">&nbsp;
</span>During his tenure in the Senate, he served as chairman of
the Banking and Insurance Committee. He was honored by the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
Wildlife Federation as the 1995 Conservation Legislator of the
Year. In 1996, he was the Legislator of the Year by the National
Federation of Independent Business.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial">&nbsp;
</span>He was selected 1997 Legislator of the Year by the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
Independent Insurance Agents.<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial"><font size=2>Lt.
Gov. Windom graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Sidney Lanier High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in
Montgomery, the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Alabama<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of
Alabama School of Law<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial">&nbsp;
</span>While at <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, he was selected for membership in
Jasons, the senior Honor Society at the University, Omicron
Delta Kappa and Whos Who Among Students.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial">&nbsp;
</span>He was a member of the nationally recognized University
Debate Team.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial">&nbsp;
</span>In law school he was elected to the Student Senate,
received the Libby Anderson Cater award as Most Outstanding
Student Legislator and was named to the Bench and Bar Legal Honor
Society.<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial"><font size=2>In
1974, Lt. Gov. Windom moved to Mobile and joined the firm of
<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>McDermott, Slepian, Kittrell and Fleming<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, which later became
<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>McDermott, Slepian, Windom and Reed<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial">&nbsp;
</span>In 1986, the firm merged with the Birmingham-based firm
<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Sirote<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> &amp; <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Permutt<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, where he is currently a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>senior partner<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial">&nbsp;
</span>He is a member of the Mobile Bar Association, the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
Bar Association, the American Bar Association, the Bar of the
Supreme Court of the United States and American Association of
Attorney Mediators.<o:p>
</o:p>
<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoBodyText" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial"><font size=2>Lt.
Gov. Windom has been an active member of the Mobile community. He
has served <span style="mso-spacerun: yes; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial">&nbsp;</span>as
a board member of the Mobile Area Chamber of Commerce, as an
officer and board member of the Mobile Jaycees, past president and
board chairman of the Greater Gulf Coast State Fair, past
president of the Cystic Fibrosis Association and as a member of
the Downtown Mobile Lions Club. <o:p>
</o:p>
<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial; mso-fareast-font-family: Times New Roman; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA"><font size=2>During
his college days, Lt. Gov. Windom served in the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>United States Air
Force Reserve<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. Today, he is a member of the First Baptist Church
of Tillmans Corner.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial">&nbsp;
</span>He is married to the former <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Mary Becker<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> of Bay Minette and
is the father of two adult sons, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Robert<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Thomas<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.</font></span></div>
</td>
<td valign=top width=30 height=544></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<head>
<title>State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> -<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> - Biography</title>
</head>

<body marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" leftmargin="0" topmargin="0" bgcolor="#FFFFFF" text="#000000" alink="#FF00FF" onload="runit()" background="Images/nav-back.gif">
<div align="left">

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%">
  <tr>
    <td valign="top" align="left"><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
      <tr>
        <td align="left" bgcolor="#000000"><a href="http://www.governor.state.al.us/" target="_top"><img src="Images/nav-1-capitol.gif" alt="click for home" border="0" width="90" height="127"></a></td>
      </tr>
    </table>
    </td>
    <td bgcolor="#FFFFFF" valign="top" width="100%"><div align="center"><center><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%">
      <tr>
        <td bgcolor="#800080" valign="top"><font size="1"><a name="TOP" target="main"></a></font><img src="Images/dot_clear.gif" width="1" height="10" alt></td>
        <td bgcolor="#800080" valign="top" align="right"><img src="Images/dot_clear.gif" width="1" height="10" alt></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td bgcolor="#800080"><img src="Images/dot_clear.gif" width="8" height="1" alt><img border="0" src="Includes/FL-name-title.gif" width="276" height="46"></td>
        <td bgcolor="#800080" align="right"><img border="0" src="Images/FL-top-title.gif" width="399" height="59"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td bgcolor="#800080" valign="top"><img src="Images/dot_clear.gif" width="1" height="10" alt></td>
        <td bgcolor="#800080" valign="top" align="right"><img src="Images/dot_clear.gif" width="1" height="10" alt></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td bgcolor="#FFFFFF" valign="top"></td>
        <td bgcolor="#FFFFFF" valign="top" align="right"><form NAME="form2" target="main">
          <font size="2"><p>&nbsp;</p>
          </font>
        </form>
        </td>
      </tr>
    </table>
    </center></div></td>
  </tr>

</div>
<div align="left">

        <td bgcolor="#FFFFFF"><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1" bgcolor="#CC3399">

          <tr>
            <td bgcolor="#FFFFFF"><a href="http://www.governor.state.al.us/firstlady/index.htm" onMouseOver="swapOn('image5'); return true" onMouseOut="swapOff('image5');"><img src="images/menu/fl-menu-home-off.gif" name="image5" alt border="0" width="77" height="27"></a></td>

        </td>
      </tr>
    </table>
      <p>&nbsp;
</td>
    <td valign="top" nowrap></td>
    <td valign="top" width="500"><u><strong><font face="arial,helvetica" size="3"><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>First
      Lady<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Lori Siegelman<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></font></strong></u><br>
      <br>
      <img border="2" src="Images/bio/First-lady-portrait.jpg" align="right" width="200" height="223"><font face="Arial" size="2"><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Lori Allen Siegelman<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is a long-time supporter of
      the arts, children, volunteerism and <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s wildlife and wilderness
      areas.<br>
            <br>
            Lori attributes her deep appreciation of the
      arts to her father, Irvin, who was a pianist and artist, and to her
      mother, Evelyn, who is an arts activist. She serves as a volunteer with
      Booker T. Washington High School, an arts magnet high school in Montgomery,
            as a member of the board of directors of the&nbsp;Alabama
      Shakespeare Festival, Birmingham Summerfest Junior Ensemble, the N.A.L.L.
      Art Foundation, and various arts initiatives.<br>
      &nbsp;</font>
            <table border="0" width="100%">
              <tr>
                <td width="75%"><img name="slideshow" src="images/bio/rotate-art3.jpg" border="4" hspace="5" vspace="5" valign="top" align="left" width="150" height="225">
<font face="Arial"><font size="2">Lori is creating many projects to stimulate
      students involvement in the arts.
      These projects include the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#146;s Children Arts Festival and
      Reach for the Stars, which serves to inspire children to reach for their
      goals by following the examples of other successful Alabamians.
      She serves on the board of directors of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Civil Justice
      Foundation which provides financial assistance to charitable organizations
      that support disadvantaged, disabled and at-risk children.
      She also hosts an annual Easter Egg hunt for&nbsp;disadvantaged and
      disabled&nbsp;children and Christmas party for children who are awaiting
      permanent placement with families.</font><br>
                  &nbsp;&nbsp;</font></td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                      <td width="100%" valign="top"><img border="2" src="Images/bio/LORI-SIEGELMAN-2.jpg" width="132" height="191" align="right"><font face="Arial" size="2">Her
                        love of the outdoors is exemplified through her
                        involvement as co-chairperson of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#146;s Millennium
                        Trails Project which is part of a national initiative
                        that recognizes, promotes and stimulates the creation of
                        trails that bring people and communities together in a
                        healthy way, to honor the past and imagine the future.<br>
                        She is also committed to the restoration of WPA-era log and
      stone cabins in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Alabama<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> State parks.&nbsp;<br>
                        &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<br>
                        Lori graduated from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Alabama<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor&#146;s
      degree in social work<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> and received a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>master&#146;s degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Florida State
      University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.&nbsp; In addition to being a mother, wife and first lady, she
      is a professional therapist and currently employed with a private
      counseling center.<br>
                        &nbsp;<br>
                  She and <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Governor Siegelman<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> are the proud parents of daughter
                  <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Dana<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and son <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Joseph<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.</font></td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td width="75%"></td>
              </tr>
            </table>
      &nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" nowrap></td>
    <td valign="top" nowrap>
      <p>
</td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td valign="top" nowrap></td>

<title><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jane Dee Hull<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></title>
</head>
<body leftmargin=0 topmargin=0 link="#7d98b6" bgcolor=navy>
<table width=700 border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 align=left valign=top>
<tr>
<td valign=top bgcolor="#7d98b6">
<table id=navigation width=150 border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 align=left valign=TOP bgcolor="#7d98b6">
<tr>
<td align=middle valign=top><img alt="State Seal" border=0 height=125 src="graphics/seal.jpg" width=125></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#7d98b6"><a href="http://www.state.az.us" target=_blank><font face="Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif" size=2 color=white pointsize=10><strong>State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Arizona<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></strong></font></a></td>

<td valign=bottom><img height=1 src="graphics/sep.gif" width=145></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#7d98b6"><a href="index.html"><font face="Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif" size=2 color=white pointsize=10><strong>Governor Hull</strong></font></a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign=bottom><img height=1 src="graphics/sep.gif" width=145></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#7d98b6"><a href="govbio.html"><font face="Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif" size=2 color=white pointsize=10><strong>Governor's Biography</strong></font></a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign=bottom><img height=1 src="graphics/sep.gif" width=145></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#7d98b6"><a href="sos/index.html"><font face="Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif" size=2 color=white pointsize=10><strong>State of the State</strong></font></a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign=bottom><img height=1 src="graphics/sep.gif" width=145></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#7d98b6"><a href="news/index.html"><font face="Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif" size=2 color=white pointsize=10><strong>News Room</strong></font></a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign=bottom><img height=1 src="graphics/sep.gif" width=145></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#7d98b6"><a href="kids/index.html" target=_top><font face="Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif" size=2 color=white pointsize=10><strong><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Arizona<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Kids</strong></font></a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign=bottom><img height=1 src="graphics/sep.gif" width=145></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#7d98b6"><a href="post/index.html"><font face="Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif" size=2 color=white pointsize=10><strong>Contact Governor Hull</strong></font></a></td>
</tr>

<td valign=bottom><img height=1 src="graphics/sep.gif" width=145></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#7d98b6"><a href="offices/index.html"><font face="Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif" size=2 color=white pointsize=10><strong>Offices of the Governor</strong></font></a></td>

<td><img alt="" border=0 height=399 src="graphics/spacer.gif" style="HEIGHT: 399px; WIDTH: 50px" width=50></td>

</table>
</td>
<td valign=top bgcolor=white>
<table align=left width=550 border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 bgcolor=white valign=TOP>
<tr>
<td height=60 bgcolor=navy colspan=2><img height=60 width=550 align=middle alt="" border=0 src="graphics/banner.jpg"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan=2 bordercolor=white><center><font face=arial size=6><strong><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jane Dee Hull<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></font><br><font size=4>Governor, Secretary of State, 
Speaker of the House</strong></font><br><img alt="" border=0 src="graphics/seperator.gif" width=400 height=6></center></font><br></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0.12in"><p><font face=arial size=2>As 
<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Arizona<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jane Dee Hull<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> lists education, 
healthcare, the economy and preserving the states natural 
beauty as her top priorities.&nbsp; She has made a record 
number of judicial appointments and enacted tax cuts for a 
record eighth and ninth consecutive years, including 
reductions in the vehicle licensing tax and selected business 
taxes. </p>
<p>In education, Governor Hull resolved the 
long debate on school construction with the 
StudentsFIRST program that assures equity for every student in 
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Arizona<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.&nbsp; Seven new schools are built and filled with students 
and another 125 new schools have been approved.&nbsp; Another $380 
million is approved to upgrade school buildings.</p>
<p><img align=right alt="Governor Hull" border=0 height=260 src="graphics/current_old2.jpg" width=199>
Governor Hull now is focused on strengthening learning in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Arizona<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> classrooms.&nbsp; Hulls 
Education 2000 proposal, which will raise $459&nbsp;million in new funds, passed the Legislature 
in June and was approved by a public vote in November.&nbsp; It will 
provide higher teacher salaries and smaller classrooms in 
kindergarten through high school and encourages New Economy 
initiatives in higher education.&nbsp; After the Legislature passed 
Education 2000, the Governors public approval ratings reached 75 
percent.&nbsp;</p>
<p>In health care, 94,000 children of the working poor now receive 
health coverage thanks to the Governors KidsCare program.&nbsp; In 
behavioral health, funding for the seriously mentally ill has 
increased by 84 percent since the Governor took office, up from $225 
million in fiscal year 1997 to $415 million in fiscal year 
2001.&nbsp; The Governor also obtained a three-year appropriation of 
$80 million to build a new <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Arizona<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> State Hospital and the initial 
phases of construction have begun. Growth management and open space 
are also top priorities.&nbsp; Hulls Preserve <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Arizona<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> initiative, 
passed by voters in 1998, provides $220 million as matching funds 
for open space preservation.</p>
<p>The 2000 Growing Smarter Plus law gives 
local communities tough tools to control sprawl.</p>
<p>Current initiatives from the Governor 
include the Vision 21 Transportation Task Force, the Partnership for 
the New Economy, a steering committee that has developed strategies 
to enhance <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Arizona<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s participation in the knowledge-based New 
Economy and the Efficiency and Accountability in K-12 Education Task 
Force.&nbsp;</p>
<p>Born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Kansas 
City<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, Governor Hull and her husband <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Dr. Terry Hull<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> came to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Arizona<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> 
in 1962.&nbsp; Dr. Hull served as a physician in public health 
service and the Governor <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>taught school on the Navajo Nation<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> until 
1964.&nbsp; They settled in <TAG name="RESCITY" value="start"/>Phoenix<TAG name="RESCITY" value="end"/> where Dr. Hull practiced 
obstetrics and gynecology for 32 years and now works as a 
consultant.&nbsp; Governor Hull served the <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> Party by 
becoming a legislator, the first woman Speaker of the House and the 
first <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> Secretary of State in 50 years before becoming 
<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1997<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> </p>
<p>Governor Hull's contributions to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Arizona<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> have been widely recognized.  For example some of the Governor's awards include: </p>
<ul>
<li>October 21, 1989 
<p style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0.12in">The Distinguished Public Award presented by the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Arizona<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Regional Board of Directors of the Anti-Defamation League.</p>
<li>1999
<p style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0.12in">The Athena Award presented by the international business group, the Athena Foundation.</p>
<li>May 3, 2000 
<p style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0.12in">Lifetime Achievement for Excellence in Education presented by the Metropolitan Education Commission. </p>
<li>May 18, 2001
<p style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0.12in">The Good Neighbor Award presented by the United States-Mexico Chamber of Commerce. </p>
<li>June 3-9, 2001
<p style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0.12in">The LULAC (League of United Latin American Citizens) Convention Award.</p>
<li>2001
<p style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0.12in">The Friends of Education Award presented by the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Arizona<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Education Association.</p>
</li>
</ul></font>
<p><font size=-1>Governor Hulls 
Press Office: (602) 542-1342</font></p>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><img alt="" border=0 height=23 src="graphics/spacer.gif" style="HEIGHT: 23px; WIDTH: 50px" width=50></td>
</tr>
</table>
</td></tr>
</table>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<input border=0 name=submit type=submit value="Search"><br>
<a href="http://energybrain.ca.gov/SRVS/CGI-BIN/WEBCGI.EXE?New,Kb=HowDoI_KB,U={B8F60310-DA4F-11D3-94F4-00500463020E},Company={7B418571-6948-11D5-A454-00306E027861},d=993765549453,VARSET_BV_SessionID=@@@@2067332694.0998330643@@@@,VARSET_BV_EngineID=callkclfmihbemfcfkmchcgi.0"><img alt="Most Frequently Asked Questions" border=0 height=17 src="/govsite/images/howdoi.gif" width=68><img alt=" " border=0 height=6 src="/govsite/images/spacer.gif" width=6><a href="gov_search_adv.jsp?BV_SessionID=@@@@2067332694.0998330643@@@@&BV_EngineID=callkclfmihbemfcfkmchcgi.0"><img alt="Advanced Search" border=0 height=17 src="/govsite/images/advansearch.gif" width=93>

<tr>
<td colspan=3 valign=top>
<table border=0 cellpadding=0 width=601>
<tr>
<td>
<img alt=" " border=0 height=10 src="/govsite/images/spacer.gif" width=10>
</td>
<td>

<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=10 width="100%">
<tr>
<td align=left valign=TOP>
<img align=LEFT src="/govsite/images/biography/Gray_Davis_Bio.gif" width=125 height=158 border=0 alt="Photograph of Governor Gray Davis">
<p align=JUSTIFY>&nbsp;</p>
<p class=content><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Joseph Graham Davis, Jr<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>. (nicknamed Gray by his mother) was overwhelmingly elected the 37th <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 3, 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, winning 58 percent of the statewide vote. In the June primary election, Davis shocked political observers by not only handily defeating two better funded <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Democratic<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> opponents, but by also finishing ahead of the unopposed Republican nominee. It was the continuation of an old tradition; in his successful campaign for <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1994, he received more votes than any other <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Democratic<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> candidate in America.  </p>
<p class=content>Described by the San Jose Mercury News as "perhaps the best-trained Governor-in-waiting <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> has ever produced." <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Gray Davis<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> has made improving public education his administration's number-one priority. As his first official act as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, he called a special session of the Legislature to address his proposals to ensure that every child can read by age 9, strengthen teacher training and education, and increase accountability in the schools. </p> <p class="content">As <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Gray Davis<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> focused on efforts to keep jobs in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> and encourage new and fast-growing industries to locate and expand in the state. He also led the fight to keep a college education affordable for <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s middle-class families, pushing through the largest student-fee reduction in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> history. As the state's second-highest officeholder, he also served as President of the State Senate, Chair of the Commission for Economic Development, Chair of the State Lands Commission, Regent of the University of California and Trustee of the California State University. </p> <p class="content">Prior to becoming <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, Gray Davis served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>State Controller<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for eight years. As <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s chief fiscal officer, he saved taxpayers more than half a billion dollars by cracking down on Medi-Cal fraud, rooting out government waste and inefficiency, and exposing the misuse of public funds. He was the first <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Controller<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> to withhold paychecks from all state elected officials, including himself, until the Governor and the Legislature passed a long-overdue budget; and he found and returned more than $1.8 billion in unclaimed property to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> citizens, including forgotten bank accounts, insurance settlements, and stocks. </p><p class=content>From 1983-1987, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Gray Davis<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>served in the State Assembly from Los Angeles County<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and was <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Chief of Staff<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> to <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Governor Edmund G. Brown, Jr<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. from 1975-1981. As Chair of the California Council on Criminal Justice in the 1970s, he started the statewide Neighborhood Watch program. </p><p class=content><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Gray Davis<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>New York City<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>December 26, 1942<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>. As a cum laude graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Stanford University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> with a <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Columbia University Law School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> degree, he served as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>U.S. Army Captain<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in Vietnam and was awarded the Bronze Star for meritorious service. </p><p class=content>He has been married since <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1983<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/> to the former <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Sharon Ryer<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> of Santee, San Diego County. <br></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>


</td>

<td colspan=3 bgcolor="#CEDBEF" valign=TOP>
<p><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=2><br>
<font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=1><a href="../about/biography.asp">BIOGRAPHY</a></font></font></b></p>
<div align=LEFT><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=2><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=1>

<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lt. Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></a></b></font></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=MIDDLE align=LEFT bgcolor="#ECF1F9">
<td height=20><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=1><b><a href="photo/photogallery.asp#Speaker">As

</p>
</div>

<table width="101%" border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0>
<tr>
<td width=149 height=770 bgcolor="#CEDBEF">
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</td>
<td width=15 height=770>&nbsp;</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>
</td>
<td colspan=3 rowspan=3 bgcolor="#FFFFFF" valign=TOP align=LEFT>
<p><b><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=4><br>
Biography</font></b></p>
<hr size=1 width="98%">
<div align=LEFT><img src="../images/biocruz.jpg" width=215 height=240 alt="Photo of the Lt. Governor" align=right hspace=5><font size=2 face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Cruz 
M. Bustamante<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was elected <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor of the State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> 
in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, the latest step in a career in public office that began 
when he was elected to the state Assembly in a special election in 1993. 
He was elected <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Speaker of the Assembly<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> by his colleagues in December 1996, 
and served as Speaker until February 1998. A first generation Californian, 
Bustamante was the first Latino to serve as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Speaker of the Assembly<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, and 
upon his election as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, he became the first Latino elected 
to statewide office in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> in more than 120 years. </font></div>
<p align=LEFT><font size=2 face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">As 
<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, Bustamante is the President of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Senate, 
serves as a Regent of the University of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> and is a Trustee of 
the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> State University system. The Lieutenant Governor also serves 
as a member of the State Lands Commission, chairman of the Commission 
for Economic Development, vice-chairman of the Commission of the Californias, 
and is a member of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Rural Policy Task Force and the World 
Trade Commission. </font></p>
<p align=LEFT><font size=2 face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">During 
his term, Lieutenant Governor Bustamante has participated in international 
trade missions to Mexico, Germany, Israel and Italy. In addition, he hosted 
a trade summit with the Governor of the Mexican State of Jalisco. To promote 
tolerance and encourage dialogue on issues of diversity, Bustamante formed 
the Lieutenant Governor&#146;s Commission for One <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>. This commission 
meets quarterly and is currently exploring ways in which the media and 
our schools can foster tolerance. During Bustamante's term as Speaker, 
the Legislature reduced class sizes, enacted a $1.7 billion tax cut, extended 
health insurance coverage to 600,000 low-income children, reformed welfare 
and rolled back student fees at state universities and colleges. Bustamante 
authored the laws that provided $1 billion to put updated textbooks into 
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> classrooms, allowed the State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> to join the multi-state 
litigation against tobacco companies, and prohibited job application fees.</font></p>
<p align=LEFT><font size=2 face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Governor 
Gray Davis named the Lieutenant Governor as co-chair of the Governor&#146;s 
Commission on Building for the 21<sup>st</sup>Century, which is directed 
to develop a long-term plan to address the state&#146;s critical infrastructure 
needs. The Governor also named him to the University of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Merced 
Implementation Team, a task force proposed by the Lieutenant Governor 
to speed up the formation of the tenth University of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> campus. 
An advocate of full participation in the 2000 decennial census, Lieutenant 
Governor Bustamante proposed the creation of a panel to develop and oversee 
an outreach strategy to encourage full participation in the 2000 federal 
decennial census. Based on this proposal, Governor Davis created the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> 
Complete Count Committee and named Lieutenant Governor Bustamante as a 
member. In January 2000, Bustamante was also appointed by President Bill 
Clinton to serve on the United States Census Monitoring Board, which is 
responsible for monitoring the Census Bureau's preparation and implementation 
for the 2000 decennial census.</font></p>
<p align=LEFT><font size=2 face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">A 
native of <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Dinuba, California<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>, and a graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Tranquility High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, 
Bustamante attended <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Fresno City College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, and then <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Fresno State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, 
where he was active in the student Senate. Bustamante served as the Program 
Director of the Summer Youth Employment Training Program, which was responsible 
for employing more than 3,000 Central Valley teenagers each summer. He 
later worked as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>district representative<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Congressman Rick Lehman<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> 
and <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Assemblyman Bruce Bronzan<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, whom he replaced in the Assembly in 1993. 
</font></p>
<p align=LEFT><font size=2 face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Devoted 
to his family, Bustamante is married to the former <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Arcelia De La Pena<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>. 
They have three daughters, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Leticia<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Sonia<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Marisa<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>; a grandson, David; 
and a granddaughter, Lauren.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr></tr>
<tr></tr>
</table>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<td colspan=3 valign=top>

<tr>
<td>
<img alt=" " border=0 height=10 src="/govsite/images/spacer.gif" width=10>
</td>
<td>

<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=10 width="100%">
<tr>
<td align=left valign=TOP>
<img align=LEFT src="/govsite/images/biography/Sharon_Davis_Bio.gif" alt="Sharon Davis" width=168 height=191 border=0>
<p align=JUSTIFY>&nbsp;</p>
<p class=content><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Sharon Davis<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> focuses her attention on issues that affect children's health, safety and well being.  Both Governor Davis and the First Lady share a commitment to the State's most precious resource, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s children.  The First Lady's vision of ensuring that all children be nurtured and cared for in a safe, protective environment complements the Governor's priority of strengthening education for <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s six million public school children.</p><p class=content>As <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Sharon Davis<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is an effective advocate for children by focusing on education and health issues.  She visits schools throughout the state to encourage students to raise their expectations and performance as well as to promote parental involvement.</p><p class=content>The First Lady is the official spokesperson for the Healthy Families Program, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s health insurance program that provides full medical, dental, and vision care coverage for children of working families.  Since Governor Gray Davis took office, the number of children enrolled in Healthy Families increased by 300 percent.  </p> <p class="content">The First Lady plays a key role in the California Mentor Initiative which assists the Davis Administration goal to recruit one million new mentors across the state.  Mentors offer young people encouragement, friendship and motivation to help them not only excel academically, but in every aspect of their lives.</p> <p class="content">Each year in October, the First Lady hosts the annual Governor's Conference for Women, the most prestigious one-day women's conference in the nation, bringing together 10,000 women from diverse backgrounds.  She has also participated in the Habitat for Humanity First Ladies Build national program.<br></p>
<p class=subtitle>Community Involvement</p>
<ul class=content><li><i>Spokesperson,</i><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Healthy Families Program</li><li><i>Honorary Chair,</i>Governor's Book Fund</li> <li><i>Honorary Chair,</i> <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Mentor Initiative</li> <li><i>Advisory Council Member,</i> School-to-Work Advisory Council</li> <li><i>Honorary Chair,</i> Girl Scouts of America</li> <li><i>Honorary Chair,</i> Leland Stanford Mansion Foundation</li> <li><i>Honorary Chair,</i> Governor's Office on Service and Volunteerism(GovServ)</li><li><i>Honorary Chair,</i>Keep California Beautiful</li><li><i>Founding Member,</i>Los Angeles BUDDY Committee of the NOW Legal Defense Fund</li><li><i>Honorary President of the Board of Directors,</i>Children Uniting Nations</li><li><i>Member of the Los Angeles Board of Directors,</i>United States Holocaust Memorial Museum</li><li><i>Member,</i>National Women's Political Caucus, Westside</li><li><i>Co-Chair,</i><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>California<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Arts Council Creativity Forum </li></ul>
<p class=content>In the early 1990s, <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Sharon Davis<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was founder and managing partner of the Davis Miller Company, a public relations firm specializing in high-tech companies and consumer products.  She previously served as Program Director for a non-profit foundation, with a $3 million annual giving program.  The First Lady grew up in the San Diego suburb of <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Santee<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> with her parents, Donald and Mary Ryer, her sister and five brothers. She studied journalism at <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>California State University, Sacramento<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. </p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>


</td>
</tr>

Policy</a>|
