<html>
<head>


<title><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Bill Owens<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> Biography</title>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
<font size=+2>Biography</font>
<blockquote><font size=+3><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/></font>
<br><font size=+3><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Bill Owens<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></font>
<br>&nbsp;
<table border=0 width="90%">
<tr>
<td valign=TOP width="21%"><font size=1><img src="http://www.state.co.us/gov_dir/billbio.jpg" height=148 width=117>
<br>Birthdate:&nbsp;
<br><TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>October 22, 1950<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/></font>
<p><font size=1>Spouse:&nbsp;
<br><TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Frances Owens<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/></font>
<p><font size=1>Family: Married,&nbsp;
<br>three children</font>
<p><font size=1>Religion:&nbsp;
<br>Catholic</font>
<p><font size=1>Occupation:&nbsp;
<br><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></font>
<p><font size=1>Elected:&nbsp;
<br><TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/></font>
<p><font size=1>Term Expires:&nbsp;
<br>January 2003</font>
<p><font size=1>State Population:&nbsp;
<br>4 million</font>
<p><font size=1>State Budget:&nbsp;
<br>$10.9 billion</font>
<p><font size=1>Chief of Staff:&nbsp;
<br>Roy Palmer</font>
<p><font size=1>Media Contacts:&nbsp;
<br>Dick Wadhams
<br>Amy Sampson</font>
<p><font size=1><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>
<br>136 State Capitol&nbsp;
<br>Denver, CO 80203</font>
<p><font size=1>(303) 866-2471 Phone</font>
<p><font size=1>(303) 866-2003 Fax</font>
<p><font size=1>Website <a href="http://www.state.co.us/">www.state.co.us</a></font></td>
<td valign=TOP width="79%">
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:.4pt;border-collapse:
 collapse;mso-table-layout-alt:fixed;mso-padding-alt:0in 0in 0in 0in">
<tr>
<td width=500 style="width:375.0pt;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in">
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Times New Roman"><strong>Career:
</strong><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Times New Roman">Prior
to his election as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Bill Owens<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> worked for 20 years in
the private sector with the consulting staff at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Deloitte and Touche<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, with
the Gates Corp., and as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>director of a trade association<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. His <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>undergraduate
degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> is from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Stephen F. Austin State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, and he earned a
<TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>master's degree in Public Affairs<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Lyndon B. Johnson School at the
University of Texas<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, where he was awarded a two-year fellowship. <o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Times New Roman">Election
History:</span></b><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Times New Roman">
<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Times New Roman">Governor
Owens was sworn in as <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s 40th <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>January 12, 1999<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, the
first <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> to be elected <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in 28 years. Owens also
<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>served in both the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> House of Representatives and the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
Senate<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, as well as for four years as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>State Treasurer<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Owens was the first <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> elected <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Treasurer<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 20 years.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Times New Roman">Accomplishments:</span></b><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Times New Roman">
<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Times New Roman">In
his first two years in office, Governor Owens fulfilled all three of the
pledges he made during his 1998 campaign.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Owens pushed through the legislature the largest tax relief package
in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s history  a $1 billion per year of tax cuts.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>This includes a cut the income tax rate, a lowering of the sales
tax rate, elimination of the marriage penalty, and a reduction in the
capital gains tax. <o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoBodyText"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Times New Roman">As
<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, Owens passed a comprehensive education reform package that will
be the first step in bringing true accountability to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s public
schools.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>The plan implements
annual student testing, accountability reports on every school and
automatic conversion of failed public schools to charter schools.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Owens also boosted <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s K-12 education funding in real
terms for the first time in a decade.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoBodyText"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Times New Roman">Owens
sought and received voter approval of a referendum to allow bonding of
highway construction projects, speeding up major road improvements across
the state without raising taxes.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Times New Roman">Governor
Owens also championed efforts to strengthen <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s families.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>These include focusing resources on reducing youth violence,
fostering partnerships with faith-based organizations to offer social
services, and reforming the Childrens Health Insurance Program to
reduce enrollment barriers for low-income children.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Times New Roman"><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;</span>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</blockquote>
<p><i>last modified: March 21, 2001
</i>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<html>
<head>
<title><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Joe Rogers<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></title>
</head>
<body link="#0000ff" vlink="#800080">
<p><img src="coloflag.gif" width=75 height=58><font size=2>&nbsp;</p>
</font><font size=5><p align=CENTER><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Joe Rogers<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></p>
<p align=CENTER>Biographical Information</p>
</font><font size=2><p>&nbsp;</p>
</font><p align=JUSTIFY>A commitment to caring and a determination to strengthen
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> and America best symbolize <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Joe Rogers<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>. He represents a new generation of American
leadership. </p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>At <TAG name="AGE" value="start"/>34<TAG name="AGE" value="end"/><b>, </b><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Joe Rogers<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is the youngest <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in the
country. Joe has deep roots in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>. He grew up in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Denver<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> and <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Commerce City<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>. He attended
Denver Public Schools and graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Adams City High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> where he distinguished
himself by lettering in track, tennis and jazz band; and served as commencement class speaker for
the Class of 1982. Rogers entered <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Colorado State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> (CSU) where he worked his way
through school majoring in <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Business<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>. From there he went on to law school at <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Arizona State
University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> (ASU) where, in addition to his course-work, Rogers held a variety of legal apprentice
positions, including a position with one of the top law firms in the Southwest. Rogers also held an
<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>extern-clerk position<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> under <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>United States District Court Judge Robert Broomfield<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. While in his
first year of law school, Rogers<b></b>was recognized for his legal skills when he won the
school's first ever National Championship by winning the American Bar Association Negotiation
Competition, a contest involving some 80 U.S. law schools</p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>In the fall of 1989, Rogers joined <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Davis, Graham<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> &amp; <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Stubbs<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, one of
the oldest and largest firms in Colorado. During his near 4-year tenure at the firm, Rogers devoted
25 percent of his time to community service and represented the firm on a six-month assignment
to the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Bar Association's Lend-A-Lawyer program, where he provided no-cost legal
services to the poor in rural Southeast <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>. Rogers also<b></b>served as a member of the
board of directors for the Denver Bar Association Credit Union between 1990 and 1993.</p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>Between 1993 and 1995 Rogers served<b></b>as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Staff Counsel<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> to
<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Colorado's former United States Senator Hank Brown<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in Washington, D.C., where he advised
Brown on issues related to business, agriculture, banking, telecommunications, economic
development, transportation, housing, and the judiciary.</p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>On January 13, 1998, Rogers announced his candidacy <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant
Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>. On May 30, 1998, he was nominated as a candidate for <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> at the
<TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> State Assembly and on August 11, 1998, Joe was selected as the <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> nominee
for <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> and became Bill Owens running mate for Governor. <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Joe
Rogers<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was sworn in as <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Colorado<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on January 12<sup>th</sup>. </p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>Joe is married to <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Juanita Kay<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> and they have three young children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Trent<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>,
(4) <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jordan<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, (2) and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Haley<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> (1).</p></body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC


<html>
<head>
<title>Biography of <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>John G. Rowland<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></title>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" vlink="#FF0000">
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<table border=0 width=653 cellpadding=6 cellspacing=2>
<tr>
<td width=508><blockquote>
<p align=center><strong><em><font face="Book Antiqua"><big><big>Biography of <br>
<TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>John G. Rowland<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></big></big></font></em></strong></p>
<font face="Century Schoolbook"><p align=JUSTIFY>On <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>January 4, 1999<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>John G. Rowland<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was
sworn into a second term as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of the State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>. He first took office in
<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1995<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> at age 37 and was reelected in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> with the highest plurality in state history. </p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>Since 1995 he has made responsible budgeting, spending restraint and
improving the quality of life in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> top priority.</p>
<p align=JUSTIFY><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> has run budget surpluses totaling over $1.2 billion over
the past six fiscal years. In the summer of 1998, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> taxpayers received tax
rebate checks for the first time in state history. In 1999, taxpayers received
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s second consecutive tax rebate.</p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>Governor Rowland has secured tax cuts of more than $2 billion since
1995, giving <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> workers their first real tax cuts in years.</p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>To help the state&#146;s economy and create jobs, Governor Rowland has
worked to improve the state&#146;s overall business climate, including a 1/3 reduction in
the corporation tax. The state has regained 112 percent of the jobs lost in the recession
of the early 1990&#146;s. </p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>To improve the quality of life for all <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> residents, he is
also investing more than $2 billion to rebuild the state&#146;s education system, from
pre-school through college. Governor Rowland has also made a landmark commitment to
natural resource preservation, from acquiring 200,000 additional acres of open space to
aggressive cleanup of Long Island Sound.</p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>Under Governor Rowland&#146;s leadership, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> enacted some of
the toughest welfare reforms in the nation, including work requirements and a 21-month
time limit on benefits. More than 17,000 have left the welfare rolls since 1996 and the
welfare rolls are at the lowest in almost a decade. </p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>To make <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> safer for its citizens, Governor Rowland is adding
hundreds of new state troopers to the streets and forcing criminals to serve at least 85%
of their sentences.</p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>He has also worked to secure a more workable death penalty, and
strengthen Megan&#146;s Law to better protect children from sex offenders. He also called
for a constitutional amendment to protect victim&#146;s rights.</p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>To help protect abused and neglected children, Governor Rowland has
brought the state&#146;s child protection system to a new degree of openness. He has
worked to hire more social workers, move more staff into the field to work directly with
at-risk children, and make it easier to remove at-risk children from abusive homes. </p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>Governor Rowland also proposed the HUSKY Plan to provide health
insurance to an estimated 90,000 uninsured <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> children. The HUSKY Plan
(Healthcare for UninSured Kids and Youth) was implemented in 1998.</p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>Governor Rowland has a long history of public service. In 1980, at age
23, he was elected to the Connecticut State Legislature to represent the 73rd Assembly
District. He served until 1984, when he was elected to the United States House of
Representatives at age 27. He represented the Fifth Congressional District until 1990.</p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>Governor Rowland&#146;s family has lived in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> for more than
200 years and has a 50-year tradition of public service. Governor Rowland&#146;s father
and grandfather both served as Comptroller for the City of Waterbury. His grandfather was
instrumental in uncovering massive municipal corruption during the 1930&#146;s. Four
generations of the Rowland family have owned an insurance firm, which Governor Rowland has
helped to manage.</p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>Governor Rowland has received many public service awards, including
both the Malcolm Baldridge and the Ella Grasso awards. He was the first <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> to
receive the Excellence in State Government award. He has received two Yale University
Chubb Fellowships, the first President's Medallion for public service from Southern
Connecticut State University, an <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>honorary doctorate of humane letters<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Teikyo Post
College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, and <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>honorary doctor of law degrees<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from both the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Hartford<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and the
<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of New Haven<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.</p>
<p align=JUSTIFY>Governor Rowland has lived his entire life in the <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Greater Waterbury
area<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>. He is a graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Holy Cross High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Waterbury and <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Villanova University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. </p>
<p>Governor Rowland and his wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Patricia<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, reside in the Governor&#146;s Residence in
<TAG name="RESCITY" value="start"/>Hartford<TAG name="RESCITY" value="end"/>. They have five children between them: <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Kirsten<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Ryan<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Robert John<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Julianne<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and
<TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Scott<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.</font></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><font face="Century Schoolbook">Return to <a href="index.html">Main Page</a></font></p>
<p align=left><br>
<a href="http://www.state.ct.us/" target><img src="images/ctreturn.gif" alt="Go to ConneCT" border=0 width=396 height=35></a></p>
</blockquote>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width=508></td>
</tr>
</table>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC


<html>
<head>
<title><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lt. Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>M. Jodi Rell<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> - Biography</title>
</head>
<body text="#000000" vlink="#FF0000" alink="#0000FF" topmargin=2>
<div align=center><center>
<table border=0 cellpadding=4 width=585>
<tr>
<td width="100%"><p align=center><img src="images/biohdr.jpg" width=540 height=69></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="100%"><font align=justify face="Arial" size=2><img align=left src="images/silhoutte75.jpg" border=0 hspace=12 vspace=6 width=139 height=211></font>
<font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000"><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>M. Jodi Rell<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#146;s 105<sup>th</sup>
<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>. She was first elected to the position in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>. Rell was re-elected,
along with Governor John G. Rowland, in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>. She is the first <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> Female
<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#146;s history.</font><p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">As <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jodi Rell<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> presides over the state Senate as its
President and serves as acting governor when Governor Rowland is out of state.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">The<i>Hartford Courant</i>has called
Lieutenant Governor Rell, &quot;the governor&#146;s best asset, a beacon for progress and
a moral compass for the administration.&quot;</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">Lt. Governor Rell has actively and
aggressively championed a variety of issues and initiatives aimed at improving the quality
of life in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">In the spring of 2001, Lt. Governor Rell
began an anti-violence campaign titled &quot;<a href="silentnomore/index.html" target=_top>Silent No More: A <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Conversation on Violence</a>.&quot; She has
initiated a statewide dialogue on the issue of violence in every aspect of our society
&#150; school and workplace violence, road rage and domestic abuse. Silent No More will
get <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> residents to begin a discussion and discover the root causes of violence
and to work toward finding solutions. Lt. Governor Rell has already engaged many citizens
in the discussion, including parents, social workers, judges, education experts and
community leaders. She plans to continue forums across the state to not only find
solutions to the violence, but to get answers as to why many people have become numb to
it.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">In late 1999, Lt. Governor Rell presented
Governor Rowland with a comprehensive plan to ensure that <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#146;s schools and
libraries are prepared to meet the computer and information technology needs of the 21<sup>st</sup>
Century. In her <a href="cmptplan.htm" target=_top>19-point plan</a>, she recommended,
among other changes, that students be cyber-ready by the sixth grade, that all K-12
classrooms be fully wired and connected to the Internet and that a <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Education
Network be established to connect colleges, libraries and schools. Nearly all points of
the plan were approved by the legislature and, once implemented, the plan will offer the
best opportunities for children, teachers and parents in terms of integrating
state-of-the-art information technology into classrooms across the state.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">During her tenure as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>,
<TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jodi Rell<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> has worked to bring attention to breast cancer awareness, education and
prevention. Since 1995, she has participated in numerous National Mammography Day and Race
for the Cure events. She has also sponsored free and reduced-cost mammograms in her State
Capitol Office every October during Breast Cancer Awareness Month.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">Since 1998, Lt. Governor Rell has led a
campaign to collect funds for breast cancer research through donated state income tax
refunds. By using a voluntary check-off box on the state income tax form, taxpayers have
given more than $290,000 over the past three years. Funds collected have been deposited
into the Breast Cancer Research and Education Fund for breast cancer-related outreach,
education, research, counseling and community service programs.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">A strong supporter of veterans, Lt.
Governor Rell worked to successfully secure $50,000 in funding in the 1999-2000 state
budget for the <a href="http://www.womensmemorial.org/" target=_top>Women in Military
Service for America Memorial at Arlington National Cemetery</a>. The Memorial honors the
1.8 million women &#150; including 15,000 from <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> - who have served in the United
States military since the Revolutionary War. Given this funding, Connecticut will now have
a rightful place on the Memorial&#146;s Honor Roll of the States.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">The lieutenant governor also led an
initiative in 2000 to give high school diplomas to World War II Veterans who left high
school to serve their country. Her support led to passage of a bill that enables honorably
discharged WWII veterans to receive high school diplomas if, because of their military
service, they left high school and did not complete their education following their return
from the war.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">During the 2001 legislative session, Lt.
Governor Rell urged Governor Rowland to include $3 million in his proposed budget to
purchase a <a href="Prelease/2001/thermlimg.htm" target=_top>thermal imaging camera</a>
for use by career and volunteer firefighters in each of the more than 300 fire departments
in the state. The cameras, which are an effective tool for finding victims in a smoky or
burning building, can also locate the source of fires.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">Lt. Governor Rell has played a key role in
raising funds for the <a href="Prelease/2000/firememorial.htm" target=_top><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
Firefighters Memorial</a>, to be built on the grounds of the Fire Training Academy in
Windsor Locks. She was also instrumental in securing $100,000 in state funding for the
memorial, which is scheduled to be completed by the end of 2001.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">After being sworn in to her first term as
<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1995<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, Rell established the Lieutenant Governor&#146;s Commission on
State Mandate Reform. As part of the Commission&#146;s work, she crisscrossed the state,
visiting 101 town halls and meeting with officials from all 169 municipalities to discuss
state mandates and issues of state and local concern. Following these meetings and the
issuance of a final report by the Lieutenant Governor&#146;s Commission on State Mandate
Reform, the legislature passed several laws reforming burdensome state mandates, including
laws regarding heart and hypertension.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">In 1998, Lt. Governor Rell was appointed
by the governor to chair the Hartford Economic Development Advisory Group (HEDAG). In its
final report, HEDAG recommended that the state and city, in partnership, focus on six
specific areas, or pillars, that will serve as a catalyst for economic development and
strengthen Hartford&#146;s role as a sports, education and cultural center. These pillars
formed the basis of the historic &quot;Adriaen&#146;s Landing&quot; legislation signed
into law by Governor Rowland calling for Hartford to be the site of a sports stadium and
convention center complex, a downtown higher education center, increased parking and
downtown housing, and riverfront improvements.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">Also, in an effort to recognize the
tremendous volunteer efforts of individuals and groups throughout the state, Rell
established the &quot;<a href="treasures1.htm" target=_top>Lt. Governor&#146;s
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Treasures Award</a>.&quot; This award program is designed to honor the unsung
heroes of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> &#150; those who give of their time and their talents, not for pay
or recognition, but out of kindness and an abiding sense of responsibility and compassion.
Each month Rell presents a &quot;Lt. Governor&#146;s <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Treasures Award&quot; to
one individual and one organization that has made extraordinary volunteer contributions in
their community.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">For younger <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> volunteers, Lt.
Governor Rell presents a &quot;<a href="rellsrewards.htm" target=_top>Rell&#146;s Reward</a>&quot;
each month. Based on the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Treasures award, Rell&#146;s Reward is given to young
residents who are beginning a lifelong commitment to others through volunteer work in
their communities.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">The Lieutenant Governor serves as a member
of the Prison and Jail Overcrowding Commission and the Governor&#146;s Law Enforcement
Council. She is also a member of the Yale Corporation and the State Finance Advisory
Committee.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">Prior to her election as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant
Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, Rell <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>served in the state House of Representatives<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for ten years. She served in
many leadership positions, including Assistant Minority Leader and Deputy Minority Leader.
Her tenure in the House, representing Connecticut&#146;s 107<sup>th</sup>Assembly
District, began in 1984, and she was re-elected four consecutive times.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">Lt. Governor Rell is active in the
National Conference of Lieutenant Governors and the National Order of Women Legislators
(NOWLs). She is a past national president of NOWLs. In 1995, she was honored by the
organization, along with journalists Diane Sawyer and Helen Thomas, at the National Press
Club in Washington, D.C., as a recipient of its prestigious Leadership Award.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">She is a member of the Board of Trustees
of the Regional YMCA of Western <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> and the Candlewood Lions Club.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">Many organizations around the state have
presented awards to Rell during her tenure as lieutenant governor. She received the 2001
Impact Award from the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Technology Council and the First for Kids 2001 Policy
Leadership Award from <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Voices for Children, an advocacy group. In addition, she
has been honored by the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Library Association, the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Chapter of the
American College of Health Care Administrators, the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Dental Association and the
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Federation of Business and Professional Women, among others.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">Born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Norfolk, Virginia<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, Lt. Gov. Rell
attended <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Old Dominion University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Western Connecticut State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. She received an
<TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>honorary doctorate of laws degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Hartford<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 2001.</font></p>
<p><font face="Times New Roman" color="#000000">She and her husband, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Lou<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, live in
<TAG name="RESCITY" value="start"/>Brookfield<TAG name="RESCITY" value="end"/>. They have two grown children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Meredith<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Michael<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.</font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="100%"><font face="Times New Roman"><p align=center></font>

</td>
</tr>
</table>
</center></div>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC


<html>
<head>
<title>Biography of the <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></title>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" background="images/background.gif" vlink="#008080" alink="#008080">
<table border=0 width=630 cellpadding=6 cellspacing=2>
<tr>
<td border=1 width=115 align=CENTER valign=TOP><a href="http://www.state.ct.us/governor/"><img src="images/side.gif" border=0 align=bottom border=0 usemap="firstlbio.htm#smallheading" ismap alt="Home" width=130 height=175></a></td>
<td width=485><blockquote>
<p align=left><font color="#000000" size=5><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>FIRST LADY<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/><br>
</font><font color="#000000" size=7><em><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Patricia L. Rowland<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></em></font></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p align=left><font color="#000000" size=6><em>A Profile</em></font></p>
<font face="Arial Narrow"><p>A native of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Patricia L. (Patty)
Rowland<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Hartford<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> and was raised and educated through high school in the
<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Greater Waterbury area<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>. </p>
<p>She graduated Magna Cum Laude from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Marymount College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Tarrytown, New York, as an
<TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>English major<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>, and following college pursued a career in public relations as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Director of
Internal Communications<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Colonial Bancorp<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in Waterbury and later at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Lincoln First Bank
<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>in White Plains, New York.</p>
<p>After her two sons were born, she devoted her time to family, civic, and volunteer
activities. An active member of the Woodbury Junior Woman&#146;s Club, Mrs. Rowland was
involved in fund-raising and numerous charitable projects. She also served on the board of
directors of the Waterbury Day Nursery Association and as a volunteer for the Woodbury
Republican Town Committee.</p>
<p>In her role as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, Mrs. Rowland has embraced the growth of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#146;s
tourism industry. She serves as Honorary Chairperson of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Tourism Council,
promoting tourism to state residents as well as out-of-state travelers and works with the
Office of Tourism to raise awareness of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#146;s beauty and diversity. </p>
<p>She is a member of the Board of Trustees of the Mark Twain House, a member of the
Development Committee for the Mark Twain House, an elector for the Wadsworth Atheneum,
Honorary Chairperson of the Friends of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> State Parks as well as a member of the
Board of Trustees of Sea Research Foundation, Inc. </p>
<p>She also serves as Honorary Chairperson of The Governor&#146;s Residence Conservancy,
which oversees the restoration and refurbishment of the Governor&#146;s Residence in
Hartford.</p>
<p>In addition, Mrs. Rowland is a spokesperson for The American Cancer Society&#146;s
Breast Cancer Awareness program. She served as Honorary Chair of the 1996 RACE FOR THE
CURE as well as Honorary Co-Chair of the 1997, 1998, and 1999 CT RACE FOR THE CURE. She is
also involved with fund-raising efforts for non-profit organizations throughout the state,
including her own annual fund-raising event which is held during the holiday season to
benefit <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Connecticut<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#146;s needy.</p>
<p>In her spare time Mrs. Rowland enjoys antiquing, biking, skiing, and playing golf. </p>
<p>Her most rewarding role is being mother to her two sons, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Ryan<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Scott<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and spending
time with her family which includes John&#146;s children, Kirsten, R.J. and Julianne. They
reside at the Governor&#146;s Residence in <TAG name="RESCITY" value="start"/>Hartford<TAG name="RESCITY" value="end"/>.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial Narrow">Return to <a href="index.html">Main Page</a></font></p>
</blockquote>
<p align=left>&nbsp;</p>
<p align=left><br>
<a href="http://www.state.ct.us/" target><img src="images/ctreturn.gif" alt="Go to ConneCT" border=0 width=396 height=35></a></p>
</blockquote>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0 width=100% valign=top>

<img src="http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/images/cleardot.gif" width=8 height=1 alt="" border=0></td>
<td bgcolor="#ECECD7" width="100%" nowrap>&nbsp;
<b><a href="../index.html"><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>Government</a></b></font>
&gt; 
<b><a href="index.html"><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>Learn</a></b></font>
&gt; 
<b><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>Biography</a></b></font>
</td>
</tr>
<tr><td width=8 nowrap=NOWRAP><img src="http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/images/cleardot.gif" width=8 height=1 alt="" border=0></td>
<td><br>
<table border=0><tr><td width=2 nowrap=NOWRAP><img src="http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/images/cleardot.gif" width=2 height=1 alt="" border=0></td>
<td><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
<table width=420 border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0>
<tr>
<td width=473>
<font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=5><b><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>John Ellis "Jeb" Bush<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></b><br></font>
<font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=4><b><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></b><br></font><br>
<font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
The Capitol<br>
Tallahassee, Fl.  32399<br>
Phone: 850/488/7146<br>
Fax:  850-488-0801<br>
<a href="http://www.myflorida.com">www.myflorida.com</a><br>
<a href="mailto:jeb.bush @myflorida.com">jeb.bush @myflorida.com</a>
<ul>
<li>Birthdate: <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>Febuary 11, 1953<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>
<li>Spouse:    <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Columba Bush<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>
<li>Family:    Three children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>George<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Noelle<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jebby<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>
<li>Religion:  Roman Catholic           
<li>Elected:   <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>	 
<li>Term Expires:January 2003
</li>
</ul>
<font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
<p><b>Career: </b>
<p><img align=right src="http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/images/jeb_bush.gif" width=78 height=104 border=1 alt="Governor Jeb Bush" hspace=3>
<TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jeb Bush<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor's degree in Latin American Affairs<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Texas at Austin<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. He came to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> from Texas in 1980 as a businessman with a small family and big dreams of opportunity. In 1981, he helped start the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Codina Group<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, a Miami-based real estate development company. There Bush served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>president<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>chief operating officer<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. Equally active in civic and political affairs, he served as <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s secretary of commerce<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> under Bob Martinez, Florida's 40th governor. As <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>secretary of commerce<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, he ardently promoted <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s business climate worldwide. Following an unsuccessful bid in 1994 for governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, Bush founded a think tank, the Foundation for Florida's Future, helped launch the state's first charter school in Liberty City and authored Profiles in Character, a book profiling 14 of Florida's civic heroes. 
</font>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
<b>Election History: </b>
</font>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
Governor Bush was elected the 43rd <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor of the state of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 3, 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>. 
Garnering 55 percent of the vote, he succeeded his Democratic predecessor, Governor Kenneth 
"Buddy" McKay, who took office in December 1998 upon the death of the late Governor Lawton 
Chiles. 
</font>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
<b>Accomplishments:</b>
</font>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
During his first three years in office, Governor Bush and his administration have honored their commitments to the people of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> to improve public schools; provide substantial, broad-based tax relief; fight the battle against illegal drugs; protect the natural environment; get tough on criminals who use guns; and reform social services to better serve children, elders and those with disabilities. 
</font>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
Enacted in 1999, the Bush/Brogan A+ Plan for Education has provided a record three-year increase of $2.4 billion (23% increase) in K-12 funding, while also holding schools accountable for teaching all students reading, writing and math skills and ensuring that no child is left behind.  <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s schools and students are meeting the challenge, as the number of schools receiving an "F" grade has decreased from 78 in 1998-99 to four in 1999-2000 to potentially zero in 2000-2001. Minority students are particularly succeeding, as their gains on the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Comprehensive Assessment Test have outpaced the gains of non-minority students. 
</font>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
In 2001, the Legislature passed another historic reform, the Education Governance Reorganization Act.  <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> will now have a seamless K-20 system led by State Board of Education and a new Board of Trustees at each of its 11 public universities. This 21st century vision enshrines a student-centered approach at every level while maintaining local control and the individual character of every institution.  
</font>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s index crime rate fell in 2000 to its lowest level in 28 years, thanks to Governor Bush's approval of tough sentencing laws like 10-20-Life.  Innovative, interagency efforts such as Operation Riverwalk in Miami are also making a difference in the fight against illegal drugs.  Drug use most recently fell 15 percent in one year (Spring '99 to Spring '00).
</font>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
Tax relief remains a key catalyst for economic growth and opportunity for all Floridians, and Governor Bush has championed $1.6 billion in tax cuts over three years.  He continues working to eliminate the Intangibles Tax, a burden which falls particularly hard on <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s elders.
</font>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
Governor Bush has championed elders and <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s other most vulnerable citizens by promoting community-based care models wherever possible.  Funding increases in social services have included $79.2 million (75 percent increase) for the developmentally disabled; $86.8 million to expand child welfare services; $64.2 million for the mentally ill; and $53.7 million to provide community-based care alternatives for elders.  In 2001, Governor Bush negotiated a visionary deal with Pfizer that aims to reduce prescription drug costs for elders on Medicare through "disease management," which will employ specially trained nurses to monitor Medicare patients and encourage good dietary and exercise habits, thus reducing the need for emergency room care.
</font>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
Governor Bush's One <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Initiative aims to increase opportunity and diversity in the state's universities and in state contracting without using policies that discriminate or that pit one racial group against another. The plan has enjoyed remarkable success, as preliminary figures show an increase in the number of minority students admitted to the State University System in its first year.  And in state contracting, the awarding of state contracts to minority-owned businesses is up more than 50 percent in the first full year of One <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, and up 90 percent in the 15 state agencies under the Governor's supervision.
</font>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
Not only protecting but also restoring <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s environmental heritage has been a top Bush priority as well.  In 2000, he championed historic legislation in both Tallahassee and Washington to restore the natural beauty and diverse ecosystem of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s Everglades, and this year he approved $100 million for the Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan.  This long-term, multi-billion dollar effort is a testament to how people at all levels of government and across partisan and regional lines can work together to achieve a goal of great public purpose.  
</font>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
Other environmental initiatives promoted by Governor Bush include restoring the natural courses of key <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> rivers, acquiring millions of acres of land through the $3 billion <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Forever program, improving water quality across the state, developing a growth management strategy which will protect <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s renowned natural beauty for decades to come, and consistently opposing oil drilling in waters directly off <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s coast. 
</font>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
2001 also saw the passage of a bipartisan reform that makes <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s elections system a model for the nation and the world. Included in this reform package is $32 million to upgrade our state's voting technology and voter education programs, which will ensure that in the future laws, not the lawyers, will govern elections in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.
</font>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
Governor Bush has also kept his promise to provide smaller, more efficient government by instituting his Service First initiative, aimed at reforming and modernizing <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s outdated civil service system, and by also employing technology to increase service while reducing cost. Service First will deliver better services to Floridians, while providing greater accountability and flexibility to our state workers, and, for the first time in our state's history, rewarding them for good performance.
</font></p>
<p><font face="arial,helvetica,verdana" size=2>
Governor Bush created the first interactive, web-based E-Budget in state and national history, and through consolidation and outsourcing has reduced the state bureaucracy by 2,351 permanent positions, with 4,233 more proposed for 2001-02.  Through the use of e-mail and programs like "Capital for a Day" and "Open Office Hours," Bush has become the most accessible Governor in state history, and has placed <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> at the forefront of using technology to provide citizens with better access to information. 
</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<br>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<br>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

</td>
<td valign=top width=461>
<table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0 width=100% valign=top>
<tr><td width=8 nowrap=NOWRAP>
<img src="http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/images/cleardot.gif" width=8 height=1 alt="" border=0></td>
<td bgcolor="#ECECD7" width="100%" nowrap>&nbsp;
<b><a href="../index.html"><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>Government</a></b></font>
&gt; 
<b><a href="index.html"><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>Learn</a></b></font>
&gt; 
<b><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>Meet <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lt. Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Frank Brogan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></b></font>
</td>
</tr>
<tr><td width=8 nowrap=NOWRAP><img src="http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/images/cleardot.gif" width=8 height=1 alt="" border=0></td>
<td><br>
<table border=0><tr><td width=2 nowrap=NOWRAP><img src="http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/images/cleardot.gif" width=2 height=1 alt="" border=0></td>
<td><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=5><b><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Frank T. Brogan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></b></font><br><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/><br><br><img align=right hspace=4 src="images/frank_brogan.gif" border=1 width=79 height=104 alt="Lt. Governor Frank Brogan">
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
<TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Frank T. Brogan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, 15th <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor of the State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, came to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> to begin a career in public education. A former <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>classroom teacher<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, PTA president, <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>dean of students<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>assistant principal<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>principal<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>superintendent<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Commissioner of Education<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, Lt. Governor Brogan is best known for his leadership and commitment to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s children and the teaching profession.</font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
<b>Accomplishments in Education</b></font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
<TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lt. Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Frank T. Brogan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is a champion for <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s public schools. His philosophy is simply that all children can learn, and that schools must be held accountable for ensuring that learning is in a safe and friendly environment.</font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
As a former <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>5th grade teacher<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>dean of students<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>principal<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, Lt. Governor Brogan is very familiar with the challenges and opportunities that face our public schools. In fact, while serving as the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Assistant Principal<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Murray Middle School<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in Martin County, Brogan faced the challenge all parents and schools dread - a suicidal youngster with a gun, knives and mace. Assistant Principal Brogan successfully wrestled the discharging gun from the student's hands. Since that time, ensuring that schools are safe has become a central theme of his work.</font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
Elected in 1994 as the youngest and first <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> Commissioner of Education of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, Lt. Governor Brogan made his mark as a staunch supporter of higher academic standards, the development of second chance or alternative schools and the right for teachers to remove disruptive students from their classrooms.  
His most important legacy as Commissioner was bringing greater accountability to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> schools. Key changes included: (1) the development of a process to identify and improve low performing schools; (2) the passage of the Sunshine State Standards, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s academic standards now required of students as they progress from grade to grade; (3) and leading the effort to raise the passing score for the High School Competency Test to help prepare <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s high school graduates for postsecondary education.</font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
Lt. Governor Brogan's lifetime work in education has culminated in the Bush/Brogan "A+ Plan for Education."  Passed in 1999, this visionary reform has provided a record three-year increase of $2.4 billion (23% increase) in K-12 funding, while also holding schools accountable for teaching all students reading, writing and math skills and ensuring that no child is left behind.  <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s schools and students are meeting the challenge, as the number of schools receiving an "F" grade has decreased from 78 in 1998-99 to four in 1999-2000 to potentially zero in 2000-2001. Minority students are particularly succeeding, as their gains on the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Comprehensive Assessment Test have outpaced the gains of non-minority students.</font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
In addition to the A+ Plan, Lt. Governor Brogan helped to promote the Governor's Mentoring Initiative and serves as a mentor to a middle school student in Tallahassee.</font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
Among Lt. Governor Brogan's numerous awards in education and issues affecting children are the 1996 Civil Rights Award in Education, the 1998 Child Advocate of the Year, and the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> School Boards Association's Lifetime Achievement Award.</font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
<b>Program and Policy Initiatives of the Lt. Governor</b></font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
As legislative liaison for Governor Bush, Lt. Governor Brogan has helped ensure that "Promises Kept" can be stamped on the platform issues on which they ran, including tax relief ($1.6 billion over three years), reduction of violent crime (to a 28-year low in 2000), environmental protection (including the Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan), and serving the needs of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s most vulnerable citizens (especially our children, frail elders and the developmentally disabled).</font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
Lt. Governor Brogan has chaired the Long-Term Care Task Force, the Commission on the Homeless and serves as the administration's point person on realizing commercial opportunity in space.  He led the Enterprise <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> trade mission to South Africa and later this year will lead another such mission to Japan and South Korea.</font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
<b>Civic Involvement</b></font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
In addition to serving as a champion for education and children, Lt. Governor Brogan has served as a leader for other important causes. During the past few years, he has become especially involved in the fight against cancer. He has received a Public Service Award from the Pioneers in Prostate Cancer and has used his remarkable speaking ability to crusade in the fight against breast cancer.</font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
<b>Personal Information</b></font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
<TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Frank T. Brogan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, and his twin, John, were born on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>September 6, 1953<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, as the youngest of six children who grew up in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Cincinnati, Ohio<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>.  The first in his family to graduate from college, he earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor's degree in education<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Cincinnati<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>master's<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Florida Atlantic University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.</font>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
Lt. Governor Brogan and his late wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Mary<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, also known for her commitment to teaching and education, were childhood sweethearts married for over twenty years.
</font>
<br><br>
<br>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<br>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<td width=144></td>

</td>
</tr></table>

<td bgcolor="#ECECD7" width="100%" nowrap>&nbsp;

&gt; 
<b><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>Meet the <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Columba Bush<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></b></font>
</td>

<tr><td width=8 nowrap=NOWRAP><img src="http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/images/cleardot.gif" width=8 height=1 alt="" border=0></td>
<td><br>
<table border=0><tr><td width=2 nowrap=NOWRAP><img src="http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/images/cleardot.gif" width=2 height=1 alt="" border=0></td>
<td><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>
<p><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2><img src="images/mrsbush.jpg" width=115 height=144 align=right border=0 alt="Mrs. Bush"></font><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Columba Bush<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, formerly <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Columba Garnica 
Gallo<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Leon, Guanajato, Mexico<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>1954<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>. In February 
1971, Governor Bush and Mrs. Bush met in Leon, Mexico, while Jeb 
was teaching English in an exchange program for his school, Phillips 
Academy. After Governor Bush graduated from the University of Texas, 
he and Columba were married on February 23, 1974, in Austin, Texas. 
In 1980, they moved to Miami, where they raised their three children, 
<TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>George<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Noelle<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jebby<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.<br><br>Mrs. Bush has been active in her community. She is currently 
a spokesperson and a member of Informed Families of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, a 
non-profit organization which is involved in educating families 
on the perils of drug abuse. She is also the Co-Founder of the 
Children's Cultural Education Fund of the Ballet Folklorico, which 
raises money for the national dance troupe of Mexico. The Foundation 
sponsors free performances of the Ballet Folklorico so it can 
be seen by school-age children across the United States. More 
than 250,000 children have seen the Ballet to date.
</font><br><br><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>As <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Florida's First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, Mrs. Bush has chosen to dedicate her time and energy to help promote art appreciation among <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s young 
people, and to speak out about the evils of drug abuse.</font><br><br><font face="arial, helvetica, verdana" size=2>Governor and Mrs. Bush have been married for <TAG name="YRSMARR" value="start"/>27 years<TAG name="YRSMARR" value="end"/>, and have three children: <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>George<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Noelle<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jeb<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.</font>
<br>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<br>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>

<html>
<head>


<title><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Benjamin J. Cayetano<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> - Biography</title>
</head>
<body bgcolor=white link=blue vlink=blue>
<a name=top></a>
<center>
<p>
<table border=0 width=506>
<tr>
<td width=440 valign=top><img src="images/WebtapabarGov.jpg" alt="WebtapabarGov.jpg (26233 bytes)" width=504 height=305>
<div align=justify>
<p><font face="VERDANA,ARIAL" size=4><b>BIOGRAPHY</b></font></p>
<p><font face="VERDANA,ARIAL" size=2><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Benjamin J. Cayetano<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is in his second four-year term as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of the State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>. He is the State&#146;s fifth <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> and the first of Filipino ancestry.<br>
<br>
Hawaii voters elected him their Governor in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, and he was re-elected in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>.<br>
<br>
Governor Cayetano, a <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Democrat<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/>, has served more than a quarter of a century in public office, winning all of his eight career elections since 1974. He spent 12 years in the Hawaii State Legislature, two terms in the House from 1975 to 1978 and two terms in the Senate from 1979 to 1986. In 1986, he was elected to his first four-year term as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>lieutenant governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and re-elected in 1990.<br>
<br>
The Cayetano Administration has been primarily noted for helping to bring <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> out of eight years of economic stagnation through responsible fiscal policies.<br>
<br>
The conservative Cato Institute recently gave the Governor high marks in its 2000 Fiscal Policy Report Card on America&#146;s Governors. Governor Cayetano ranked 7th among the nation&#146;s governors and the Cato Institute gave him a &quot;B.&quot; A Cato economist was quoted as saying, &quot;We rate him very highly. He&#146;s been one of the biggest tax-cutting governors in the country...&quot;<br>
<br>
Among the accomplishments of the Cayetano Administration:<br>
<br>
</font></p>
<ul>
<li><font face="VERDANA,ARIAL" size=2>Saving taxpayers nearly $2 billion over six years through one of the biggest personal income tax cuts in the country;<br>
<br>
</font>
<li><font face="VERDANA,ARIAL" size=2>Building a record number of 13 new schools over the last six years;<br>
<br>
</font>
<li><font face="VERDANA,ARIAL" size=2>Enacting the landmark Technology Omnibus Bill to provide some of the most progressive incentives in the nation to attract high technology companies;<br>
<br>
</font>
<li><font face="VERDANA,ARIAL" size=2>Leading the nation in welfare reform in 1999, which led the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services to award $5 million to the State;<br>
<br>
</font>
<li><font face="VERDANA,ARIAL" size=2>Reducing the cost of doing business in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> through tax and structural reforms, including significantly cutting workers&#146; compensation premiums;<br>
<br>
</font>
<li><font face="VERDANA,ARIAL" size=2>Developing more homes for native Hawaiians and low-income residents than at any other time in the history of the State;<br>
<br>
</font>
<li><font face="VERDANA,ARIAL" size=2>Acquiring special places in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> &#150; the Ka Iwi coastline and Lumahai Beach and the Hanalei River on Kauai &#150; to protect the natural environment;<br>
<br>
</font>
<li><font face="VERDANA,ARIAL" size=2>Helping to reform the former Bishop Estate, our nation&#146;s largest charitable educational trust, and;<br>
<br>
</font>
<li><font face="VERDANA,ARIAL" size=2>Obtaining autonomy for the University of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> system.<br>
<br>
</font>
</ul>
<p><font face="VERDANA,ARIAL" size=2>The Administration has focused on diversifying the local economy through new industries, such as high technology. The number of high technology firms in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> has tripled from a decade ago. The Governor also cut the size of the public sector workforce and restructured government to encourage efficiency.<br>
<br>
Governor Cayetano has been recognized nationally and internationally with numerous awards for his accomplishments in public service, among them University of California at Los Angeles&#146; Edward A. Dickson Alumnus of the Year Award, an <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>honorary Doctor of Public Service<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Loyola Marymount University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, the Harvard Foundation Leadership Award, the UCLA Medal, UCLA&#146;s John E. Anderson Graduate School of Management Distinguished Leadership Award, and an <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>honorary Doctor of Laws<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> Degree from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of the Philippines<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.<br>
<br>
While serving as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, he established the A+ After School Program to provide care for latchkey children in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#146;s public elementary schools. In 1991, the Asia-Pacific Academic Consortium for Public Health awarded then-Lieutenant Governor Cayetano the Excellence in Leadership Medallion for the A+ program. This work as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> remains heavily identified with the Governor today.<br>
<br>
Some of his noteworthy accomplishments in the Legislature include: Chairing the Senate investigative committee that uncovered mismanagement of the 1982 heptachlor crisis; helping to establish the first Hula Mae loan program to provide low-interest housing loans to &quot;gap-group&quot; families; being instrumental in enacting laws to require automobile insurance companies to provide premium rollbacks and increased no-fault coverage; and authoring legislation to establish the first program in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> to test Vietnam veterans suffering from the effects of Agent Orange.<br>
<br>
An attorney by profession, Governor Cayetano <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>practiced law<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for 15 years prior to being elected Lieutenant Governor. From 1983 to 1986, he was a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>partner<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in the law firm of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Schutter Cayetano Playdon<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>.<br>
<br>
He is a 1958 graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Farrington High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Honolulu, Hawaii. Governor Cayetano earned his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Bachelor of Arts in Political Science<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>UCLA<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1968, and a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Juris Doctorate<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Loyola Law School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Los Angeles in 1971.<br>
<br>
He is married to the former <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Vicky Tiu<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, who is the President and Chief Executive Officer of United Laundry Services. The first family includes five children: <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Brandon<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Janeen<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Samantha Cayetano<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Marissa<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>William Liu<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and one grandchild Micah Ancheta.<br>
</font></p>
</div>
<p><a href="#top"><font face="VERDANA,ARIAL" size=2><img src="../images/top.gif" alt="Top" border=0 width=39 height=13></font></a></p>
<p>
<a href="_vti_bin/shtml.exe/bottom.htm/map"><img ismap usemap="#FrontPageMap" border=0 height=46 alt="footer.jpg (11823 byt es)" src="images/footer.jpg" width=504><map name="FrontPageMap"></map></a>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</center>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC


<html>
<head>
<title>Meet Lieutenant Governor Hirono</title>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#ffffff" link="#800080" vlink="#000080" text="#000000" topmargin=0 leftmargin=0>
<a name=top></a>
<table border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0>
<tr>
