<td height=88></td>
<td width=534 height=88 valign=top align=left>
<p align=center><center><font face="Times New Roman" color=#ffffff size=6><i>Meet Lieutenant Governor Hirono<br></i></font>
</td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td height=3></td>
<td colspan=2></td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td height=6></td>
<td colspan=5></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td height=803></td>
<td></td>
<td width=162 height=803 colspan=3 rowspan=1 valign=top align=left>
<map name=map486>
</map>
<img width=162 height=803 border=0 src="img9.gif" usemap="#map486" alt="photo of Lt. Gov. Hirono"></td>
<td width=380 height=1074 colspan=1 rowspan=4 valign=top align=left>
<table border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0>
<tr>
<td width=3 height=3></td>
<td width=372></td>
<td width=3></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td height=1066></td>
<td width=372 height=1066 valign=top align=left>
<p align=justify><font face="Arial" color=#000000 size=3><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Mazie Keiko Hirono<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is the State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s ninth elected <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>lieutenant governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, serving in her second term.&nbsp; She was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Fukushima, Japan<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>November 3, 1947<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/> and immigrated to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> with her mother and brother when she was eight years old.&nbsp; <br></font><font face="Arial" size=1><br></font><font face="Arial" size=3>Educated in public schools in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, she went on to graduate Phi Beta Kappa from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Hawaii at Manoa<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.&nbsp; She later earned her <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Georgetown University Law Center<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.<br></font><font face="Arial" size=1><br></font><font face="Arial" size=3>Ms. Hirono returned to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> to serve as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Deputy Attorney General<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in the Anti-trust Division and later practiced with the firm of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Shim, Tam, Kirimitsu, Kitamura &amp; Chang<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> for four years.<br></font><font face="Arial" size=1><br></font><font face="Arial" size=3>As a state lawmaker, she played a key role in preserving <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s landmark Land Reform Act, affirming the right of working families to buy the single family lots under their homes.&nbsp; <br></font><font face="Arial" size=1><br></font><font face="Arial" size=3>During her seven terms in Hawaii's House of Representatives, she earned a reputation as a dedicated consumer advocate and outspoken member of the House Women's Caucus with over 120 of her bills becoming law.<br></font><font face="Arial" size=1><br></font><font face="Arial" size=3>Mazie was first elected <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, making her America's first immigrant woman of Asian ancestry elected to statewide office.&nbsp; As <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, she also serves <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s Secretary of State.<br></font><font face="Arial" size=1><br></font><font face="Arial" size=3>In her first term, Lt. Governor Hirono directed the Administration's efforts to reform auto and workers' compensation insurance.&nbsp; She was the guiding force in the creation of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Employers Mutual Insurance Company (HEMIC), a private, non-profit insurance company that provides workers' comp coverage to Hawaii businesses, especially small businesses.&nbsp; <br></font><font face="Arial" size=1><br></p><p align=left></font><font face="Arial" size=3>She chaired the Governor's Task Force on Science and Technology and worked with the president of the University of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> to create University Connections, a group bringing business and research communities together.&nbsp; <br></font><font face="Arial" size=1><br></p><p align=justify></font><font face="Arial" size=3>In her second term, Hirono is leading the charge in reducing the burden of state rules on the business community through her Slice Waste and Tape project (SWAT).&nbsp; She actively promotes enhancing <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s economy through aviation, hi-tech and other initiatives, and is the chair of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s policy group on teacher quality through the National Commission on Teaching and America's Future.<br></font><font face="Arial" size=1><br></p><p align=left></font><font face="Arial" size=3><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Mazie Hirono<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is married to attorney <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Leighton Kim Oshima<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>.&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; </font><font face="Arial" size=2><br></font>
</td>
<td></td>
</tr>

<p align=center><center><font face="Arial Black" color=#ffffff size=2><br><center><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Mazie Hirono<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is the first woman of Asian ancestry to be elected to a statewide office.<br></font>

<html>
<head>


<title>Mrs. <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Vicky Cayetano<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> : Meet the First Lady</title>
</head>
<body>
<center>
<table border=0 width=506>
<tr>
<td valign=top>
<center>
<img src="images/FirstLady.jpg" alt="FirstLady.jpg" width=504 height=304></center>
<p><font face="verdana,arial" size=2>Mrs. <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Vicky Cayetano<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> and Governor <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Benjamin J. Cayetano<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> were married on <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>May 5, 1997<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/>, in a private ceremony at Washington Place.</font></p>
<p><font face="verdana,arial" size=2>Mrs. Cayetano was born in the <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Philippines<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> and raised in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>San Francisco<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>, the sixth of nine children. With a family very involved in the performing arts, at the age of six Vicky appeared along side Elvis Presley in <em>It Happened at the</em><em>World's Fair</em>. She later attended <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Stanford University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and moved to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> in 1983.</font></p>
<p><font face="verdana,arial" size=2>In 1988 Mrs. Cayetano helped form <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>United Laundry Services<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. Since 1990 she has served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>CEO<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for the company which employs nearly 300 people. A privately held corporation, the company provides commercial laundry services to thrity hotels and five major health care facilities.<br>
<br>
Although continuing in her professional career, the First Lady is active in many organizations such as, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Foodbank, Girl Scout Council of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, the American Cancer Society, the American Heart Association, March of Dimes, Alzheimer's Association, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Literacy, Inc., Bishop Museum, Juvenile Diabetes International, National Multiple Sclerosis Society-Local Chapter, MADD, HUGS, Salvation Army and Child and Family Services. She is a Director of the Pacific and Asian Affairs Council and a Trustee of the State Library Foundation. <br>
<br>
Apart from these efforts, <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Vicky Cayetano<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>'s primary legacy to the people of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> may be her establishment and leadership of the Washington Place Foundation. This entity exists solely for the preservation and restoration of this venerable Governor's Mansion and former home of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Hawaii<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s last Queen.</font></p>
<p><font face="verdana,arial" size=2>Mrs. Cayetano has two children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Marissa<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, 17 and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>William<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, 14.</font></p>
<center>
<p>
<a href="_vti_bin/shtml.dll/default.htm/map"><img ismap usemap="#FrontPageMap" border=0 height=53 alt="Tapabottom.jpg (10480 bytes)" src="images/Tapabottom.jpg" i- width=504><map name="FrontPageMap"></map></a>
</center>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</center>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC


<html>
<head>
<title>The Office of the <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> and Lt. Governor</title>
<link rel=stylesheet href="../dhtml/gov99.css">
</head>
<body bgcolor="#ffffff" link="#341A0B" vlink="#341A0B" alink="#B5B1CA">
<table width=496 border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 align=center>
<tr align=left valign=top>
<td><img src="../desk_top_images/file_mastREV4.gif" width=496 height=93 alt="File Navbar" border=0 usemap="#file_map1"></td>
</tr>
<tr align=center valign=top>
<td bgcolor="#F0F0E1">
<table width="95%" border=0 cellpadding=6>
<tr align=left valign=top>
<td>
<center>

<center>
<div align=LEFT>
<div align=LEFT>
<p align=center><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><b><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>GOVERNOR<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> 
<TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>TOM VILSACK<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></b></font></p>
<p align=center><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><b>
BIOGRAPHY</b></font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">The Honorable 
<TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Thomas J. Vilsack<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">The Honorable 
<TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Thomas J. Vilsack<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was elected <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor of the State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> 
in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>. Before becoming governor, he <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>practiced law<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for 
over twenty years, was elected <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>mayor of Mt. Pleasant, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> 
in 1987 and was elected to the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> State Senate in 1993.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Pittsburgh, 
Pennsylvania<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, Vilsack met his future wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Christie Bell<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, 
while he was a student at <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Hamilton College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Clinton, New 
York and she was a member of the charter class of Kirkland 
College. They married after his first year at <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Albany Law 
School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, where he graduated with the Class of 1975.</font></p>
<table width="100%" border=0>
<tr>
<td width="48%"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><img src="tom_sept1.gif" width=158 height=175></font></td>
<td width="2%">&nbsp;</td>
<td width="50%"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><a href="../desk_top_images/photos/vilsacks1.jpg"><img src="vilsacks_sept1.gif" width=159 height=216 border=0></a></font></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Governor Vilsack 
and his wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Christie<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, have two sons, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jess<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, a first-year 
law student, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Doug<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, a college sophomore.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">As <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, 
<TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Tom Vilsack<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is committed to improving schools for our children 
and preserving and strengthening Iowa's families and communities.</font><br>
</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"></font></p>
</div>
</div>
</center>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

</center>
</td>
</tr>

<html>
<head>
<title>The Office of the Governor and Lt. Governor</title>
<link rel=stylesheet href="../dhtml/gov99.css">
</head>
<body bgcolor="#ffffff" link="#341A0B" vlink="#341A0B" alink="#B5B1CA">
<table width=496 border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 align=center>
<tr align=left valign=top>
<td><img src="../desk_top_images/file_mastREV4.gif" width=496 height=93 alt="File Navbar" border=0 usemap="#file_map1"></td>
</tr>
<tr align=center valign=top>
<td bgcolor="#F0F0E1">
<table width="95%" border=0 cellpadding=6>
<tr align=left valign=top>
<td>
<div align=left><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="+1"><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>S</font><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="-1">ally 
J. Pederson<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Muscatine<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> and grew up in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Vinton, Iowa<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>. The 
Lt. Governor got her first job at age 10, when she started <img src="../desk_top_images/photos/sally_sept1.jpg" width=158 height=175 align=left alt="Lt. Governor Sally Pederson">delivering 
<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>The Cedar Valley Times<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. She graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Iowa State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> 
in 1973 with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degree in Hotel, Restaurant and Institution Management<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>.</font>
</div>
<p align=left><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="-1">The 
Lt. Governor worked for <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Meredith Corporation<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in Des Moines, where 
she rose through the ranks to become <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>senior food editor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for the 
firm's flagship publication, <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Better Homes and Gardens (c) magazine<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>.</font></p>
<p align=left><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="-1">She 
married <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>James A. Autry<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1982<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/>. Their family includes three sons: 
<TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Rick<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jim, Jr.<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Ronald<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, a daughter-in-law, Lyn, and two grandchildren.</font></p>
<p align=left><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="-1">The 
Lt. Governor worked for Meredith until 1984, when she decided to 
spend more time at home with her son, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Ronald<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, who was later<a href="../desk_top_images/photos/pedersons.jpg"><img src="../desk_top_images/photos/pedersons_oct99.gif" width=159 height=205 align=right alt="The Pedersons" border=0></a>
diagnosed with autism.</font></p>
<p align=left><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="-1">
Since 1984, the Lt. Governor has devoted much of her time to community 
service on the local, state and national levels. She served as President 
of Polk County Health Services, overseeing a $30 million budget. 
She has served as board president for the Autism Society of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, 
and was the founding president of The Homestead Living and Learning 
Center for Adults with Autism. The Homestead, located east of Des 
Moines, is a national model of an innovative rural residential and 
vocation program for adults with autism.</font></p>
<p align=left><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="-1">The 
Lt. Governor also has served on the board of directors of Blank 
Children's Hospital, The Des Moines Playhouse, Very Special Arts 
Iowa, YWCA Aliber Child Care Center, the YMCA Central Branch, and 
the State Special Education Advisory Panel.</font></p>
<p align=left><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="-1">She 
currently serves on the board of directors for the National Alliance 
for Autism Research, the Mid-Iowa Health Foundation, and Legacy 
150.</font></p>
<p align=left><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="-1">Before 
being tapped by Tom Vilsack to run for Lt. Governor, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Sally Pederson<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> 
had never sought political office, but served as a forceful advocate 
on education and state and federal legislation for children with 
special needs. The Lt. Governor now serves as the lead of the Vilsack-Pederson 
team on workforce, disability, diversity, and human service issues 
for the state.</font></p>
<p align=left><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="-1">In 
that capacity, Lt. Governor Pederson chairs the Governor's 21st 
Century Workforce </font><font face=arial size="-1"><img src="../desk_top_images/photos/Sally_and_grandkids_oct99.jpg" width=215 height=161 align=left alt="Sally with her grandkids"></font><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="-1">Council. 
The Lt. Governor also is the chair of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Jobs for America's Graduates, 
a new initiative focused on helping those students most likely to 
drop out of school to graduate and become successfully employed. 
And, she chairs the Task Force for Equal Opportunity in Employment, 
charged with advising the Department of Personnel on the implementation 
of the state's Equal Opportunity and Affirmative Action Goals.</font></p>
<p align=left><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="-1">Her 
advocacy on behalf of persons with disabilities garnered her special 
guest status at the first White House Conference on Mental Health. 
The Lt. Governor and her office recently organized the 6th Annual 
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Conference on Diversity.</font></p>
<p align=left><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="-1">
<TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lt. Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Sally Pederson<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> has been described by one <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> newspaper 
as "smart but not smug, assertive but not annoying, determined but 
not divisive. . . She has the education, the common sense, the leadership 
skills and the passion and compassion to run this state." </font></p>
<p align=left><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="-1">If 
you would like to <a href="../comments/index.html">contact the Lt. 
Governor </a>, please use the online mail form <a href="../comments/index.html">here</a>. 
Thank you.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p align=CENTER><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="-2" color="#FFFFFF">

</font></p>

<html><head><title>The Office of the Governor and Lt. Governor</title>
<link href="IAspouse_files/gov99.css" rel=stylesheet>
</head>
<body alink=#b5b1ca bgcolor=#ffffff link=#341a0b vlink=#341a0b>
<table align=center border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 width=496>
<tbody>
<tr align=left valign=top>
<td><img alt="File Navbar" border=0 height=93 src="IAspouse_files/file_mastREV4.gif" usemap=#file_map1 width=496></td></tr>
<tr align=middle valign=top>
<td bgcolor=#f0f0e1>
<table border=0 cellpadding=6 width="95%">
<tbody>
<tr align=left valign=top>
<td>
<center>
<center>
<div align=left>
<div align=left>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=-1><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Christie 
Vilsack<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> grew up in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Mt. Pleasant, Iowa<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>. She received her <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>B.A. in 
English<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> at <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Kirkland College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Clinton, New York. <img align=left alt="Christine Vilsack" height=175 src="IAspouse_files/christine_sept1.gif" width=158>She met her 
husband, Governor <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Tom Vilsack<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, during their freshman year of 
college. After her first year of teaching and his first year of law 
school they were married in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Mt. Pleasant<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>. After Tom finished Albany 
Law School, they moved to <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Mt. Pleasant<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> in 1975, where Tom practiced 
law with her father and brother. </font></p></div>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=-1>She has 
volunteered with Global Volunteers as a teacher in Jamaica and 
Poland. She has served on the boards of the Henry Country Cancer 
Society and the Southeast <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Symphony. She is currently a member 
of the Board of Trustees of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Wesleyan College and the Terrace 
Hill Commission. </font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=-1><font face=Arial><a href="http://www.state.ia.us/governor/desk_top_images/photos/vilsacks1.jpg"><img align=right alt="The Vilsack Family" border=0 height=216 src="IAspouse_files/vilsacks_sept1.gif" width=159></a></font>Since 
becoming the <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>January 1999<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Christie Vilsack<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> 
has worked tirelessly to improve literacy efforts, expand 
opportunities at community libraries, and focus attention to issues 
facing young <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> women. </font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=-1>In April 2000, 
Vilsack created <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Stories 2000, an initiative designed to help 
parents and communities understand the importance of early childhood 
reading and group storytelling. A goal of the initiatives is to 
ensure that <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> children make reading a lifelong trait. Vilsack has 
launched a pilot program to promote literacy and storytelling in 
seven communities, and she hopes to expand the program across <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>. 
Iowa Stories 2000 also will include a "Books for Babies" program 
where each newborn adopted child will receive a storybook from the 
First Lady and the Governor. </font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=-1><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Christie 
Vilsack<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> also has made libraries the keystone of her literacy 
initiative. Referring to libraries as the "souls of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> 
communities," she has worked to expand community library projects 
through her support of Enrich <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> - a program that partners the 
state with communities to provide Iowans with more educational 
resources in their local libraries. Vilsack intends to visit all 500 
libraries in the state during her first four years as the <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First 
Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>. So far, she has traveled to more than 200 libraries in less 
than two years. </font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=-1>Vilsack has 
also invested her efforts in focusing attention on the issues facing 
adolescent women. In Fall 2000, she will host the 2nd Annual Women's 
Health Conference, which will center on the critical health issues 
facing young women daily. Vilsack has convened a group of teenage 
women from across <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> to help her set the agenda and activities for 
the conference. </font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=-1>In partnership 
with <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s Secretary of State Chet Culver, Christie sponsors the 
Capitol Project, which brings high school students to the capitol 
during the legislative session to experience law-making first-hand. 
Vilsack speaks to students about the importance of good citizenship 
and being involved in the political process. </font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=-1>Vilsack has 
been a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>teacher<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for more than 28 years. Before moving to Des Moines, 
she taught 8th grade language arts in Mount Pleasant for 18 years, 
and freshman English and journalism at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Iowa Wesleyan College<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> for six 
years. She has been a regular <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>feature writer<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>editorial page 
columnist<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Mt. Pleasant News<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=-1>Vilsack now 
works tirelessly to make <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> her classroom. When she is not 
traveling the state, Vilsack hosts numerous events to draw Iowans to 
Terrace Hill - which she considers a home for all Iowans. From her 
monthly teas to the annual Spring Fling parties, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Christie Vilsack<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> 
continues to look for innovative and educational ways to invite 
Iowans to Terrace Hill.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=-1>A native of 
Mount Pleasant, Vilsack has a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Bachelor of Arts degree in English<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> 
from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Kirkland College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in New York, and a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Master of Arts degree in 
journalism<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Iowa<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=-1>She and 
Governor Vilsack have two sons, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jess<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> is in his first year of law 
school at the University of Iowa, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Doug<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, is a sophomore at 
Colorado College in Colorado Springs. 
</font></p></div></center></center></td></tr></tbody></table></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p align=center><font color=#ffffff face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=-2>
</font></p>

<html>
<head>
<title>Governor's Site: Governor's Biography</title>
<link rel=STYLESHEET href="govsite.css" type="text/css">
</head>
<body bgcolor="#3366cc">
<center>
<table border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 width="90%">
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top background="./images/splitback.gif"><a href="./default.htm"><img src="./images/subleft.gif" alt="George H. Ryan, Governor of Illinois" border=0 width=121 height=35></a></td>
<td bgcolor="#ffffff" align=left valign=top><img src="./images/biography.gif" alt="Biography" border=0></td>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#003399" align=left valign=top class=navsmall>
<a href="./default.htm"><font color="#ffffff">Home</font></a><br>
<a href="./building.htm"><font color="#ffffff">Building&nbsp;A&nbsp;New&nbsp;Illinois</font></a>&nbsp;<br>
<a href="./getdone.htm"><font color="#ffffff">Getting Things Done</font></a><br>
<a href="./first.htm"><font color="#ffffff">First Lady</font></a><br>
<a href="./boards.htm"><font color="#ffffff">Boards &amp; Commissions</font></a><br>
<a href="./office.htm"><font color="#ffffff">Office Matters</font></a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#ffffff" width="100%">
<table border=0 cellpadding=5 cellspacing=0 width="100%">
<tr>
<td><img src="/gov/images/gryansm.jpg" alt="Photo of George Ryan" border=1 width=125 height=150 align=left>
<h2>Governor Ryan's Links:</h2>
<p><a href="./history.htm">State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> History</a><br>
<a href="./constitution.htm"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Constitution</a><br>
<a href="./ilgovernors.htm"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Governors</a><br>
<a href="./duties.htm">Duties of the Governor</a><br>
<a href="http://www.legis.state.il.us"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> General Assembly</a><br clear=all>
<p><br>
<h2>Biography</h2>[ <a href="#chrono">Chronological Biography</a>]</p>
<p><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George H. Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was elected <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>' 39th <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 3, 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, continuing a distinguished career of public service. </p>
<p>Governor Ryan, born <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>February 1934<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>secretary of state<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for eight years (1991-1999) and <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>lieutenant governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for eight years (1983-91). He also had an accomplished 10-year legislative career (1973-1983). </p>
<p>A lifelong resident of <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Kankakee<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> and a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>pharmacist<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, Ryan has been a leader on both the local and state level. He began his political career as a member and later chairman of the Kankakee County Board. He was elected to the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> House in 1972 and re-elected four times. During that tenure, he served two terms as House <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> leader and one term as Speaker of the House (1981-1983). </p>
<p>Since taking office in January 1999, Gov. Ryan has proposed and successfully passed the historic and visionary Illinois FIRST legislation.  The <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> FIRST program provides $12 billion to rebuild and expand the state's roadways, renovate mass transit systems, build, repair and renovate schools, clean environmental hazards, and upgrade water and sewer systems to improve the quality of life for <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> residents.</p>
<p>Gov. Ryan also passed significant legislation to increase education and training funding to 51% of all new revenue.  The Governor proposed and passed, the innovative EDGE tax credit for companies creating jobs in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, the CAP law to prevent child access to guns, the 15-20-Life law to impose tougher sentences on criminals who use guns, the open lands trust initiative to acquire and preserve land for future generations, and the HMO patient bill of rights to make managed care more fair and responsive to Illinois members.</p>
<p>During Ryan's second legislative term, he demonstrated his commitment to educate our children and prepare the workforce for the challenges of the New Economy.  The VentureTECH initiative will promote technology by investing in the people, programs and physical structures as well as to promote venture capital investment. In January of 2000, after 13 people sentenced to death row were found to have been wrongfully convicted, Gov. Ryan took the unprecedented step of declaring a moratorium on executions and established a commission to comprehensibly review the system of capital punishment. Gov. Ryan said, "Until I can be sure, with moral certainty, that no innocent man or woman is facing a lethal injection, no one will meet that fate."  Also, the Governor has created a commission to rewrite the state's outdated and confusing criminal code.</p>
<p>As a result of Gov. Ryan's commitment to public service and his legislative accomplishments, he has been named 'Man of the Year' and received various other awards by numerous organizations including; the City Club of Chicago, the Veterans Leadership Program, Arab-American Business and Professional Association, Joint Civic Committee of Italian Americans, American Associates Ben Gurion University, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Commission Against Handgun Violence and Coalition Unity Community Action-ORTC.</p>
<p>As <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>secretary of state<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, Ryan worked to promote an efficient and cost-conscious administration that provided high-quality service to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> taxpayers and motorists. At the same time, he broke new ground in the fight against drunk driving, in the prevention of violence in society, in support of adult literacy, in increasing awareness about the need for organ donors and in the use of 21st Century technology in libraries and government.</p>
<p>Secretary Of State Ryan proposed and passed significant legislation and introduced various initiatives;</p>
<ul>
<li>Lowering the legal limit for drunk driving from a blood-alcohol content of .10 percent to .08 percent. 
<li>"Use It & Lose It" suspending the drivers' licenses of underage motorists who drink and drive.
<li>"Graduate to Safety" requiring teens to get more training during their first years behind the wheel.
<li>Requiring all new school bus drivers to undergo complete criminal background checks.
</ul>
<p>Ryan is a graduate of Kankakee public schools, served with the U.S. Army in Korea and, following his discharge, obtained a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor's degree in pharmacy<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Ferris State College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Big Rapids, Michigan. After 42 years of family ownership, the Ryan pharmacies were sold in 1990.</p>
<p>George and <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Lura Lynn Ryan<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> are the parents of a son and five daughters, including triplets.  They have fourteen grandchildren. </p>
<a name=chrono><hr></a>
<h2>Chronological Biography</h2>
<table border=1 cellpadding=3 cellspacing=0 width="90%">
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top><TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>Feb. 24, 1934<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/></td><td align=left valign=top>George H. Ryan is born to Thomas and Jeanette Ryan, the last of 3 children.  The Ryans also are legal guardians to a niece (Nancy Ferguson) after her parents die in an accident.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1935</td><td align=left valign=top>George H. Ryan's father, Thomas Ryan, moves to Chicago and takes a job as a pharmacist.  Later that year, he is relocated to Kankakee as a pharmacist.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1948</td><td align=left valign=top>Thomas Ryan opens his own drug store in Kankakee.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1952</td><td align=left valign=top><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> graduates from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Kankakee High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and enrolls at <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Butler University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Indiana.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1954</td><td align=left valign=top>George Ryan is drafted and completes a 2-year stint in the U.S. Army.  He is stationed in South Korea.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top><TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1956<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/></td><td align=left valign=top>George Ryan marries his high school sweetheart, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Lura Lynn Lowe<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1957</td><td align=left valign=top>A daughter, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Nancy<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, is born to the Ryans.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1961</td><td align=left valign=top>George Ryan graduates from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Ferris State College in Big Rapids<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, Michigan with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor's degree in pharmacy<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1961</td><td align=left valign=top>A daughter, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Lynda<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, is born to the Ryans.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1962/90</td><td align=left valign=top><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is co-owner of the family-pharmacies in Kankakee.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1962</td><td align=left valign=top><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> serves as campaign manager for State Senator Edward McBroom.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1962</td><td align=left valign=top>Triplet daughters, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Julie<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Joanne<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jeanette<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, are born to the Ryans.  </td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1964</td><td align=left valign=top>A son, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>George<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, is born to the Ryans.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1966</td><td align=left valign=top><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is appointed to the Kankakee County Board and is elected to the board in 1968.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1972</td><td align=left valign=top><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is elected to the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> House and is sworn into office in 1973.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1977</td><td align=left valign=top><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> becomes <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> House Minority Leader.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1981</td><td align=left valign=top><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> becomes <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Speaker of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> House<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1982</td><td align=left valign=top><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is elected <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> lieutenant governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> with Governor James R. Thompson.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1986</td><td align=left valign=top><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George H. Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is re-elected <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> lieutenant governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> with Governor James R. Thompson.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1990</td><td align=left valign=top><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George H. Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is elected <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Secretary of State<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1994</td><td align=left valign=top><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George H. Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is re-elected <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Secretary of State<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top><TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/></td><td align=left valign=top><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George H. Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is elected <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>.</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top>1999</td><td align=left valign=top><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George H. Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is sworn in as <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>' 39th <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>.</td></tr></table>
</td></tr></table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<center>

<html>
<head>
<title></title>
</head>
<body>
<table width=631 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0>
<tr>
<td align=LEFT height=167 valign=bottom width=641><img border=0 src="Images/Secondary-Header.jpg" alt="Corinne Wood - Lieutenant Governor" width=641 height=167></td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width=641 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0>
<tr>
<td width=140 bgcolor="#CC0000" valign=TOP align=CENTER><a href="Index.htm"><img src="Images/Button-Home.png" width=140 height=52 border=0></a><br><br><a href="Bio.htm"><img border=0 src="Images/Button-About.png"></a><br><br>
<a href="Achievements.htm"><img border=0 src="Images/Button-Achievements.png"></a><br>
<br>
<a href="Programs-Policies.htm"><img border=0 src="Images/Button-Programs.PNG"></a><br><br><a href="News.htm"><img src="Images/Button-News.png" width=140 height=52 border=0></a><br><br><a href="LtGovOffice.htm"><img src="Images/Button-Office.png" width=140 height=52 border=0></a><br><br><a href="Contact.htm"><img src="Images/Button-Contact.png" width=140 height=49 border=0></a><br>&nbsp;</td>
<td width=485 align=LEFT valign=TOP>
<h3 align=center><font face="Arial" color="#CC0000"><br>
Biography</font></h3>
<blockquote><font size=3>
<p><font face="Arial">In <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Corinne Wood<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> made history by
becoming <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> first female <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>. She pledged
to be active in her role as the states second highest-ranking
official, and has fulfilled that promise by providing strong
leadership in health care, environmental protection, senior
advocacy, rural affairs and streamlining state government. Wood
brings extensive experience in the public and private sectors to
the Office of <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, a post previously held by
Governor George Ryan and former U.S. Senator Paul Simon.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial">Lt. Governor Wood began her career in public
service over 20 years ago. Known as an effective advocate for
women and children, Woods experience includes service as a
state representative, attorney, and community activist, as well as
wife and mother. Among her achievements, she earned distinction as
one of &quot;100 Women Making a Difference&quot; in Illinois by <i>Todays
Chicago Woman</i>magazine, and was chosen to chair the Midwestern
Region of the National Conference of Lieutenant Governors.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial">As a breast cancer survivor, Wood is
dedicated to improving health care for women. Her leadership
abilities led Governor George Ryan to appoint her as Chair of <i>Womens
Health <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></i>, an interagency program that focuses on
enhancing womens health education and services. She also serves
as Honorary Chair of the Governors Commission on the Status of
Women.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial">Together with Governor Ryan, Wood has worked
to triple funding for the state Office of Womens Health,
expanding health education and outreach efforts and making a
program for low-cost breast and cervical exams available to more
women throughout <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>. She also created and hosts a Midwest
Emmy-nominated cable television show, <i>Todays Healthy Woman</i>,
to provide important health information to Illinois women and
their families.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial">In her first term, Wood launched the highly
regarded &quot;Check for a Cure&quot; campaign to increase
contributions to the states breast cancer research fund. Her
initiative was extremely effective, and in the first year doubled
the revenue donated to this fund. Her efforts on behalf of the
campaign in 2000 sustained and expanded its remarkable success.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial">In addition to health advocacy work, Wood
acts as the states advocate for rural areas as Chair of the
Governors Rural Affairs Council and the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Rural Bond
Bank, an agency that assists smaller communities in obtaining
financing for local infrastructure. As chair of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> River
Coordinating Council, Wood also directs the states strategy in
protecting the Illinois River Watershed and its tributaries. She
worked to double funding for a voluntary incentive program to
remove eroding lands from farm production and now is leading <i><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
Rivers 2020</i>, a bold, long-range initiative to restore <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
waterways. She also serves as Chair of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Main Street
Council, which provides assistance to communities in restoring
their downtown and historic areas.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial">After graduating Phi Beta Kappa from the
<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Illinois<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Loyola University School of Law<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, Wood
was named <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>general counsel<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> to the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Commissioner of Banks
and Trusts<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. She later joined the Chicago law firm of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Hopkins and
Sutter<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. While Corinne and her husband, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Paul<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, raised their three
children, she served her community as an active member of
charitable, political and governmental boards and commissions.
Woods community involvement spurred her election to the
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> House of Representatives.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial">During her first year as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>member of the
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> legislature<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, she passed more bills signed into law than
any other freshman state representative. Her hard work caught the
attention of George Ryan, who tapped her to be his running mate.
Wood made campaign visits to all 102 counties in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>,
discussing the ambitious agenda of the Ryan/Wood team. On November
3<sup>rd</sup>, 1998, George Ryan and Corinne Wood were elected
Governor and <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial">Corinne and <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Paul<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, an investment banker, have
been married for <TAG name="YRSMARR" value="start"/>22 years<TAG name="YRSMARR" value="end"/>. They and their three children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Ashley<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>,
15, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Brandon<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, 14, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Courtney<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, 11, reside in <TAG name="RESCITY" value="start"/>Lake County<TAG name="RESCITY" value="end"/>.</font></font></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p align=center>
<img src="Images/WoodFamily.jpg" width=305 height=230 border=0 alt=""></p></blockquote>
</td>
<td width=10 bgcolor="#CC0000">&nbsp;</td>
</tr>
</table>

of <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Corinne Wood<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/><br>
&nbsp;214
Statehouse&nbsp; *&nbsp; Springfield, IL&nbsp; 62706<br>
217/782-7884 (Voice) *
217/524-6262 (Fax) * 217/785-5946 (TDD)<br>

<html>
<head>
<title>Governor's Site: <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Lura Lynn Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></title>
<link rel=STYLESHEET href="govsite.css" type="text/css">
</head>
<body bgcolor="#3366cc">
<center>
<table border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 width="90%">
<tr>
<td align=right valign=top background="./images/splitback.gif"><div class=alignright><a href="./default.htm"><img src="./images/subleft.gif" alt="George H. Ryan, Governor of Illinois" border=0 width=121 height=35></a></div></td>
<td bgcolor="#ffffff" align=left valign=top><img src="./images/llr.gif" border=0 alt="Lura Lynn Ryan" width=415 height=35></td>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#003399" align=left valign=top class=navsmall><a href="./default.htm"><font color="#ffffff">Home</font></a><br>
<a href="./building.htm"><font color="#ffffff">Building&nbsp;A&nbsp;New&nbsp;<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></font></a>&nbsp;<br>
<a href="./getdone.htm"><font color="#ffffff">Getting Things Done</font></a><br>
<a href="./first.htm"><font color="#ffffff">First Lady</font></a><br>
<a href="./boards.htm"><font color="#ffffff">Boards &amp; Commissions</font></a><br>
<a href="./office.htm"><font color="#ffffff">Office Matters</font></a>
<br>
<p class=navsmallbold><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Lura Lynn Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></p>
<span class=navsmallbold><a href="./women/"><font color="#ffff99">Governor's Council on the Status of Women in Illinois</font></a>
<hr>
<a href="http://www.state.il.us/lincolncam/"><font color="#ffff99">Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library &amp; Museum</font></a>
<hr>
<a href="http://www.prevention.org"><font color="#ffff99">Prevention First</font></a>
<hr>
<a href="http://www.urbanext.uiuc.edu/4H/"><font color="#ffff99">All About 4H</font></a></span></p>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#ffffff" width="100%">
<table border=0 cellpadding=5 cellspacing=0 width="100%">
<tr>
<td>
<table border=0 cellspacing=5 cellpadding=0 width="100%">
<tr>
<td><img src="./images/llryan.jpg" alt="Photo of Lura Lynn Ryan" border=0 width=150 height=182 align=left></td><td><a href="http://www.futures4kids.org"><img src="./images/llr_ffk.gif" alt="Futures For Kids" border=0 width="" height=182></a></td></tr></table><p><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Lura Lynn Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> and her husband, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Governor <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>George H. Ryan<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> (R), have worked for more than twenty years to fight alcohol and other drug abuse, advance adult literacy, encourage organ donation, promote <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> arts and crafts, and preserve the state's rich history and culture.</p>
<p>Mrs. Ryan has received numerous awards for her advocacy of substance abuse prevention programs.  In 1992, Prevention First, Inc., dedicated its research libraries in Springfield and Chicago in her honor. The <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Lura Lynn Ryan<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> Prevention Research Library is named after <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>' First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in recognition of her many years of dedicated work to promote prevention practices in the state and nationally. </p>
<p>The library has established itself as the primary source for substance abuse prevention materials and resources in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.  It offers the largest specialty collection of substance abuse prevention and related materials in the state and includes 15,000 books, close to 2,000 audiovisual items, subscriptions to fifty specialty periodicals, and links to over 3,000 libraries internationally.</p>
<p>Online library services through <a href="http://www.prevention.org">the Prevention First webpage</a>include reviews of new and current publications, the ability to reserve library collection holdings, and the capability for querying library staff on particular research subjects or materials.</p>
<p>More recently, Mrs. Ryan received the Prevention Leadership Award from the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Alcoholism and Drug Dependence Association and the 2000 Leadership Award from the board of directors at TASC (Treatment Alternatives for Safer Communities).  The McDonald's Corporation presented Mrs. Ryan with their prestigious Founder's Award for her work with the Ronald McDonald's House Charities and her advocacy on behalf of children.</p>
<p>In support of Governor Ryan's children's agenda, Mrs. Ryan chairs <i>Futures for Kids</i>, a statewide campaign aimed at reducing juvenile delinquency, substance abuse and violence among <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> youth. The goal is to serve more children and families through better programs, more coordinated agency efforts, less duplication and the most effective use of the state's resources.  For more information, please visit the <i>Futures for Kids</i>website at <a href="http://www.futures4kids.org">www.futures4kids.org</a>.</p>
<p>In February 2001, Mrs. Ryan was honored for her extensive efforts and contributions on behalf of tourism in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.  The first-ever <i>Friend of Tourism Award</i>was presented to the First Lady at the Governor's Conference on Tourism.</p>
<p>Mrs. Ryan promotes <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>' rich history and resources through various projects. She is the guiding force behind the <i>Made In <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></i> catalogue promoting hand-made items created by <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>' finest artisans.  The latest edition will be available in the spring of 2001.</p>
<p>As President of the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum Foundation, Mrs. Ryan has been instrumental in the planning of this magnificent complex to be built in Springfield, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.</p>
<p>Mrs. Ryan is currently spearheading the creation of a book commemorating the history of the <a href="http://www.state.il.us/gov/mansion2/"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Illinois<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Executive Mansion</a>and the families that have resided within its walls.</p>
<p>In 1999, she was selected by <i>Today's Chicago Woman</i>as one of &quot;100 Women Making A Difference.&quot; </p>
<p>The former <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Lura Lynn Lowe<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was born <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>July 5, 1934<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Aroma Park, Illinois<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>.  She was educated in Kankakee schools and is a graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Moser Business College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.  The Ryans were married June 10, 1956.  They have six children, including triplet daughters, and fourteen grandchildren.</p>
</td></tr></table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p class=pcenter align=center><span class=pcenter align=center>
<center>
<table border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 width="95%">

207 Statehouse<br>
Springfield, IL 62706<br>
217-782-0244<br>
217-558-2239 TDD<br>

<a href="/gov/fellowship/index.html" onmouseout="MM_swapImgRestore()" onmouseover="MM_swapImage('sub07','','/gov/images/sub07_f2.gif',1);"><img name=sub07 src="/gov/images/sub07.gif" width=190 height=20 border=0 alt="Fellowship Program"></a><br>
<a href="/gov/contact/index.html" onmouseout="MM_swapImgRestore()" onmouseover="MM_swapImage('sub08','','/gov/images/sub08_f2.gif',1);"><img name=sub08 src="/gov/images/sub08.gif" width=190 height=22 border=0 alt="Contact the Governor"></a><br>
<a href="/gov/executive/index.html" onmouseout="MM_swapImgRestore()" onmouseover="MM_swapImage('sub10','','/gov/images/sub10_f2.gif',1);"><img name=sub10 src="/gov/images/sub10.gif" width=190 height=19 border=0 alt="Executive Orders"></a><br>

</td>
<td>
<table width="100%" border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td valign=top colspan=2><img name=subspacer src="/gov/images/subpiece.gif" width=129 height=50 border=0 alt="  "></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top>
<td colspan=2>
<table width="100%" border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0>
<tr>
<td colspan=4>
<font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><b><font size="+1">Biography</font></b></font></td>
</tr>
<tr bgcolor="#0000CC">
<td height=1><img src="/gov/images/shim.gif" alt=" " width=200 height=1></td>
</tr>
</table>
</td></tr>
<tr><td colspan=2>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr><td width=20>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td valign=top>
<p>
<center><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica"><font size=+2><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>FRANK O'BANNON<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></font></font></b>
<br><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica"><font size=+1>Forty-Seventh <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor
of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></font></font></b>
<p><img src="/gov/images/oban_small.gif" border=0 height=151 width=122 alt="Governor O'Bannon"></center>
<p><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Frank O'Bannon<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was first elected on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 5, 1996<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> and reelected to a second term on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 7, 2000<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>.  For his first inauguration ceremony, Governor O'Bannon invited all Indiana 4th graders, something no Governor had ever done. Fourth graders, who study <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> history as part of their curriculum, were invited back for the second inauguration. More than 25,000 students and visitors attended the <a href="/gov/webcast/inauguration.html">second inauguration on January 8, 2001</a>, making it the largest gubernatorial inauguration in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> history. 
<p>Under Governor O'Bannon's leadership:
<ul>
<li>Education is improving:
<ul><li><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> schools are above the national average in math and reading scores.
<li><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> has one of the most comprehensive assessment and accountability systems in the nation.
<li><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> has some of the nation's highest math, English and science standards.</ul>
<li>The economy is strong:
<ul><li>More than 3 million Hoosiers are working - more than ever before.
<li><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> is in the top ten in the nation for growth of high-wage jobs, lowest poverty rate and lowest unemployment rate.
<li><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> ranks 11th nationally in high-tech jobs.</ul>
<li>Families are being helped:
<ul><li><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> is a national leader in welfare reform. Among the states, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> has ranked in the top ten in job placement and job retention and earnings.
<li><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> is noted nationally for providing health insurance to 373,000 children whose families could not otherwise afford it. </ul>
</ul>
<p><b>Investing in Education</b>
<p>Governor O'Bannon's top priority is education. On the national level, O'Bannon serves as chair of the National Education Goals Panel, a bi-partisan organization committed to improving education. He has also served as co-chair of the National Governor's Association Extra Learning Opportunities Task Force.
<p>O'Bannon's Quality Teaching initiative will provide teachers with the professional development training and tools they need, and our children deserve.  He's also working for more flexibility and accountability in our public schools, increasing reading and math readiness, and is urging a greater emphasis on early childhood education. 
<p>Governor O'Bannon formed the <a href="http://www.che.state.in/us/roundtable">Education Roundtable</a>, co-chaired with Superintendent of Public Instruction Suellen Reed, to help shape education policy.  He brought together business leaders, educators, parents and students throughout the state asking for suggestions to improve Indiana's public schools. The Roundtable created new accountability laws requiring schools to make continuous improvements, while also giving schools flexibility to determine how to meet their goals.  The Roundtable has also championed a plan that gives Indiana some of the highest math, English and science standards in the nation.   Work is now underway to adopt new standards for geography, economics, civics and history as well.
<p>Under O'Bannon's leadership, state support for public education is at an all-time high. During his first term, he increased funding for colleges and universities by a total of 28 percent. He launched the <a href="http://www.ccindiana.net/">Community College of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> system</a>that provides a convenient and affordable way for students of all ages to pursue advanced education. The Community College system has experienced tremendous success with two consecutive semesters of record-setting enrollment growth at the first four campuses. During the next five years, the Community College of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> will expand to all 23 Ivy Tech State College sites.
<p>Also on the education front, he has: 
<ul>
<li>Launched the "Ready to Read" program to ensure that all 3rd graders can read at or above 3rd grade level; 
<li>Increased funding for the <a href="http://www.state.in.us/cji/juv/safehaven.htm ">Safe Haven </a>program, keeping school buildings open before and after normal hours for tutoring, recreation and anti-violence, anti-drug messages;
<li>Promoted character education and developed a <a href="http://www.character-development.org">Center for Character Development</a>in partnership with Anderson University; and 
<li>Dedicated additional state funding to tutor high school students who need help with the ISTEP+ graduation qualifying exam. Even with the new graduation qualifying exam requirement, a higher percentage of high school seniors is graduating than ever before.
</ul>
<p>Also for children, Governor O'Bannon has launched the <a href="/fssa/children/bbb">Building Bright Beginnings</a>initiative to emphasize the importance of emotional and brain development of children from birth to 4 years of age.  The parents of every newborn now receive a colorful, easy-to-read growth calendar to take home. So far, more than 400,000 of these calendars have been distributed.  The information helps parents give the attention, affection and stimulation that young children need to reach their full potential. The program also promotes quality childcare and helps parents recognize and remove lead and mercury hazards from their homes. 
<p><b>Keeping <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> in a State of Progress</b>
<p><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> residents have not had a state tax increase in 12 years, dating back to 1988, the first year of the Bayh-O'Bannon administration and continuing through today. 
<p>In addition, Governor O'Bannon cut taxes by at least $1.5 billion during his first term in office. That includes:
<ul>
<li>Property tax cut = $863.4 million
<li>Income tax cut = $507.4 million
<li>Inheritance tax cut = $59.3 million
<li>Business Employment tax cut = $107.9 million
</ul>
<p>O'Bannon also gave Hoosiers relief at the gas pump from July - September 2000 by suspending the sales tax on gasoline. This action saved Hoosier taxpayers more than $30 million at a time of low gasoline supplies and high gasoline prices.
<p>O'Bannon's prudent fiscal management has earned the state outstanding credit ratings from Wall Street, saving <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> taxpayers tens of millions of dollars in financing new school buildings, highways and other public construction. O'Bannon also invested more than $564 million to improve the Crossroads of America's vital highway network. 
To further maintain the state's strong economic growth, he helped create the <a href="http://www.21stcentury-research.org">21st Century Research and Technology Fund</a>.  This fund has awarded more than $49 million to nearly 200 schools, businesses, and partnerships that are making technological advances.  Supporting these academic-private sector partnerships stimulates technology development and transfer, as well as bolstering clusters of high-tech companies that are crucial if Indiana is to increase the number of high-tech jobs in the state.
<p><b>Helping Hoosier Families</b>
<p>Under Governor O'Bannon's direction, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> is a national leader in the effort to extend health care coverage to its citizens.  More than 373,000 Hoosier children whose parents work, but either don't have access to health insurance through their jobs or can't afford the premiums, have signed up for the health insurance program, <a href="/fssa/hoosier_healthwise.com">Hoosier Healthwise</a>. In addition to increasing coverage, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> made it simpler and more convenient for parents to sign their children up. 
<p>O'Bannon also committed funds to triple the number of families served by <a href="/fssa/families/protection/dfchealthy.html">Healthy Families <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></a>, which teaches parenting and coping skills one-on-one in Hoosier homes. The program has achieved a remarkable success rate in preventing child abuse and neglect in the high-risk families taking part. It is funded with savings achieved by moving Hoosiers from welfare rolls to payrolls.
<p><b>Keeping Our Streets Safe </b>
<p>Governor O'Bannon believes the recent explosion of clandestine labs producing methamphetamine, or meth, poses a significant threat to public safety. His initiative to make <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> safer includes making meth violations equivalent to the penalties for offenses relating to cocaine and giving Indiana law enforcement officers the resources needed to swiftly and properly dismantle these dangerous labs.
<p>The Governor also created the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Office of Drug Control Policy, chaired by Karen Freeman-Wilson, to coordinate state activities related to the reduction of drug abuse and its consequences to the state. The office will work with local, state and federal agencies, as well as private groups, to ensure the implementation of comprehensive and accountable drug policy for <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>. 
<p>O'Bannon persuaded the legislature to pay for 540 more police officers in 292 police districts across the state, giving some communities their first full-time law enforcement ever. He has also built more facilities to lock up adult and juvenile offenders and has expanded the sex-offender registry. 
<p><b>Making a Difference in Communities</b>
<p>When the legislature is not in session, Governor O'Bannon rolls up his sleeves at least one day each month in his "A Day Makes a Difference" campaign, encouraging other leaders as well as everyday citizens to volunteer in community service projects. He has tutored children on computers, served food to the homeless, helped to build or rehabilitate low-income housing and spruced up other public and non-profit facilities. 
<p><b>Hoosier Family Values and Experiences</b>
<p>Previously, O'Bannon served eight years as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>lieutenant governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. That followed 18 years as a part-time <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>legislator in the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Senate<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, where he represented eight counties in southern <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>. For the last 11 of those years his colleagues chose him as the <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Democratic<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> floor leader. Before his election to statewide office, he also <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>practiced law<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at the Corydon firm of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>O'Bannon, Funk and Simpson<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. He is <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>chairman<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>O'Bannon Publishing Company<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in Corydon, publishing weekly newspapers in Harrison and Crawford counties. 
<p>Frank O'Bannon grew up in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Harrison County<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>. He graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Corydon High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1948 and received a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor's degree in government<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Indiana University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1952. After two years in the U.S. Air Force, he returned to Bloomington to earn a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>I.U.<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1957<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/>. Also that year, he and his wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Judy<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, were married. 
<p><a href="/gov/firstlady"><TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Judy O'Bannon<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/></a> promotes the arts, community development and historic preservation throughout Indiana. She chairs the Governor's <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Indiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> 2016 program, helping communities statewide take stock of their roots as they work toward a better future. Governor and Mrs. O'Bannon live at the Governor's Residence in <TAG name="RESCITY" value="start"/>Indianapolis<TAG name="RESCITY" value="end"/>. They have three children (<TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Polly<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jennifer<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jonathan<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>) and four grandchildren (Beau, Chelsea, Asher and Demi).
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="95%" border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0>
