<html>
<head>
<title>Governor Patton Biography</title>
</head>
<body background="graytext.gif" bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
<p align=center><img src="biologo.gif" width=503 height=100></p>
<p align=center><img src="govsign2.jpg" width=208 height=151></p>
<font size=3>
<p class="MsoNormal" align=center style="text-align:center"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal">Biography of <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Paul E. Patton<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/><o:p>
</o:p>
</b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align=center style="text-align:center"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal">January 2000<o:p>
</o:p>
</b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;;
mso-fareast-font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;;mso-ansi-language:EN-US;mso-fareast-language:
EN-US;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA">Let us invest in the intellectual capital of
our people&., with that statement in his second inaugural address on
<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>December 7, 1999<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Paul Patton<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> began his historic second term as
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s chief magistrate with a vow to rededicate and recommit himself to
another four years of activism toward his goal of improving the quality of life
for all Kentuckians.</span><b><span style="font-size:18.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt"><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">As we enter the 21<sup>st</sup>century, building the
intellectual capital of our people through education will be the number one
priority in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>During these
next four years we will address the educational needs of our society in every
aspect, with a new focus on early childhood development and adult literacy.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Well invest in more infrastructure, including a comprehensive effort
to bring potable water to every <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> household.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Well tackle healthcare and make our tax system fairer.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Well protect the environment with a statewide garbage pickup and
recycling program.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>And well
improve our economy, targeting the Appalachian region of our state.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>All of these initiatives are aimed at providing a quality of life for our
citizens that is second to none.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">These are the words of <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Paul Patton<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>the mountains
of Eastern Kentucky<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, son of a teacher and school cafeteria worker who instilled
in him the value of education, honest living and hard work.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">A 1959 graduate of the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Kentucky<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degree
in mechanical engineering<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Paul Patton<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> spent the next 20 years building a
successful coal business and then turned to public service.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>He has served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s Deputy State Transportation Secretary<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>,
leader of the State <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Democratic<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> Party and three terms as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Pike County Judge
Executive<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>In 1991, Patton became
<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s Lt. Governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and made history by also serving as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Secretary of the
Economic Development Cabinet<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">In <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>December of 1995<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Paul Patton<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> began his first term as
<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, after a close election that hardly anyone thought he could win. In his
inaugural address, he said he wanted to make his mark as the higher education
governor.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Governor Patton believes that education and economic
development are the means by which <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s standard of living, now below
the national average, can be raised to a more acceptable quality. He has already
established a track record of creating tens of thousands of jobs and attracting
new industry to the commonwealth, including more than 100 Japanese companies.
His unique package of tax incentives has drawn national acclaim, and placed
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> as one of the most attractive places in the United States to locate
business. <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> has consistently been among the top ten states in terms of
economic development, with the second lowest cost of doing business, and a
workforce ten percent more productive than the national average.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;;
mso-bidi-language:AR-SA">The governor is earning national recognition for his
devotion to education and his leadership abilities. Most recently he assumed the
Chair of the Southern Governors Association and is serving as chair of the
<TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Democratic<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> Governors Association. He is Chair of the Council on State
Governments and was also picked by U.S. Education Secretary Dick Riley to head a
new education commission to look at the high school senior year.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>He just completed a term as Chairman of the National Education Goals
Panel and the Education Commission of the States, and has chaired the Southern
Regional Education Board, and the Southern Growth Policies Board.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent">In <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1999<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, Paul Patton became the first <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in nearly 200 years to be elected to two successive terms.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>In his second inaugural address, he said, the top priority for the
next four years will be education, education, education and education.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent">And the 2000 session of the General Assembly proved
to be exceptionally productive for education. Governor Patton said, I believe
that history will record this session as the turning point, a sea change, in the
way Kentuckians think about education, particularly postsecondary education.</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent">Virtually the entire budget that the Council on
Postsecondary Education proposed and the governor supported was enacted by the
General Assembly.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>The governor
called it a quantum leap in funding and an affirmation of the council's
role in coordinating that funding and how the money is spent.</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent">The postsecondary education budget included a 19%
increase in base funding plus $120 million for the Governors Bucks for
Brains program to encourage a match in private giving to universities in
support of research and excellence in teaching.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent">With this 2000 session, we have cemented the
commitment we made when we approved the Postsecondary Education Improvement Act
in 1997.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>From this point on,
efforts to politicize and protect turf among our institutions of higher learning
will find fewer and fewer friends in Frankfort.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>The culture has changed!</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent">All through his career in public service, the
governor has followed up his words with actions, proposing initiatives that will
result in educational improvements, economic security, a clean environment and a
safe, healthy and secure future for the children of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent">&quot;I would rather be a leader who makes a
difference in the lives of the people of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, than a caretaker whose
footprints leave no trace in history,&quot; Governor Patton says<span style="font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt">.</span>
Our mission is not complete, but it is clear our goals have moved us in the
right direction.</p>
<p align=CENTER>-30-</p>
</font>
<p align=center>Return to <a href="http://www.state.ky.us/">State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Homepage</a>
</p>
<p align=center>Return to <a href="govmenu6.htm">Governor Patton's Homepage</a></p>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC


<html>
<head>
<title>Lt. Governor Biography</title>
</head>
<body background="http://www.state.ky.us/agencies/gov/ltgov/images/graytext.gif" bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
<p class="MsoTitle" align=center><u><font size=4>Biography<o:p>
</font>
</u></p>
<p class="MsoSubtitle" align=center><u><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt"><font size=4><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Stephen L. Henry<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/><o:p></o:p>,
M.D.</font></span></u></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align=center style="text-align:center"><u><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt"><font size=4><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lt.
Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></font></span></u></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">Dr.
<TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Stephen L. Henry<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> entered <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s history books as one of the youngest
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> lieutenant governors and the first ever elected to serve two
consecutive terms.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>His leadership
abilities have earned him the prestigious chairmanship of the National
Conference of Lieutenant Governors, elected by his peers both democrat and
republican.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>The 47-year-old
orthopedic surgeon is also the only medical doctor to ever be elected to the
office of <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">At
<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Western Kentucky University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> he received his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>B.S. in Biology/Chemistry<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> while
serving as class president and president of the student government.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Dr. Henry received his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>medical degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> at the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Louisville
School of Medicine<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> where he remained to do his internship in general surgical
and his orthopedic residency.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>While
there, he exercised his penchant for politics by serving as class president,
medical school student government president, medical class president, and later
as president of the U of L House Staff Association.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s
first doctor has a strong background in veteran and medical research and
has published over 100 articles/chapters, which have brought him many national
awards. One of the most prestigious awards is the Edwin G. Bovill National
Research Award.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">As an
orthopedic surgeon, Dr. Henry has won international acclaim.<span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">&nbsp; </span>Already known as a fine surgeon and teacher, he has also
played an instrumental role in the research, development and use of breakthrough
techniques using antibiotic beads.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Dr.
Henry and his innovative techniques received international recognition on CNN
during the Persian Gulf War, when the beads were used to treat wounded soldiers.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>His work was widely reported by several other national new organizations
and won him personal recognition from General Schwarzkopf.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>As a result of this recognition, Dr. Henry, is completing a chapter on
lower extremity injuries for the U.S. Department of Defense.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">As an
international speaker he has traveled to many countries around the world, some
include: Granada, Spain; Vienna, Austria; Berlin, Germany; Guatemala City,
Guatemala; Valbella, Switzerland; Seoul, Korea; London, England; University of
Beijing in China; Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem and the University of Tel Aviv
in Israel.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;</span><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoBodyText"><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal">Community
Service:</span><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">Dr.
Henry has always been an advocate for community service and has led by example.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Dr. Henry has received the Jefferson Award from the American Institute
for Public Service, Ten Outstanding Young Americans given by the United States
Jaycees, Ashland Oil Foundation Outstanding Young <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Leader and the
prestigious Bell Award given by the Spirit of Louisville Foundation, all given
for outstanding community service and leadership.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoBodyText"><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal">Education:</span><b><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;"><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">Lt.
Governor Henry is an advocate for community service to be included in all
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> schools curriculum, which led him to lobby the Citizens Scholarship
Foundation of America to consider placing a Dollars for Scholars chapter in
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Through his successful
efforts he now serves as the honorary chairman of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Dollars for
Scholars board of directors, which encourages and rewards students with
educational scholarships for community involvement.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">During
his first term of office <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s classrooms were recognized as the most
technologically advanced in the nation.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Each
classroom in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> has a high-speed computer, connected to the Internet.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> was honored as the number one state for computer connectivity,
providing one computer for every eight students.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">He
continues his involvement with education by attending state meetings of the
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Retired Teachers, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Education Association, and is presently
lobbying for retired teachers health benefits.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>He remains current in his understanding of what is needed in this state
to achieve and maintain high educational standards, and is an avid supporter of
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s unique Education Pays program.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoBodyText"><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal">Health Care:</span><b><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">As an
obvious choice as a leader in health care initiatives and his commitment for
better and affordable health care for all Kentuckians, Dr. Henry continues to
treat indigent patients at Louisvilles University Hospital.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">Regarded
as an expert in the field of health care, he has been the keynote speaker in
numerous conferences addressing health related issues. Most recently at the
University of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s Donovan Scholars Program on aging issues, the Summit
on African American Health Initiatives and the Kentucky Nurses Association
annual convention.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">His
efforts and commitment were instrumental in bringing about <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s
Patients Bill of Rights, which puts medical decisions back into the
hands of where it belongs, the patient and the doctor.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Dr. Henry was the force behind appealing the decision of HMOs to
prohibit genetic testing for health insurance ratings.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">He
continues to work toward the elimination of both a prescription drug sales tax
for drugs issued through any source and taxation on medical samples.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>He succeeded in passing a resolution as Chairman of the National
Conference of Lieutenant Governors, urging the United States Congress to enact a
Medicare prescription drug benefit.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">He
has specifically concentrated his health care efforts in the Appalachian Region
urging public education in regard to mammograms, health screenings, and smoking
cessation classes<o:p>
</o:p>
.</span><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">Dr.
Henry is deeply involved in the successful effort to see that the states
ambulance service providers receive payment in a timely manner to enable them to
keep in operation and to maintain top manpower and efficiency.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>In the past two months he organized statewide seminars as a means to help
resolve the current Medicare reimbursement crisis affecting <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s
ambulance providers. &nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoBodyText"><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal">Environment:</span><b><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">As an
avid supporter of the environment, Lt. Governor Henry is the founder of The
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Clean Fuels Coalition, whose direction works toward preserving clean
air by providing a non-fossil fuel source of energy.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">He is
also co-founder of the Future Fund Land Trust, which has preserved 1000 acres
dedicated to provide green space and a public park area in Louisville. In 1997,
he won the Mary Bingham Land Conservation Award for this project.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">He
serves on the board of directors of the Waterfront Development Corporation,
which coordinates land use planning for the Louisville waterfront area and
includes areas of historic downtown, with goals of developing and re-developing
for the benefit of tourism and public usage.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoBodyText"><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal">Aging:</span><b><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">Like
the rest of the nation, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> is experiencing a major population change in
all age groups.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Dr. Henry realizes
that the pyramid has become inverted, with older groups rapidly becoming larger
than younger segments of the population.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>He
is focusing his attention on aging issues and is committed to bringing members
of this population improved and less complicated services.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>He has proposed to elevate the Office of Aging Services to a more
independent level, where seniors can contact one office to obtain
services.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">Dr.
Henry is working with the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Nurses Association to educate <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s
aging population and home caregivers about basic home health and preventative
care matters.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">He
expects to have a large team of nurses conducting training sessions to
facilitators across the state.</span><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">He is
a strong advocate on long-term care insurance and a proponent of Adult Day Care.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>He is currently developing legislation that provides incentives and
rewards for those who buy Long Term Care insurance.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>This form of insurance also can include assisted living and adult day
care expenses.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Realizing that the
current generation of Americans is handling the care of both their children and
their parents - he has proposed that adult day care services be offered
statewide, providing a better quality of life for our aging population.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">Another
aging initiative of Lt. Governor Henry is Seniors on Call.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>This initiative will establish a pool of part-time senior workers for
local industries to tap and provide the companies with flexible and accessible
labor that will benefit seniors by keeping them active mentally and
physically, as well as giving them extra income.</span><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoBodyText"><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal">Veterans:</span><b><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">Lt.
Governor Henry has played a key role in developing the administrations policy
towards veterans.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>During this
administration we have seen the Office of Veterans Affairs moved from the
Department of Military Affairs and given independent status directly under the
Governors Office.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>At the same
time we have seen the field staff doubled which has meant more that one million
dollars in additional benefits for Kentucky Veterans.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Lt. Governor Henry has been instrumental in the funding for two new
veterans nursing homes in the state that are currently under construction.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">One
very important piece of legislation proposed by the Lt. Governor is the
Veterans Right to Know Act.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>For
many years the states have shouldered the responsibility of implementing federal
programs and benefits without resources or assistance from the VA.<span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>Dr. Henry is working on an outreach program to
fully inform veterans of benefits available to them.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">Lt.
Governor Henry, along with his wife <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Heather<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, are working to provide <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s
estimated 5,000 homeless veterans a hand up by building a transitional housing
facility strictly for veterans.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>This
would be a first in the state of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family:&quot;Times New Roman&quot;">Dr.
Henry has a schedule that is unbelievably complex, with a host of additional
medical and political activities that doesnt quite fit in any category.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>This capable leader and visionary walks the walk and continues his
tireless quest for a better <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>He
recently married another outstanding <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> achiever, Miss America 2000,
<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Heather Rene French<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>They are
eagerly awaiting the birth of their first child later this summer.<o:p>
</o:p>
<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC


<html>
<head>
<title><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>JUDI CONWAY PATTON<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> - <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>FIRST LADY<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> </title>
</head>
<body background="graytext.gif" bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
<p align=center><img src="judikids.jpg" width=320 height=203 alt="judikids.jpg (24983 bytes)"></p>
<p align=center><font size=4><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>JUDI CONWAY PATTON<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></font></p>
<p align=center style="text-align:center;mso-pagination:none"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><font size=4><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>FIRST
LADY of the COMMONWEALTH of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>KENTUCKY<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/><o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></b></p>
<hr>
<p class="MsoNormal" align=center style="text-align:center;mso-pagination:none"><i><span style="font-size:14.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold">Children
have small voices which are never heard.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br>
Their voices must be heard through us.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></i></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-pagination:none"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman">The
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Constitution mentions no specific duties for the spouse of the Governor
of the Commonwealth.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>That provides
a tremendous opportunity for First Ladies to choose what they will do with their
role and their visibility.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"></span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Judi
Patton<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is offering unique leadership and is establishing the position that no
<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> needs to be known solely by the accomplishments or
priorities of her husband.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>In
short, she is the designing of the role of First Ladies for the 21<sup>st</sup>
Century.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">She
decided early in the Patton Administration that she would lend her leadership to
those who do not typically have a voice in government, to women and children
harmed by abuse and violence.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Mrs.
Pattons advocacy is being felt across <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, and across the nation.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>In July 1998, Vice President Al Gore traveled to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> to award a
special domestic violence grant to the Governor and Mrs. Patton, calling them
the foremost leaders in the country on this issue. Immediately upon her
husbands ascension to the governorship, Mrs. Patton began pushing legislative
reform on behalf of women victimized by battering and children harmed by abuse.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>She testified on legislation allowing victim advocates to accompany
victims into court, on a bill to provide domestic violence training to key
professionals, and on legislation to allow the testimony of sexually abused
children to be videotaped rather than requiring them to testify in person before
the person who allegedly harmed them.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Mrs.
Patton serves as special advisor to the Governors Office of Child Abuse and
Domestic Violence Services and co-chairs with former Governor John Y. Brown,
Jr., the Governors Council on Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>In 1998, she worked with the Governor to set aside<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>$1 million to upgrade the 15 facilities in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> which house battered
womens shelters, and in the 2000 biennium budget her advocacy resulted in an
increase in operating funds for spouse abuse centers of $1.1 million, the
largest one-time increase in history.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Her
work on behalf of womens safety also extends to the issue of rape.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>In the fall of 1999, Mrs. Patton successfully lobbied the Governor to
create a first of its kind Governors Task Force on Sexual Assault, a body for
which she served as honorary chair.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>That
successful work group now has been folded into the Governors Council.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Through the Task Force, Mrs. Patton proposed legislation to create Rape
Crisis Centers in statute, to remove special restrictions on marital rape
victims, to toughen the states response to sexual offenders, to create
additional civil remedies and other protections for rape and stalking victims,
and other reforms.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Mrs.
Patton also has been instrumental in changing <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s laws to protect child
victims, twice proposing legislation to strengthen the hand of the court in
removing abused children from homes where their lives are threatened.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>She took on the expansion of Childrens Advocacy Centers across
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, working with Governor Patton to put $1.8 million in the 2000-2001
biennium budget toward that effort.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Continuing
her role as a champion for the protection of families and children, during the
1998 legislative session Mrs. Patton worked with <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Chief Justice Robert
Stephens to ensure the passage of HB 544 that provides a system of family courts
in several of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s counties.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>The
First Lady has been outspoken in addressing this issue that forces families and
children to appear before several different judges when they are often dealing
with the same matter. <o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Mrs.
Patton has become a tireless voice for women and children who have suffered from
violence or abuse.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Her sincerity
and the strength of her convictions have drawn praise from lawmakers, victim
advocates and the media.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Many
constituencies have recognized her for her efforts.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b><i style="mso-bidi-font-style:normal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Awards:<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></i></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-pagination:none;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1996, Mrs. Patton
received national attention for her strong advocacy and support for child abuse
legislation when she was awarded by the National Center for Missing and
Exploited Children.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-pagination:none;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1996, she received an
Outstanding Legislative Advocacy award from the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Coalition Against Rape
and Sexual Assault.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1996, she received
from the<b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal"></b><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Psychological
Association the <i><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Distinguished Citizen Award</i>in recognition of
her dedicated leadership in advocating for psychological services for victims of
sexual abuse and domestic violence.<b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal"><o:p>
</o:p>
</b></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-pagination:none;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1996, she traveled to
Washington, D.C., with Governor Patton to receive her second national
recognition at the 11<sup>th</sup>National Conference on Child Abuse and
Neglect where she received a <i>Commissioners Award</i>from the Department
of Health and Human Services. <o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-pagination:none;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1996, the first <i>Committed
to Peace in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Homes Award</i>was bestowed on the First Lady by the
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Domestic Violence Association. <o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-pagination:none;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1997, she received an
Outstanding Leadership award from the Commonwealths Attorneys Association.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;mso-pagination:none"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1997, she received the
first <i>Outstanding Advocate Award</i>from the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Council on Child
Abuse.<b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal"><o:p>
</o:p>
</b></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1997, she was honored
by the Lexington<b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal"></b>YWCA with the <i>Smith-Breckinridge
Award</i>for outstanding leadership in support of women and children.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1997, she received the
<i>Distinguished Alumna Award</i>, Pikeville High School.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1998, she was honored
by Board of Directors of Very Special Arts <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> for support of Arts
Opportunities for Persons with Disabilities.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1998, she received an
award for Outstanding Service to Children from the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Council for
Exceptional Children, Chapter 5.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1998, she received the
<i>Junior Williamson Memorial Award</i>presented by the Pike County Chamber of
Commerce for her contributions to the community because of her long hours of
dedicated and unselfish work as a citizen of Pike County.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1999, she received the
<i style="mso-bidi-font-style:normal">Friend of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s Children Award </i>from
the Exploited Childrens Help Organization.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo2;tab-stops:list .25in"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1999, she was granted
the <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters (L.H.D.)<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the board of
directors of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Pikeville College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo2;tab-stops:list .25in"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span>In 1999, Children First honored her with a special award for her
outstanding leadership in advocating for children.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Children First recognizes each year one outstanding individual whose
contributions to child victims of sexual abuse have demonstrated leadership, a
strong commitment to advocacy on behalf of child victims, and whose dedication
and tireless efforts have inspired others to greater service. <span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo2;tab-stops:list .25in"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span>In 2000, she received the Joy of Life Award from the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
Cancer Program and the Brown Cancer Center for her contributions to breast
cancer.<span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo2;tab-stops:list .25in"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span>In 2000, she received the Leadership Award from the Susan G. Komen
Breast Cancer Foundation and BMW Ultimate Drive for the Cure.<span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo2;tab-stops:list .25in"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span>In 2000, she received an outstanding child advocate award from the
Sunshine Center in Frankfort, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> where also a childrens playroom was
dedicated in her honor.<span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 2000, she received the
Gold Medal Award from the Family Place in Louisville for her work on behalf of
abused children.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo2;tab-stops:list .25in"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 2000, she was given
the annual Leadership Award bestowed by the Center for Women and Families in
Louisville.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo2;tab-stops:list .25in"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 2000, she again was
honored by the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Commonwealths Attorneys Association in recognition
of the successful legislative package she championed before the 2000 Session of
the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> General Assembly.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo2;tab-stops:list .25in"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 2001, the Barren River
Area Child Advocacy Center honored her for her efforts on behalf of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s
children by establishing the Judi C. Patton Community Conference Hall in the
newly constructed advocacy center.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo2;tab-stops:list .25in"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Symbol"><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-family: Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 2001, she was
presented the Key to the City by the Mayor Sandy Jones of Bowling Green who was
joined by Warren County Judge Executive Mike Buchanon who presented a joint
proclamation declaring January 12, 2001 as Childrens Advocacy Day in honor of
the First Lady.<o:p>
</o:p>
<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal"><i style="mso-bidi-font-style:normal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Women
and their Health<o:p>
</o:p>
</span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></i></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">The First Ladys
work with womens issues also extends to healthcare. In 1996, she was
instrumental in getting HB 504 passed to require insurance carriers operating in
the state to provide coverage for autologous bone marrow and stem cell treatment
by transplantation to breast cancer patients receiving chemotherapy.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>During the 1998 legislative session, she worked to seek passage of the
Womens Health Bill that included creating by 1999 an Office of Womens
Physical and Mental Health.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>The
bill also required insurance companies operating in Kentucky to pay for breast
reconstruction and equalization for cancer victims.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Mrs. Patton serves
as Honorary Chair for the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Breast Cancer Coalition and the Chair of the
Governors Task Force on Breast Cancer, which was created by Executive Order
in 1998.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>The task force was
comprised of members of the<b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal"></b>medical
community, insurance providers, health educators, lawmakers, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Department
for Public Health, survivors, American Cancer Society and breast cancer support
organizations. Its charge was to determine <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s highest areas of
incidence, diagnostic services, and ability to address breast cancer in the
Commonwealth with regard to the care and availability of medical services to
support women who have been diagnosed with the disease.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
</span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">On-going work on
the issues identified by the Breast Cancer Task Force continue through the
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Cancer Programs at the University of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> and the University of
Louisville.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Mrs. Patton remains an
advisor for this work.<o:p>
</o:p>
</span><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><o:p>
</o:p>
</span></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Also in 1998, she
hosted at the Governors Mansion the first-ever statewide reception for breast
cancer survivors.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>She drew praise
from breast cancer support groups across the state for her efforts to recognize
and celebrate the strength and resiliency of women who are breast cancer
survivors. Again, in May 1999 and May 2000 in honor of Mothers Day, she
opened the Governors Mansion and has hosted several thousand-breast cancer
survivors in a <i style="mso-bidi-font-style:normal">Celebration of Hope.</i>
&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In October 1998
and continuing through 2000, she spearheaded state government employees
participation in Lee National Denim Day, where employees can wear jeans to work
in return for their $5 contribution.<span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">&nbsp; </span>In the last three years, employees have raised over $20,000
to benefit the Susan Komen research foundation.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 1996, she
gained national recognition for enlisting state government employees in the 2.6
million-signature campaign to seek congressional funds to support breast cancer
research. </span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In May 1997, she
led <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> in the Mothers Day Mammogram program working with Rite Aid
Corporation, the Department for Public Health and the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Breast Cancer
Coalition. Mrs. Patton was one of only nine first ladies in the country to
introduce the program in the states. She continues to assist with this statewide
program to provide free or reduced cost mammograms to uninsured or underinsured
women. </span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">She has
participated in the Walk for Her Lifetime and served as the 1998 Honorary Chair
for the walk to support the services of the mobile mammography unit of
Appalachian Regional Healthcare. Events in 2000 forced ARH to discontinue use of
the van and Mrs. Patton again went to work bringing interested partners to the
table to restore mobile mammography services to East Kentucky counties where
mammography facilities are limited.</span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Her interest in
childrens healthcare prompted a new program begun in 1998. Mrs. Patton was
instrumental in the creation of a greeting card that is sent to new parents from
her and the Governor.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Done with the
support of the Department for Public Health Office of Immunization and Hallmark,
the card contains a message inside from the Governor and First Lady reminding
all new parents of the importance of childhood immunizations as key to
childrens early healthcare.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>The
card also provides a record for parents to take to their doctors to record
immunizations.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>The card is
distributed to all new parents whose children are born in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> hospitals.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Mrs. Patton also
serves as the honorary chair for the state government employees March of Dimes
Walk America campaign.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Through her
efforts, again on behalf of the states children, contributions have risen
significantly over the last three years.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In 2000, Mrs.
Patton signed on as co-chair for the Commonwealth Coalition, a program geared to
reduce alcohol and drug abuse among teens.</span><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal"><i style="mso-bidi-font-style:
normal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Other Works of the First Lady</span></i><i style="mso-bidi-font-style:normal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></i></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;mso-pagination:none"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Judi
Patton<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> is an extremely active and visible <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> and is the first <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> to be a member of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Commission on Women.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
</span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;mso-pagination:none"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In
addition to her ongoing work with women and childrens issues, she supports
numerous special projects.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>In the
summer of 1997, the First Lady and Governor joined former President Jimmy
Carter, Rosalyn Carter and First Lady Hillary Clinton along with thousands of
volunteers from the United States and other countries for the Habitat for
Humanity Blitz Build which constructed over 100 homes in East <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> and
Tennessee. It was the largest construction undertaking of Habitat in a one-week
period.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>In 1998, she supported the
First Ladies Habitat Build in Richmond.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>In 1999, she joined Governors spouses nationwide in the National
Governors Association First Ladies Build and served as honorary chair for
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s Habitat for Humanitys First Ladies build in Frankfort.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;mso-pagination:none"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">On
the national level, Mrs. Patton collaborated and teamed with Indiana First Lady
Judy OBannon to do the first joint public service announcement done by the
two first ladies of the neighboring states to promote the value of reading to
children.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Later, Mrs. Patton and
Mrs. OBannon were joined by Ohio First Lady Hope Taft in a tri-state public
service announcement targeted toward parents and reading.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;mso-pagination:none"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">On
a statewide level, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Judi Patton<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> co-chaired the $3 million fundraising drive for
the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> History Museum that opened in 1999.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>She has served as Honorary Membership Chair of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Congress of
Parents and Teachers Association.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>She
also works actively with the development of the Salato Wildlife Project within
the office of Fish and Wildlife and serves as Chair of the Backyard Wildlife
Project.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>In 1998, she officially
opened the <i style="mso-bidi-font-style:normal">Kentuckians Before Boone</i>
exhibit that focuses on <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s first citizens - its Native Americans.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
</span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;mso-pagination:none"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">At
the urging of the First Lady, Governor Patton, in 1996, created the states
first Native American Heritage Commission that is dedicated to the preservation
of the Native American heritage and culture of the Commonwealth.<span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">&nbsp; </span>Because of her Native American background, Mrs. Patton was
appointed chair for the Native American Heritage Commission by the Governor.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Her own Native American ancestry includes her great-great-grandmother on
her fathers side and her great-grandmother on her mothers side who were
both Cherokee.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;mso-pagination:none"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">During
the 1998 legislative session she worked successfully to pass HB 801 that calls
for November to be recognized as the first-ever Native American Month in the
Commonwealth.</span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoBodyText2"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman">Mrs.
Patton also serves as co-chair with country music legend Loretta Lynn for the
building of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Music Country Museum and Hall of Fame.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>The building to be located in Renfro Valley will be completed in 2002.</span><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;mso-pagination:none"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">In
addition, she serves on the boards of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Opera, Thomas Clark
Foundation, and New Opportunity School for Women. For the last four years she
has worked with the Department for Natural Resources in supporting Arbor Day.
And she works with the Department of Transportation Drive Smart Team and its
child passenger safety program.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>She
is also spokesperson for the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Department of Parks get-a-ways for
foster parents and their families.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>She
is a member of the First Presbyterian Church of Pikeville. &nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;mso-pagination:none"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:normal"><i style="mso-bidi-font-style:normal"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Personal
Information</span></i></b><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;mso-pagination:none"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>First
Lady<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Judi Patton<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> and Governor <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Paul Edward Patton<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> have four children:<span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">&nbsp; </span><TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Chris<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Nicki<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Bambi<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jan<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and three very special
grandchildren:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Chase, Jan, Jr. and
Judith Paige. She is a graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Pikeville High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and attended <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Pikeville
College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;mso-pagination:none"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt">Mrs.
Patton is a native of <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Pike County, Kentucky<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>, and one of four daughters born to
the late Roy and Esta Conway.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Her
father was murdered while serving as sheriff of Pike County and her mother
served the remainder of his term.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>After
completing her husbands term and an unsuccessful run for the office, Mrs.
Conway served as a social worker in the mountains of East <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> while rearing
her four daughters:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Anna Ruth,
Colleen, Judi and Nanci Roy.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>The
First Lady of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kentucky<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> credits her mothers lifelong work with women and
children as her inspiration for the work to which she devotes herself today. <o:p>
</o:p>
</span></p>
<b><i>
<table border=0 width="100%">
<tr>
<td width="50%">Official Address:</i><br>
Governor&#146;s Mansion<br>
704 Capitol Avenue<br>
Frankfort, KY 40601<br>
E-Mail: <a href="mailto:jpatton@mail.state.ky.us">jpatton@mail.state.ky.us</a><i><p>&nbsp;</p>
<p></i>&nbsp;</td>
<td width="50%">For More Information, contact:<br>
Kay Harrod<br>
Executive Assistant to the First Lady<br>
Governor&#146;s Office<br>
700 Capital Avenue<br>
Frankfort, KY 40601<br>
Phone: (502) 564-2611<br>
Fax: (502) 564-2517<br>
E-Mail: <a href="mailto:kharrod@mail.state.ky.us">mailto:kharrod@mail.state.ky.us</a><font size=4></font></td>
</tr>
</table>
</b>
<p align=center><a href="http://www.state.ky.us/agencies/gov/juditxt.htm">Return to
First Lady's Home Page</a></p>
</body>
</html>

<head>
<title><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Massachusetts<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jane Swift<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></title>
</head>
<body text="#000000" bgcolor="#FFFFFF" link="#212B74" vlink="#AD7331" alink="#EE0000" background="images/bground.gif">
<table border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=5 width=640>
<tr align=LEFT>
<td valign=top width=155 align=left><br>
<a href="../index.htm"><img src="images/magnet2.gif" alt="NavHeader and Link back to Magnet Home" border=0 width=111 height=106></a><br>
<a href="gov.htm"><img src="images/btmain.gif" alt="Button - Link to Main Page" border=0 width=120 height=36></a><br>
<a href=""></a>
<a href="gov-bio.htm"><img src="images/btgovbio.gif" alt="Button - Link to Governor's Biography" border=0 width=120 height=36></a><br>
<a href="contact.htm"><img src="images/btcntct.gif" alt="Button - Link - How to contact the Governor" border=0 width=120 height=36></a><br>
<a href="intpost.htm"><img src="images/btintrs.gif" alt="Button - Link to Internship Opportunities" border=0 width=120 height=36></a><br>
<a href="funstuff.htm"><img src="images/btkids.gif" alt="Button - Link to Fun Stuff and Kids' Pages" border=0 width=120 height=36></a><br>
<a href="govco.htm"><img src="images/btcncil.gif" alt="Button - Link to Governor's Council" border=0 width=120 height=36></a><br>
<a href="privacypolicy.html"><img alt="Button - Link to the Privacy Policy Governing this Web Site" border=0 height=36 src="images/privpol.gif" width=120></a>
<br>
<a href="mailto:GOffice@state.ma.us"><img src="images/mailbox.gif" alt="Image - Mailbox" border=0 width=120 height=36></a></td>
<td valign=top width=485 align=left><p align=left><img src="images/govbio.jpg" border=0 width=450 height=81></p>
<div align=center><center><table border=0 cellpadding=2 width=480>
<tr>
<td valign=top align=left width=475><img border=0 src="images/OFFICEOF.JPG" hspace=2 vspace=2 align=right width=180 height=252><font face="Times New Roman" size=3>
<p><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jane Swift<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> became the <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Massachusetts<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>April 10, 2001<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> when Governor Paul Cellucci resigned to become the U.S. Ambassador to Canada.  Elected <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1998, she worked as "Co-Governor" with Governor Cellucci to stimulate economic growth, impose fiscal discipline, improve public education and enhance the quality of life for working families in the Commonwealth.</p>
<p>Governor Swift's passionate commitment to public education has dominated her career in public service.  Swift led the Cellucci-Swift Administration's effort to improve the state's public education system through strong accountability and high standards for schools, teachers and students.  As <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, she instituted meaningful remediation programs for struggling students and helped parents access more information regarding their children's schools.</p>
<p>Swift has worked hard to provide tax relief to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Massachusetts<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> families, reducing the income tax cut through a ballot initiative overwhelmingly approved by the voters.  In one of her first official acts as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, she signed the "No-New-Taxes Pledge" and filed legislation to expand the state's Earned Income Tax Credit to help low-income families keep more of their hard-earned paychecks.  Swift has also championed solutions that protect consumer privacy, provide a guaranteed college education for foster children and enable state employees to better balance the demands of work and family.</p>
<p>Swift's career as an elected official began in 1991 at age 25 when she was the youngest woman ever elected to the Massachusetts State Senate.  She quickly became the youngest woman in Senate history to hold a leadership position, rising to the rank of Assistant Minority Leader.</p>
<p><TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Governor William F. Weld<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> appointed Swift as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Director of the Office of Consumer Affairs and Business Regulation<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1997.  Prior to that position, she served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Director of Regional Airport Development<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Massachusetts<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Port Authority<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>.</p>
<p>A graduate of the North Adams Public Schools, Swift earned her bachelor's degree from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Trinity College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1987.  She is a member of the Board of Directors of the Massachusetts Girl Scout Council.  Swift, <TAG name="AGE" value="start"/>36<TAG name="AGE" value="end"/>, is a native of <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>North Adams<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>.  She currently lives with her husband <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Chuck Hunt<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> and their daughters, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Elizabeth<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, age 2, and twin newborns, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Lauren<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Sarah<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, at their family farm in <TAG name="RESCITY" value="start"/>Williamstown<TAG name="RESCITY" value="end"/>.</p>
</font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign=top align=left width=475></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign=top align=left width=475><hr width=420 noshade>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</center></div></td>
</tr>

<td valign=top width=155 align=left></td>
<td valign=top width=485 align=left><font face="Times New Roman" size=1><p align=center></font><font face="Times New Roman" size=2>&#169;1997, 1998, 1999 <strong>Commonwealth
of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Massachusetts<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></strong></font><font face="Times New Roman" size=1></font></td>
