<html><head><title><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Parris N. Glendening<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></title></head>
<body bgcolor="#FCF0BE" link="#0D0674" vlink="#A00017" alink="#06740D">
<h1><a href="/msa/mdmanual/08conoff/html/01gov.html"><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>GOVERNOR OF <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>MARYLAND<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></a></h1>
<hr>
<img align=LEFT hspace=10 src="/msa/mdmanual/08conoff/images/i006013.jpg" alt="[photograph of Governor Parris N. Glendening]">
<b><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>PARRIS N. GLENDENING<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, <i><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> (<TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Democrat<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/>)</i></b>
<ul><ul><li><a href="http://www.gov.state.md.us/gov/speech/2001/html/sos01.html"><i>State of the State</i></a>, 17 January 2001</ul></ul>
<ul>State House<br>
Annapolis, MD 21401<br>
(410) 974-3901<br>
1-800-811-8336 (toll free, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>)<br>
e-mail: <a href="mailto:governor@gov.state.md.us">governor@gov.state.md.us</a><br>
fax: (410) 974-3275<br>
tty: (410) 333-3098<br>
web: <a href="http://www.gov.state.md.us">www.gov.state.md.us</a></ul>
<br clear=left>
<hr>
<TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Parris N. Glendening<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> since <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1995<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>.
<p>
Member, Hyattsville City Council, 1973-74. Member, Prince George's County Council, 1974-82 (chair, 1979-81). County Executive, Prince George's County, 1982-94. Member, Chesapeake Bay Critical Area Commission, 1984-94; Advisory Commission on Federal-State-Local Relations, 1987-94. Board of Visitors, School of Public Affairs, University of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, College Park.
<p>
Chair, Board of Public Works, 1995-. Member, Maryland Environmental Trust, 1995-; Maryland Veterans Home Commission, 1995-; Governor's Work Force Investment Board, 1998-. Member, Appalachian Regional Commission, 1995-; Education Commission of the States, 1995- (Maryland Education Council); Interstate Mining Commission, 1995-; Interstate Oil and Gas Compact Commission, 1995-; Interstate Commission on the Potomac River Basin, 1995-; Southern States Energy Board, 1995-; Susquehanna River Basin Commission, 1995-. Chair, Southern Regional Education Board, 1995-96, 1996-97 (member, 1995-). Chair, Chesapeake Executive Council, 1998- (member, 1995-). Chair, Governor's Year-2000 Readiness Task Force, 1999-2000. Member, State Commission on the Capital City, 1999-. 
<p>
<i>Born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Bronx, New York<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>June 11, 1942<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>. <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Junior College of Broward County<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, Ft. Lauderdale, Florida, <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>A.A.<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>, 1962; <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Florida State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>B.A. (political
science)<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>, 1964, <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>M.A. (political science)<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>, 1965, <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Ph.D. (political science), 1967<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>. <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Associate Professor of Government and Politics<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>University of Maryland<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> College Park. Member, Taxation and Finance Steering Committee (1984-87) and Vice-Chair, Intergovernmental Relations Policy Steering Committee (1987-88) of National Association of Counties. President, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Association of Counties, 1987-88. Trustee Council, YMCA of Metropolitan Washington, 1988-96. Past president, National Council of Elected County Executives. Member, Professional Ethics Committee, American Society for Public Administrators, 1989-90. Board of Trustees, National Forum for Black Public Administrators. Member, Professional Society Ethics Group, American Association for the Advancement of Science. Delegate, Democratic Party National Convention, 1988, 1992, 1996, 2000. Chair, Natural Resources Committee, National Governors' Association, 1998- (member, economic development and commerce committee; transportation task force; technology task force). Member, Southern Governors' Association (executive committee). Chair, National Governors' Association, 2000-01 (vice-chair, 1999-2000). Chair, Democratic Governors' Association, 2000-01. President, Council of State Governments, 2001- (vice president, 2000). Co-author, </i>Controversies of State and Local Political Systems<i>(1972), and </i>Pragmatic Federalism: An Intergovernmental View of American Government<i>(1984), a textbook used in over 400 colleges and universities. Recipient of annual award for distinguished contributions to the practice and study of government, Washington Chapter, American Political Science Association, 1985. Donald T. Stone Award, American Society for Public Administration. Breslau-Goldman Award for dedication to social justice, Jewish Community Council of Greater Washington. Nathan Davis Award for outstanding Governor, American Medical Association, 1996. Friend of Education Award, Maryland State Teachers Association, 1997. Furman Templeton Award, Baltimore Urban League, 1998. Public Official of the Year, Governing Magazine, 2000.</i>
<p>
<hr>
<h4><center><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>PARRIS N. GLENDENING<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></center></h4>
Growing up poverty-stricken in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Florida<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>, in a house without electricity or indoor plumbing, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Parris Glendening<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> could scarcely imagine that years later he would find himself in the State House in Annapolis. Yet, driven by the values of education, hard work, personal responsibility, and a commitment to public service, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Parris N. Glendening<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> overcame humble beginnings to become the 59th <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of the State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>. 
<p>
Early in life, Governor Glendening recognized that education was the door to unlimited opportunities. A scholarship to <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Broward Community College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> started him on  his academic career. Other financial aid later enabled him to attend <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Florida State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, where he received a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor's degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> (1964), a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>master's degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> (1965), and a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Ph.D.<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> (1967), becoming the youngest student in <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>FSU<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> history to receive a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>doctorate in political science and urban administration<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>. Upon graduation, he began a career as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>professor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>University of Maryland<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, College Park, where he taught Government and Politics for 27 years. In 1984, he co-authored <i>Pragmatic Federalism, An Intergovernmental View of American Government</i>, a textbook used in over 400 colleges and universities.
<p>
The Governor's public service began in 1973 as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>City Councilman<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Hyattsville<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. He was elected to the Prince George's County Council in 1974 and twice served as Council Chair. In 1982, he was elected County Executive of Prince George's County, and is the only County Executive in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> history to serve three terms (1982-1994). Under Glendening's leadership, Prince George's County was selected as an <i>All America
County</i>by the National Civic League, and <i>City and State</i>magazine named him the "Most Valuable County Official" in the nation. In <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, he was elected to his first term as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>. In <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, Governor Glendening overwhelmingly won re-election to a second term.
<p>
<b><a href="http://www.gov.state.md.us/gov/1997review/html/educate.html">Governor's Commitment to Education</a></b>. 
Building on his life experiences and recognizing that access to a quality education makes success possible for everyone, Governor Glendening made education his top priority and increased funding for education at every level during his tenure. In his first term, the Governor increased aid to primary and secondary education by more than $600 million. In addition, funds to build and modernize classrooms more than doubled. In his second term, the Governor vowed to take <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> into the Golden Age of School Construction with a commitment to invest more than $1 billion to build and modernize classrooms over the next four years. A total of 13,500 classrooms
will be added, renovated, or modernized during his time in office. To improve both the quality of and access to higher education in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, Governor Glendening unveiled a four-year, $635 million plan to help <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s colleges and universities move toward excellence. Most recently, he worked with the General Assembly to pass the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> HOPE Scholarship Program, guaranteeing access to college for all <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> high school students who work hard, get good grades, and agree to work in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> upon graduation. The Governor's commitment to education was recognized by the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> State Teachers Association, which presented him with the Friend of Education Award in 1997.
<p>
<b><a href="http://www.gov.state.md.us/gov/1997review/html/envagn.html">Governor's Commitment to the Environment</a></b>. Governor Glendening's second great passion is protecting, preserving, and restoring our environment for future generations to enjoy. With his <a href="http://www.op.state.md.us/smartgrowth/index.html">Smart Growth-Anti Sprawl initiative</a>, the Governor has positioned <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> as a national leader in the fight to preserve existing open space, protect natural resources, reinvigorate established communities, and stem the tide of suburban sprawl. The World Wildlife Fund praised Governor Glendening's Smart Growth program as a "Gift to the Earth." The Governor is committed to continuing <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s progress in this area by working in partnership with local government to revise building codes to encourage growth and investment in existing neighborhoods. Governor Glendening has taken his passion for the environment to the national level, serving as Chair of the National Governors' Association Natural Resources Committee. <br>
<p>
<b><a href="http://www.gov.state.md.us/gov/1997review/html/pubsaf.html">Governor's Commitment to Public Safety</a></b>. 
Working with Lt. Governor <a href="/msa/mdmanual/08conoff/html/msa12084.html">Kathleen Kennedy Townsend,</a>Governor Glendening has focused on making <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> neighborhoods and communities safe and secure. With innovative programs such as community policing and HotSpots, and one of the strongest anti-gun violence measures in the nation, the crime rate in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> is decreasing nearly twice as fast as the national average. After successfully defeating the powerful gun lobby, Handgun Control, Inc. recognized the Governor for his work supporting the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Gun Violence Act of 1996. Sarah and James Brady were on hand to make the presentation. The Governor intends to further secure the safety of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s families and children by spearheading an effort to require every handgun sold in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> to have features making it childproof. <br>
<p>
<b><a href="http://www.gov.state.md.us/gov/1997review/html/jobs.html">Governor's Commitment to Job Creation</a></b>. Governor Glendening has worked tirelessly to keep casino gambling out of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>. He recognizes that a strong economy is what creates good-paying, family-supporting jobs for Marylanders. During his tenure, Governor Glendening worked aggressively with
the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> General Assembly to reduce or eliminate 15 separate taxes, including the first reduction in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s personal income tax rate in 30 years. As a result, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> saw its job creation rate rise from 44th in the nation in 1994 to 16th in 1998. Over that same time period, welfare rolls decreased by more than 62%, with 141,420 Marylanders moving from dependency to self-sufficiency. <br>
<p>
<b><a href="http://www.gov.state.md.us/gov/1997review/html/hlthagn.html">Governor's Commitment to Public Health</a></b>. 
The health of Marylanders has been a critical issue for Governor Glendening. During his time in office, the Governor has worked with the Legislature to pass both a comprehensive Patients' Bill of Rights and an innovative plan that provides access to health care for pregnant women and children in working families. In addition, the Governor has been a leading anti-tobacco advocate, working with the General Assembly to raise cigarette taxes to reduce teen smoking. Most recently, he unveiled a plan to use <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s share of the national tobacco settlement to make the State a leader in anti-smoking programs and anti-cancer research. In 1996, Governor Glendening was honored by the American Medical Association with the Nathan Davis Award for his commitment to improve public health in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.<br>
<p>
<b><a href="http://www.gov.state.md.us/gov/1997review/html/minority.html">Governor's Commitment to an Inclusive Society</a></b>. Throughout his career in public service, Governor Glendening has never forgotten his roots. He continues to bring the values of equality, opportunity, and inclusion to the decision-making table. His judicial appointments, and selection of cabinet secretaries and senior staff members reflects this deep and abiding commitment to the value of diversity. In 1998, Governor Glendening received the Furman Templeton Award from the Baltimore Urban League for his solid record of appointing African Americans, women, Hispanics, and other minorities to the judiciary and upper levels of State government. In Governor Glendening's continuing fight for fairness and inclusion, he also received the Breslau-Goldman Award from the Jewish Community Council of Greater Washington for his dedication to social justice. 
<p>
<hr>

Association</a>

<p>

<a href="/msa/mdmanual/01glance/html/mdglance.html"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> at a Glance</a></h4>

<h3><a href="/msa/mdmanual/html/mmtoc.html"><i><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Manual On-Line</i></a></h3>

<title><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Kathleen Kennedy Townsend<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Lt. Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> - Biography</title>
</head>

<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#000000"><a href="/gov/homepage/html/ltgov.html"><b><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font color="#FFFFFF"><font size=-1>Lt.
Governor Homepage</font></font></font></b></a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#000000"><a href="/gov/homepage/html/homepage.html"><b><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font color="#FFFFFF"><font size=-1>Governor
Glendening</font></font></font></b></a></td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
<td></td>
<td width=420><img align=left src="../images/msa12084b.jpg" alt="[photograph of Lt. Governor Townsend]" height=190 hspace=10>
<br><b><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=+1><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Lt. Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/></font></font></b>
<br><b><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=+1><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Kathleen Kennedy Townsend<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></font></font></b>
<br><b><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font size=+1>Biography</font></font></b>
<br>&nbsp;
<br>&nbsp;
<br>&nbsp;
<br>&nbsp;
<br>&nbsp;
<br>&nbsp;
<br>
<br>
<center>
<p>
<hr noshade width=350></center>
<p>
<TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lt. Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Kathleen Kennedy Townsend<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>'s core mission is to make <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s communities safer, stronger, and more prosperous with innovative, effective answers to the State's most critical challenges.  She has sought to draw citizens into the search for solutions and get results. 
<p>
As <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s crime czar, the designer of a nationwide model child and family services strategy, a champion for service and volunteerism, and the guiding force behind the State's economic development strategy, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Kathleen Kennedy Townsend<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> has sought to engage the best energies of citizens, cut through ideological debates and focus on results.  Vice President Al Gore has said that "Kathleen has done more for her state than most Governors."
<p>
In order to bring Marylanders into our fight against crime, Lt. Governor Townsend began the first statewide academy to teach community policing techniques designed to build trust between citizens and law enforcement.  Her HotSpot Communities Initiative joins neighborhood groups with police, prosecutors, and government agencies to design and implement a comprehensive enforcement and prevention strategy in targeted high-crime neighborhoods. Hailed as a national model by Attorney General Janet Reno, HotSpots has significantly reduced crime and restored a sense of peace and security to communities throughout the State.
<p>
Lt. Governor Townsend has used the same results-oriented strategy to maximize the impact of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s other anti-crime efforts.  Moving beyond the fruitless debate between prevention and punishment, her pioneering Break the Cycle anti-drug initiative combines drug testing, sanctions, and treatment to motivate addicted offenders to stay drug- and crime-free.  
<p>
Recognizing that strong, healthy communities grow from strong, healthy families, Lt. Governor Townsend has redesigned <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s children and family services to enable local communities to work together to meet the specific needs of families.  Lt. Governor Townsend also began one of the first statewide character education initiatives in the country, to reinforce parents' efforts to teach their children our shared values and ideals: courage, integrity, responsibility and respect. 
<p>
As Chair of the Cabinet Council on Business and Economic Development, Lt. Governor Townsend leads <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s economic development initiatives.  Along with Governor Glendening, she has worked to reduce or eliminate 15 separate taxes, including the first reduction of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s personal income tax rate in 30 years.  Under the leadership of the Glendening-Townsend Administration, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s welfare rolls shrunk by more than 62%, and <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s job creation rate jumped from 44th in the nation in 1994 to 16th in the nation last year. 
<p>
Before becoming Lt. Governor, Mrs. Townsend served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Deputy Assistant Attorney General<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>U.S. Department of Justice<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>; chaired the Robert F. Kennedy
Memorial Foundation; and founded the Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights Award. As the founder and executive director of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Student Service Alliance, she
made <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> the first State in the country to include a high school community service requirement. Mrs. Townsend also has taught at the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>University of Pennsylvania<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>,
the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>University of Maryland-Baltimore County (UMBC)<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, and at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Essex and Dundalk Community Colleges<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. Currently, she serves on the board of the John F. Kennedy
Library Foundation.  
<p>
The eldest child of Robert and Ethel Kennedy, Lt. Governor Townsend lives in <TAG name="RESCITY" value="start"/>Baltimore County<TAG name="RESCITY" value="end"/> with her husband, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>David<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, a professor at St. John's College in Annapolis.  They have four daughters, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Meaghan<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Maeve<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Kate<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Kerry<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.
<p>
<a href="initiatives.html">Signature Initiatives of Lt. Governor</a>
<p>
<hr noshade width=350>
<p><img src="../../images/redstar.gif" alt="red star" border=0>&nbsp;<font size=-1><a href="/gov/homepage/html/homepage.html">Governor</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
<img src="../../images/redstar.gif" alt="red star" border=0>&nbsp;<a href="/gov/homepage/html/ltgov.html">Lt.
Governor</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<img src="../../images/redstar.gif" alt="red star" border=0>&nbsp;<a href="http://www.mec.state.md.us"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
Electronic Capital</a></font>

State Archives</font></i></td>

<html>
<head>
<title><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Frances Hughes Glendening<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></title></head>
<body text="#000000" link="#0000ff" vlink="#551a8b" alink="#ff0000" bgcolor="#ffffff">
<table width="100%">
<tr><td><h2><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></h2>
<p><img src="/gov/homepage/images/i000517a.gif" alt="[photograph of Frances Hughes Glendening]"></p>
<h3><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Frances Hughes Glendening<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></h3>
<br>
</td>
<td>
<p align=CENTER><strong>A
Celebration of the Arts in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></strong><br>
<center><i>An Initiative of the First Lady</i>
<p><strong>presents</strong></center></p>
<p>
<center><strong><font size=-1 color="#ff0000">The Sellars Collection: Art by American Women</font><br>
<font size=-1>Government House, Annapolis
<br>March 2 - July 19</font><br>
<br>Contact Government House: 410-974-3531<br>
Media contact: Susan Casey 410-974-2316</font>
</td></tr></table>
<p><hr noshade>
<center><b><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>FRANCES HUGHES GLENDENING<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></b></center>
<p>
In her professional career, personal life and community service activities, <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> First Lady<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Frances Hughes Glendening<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> exemplifies contemporary womanhood.  As a mother, public administrator, and community volunteer, Mrs. Glendening strives to maintain a healthy balance in managing the multiple priorities of her life.
<p>
A native Marylander, she was raised in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Cumberland<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> and is a long-time resident of Prince George's County.  Mrs. Glendening's personal experiences have guided her to participate in select community activities and projects which are concentrated around hospice, mental health and suicide prevention, preventing violence among youth, women's issues and history, and the arts.
<p>
Mrs. Glendening shares her time and talents with many community organizations.  For example, she has taken an active leadership role in Hospice of Prince George's County, where she served on the board of directors from 1985-1998.  As chair of the planning committee, she spearheaded many changes over an eight-year period, to provide increasing services in care of terminally-ill patients and their families.  In addition, annually, she co-chairs and participates in the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> State annual "Race for the Cure," breast-cancer awareness run.  She is currently involved in a "Habitat for Humanity" house-building project in Anne Arundel County.
<p>
Since 1990, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s first lady also has served as a board member and resource development committee co-chair for the Prince George's Suicide Prevention Center and Hotline.  Additionally, she chairs the state-wide "Caring For Every Child's Mental Health" campaign.  In 1999, Mrs. Glendening appeared with Rosalynn Carter, former national first lady and mental health advocate and writer.
<p>.
Frances Glendening's commitment to career women's advancement always has been evident.  She has been an active member and officer of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Federation of Business and Professional Women's (BPW) Organizations, College Park Chapter, since 1976.  She also served as a BPW committee co-chair, producing two national award-winning cable TV programs, "Women's Changing Roles: Finding a Balance" and "Family Violence: A Conspiracy of Silence."
<p>
Mrs. Glendening regularly speaks on the subject of domestic violence and regularly visits women's shelters.  She currently is involved in a women-managed  "Habitat for Humanity" house-building project in Anne Arundel County.
<p>
In 1993, Mrs. Glendening spearheaded a major project which produced a book hailing the achievements of Prince George's County women throughout history. She currently is leading a similar statewide book project, Women of Achievement in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> History.
<p>
As her initial project, the first lady coordinated and assembled the premier collection of her predecessors' portraits for display at the governor's official residence, Government House. Titled, <a href="http://mdsa.net/msa/speccol/sc4800/sc4806/exhibit/html/online/home.html">"Portraits of First Ladies & Official Hostesses of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>,"</a>the exhibit was a tribute to the women who have made important contributions to the history of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.  In collaboration with <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> State Archives, Mrs. Glendening is working on a companion book to the collection, recounting the lives of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s First Ladies and Official Hostesses.  She also is the founding vice-president of the <a href="http://www.firstladies.org/">National First Ladies' Library,</a>which was dedicated in Canton, Ohio, in 1998.  She serves as that organization's co-chair for "First Ladies of the States Committee."
<p>
Since 1996, Mrs. Glendening has been touring the state with her arts advocacy
initiative, "A Celebration of the Arts in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>," publicly recognizing and promoting <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> artists, arts organizations, and arts education.  She appears at and hosts numerous events ranging from visual and performing art exhibitions to literary and art education conferences.  For example, under her direction, "A Celebration of Older Marylanders" art exhibit was on display throughout May 1998, at the State House.  Each year, Black History Month in February and Women's History Month in March are each celebrated with an art exhibit at Government House.  Similarly, Youth Art Month is celebrated each year.  And, each holiday season, students throughout <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> hand-
craft ornaments to decorate Government House.
<p>
Mrs. Glendening regularly hosts events for citizens involved in the literary, visual or performance arts.  And, she instituted a juried visual art series of exhibits at Government House showcasing <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Contemporary Artists.  In addition, she is honorary chair of the Governor's Advisory Committee on Careers in the Arts for People with Disabilities, the first of its kind in the nation.
<p>
In her professional life, Mrs. Glendening serves as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>chief legal and policy advisor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at the  <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Federal Election Commission (FEC)<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, where her work twice has taken her to the former Soviet Union to observe election processes.  She previously held positions at the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Federal Communications Commission<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Public Technology, Inc.<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> and the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Prince George's County Office of Personnel<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, where she was responsible for monitoring Comprehensive Employment and Training Act (CETA) Program.
<p>
Mrs. Glendening holds a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>B.A. in Government and Politics, and English<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>; and a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Master's degree in Public Administration and American Government<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>  all from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Maryland<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.  In 1986, she earned her <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Juris Doctorate<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Catholic University School of Law<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, where she was associate editor of the Law Review.
<p>
The First Lady is married to <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Parris N. Glendening<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, Maryland's 59th Governor.  Their son, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Raymond<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, is a college senior.  The First Lady's website is www.gov.state.md.us.
<p>
AWARDS
<br>
<ul>

2000 National Governors Association, Spouses' Leadership Committee Chair <br>
1999-2000 National First Ladies' Library Vice President <br>
1999 National Mental Health Association President's Award <br>
1999 Maryland Hall for the Creative Arts, First Lady of the Arts Award <br>
1999 The National Conference for Community and Justice, The Brotherhood/Sisterhood Award <br>
1999 The Daily Record,  <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s Top 100 Women <br>

1998 <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maryland<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Mental Health Association, Distinguished Service Award <br>

<td colspan=4><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#003366' size='-1' style='font-weight:bold'>Governor's Quick Links</font></td>
</tr>
<tr>

<img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=1 height=30>

</form></td>
<td bgcolor='#FFFFFF'><img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=10 height=400></td>

<td><img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=420 height=11><br>

<table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0>
<tr valign=top>
<td width=420 height=10 align=right colspan=3>
<a href='/gov/1,1431,7-103----,00.html'><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-1'>&lt; Back to Governor's Page</font></a></td></tr>
<tr valign=top>
<td width=420 height=10 align=left colspan=3>


<table width=420 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0>
<tr>
<td align=left><img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=80 height=10></td>
<td align=left><img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=340 height=10></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan=2>
<hr><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#003366' size='+1' style='font-weight:bold'>Biography</font><hr>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan=2>
<font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color=BLACK><p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica"><i>"<TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Gov<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/>. <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>John Engler<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> has had more impact on the lives of Michiganians over the past decade than any other single person, and his deep imprint will be evident well into the new century."</i></p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica" align=right>The Detroit News, April 9, 2001</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica" align=right>&nbsp;</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">First elected in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1990<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> as <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s 46<sup>th</sup> <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>John Engler<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is now America's most senior governor. Engler was elected chairman of the National Governors Association in August 2001.</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">&nbsp;</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">A common sense Midwestern conservative who believes strongly that every child should have the chance to succeed, Engler has made improving education <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s number one priority. With boldness and vision for the future, Governor Engler also cut taxes, reformed welfare, right-sized government and implemented the biggest road repair and rebuilding plan in state history. Under his watch, the quality of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s water, land and air resources has steadily improved.</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">&nbsp;</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">In 1994, Engler led the fight to enact Proposal A - a ballot proposal overwhelmingly approved by voters to fund schools fairly and cut property taxes. Now, all children have a foundation grant that follows them to the public schools of their choice, including more than 180 charter public schools. With funding issues resolved, high standards and rigorous assessments have helped improve student performance. To encourage academic achievement, Governor Engler created the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Merit Award - a $2,500 scholarship for college or training - that is awarded to high school students who pass their proficiency tests in reading, writing, science and math.</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">&nbsp;</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">Governor Engler has signed 31 tax cuts into law, saving taxpayers more than $25 billion. The state inheritance tax and capital gains taxes have been eliminated. Personal exemptions for children, seniors and the disabled have been increased. The personal income tax rate is being reduced to 3.9 percent - the lowest level in a quarter century - and <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s main tax on business is being phased out completely.</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">&nbsp;</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">Engler's economic policies have helped to create more than 900,000 jobs in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, cutting the state's unemployment rate from over 9 percent the year he took office to 3.4 percent in 2000 - the lowest annual level ever recorded. For an unprecedented four years in a row, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> has won the prestigious Governor's Cup for the most new factories and expansion projects in the nation. As part of the nation's most forward-looking economic development strategy, $1 billion is being invested in a "Life Sciences Corridor" from Ann Arbor to Grand Rapids, and a high-tech cybercourt to hear business disputes is also in the works.</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">&nbsp;</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">Governor Engler has strengthened <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s role as guardian of the Great Lakes, fought water diversions and invested more in clean water than any governor. Thanks to reforms of environmental laws, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> leads the nation in reclaiming contaminated brownfield sites while preserving green space and farmland.</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">&nbsp;</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">Other highlights of the Engler administration include:</p>
<ul style="FILTER: ; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0in; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: ">
<li style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">passing the $675 million Clean <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Initiative to reduce pollution, fix up state parks, improve water quality and clean up contaminated sites;</li>
<li style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">trimming state government personnel by more than 20 percent (excluding state troopers, prison guards and other public safety workers);</li>
<li style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">transforming the $1.8 billion deficit he inherited to a $1.3 billion surplus;</li>
<li style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">restoring <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s AAA credit rating;</li>
<li style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">helping nearly 300,000 families achieve independence from cash welfare and reducing welfare rolls by nearly 70 percent;</li>
<li style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">restructuring the regulation of energy and telecommunications industries to increase consumer choice and reduce rates;</li>
<li style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">investing a record-high $1.54 billion to fix our roads in 2001 alone - more than four times the amount spent in 1990;</li>
<li style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">reducing violent crime by more than 25 percent;</li>
<li style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">serving an additional 45,000 patients annually with mental health services;</li>
<li style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">giving Detroit's mayor authority to appoint the local school board and speed up the pace of reform;</li>
<li style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">increasing K-12 education spending by 84 percent; and,</li>
<li style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">dramatically improving student reading and math test scores.</li>
</ul>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">&nbsp;</p>
<p style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FILTER: ; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-FAMILY: Arial, Helvetica">Engler, <TAG name="AGE" value="start"/>52<TAG name="AGE" value="end"/>, is a graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Michigan State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degree in agricultural economics<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> and earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Thomas M. Cooley Law School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. He was recently elected to the Board of Trustees of the Gerald R. Ford Foundation. <a target=_blank href="http://www.michigan.gov/firstlady"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s First Lady, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Michelle Engler<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/></a>, is also an attorney. They are parents of six-year-old triplet daughters - <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Margaret<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Hannah<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Madeleine<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.</p>
</font>
<br>
</td>
</tr>
</table></td></tr></table><br><a href='#_TopOfPage'><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#336699' size='-2'>Top of Page</font></a>

</td>
<td><img border=0 src='/images/search_divider_81_7.gif' alt='Spacer' width=10 height=33></td>
</tr><tr valign=top>

<table width=740 border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 bgcolor='#FFFFFF'>
<a name='_TopOfPage'></a>
<tr valign=top>

<td colspan=5>
<table width=740 height=105 border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 background='/images/governor_header_85_7.jpg'>
<tr><td valign=top align=left>
<center><img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=1 height=8></center>
<img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=10 height=1>
<a href='/emi/1,1303,7-----,00.html'><img border=0 src='/images/michigan_gov_logo_522_7.gif' alt='Logo for Michigan.gov'></a>
<img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=20 height=1>
<a href='/emi/1,1303,7-----,00.html'><img border=0 src='/images/michigan_gov_seal_521_7.gif' alt='The Coat of Arms of Michigan'></a>
</td></tr>
</table>
</td></tr>
<tr valign=top bgcolor='#C0C0C0'>

<tr valign=top>
<td width=420 height=10 align=left colspan=3>


<table width=420 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0>
<tr>
<td align=left><img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=80 height=10></td>
<td align=left><img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=340 height=10></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan=2>
<hr><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#003366' size='+1' style='font-weight:bold'>Biography</font><hr>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan=2>
<font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color=BLACK>For almost 20 years <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lt. Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Dick Posthumus<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> has been a leader in lowering taxes for <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> families, improving our schools and providing better educational opportunities for our children, and making <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> a better place to start a business and create jobs.  His efforts to reform welfare have improved the lives of thousands, and he has worked tirelessly to strengthen our families and make our environment cleaner for future generations.<br>
<br>Dick&#39;s values of hard work, faith, family and service were shaped growing up on his family&#39;s farm in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/><TAG name="RESCITY" value="start"/>Southeastern Kent County<TAG name="RESCITY" value="end"/><TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>, where still today, he and his wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Pam<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, raise three daughters and a son.  In 1982, Dick answered the call of public service, and, in a come from behind upset campaign, was elected to the State Senate.  He has won every election since. <br>
<br>Dick&#39;s ability to bring people together and take on the tough issues earned him the respect of his colleagues and the trust of his constituents.  He became <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#39;s longest serving Senate Majority Leader in history, and was elected as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>. <br>
<br>His 18 year career in politics has been marked by success after success. <br>
<br>He sponsored the historic Proposal A that slashed property taxes for homeowners and improved funding for our schools.  His steady leadership also helped pass 31 more tax cuts &#45;&#45; tax cuts that put more money back into the pockets of taxpayers and brought more jobs to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> than at any other time in our history. <br>
<br>His commitment to our public schools can be seen in his frequent visits to classrooms throughout the state distributing refurbished computers to provide students more access to technology or encouraging our children to enjoy the wonder and importance of reading in their daily lives. <br>
<br>His initiatives to improve access to college and technical training for high school graduates are providing them more opportunities to afford a college education and get better paying jobs when they enter the work place. <br>
<br>Because of the efforts of Lt. Governor Posthumus, today thousands of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> families are enrolling in the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Education Savings Program making it possible for their children to attend college or a technical school, and an innovative scholarship program created by the Lt. Governor is helping more low&#45;income students get the money they need to earn a valuable associate degree anywhere in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>. <br>
<br>As a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>farmer<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Dick Posthumus<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> knows a clean and healthy environment is vital to our livelihoods.  That&#39;s why as a private citizen he supported the original bottle bill that has cleaned up our roadways and parks.  It&#39;s why he opposes any diversion of water from the Great Lakes, and why he believes <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#39;s number one environmental challenge in the decade ahead is the protection of our water supply through the rebuilding of the state&#39;s sewer infrastructure. <br>
<br>And as a husband and father, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Dick Posthumus<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> has taken a leadership role in identifying ways to end the tragic abuse of women and children in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> today.  In the winter and spring of 2001, Lt. Governor Posthumus chaired a task force committed to finding ways to eliminate all homicides resulting from acts of domestic violence.  The findings and recommendations of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Domestic Violence Homicide Prevention Task Force make&#45;up the next generation of laws and safeguards to keep the more vulnerable in our society safe from harm and abuse.  As a result of this and a lifetime commitment to children, the Child Abuse and Neglect Council of Oakland County recently awarded the Lt. Governor with its President&#39;s Award. <br>
<br>Every day his vision, courage, and quiet, inclusive leadership is making a difference for <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>. <br>
<br>Whether it&#39;s been in improving education or protecting the environment, reducing taxes or reforming welfare, creating jobs or strengthening our families, few leaders in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> history have done more to improve the lives of our citizens that <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lt. Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Dick Posthumus<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>. <br>
<br></br>
<b><font style="font-weight: bold" face="arial, helvetica, sans-serif" color="#003366" size="+1">Family of the Lieutenant Governor</font></b><hr>
<center><img src="/images/lt_gov_fam_782_7.jpg" width=300 height=175></center>
Dick and <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Pam Posthumus<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> have been married for nearly <TAG name="YRSMARR" value="start"/>30 years<TAG name="YRSMARR" value="end"/> and have four wonderful children: <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Krista<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Lisa<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Heather<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Bryan<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, along with their newest family member, Krista&#39;s husband, Rex.
<br>
<br>
<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Pam Posthumus<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> is an active community leader in Lowell, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> where she serves on the American Legion Auxiliary, Athletic Boosters, and as a 4&#45;H leader.  Her commitment to children and community, however, extends beyond her own as she serves as chairperson for the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Children&#39;s Trust Fund, an agency which raises and distributes funds for child abuse and neglect prevention programs throughout <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.
<br>
<br>
<TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Krista<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, a 1999 graduate of Michigan State University and wife to Rex Beech &#45; a native of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#39;s Upper Peninsula &#45; lives and works in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> as a public school teacher.   The Posthumus&#39; second&#45;eldest daughter, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Lisa<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, graduated from Michigan State University in May 2001, just three weeks before her younger sister, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Heather<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, graduated from Lowell High School.  The Posthumus&#39; son, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Bryan<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, is a junior at Lowell High School and is an avid hockey and football player.
</font>
<br>
</td>
</tr>
</table></td></tr></table><br><a href='#_TopOfPage'><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#336699' size='-2'>Top of Page</font></a>

</td>
<td><img border=0 src='/images/search_divider_81_7.gif' alt='Spacer' width=10 height=33></td>
</tr><tr valign=top>

<td colspan=5 align=center><br><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/emi/1,1303,7-----,00.html'>Michigan.gov Home</a></font><font size='-2'>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-104----,00.html'>Home</a></font><font size='-2'>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-104----A,00.html' alt='State Departments'>State Departments</a></font><font size='-2'>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-104----C,00.html' alt='Contact Michigan'>Contact <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></a></font><font size='-2'>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-104----F,00.html' alt=FAQ>FAQ</a></font><br><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-104----PP,00.html' alt='Privacy Policy'>Privacy Policy</a></font><font size='-2'>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-104----LP,00.html' alt='Link Policy'>Link Policy</a></font><font size='-2'>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-104----AP,00.html' alt='Accessibility Policy'>Accessibility Policy</a></font><font size='-2'>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-104----SP,00.html' alt='Security Policy'>Security Policy</a></font><br><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'>Copyright &copy; 2001 State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></font><br><br></td></tr>

<td width=150 bgcolor='#003664'>

<tr valign=top bgcolor='#FFFFFF'>
<td><img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=1 height=1></td>

<td><img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=150 height=30><br>
</td></tr></table>
<img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=1 height=30>

</form></td>
<td bgcolor='#FFFFFF'><img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=10 height=400></td>

<td><img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=420 height=11><br>

<table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0>
<tr valign=top>
<td width=420 height=10 align=right colspan=3>
<a href='/firstlady/1,1431,7-105----,00.html'><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-1'>&lt; Back to First Lady's Page</font></a></td></tr>
<tr valign=top>
<td width=420 height=10 align=left colspan=3>


<table width=420 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0>
<tr>
<td align=left><img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=80 height=10></td>
<td align=left><img border=0 src='/images/0_99_7.gif' alt='' width=340 height=10></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan=2>
<hr><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#003366' size='+1' style='font-weight:bold'>Biography</font><hr>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan=2>
<font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color=BLACK><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Michelle Engler<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, married to Governor <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>John Engler<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, is the first <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>lawyer<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> to serve as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#39;s First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>. A native Texan, she is a member of the <a href="http://www.michbar.org/"><font color="#336699"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></font></a>and <a href="http://www.texasbar.com/"><font color="#336699">Texas State Bar Associations</font></a>.
<br>
<br>
As <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, she served for nine years as the founding chair of the <a href="http://www.state.mi.us/career/mcsc"><font color="#336699"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Community Service Commission</font></a>, which encourages all state citizens, especially young people, to make a commitment to community service. She continues to serve as a member of the commission. In 1997, Michelle was appointed by retired U.S. Army General Colin Powell to serve on the board of <a href="http://www.americaspromise.org/"><font color="#336699">America&#39;s Promise &#45; The Alliance for Youth</font></a>. Reappointed in 1998, she continues to help sustain the mission launched at the <a href="http://www.whitehouse.gov/WH/New/Summit"><font color="#336699">Presidents&#39; Summit for America&#39;s Future</font></a>to encourage people to give back to their communities. Michelle also is a member of the board of directors of the <a href="http://www.pointsoflight.org/"><font color="#336699">Points of Light Foundation</font></a>and the <a href="http://www.mna.msu.edu/"><font color="#336699"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Nonprofit Association</font></a>.
<br>
<br>
Recently appointed to the newly formed <a href="http://www.servicelearningcommission.org/"><font color="#336699">National Commission on Service&#45;Learning</font></a>, Michelle works with other Commission members to increase the prevalence of service&#45;learning education programs which combine K&#45;12 curriculum with community service.
<br>
<br>
She also works to promote the <a href="http://www.fbcmich.org/mhg.htm"><font color="#336699"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Harvest Gathering</font></a>, a collaborative effort of the <a href="http://www.mda.state.mi.us/"><font color="#336699"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Department of Agriculture</font></a>and the private sector to support the <a href="http://www.fbcmich.org/"><font color="#336699"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Food Bank Council</font></a>.
<br>
<br>
Michelle received the <a href="http://www.karmanos.org/"><font color="#336699">Karmanos Cancer Institute</font></a>&#39;s Award for Leadership for her work in promoting breast cancer awareness. She has received <a href="http://www.northwood.edu/"><font color="#336699">Northwood University</font></a>&#39;s <a href="http://www.northwood.edu/dw/1993/engler.html"><font color="#336699">Distinguished Women&#39;s Award</font></a>, presented to women of "outstanding leadership and achievement" from across the nation. She is also the recipient of an <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>honorary degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <a href="http://www.alma.edu/"><font color="#336699"><TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Alma College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/></font></a>, <a href="http://www.wayne.edu/"><font color="#336699"><TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Wayne State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/></font></a>and <a href="http://www.nmu.edu/"><font color="#336699"><TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Northern Michigan University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/></font></a>.
<br>
<br>
An active supporter of the <a href="http://www.salvationarmy.org/"><font color="#336699">Salvation Army</font></a>, she was honored by the Detroit Chapter with the Army&#39;s Other Award, and has received the prestigious William Booth Award from the <a href="http://www.tsa-wmni.org/grandrapids"><font color="#336699">Grand Rapids Chapter</font></a>.
<br>
<br>
Michelle received her <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor&#39;s degree in government<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> at the <a href="http://www.utexas.edu/"><font color="#336699"><TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Texas<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/></font></a>and is a graduate of the <a href="http://www.utexas.edu/law"><font color="#336699"><TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Texas Law School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/></font></a>. Prior to her marriage, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Michelle DeMunbrun<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>partner<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in the Texas law firm of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Nathan, Wood and Sommers<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, where she specialized in bankruptcy law and commercial litigation. She is on leave from the Grand Rapids law firm of <a href="http://www.vrsh.com/"><font color="#336699">Varnum, Riddering, Schmidt and Howlett</font></a>, to raise her triplet daughters, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Margaret Rose<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Hannah Michelle<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Madeleine Jenny<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, who were born on November 13, 1994. 
<br></font>
<br>
</td>
</tr>
</table></td></tr></table><br><a href='#_TopOfPage'><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#336699' size='-2'>Top of Page</font></a>

</td>
<td><img border=0 src='/images/search_divider_81_7.gif' alt='Spacer' width=10 height=33></td>
</tr><tr valign=top>

<td colspan=5 align=center><br><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/emi/1,1303,7-----,00.html'>Michigan.gov Home</a></font><font size='-2'>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-105----,00.html'>Home</a></font><font size='-2'>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-105----A,00.html' alt='State Departments'>State Departments</a></font><font size='-2'>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-105----C,00.html' alt='Contact Michigan'>Contact <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></a></font><font size='-2'>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-105----F,00.html' alt=FAQ>FAQ</a></font><br><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-105----PP,00.html' alt='Privacy Policy'>Privacy Policy</a></font><font size='-2'>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-105----LP,00.html' alt='Link Policy'>Link Policy</a></font><font size='-2'>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-105----AP,00.html' alt='Accessibility Policy'>Accessibility Policy</a></font><font size='-2'>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'><a href='/gov/1,1431,7-105----SP,00.html' alt='Security Policy'>Security Policy</a></font><br><font face='arial, helvetica, sans-serif' color='#000000' size='-2'>Copyright &copy; 2001 State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Michigan<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></font><br><br></td></tr>

<title>Bio &amp; Media Kit</title>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" link="#0000FF" vlink="#800080" text="#000000" topmargin=0 leftmargin=0 marginwidth=0 marginheight=0>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=660>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=660 height=145 align=left valign=top><img id="Picture39" height=145 width=660 src="./Banner9.jpg" border=0 alt="The official site of Minnesota Governor Jesse Ventura"></td>
</tr>
</table><table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0 width=660>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=129>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=4 height=24><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=4 height=1 border=0></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td height=395></td>
<td width=125>
<table id="VerticalNavigationBar1" border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=125>
<tr valign=top align=left>

<tr valign=top align=left>

</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=125 height=52><a href="./press_office.html"><img id="NavigationButton5" height=52 width=125 src="./Press_Office_Button_125.jpg" border=0 alt=" Press Office "></a></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=125 height=49><a href="./the_administration.html"><img id="NavigationButton6" height=49 width=125 src="./The_Administration_Button_125_a.jpg" border=0 alt=" The Administration "></a></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=125 height=49><a href="./lt._governor.html"><img id="NavigationButton7" height=49 width=125 src="./Lt._Governor_Button_125_a.jpg" border=0 alt=" Lt. Governor "></a></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=125 height=49><a href="./first_lady.html"><img id="NavigationButton8" height=49 width=125 src="./First_Lady_Button_125_a.jpg" border=0 alt=" First Lady "></a></td>
</tr>
</table></td>
</tr>
</table></td>
<td>
<table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0 width=506>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=107>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=27 height=40><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=27 height=1 border=0></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td height=107></td>
<td width=80 align=left valign=top><img id="Picture25" height=107 width=80 src="./closeup_of_Gov_speaking_for_bio_site.jpg" border=0 alt="This is a photo of me giving a speech"></td>
</tr>
</table></td>
<td>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=399>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=7 height=5><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=7 height=1 border=0></td>
<td width=90><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=90 height=1 border=0></td>
<td></td>
<td width=163><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=163 height=1 border=0></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td colspan=2 height=33></td>
<td width=139 align=left valign=top><img id="Picture24" height=33 width=139 src="./Biography_word.jpg" border=0 alt="Biography page"></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td colspan=4 height=10></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td></td>
<td width=392 colspan=3>
<p><font color="#000000" size="+1" face="Times New Roman,Times,Times NewRoman">I was elected the 38th <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Minnesota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 3, 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, the first-ever <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Reform<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> Party candidate to win statewide office.&nbsp; I defeated Attorney General Hubert H. (Skip) Humphrey III and St. Paul Mayor Norm Coleman in a victory nobody predicted.</font></td>
</tr>
</table></td>
</tr>
</table>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=509>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=26 height=1><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=26 height=1 border=0></td>
<td width=483><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=483 height=1 border=0></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td></td>
<td width=483>
<p><font color="#000000" size="+1" face="Times New Roman,Times,Times NewRoman">With my running mate Mae Schunk, an educator of 37 years, the Ventura-Schunk ticket received the support of thousands of new voters across the state and sparked a renewed interest in making government work better.&nbsp; And we did it all while spending less than $400,000.</font><font color="#000080" size="+1" face="Arial,Helvetica,Univers,Zurich BT"></p>
<p></font><font color="#000000" size="+1" face="Times New Roman,Times,Times NewRoman">I was born <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>James Janos<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>July 15, 1951<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/> to Sgt. George Janos, a steamfitter for the City of Minneapolis, and First Lt. Bernice Janos, a nurse anesthetist.&nbsp; I grew up in the <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>south Minneapolis Longfellow neighborhood<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>, attended <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Cooper Elementary School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Sanford Junior High<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Roosevelt Senior High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1969.</p>
<p>Immediately after high school, I joined the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Navy<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> and was trained as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>SEAL<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> (Sea, Air, Land). I served in the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Navy<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> for six years.</p>
<p>After my honorable discharge from the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Navy<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in 1973, I went to <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>North Hennepin Community College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> on the GI bill.</p>
<p>For 11 years, I was a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>professional wrestler<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.&nbsp; In 1984, I retired from wrestling and became an <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>actor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, appearing in several films including <i>Predator </i>with Arnold Schwarzenegger. </p>
<p>In 1990, the people who run Brooklyn Park, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Minnesota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> were talking about destroying some important wetland, so I decided to run for <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>mayor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of the state's sixth largest city.&nbsp; I won, and served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>mayor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> until 1995, with crime reduction being one of my major issues.</p>
<p>After that, I became a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>radio talk show host<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>KSTP-AM<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> and <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>KFAN-AM<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in the Twin Cities</p>
<p>In 1998 while doing my radio show, I met with Dean Barkley, an independent maverick, and decided to run for <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> as a member of the <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Reform<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> Party.</p>
<p>Lo and behold I won.</p>
<p>In February 2000, I disassociated myself from the national Reform Party and joined the <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Independence<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> Party of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Minnesota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.&nbsp; That's what our party was originally called, before it affiliated with the <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Reform<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> Party.</p>
<p>My wife <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Terry<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> and I have been married <TAG name="YRSMARR" value="start"/>26 years<TAG name="YRSMARR" value="end"/>.&nbsp; <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Terry<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> operates a riding school at our Maple Grove horse farm.&nbsp; We have two children: <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Tyrel<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, born in 1979, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jade<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, born in 1983.</p>
<p>I am a member of the <i>Make a Wish of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Minnesota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> </i>Board of Advisors and have been a volunteer football coach at Champlin Park High School for several years.&nbsp; I am also a long-time member of the Screen Actors Guild, and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.</font></td>
</tr>
</table>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=523>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=25 height=4><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=25 height=1 border=0></td>
<td width=498><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=498 height=1 border=0></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td></td>
<td width=498>
<p><i>Media outlets interested in requesting an interview with Governor Ventura should contact the Governor's Communications Office at 651-296-0058</i></td>
</tr>
</table></td>
</tr>
</table>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=650>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=4 height=9><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=4 height=1 border=0></td>
<td width=646><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=646 height=1 border=0></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td></td>
<td width=646>
<p align=CENTER><a href="http://www.exploreminnesota.com"><img id="Picture48" height=94 width=120 src="./explore_mn_3.gif" vspace=0 hspace=0 align=LEFT border=0 alt="Explore Minnesota Web site"></a><b><font size="+1">Office of <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jesse Ventura<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/><br></font><font size="-2"></font></b><font size="-2">130 State Capitol * 75 Constitution Avenue * Saint Paul, MN 55155 <br>Voice (651) 296-3391 or (800)657-3717 * Fax: (651) 296-2089 * TDD: (651) 296-0075 or (800) 657-3598 <br>An Equal Opportunity Employer <br></font><a href="./feedback_from_constituents.html"><font size="-2"></font><font color="#0000FF" size="-2"><u>Contact Governor Ventura</u></font><font color="#000000" size="-2"><u></u></font></a><font color="#000000" size="-2"><u><br></u></font><font size="-2">For question or comments about this Web site, contact the </font><a href="mailto:dave.ruth@state.mn.us"><font size="-2">Webmaster</font></a><font size="-2"><br><br></font><a href="http://www.state.mn.us"><font size="-2"></font><font color="#0000FF" size="-2" face="Times New Roman,Times,Times NewRoman"><u>Link to Northstar</u></font></a><font color="#0000FF" size="-2" face="Times New Roman,Times,Times NewRoman"><u></u></font><font color="#000000" size="-2" face="Times New Roman,Times,Times NewRoman">- main page for State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Minnesota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></font></td>
</tr>
