<html>
<head>
<title>Biography</title>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" link="#0000FF" vlink="#800080" text="#000000" topmargin=0 leftmargin=0 marginwidth=0 marginheight=0>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=717>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=8 height=2><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=8 height=1 border=0></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td height=166></td>
<td width=709 align=left valign=top><img id="Picture193" height=166 width=709 src="./0_Old_site_709.jpg" border=0 alt="Official site of Lieutenant Governor Mae Schunk"></td>
</tr>
</table>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=718>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=8 height=40><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=8 height=1 border=0></td>
<td width=710 align=left valign=top><img id="Picture198" height=40 width=710 src="./Background_links_bar.gif" border=0 alt="Background_links_bar" usemap="#map0"><map name=map0></map></td>
</tr>
</table>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=693>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=40 height=38><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=40 height=1 border=0></td>
<td width=54><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=54 height=1 border=0></td>
<td width=54><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=54 height=1 border=0></td>
<td width=82><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=82 height=1 border=0></td>
<td width=62><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=62 height=1 border=0></td>
<td></td>
<td width=54><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=54 height=1 border=0></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td colspan=5 height=68></td>
<td width=200 rowspan=6 align=left valign=top><img id="Picture224" height=264 width=200 src="./0_Schunk_Official_Portrait_feathered.jpg" border=0 alt="Lieutenant Governor Mae Schunk"></td>
<td colspan=2></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td colspan=2 height=35></td>
<td width=136 colspan=2 align=left valign=top><a name="Top"></a><img id="Picture225" height=35 width=136 src="./0_Biography.gif" border=0 alt="Biography"></td>
<td></td>

<td colspan=2></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td colspan=5 height=102></td>

<td colspan=2></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td height=5></td>
<td width=108 colspan=2 rowspan=2 align=left valign=top><a href="./fun_facts.html"><img id="Picture246" height=51 width=108 src="./0_blue_click_Fun.gif" border=0 alt="Click for Fun Facts"></a></td>
<td colspan=2></td>

<td colspan=2></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td height=46></td>

<td colspan=2></td>

<td></td>
<td width=147 align=left valign=top><a href="./official_duties.html"><img id="Picture243" height=46 width=147 src="./0_blue_click_duties.gif" border=0 alt="Click for Official Duties"></a></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td colspan=5 height=8></td>

<td colspan=2></td>
</tr>
</table>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=717>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=24 height=24><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=24 height=1 border=0></td>
<td width=693><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=693 height=1 border=0></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td></td>
<td width=693>
<p><font color="#000000" size="+1">It's a long way from the <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Wisconsin dairy farm<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>, where I grew up, to the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Minnesota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> State Capitol.&nbsp; In between I spent 37 years as an <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>educator<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> - mostly as an <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>elementary school teacher<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.&nbsp; These outward changes in my life are held together by a common philosophy of a strong work ethic, common sense values and a belief that education is the key to achieving excellence.&nbsp; It is because </font><a href="http://www.governor.state.mn.us"><font color="#000000" size="+1"></font><font size="+1">Jesse Ventura</font></a><font size="+1"></font><font color="#000000" size="+1">shares this philosophy that I agreed to be his running mate in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>.</p>
<p>
<img id="Picture242" height=250 width=250 src="./0_one_room_school_collage.jpg" vspace=0 hspace=11 align=LEFT border=0 alt="Lt. Governor Schunk as a student in a one room school house">
&nbsp;</p>
<p></font><font size="+1">I was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Chicago, Illinois<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, but my parents moved to a&nbsp; dairy farm in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Greenwood, Wisconsin<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> when I was very young.&nbsp; My </font><a href="./my_visit_to_delnice.html"><font size="+1">father </font></a><font size="+1">was a refugee from Croatia, and my mother was Croatian-American.&nbsp; They spoke Croatian at home, so I did not learn English until I went to school at a small one-room schoolhouse.&nbsp; I was very impressed that our teacher had so much knowledge to share; I realized right away that I wanted to become a teacher, too.<br><br>&nbsp;</p>
<p>
<img id="Picture227" height=223 width=200 src="./0__Biography_Icon.jpg" vspace=0 hspace=3 align=RIGHT border=0 alt="Wedding photo of Mae and Bill Schunk">
I earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degree in education<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> at the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Wisconsin<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Eau Claire in <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1958<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/>, and took my first teaching position in Wausau, Wisconsin. That same year I married <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>William Schunk<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, a graduate of the University of Wisconsin at Madison.&nbsp; He also grew up on a dairy farm, over in Stanley, Wisconsin. Together we have always enjoyed fishing, hunting and gardening.&nbsp; In 1970 our son <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Ben<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> was born.&nbsp; He is now a technology engineer.&nbsp; Ben and his wife Jennifer live in the Twin Cities.</p>
<p>I taught in Wisconsin for 14 years, until my husband's job took us to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Minnesota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.. In St. Paul I worked in several schools for a total of 23 years, as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>teacher<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>assistant principal<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>curriculum specialist<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.&nbsp; I turned my focus to learning how to teach gifted and talented students.&nbsp; I received a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>master's degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> in that specialty at the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of St. Thomas<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in St. Paul in 1989.&nbsp; My last position was teaching gifted and talented students at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Phalen Lake School<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in St. Paul.&nbsp; I worked there right up until we were elected.&nbsp; I even went to work the day after the election - even though I had been up all night.&nbsp; I was embarrassed because I was late for the first time ever.&nbsp; To my surprise my colleagues and students had arranged a big party for me.&nbsp; I was heartbroken to leave teaching, but my new duties as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Minnesota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> have allowed me to visit schools quite often.&nbsp; I even volunteer once a week at a school near the Capitol.</p>
<p>
<img id="Picture236" height=300 width=300 src="./0_ventura_wins_300.jpg" vspace=0 hspace=25 align=RIGHT border=0 alt="Newspaper story of Governor and Lt. Governor on election night">
Governor Ventura chose me as his running mate because I was a teacher.&nbsp; He wanted someone by his side who knew about public education at the ground level; he wanted someone from the "trenches."&nbsp; When he became Governor, Jesse Ventura made me his "Ambassador for Education."&nbsp; During the campaign I pledged to visit every school district in the state, a task that has kept me very busy, but also very informed about education issues and concerns.&nbsp; I keep </font><a href="./sv_list_index.html"><font size="+1">a cyber-journal of my travels</font></a><font size="+1">on my Web site.</p>
<p><br>&nbsp;</p>
<p>
<img id="Picture234" height=195 width=300 src="./0_computer_kids.jpg" vspace=8 hspace=12 align=LEFT border=0 alt="Lt. Governor with three Moose Lake elementary students in a computer class">
My philosophy of education is to encourage every student to achieve excellence.&nbsp; Students need to learn to form the commitment to high standards at an early age.&nbsp; That's why parents need to be involved in the education of their children, starting the moment the child is born.&nbsp; For example, I took a five-year leave from teaching when my son was born, and it is one of the best decisions I've ever made.&nbsp; At most parents can volunteer at their child's school; at least they can set up a good learning environment at home.&nbsp; That includes providing a good study space, but it also means encouraging them to achieve, and helping them whenever possible.</p>
<p>Governor Ventura and I agree that the purpose of education is to enable youngsters to become productive, happy and involved citizens.&nbsp; That's why it is important to stress learning by doing, such as we find in the projects that comprise the Profile of Learning.&nbsp; It's not enough to know what is in books - true knowledge comes with being able to apply what you've learned to the real world.&nbsp; Plus, as the world changes, education must change along with it.&nbsp; When our education system was formed we had an agricultural-based local economy.&nbsp; Now we are in a technological global society.&nbsp; We aren't competing with Wisconsin and Iowa - we are competing with Argentina and Korea. In this sense we must all keep learning throughout our lives, as new situations and challenges present themselves.</p>
<p>
<img id="Picture233" height=269 width=300 src="./0_Bush_feathered_300.jpg" vspace=0 hspace=0 align=RIGHT border=0 alt="Lt. Governor with President George W. Bush">
Education has been the center of my interests, but my office has allowed me the opportunity to </font><a href="./diplomatic_visits.html"><font size="+1">travel around the world</font></a><font size="+1">and around the United States.&nbsp; I have met former President Clinton and Former President George Bush, and current president </font><a href="./may_17_bush.html"><font size="+1">George W. Bush</font></a><font size="+1">.&nbsp; Secretary of State Colin Powell and I became good friends while working together on the youth organization he directed - </font><a href="http://www.americaspromise.org/"><font size="+1">America's Promise</font></a><font size="+1">.&nbsp; These activities along with my other </font><a href="./official_duties.html"><font size="+1">official duties</font></a><font size="+1">keep me very busy indeed.</font>
</td>
</tr>
</table><table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0 width=704>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=625>
<tr valign=top align=left>

<td></td>
<td width=475><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=475 height=1 border=0></td>
</tr>

</tr>

</tr>

<a href="http://www.exploreminnesota.com/index.asp"><img id="Picture180" height=94 width=120 src="./explore_minnesota.gif" vspace=0 hspace=0 align=LEFT border=0 alt="Explore Minnesota!"></a>
<b><font color="#000000" size="+1">Office of Governor Jesse Ventura<br></font><font color="#000000">Working Real Hard, Keeping Minnesotans First ... We Will Not Fail!<br></font><font color="#000000" size="-2"></font></b><font color="#000000" size="-2">130 State Capitol * 75 Constitution Avenue * Saint Paul, MN 55155 <br>Voice (651) 296-3391 or (800)657-3717 * Fax: (651) 296-2089 * TDD: (651) 296-0075 or (800) 657-3598 <br>An Equal Opportunity Employer <br></font><a href="http://www.governor.state.mn.us/feedback_from_constituents.html"><font color="#000000" size="-2"></font><font size="-2"><u>Contact Governor Ventura</u></font><font color="#000000" size="-2"><u></u></font></a><font color="#000000" size="-2"><u><br></u>For question or comments about this web site, contact the </font><a href="mailto:paul.moore@state.mn.us"><font color="#000000" size="-2"></font><font size="-2"><u>Webmaster</u></font></a><font size="-2"><u></u></font>

<td>
<table cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0 width=523>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=186>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=19 height=9><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=19 height=1 border=0></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td height=395></td>
<td width=167 align=left valign=top><img id="Picture25" height=395 width=167 src="./First_Lady_picture.jpg" border=0 alt="This is a picture of me, the First Lady!"></td>
</tr>
</table></td>
<td>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=337>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=1 height=33><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=1 height=1 border=0></td>
<td width=334><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=334 height=1 border=0></td>
<td width=2><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=2 height=1 border=0></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td height=28></td>
<td width=336 colspan=2 align=left valign=top><img id="Picture26" height=28 width=336 src="./First_Lady_text.jpg" border=0 alt="First Lady Terry Ventura page"></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td colspan=3 height=23></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td></td>
<td width=334>
<p><font size="+1">I never thought I would be writing my life story for a governor's Web site, but here we are!&nbsp; </p>
<p>I was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Mankato, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Minnesota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, and moved to <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Minneapolis<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> when I was four.&nbsp; Even though I lived in the city, my heart remained in the country, so I returned to my grandparents' farm every chance I got.&nbsp; Helping out on the farm is where I began my love of horses and riding.</p>
<p>I graduated from high school in 1973.&nbsp; In September of 1974, I met the man now known as Governor <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Jesse Ventura<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>.&nbsp; We were married 10 months later in <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>July of 1975<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/>.&nbsp; We </font></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
</table></td>
</tr>
</table>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=518>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=19><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=19 height=1 border=0></td>
<td width=499>
<p><font size="+1">are the proud parents of a son, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Tyrel<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, who was born in 1979, and a daughter, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jade<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, born in 1983.</p>
<p>In addition to my duties as a mom, I manage our 32-acre ranch, giving riding lessons and taking care of nine horses, eight chickens, three cats and our bulldog, Franklin.&nbsp; I have also raised two champion horses through a breeding program, and show horses with my daughter throughout the state.</p>
<p>As <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, I created the Jade Foundation, an organization that distributes money to all kinds of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Minnesota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> charities. </font></td>
</tr>
</table></td>
</tr>
</table>
<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=650>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td width=4 height=32><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=4 height=1 border=0></td>
<td width=646><img src="./clearpixel.gif" width=646 height=1 border=0></td>
</tr>
<tr valign=top align=left>
<td></td>
<td width=646>
<p align=CENTER><a href="http://www.exploreminnesota.com"><img id="Picture48" height=94 width=120 src="./explore_mn_3.gif" vspace=0 hspace=0 align=LEFT border=0 alt="Explore Minnesota Web site"></a><b><font size="+1">Office of Governor Jesse Ventura<br></font><font size="-2"></font></b><font size="-2">130 State Capitol * 75 Constitution Avenue * Saint Paul, MN 55155 <br>Voice (651) 296-3391 or (800)657-3717 * Fax: (651) 296-2089 * TDD: (651) 296-0075 or (800) 657-3598 <br>An Equal Opportunity Employer <br></font><a href="./feedback_from_constituents.html"><font size="-2"></font><font color="#0000FF" size="-2"><u>Contact Governor Ventura</u></font><font color="#000000" size="-2"><u></u></font></a><font color="#000000" size="-2"><u><br></u></font><font size="-2">For question or comments about this Web site, contact the </font><a href="mailto:dave.ruth@state.mn.us"><font size="-2">Webmaster</font></a><font size="-2"><br><br></font><a href="http://www.state.mn.us"><font size="-2"></font><font color="#0000FF" size="-2" face="Times New Roman,Times,Times NewRoman"><u>Link to Northstar</u></font></a><font color="#0000FF" size="-2" face="Times New Roman,Times,Times NewRoman"><u></u></font><font color="#000000" size="-2" face="Times New Roman,Times,Times NewRoman">- main page for State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Minnesota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></font></td>
</tr>

<table width=496 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0>
<tr>
<td align=left valign=top width=299><img src="../images/ronnie_pic_inside.jpg" width=299 height=80></td>
<td width=197 align=left valign=top><img src="../images/gov_header.jpg" width=197 height=80>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan=2 align=left valign=top width=496>
<div align=center><img src="../images/spacer.gif" width=496 height=5><br>
<table width=496 border=0 cellspacing=4 cellpadding=4>
<tr>
<td>
<p align=center><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=4><b><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>RONNIE 
MUSGROVE<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/><br>
BIOGRAPHY</b></font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=2><img src="../images/ronnie_bio.jpg" width=109 height=137 align=left>On 
<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>January 4, 2000<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Ronnie Musgrove<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was elected <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s 
62nd <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>. </font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=2>His 
term as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> follows a distinguishing career of public 
service. As a two-term <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>State Senator<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, he chaired the Education 
Committee. As <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, he was recognized nationally 
as a leader among his peers, and the Governor served as 
chairman of the National Conference of Lieutenant Governors 
in 1998. </font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=2>Currently 
he serves on the Executive Committee of the Southern Regional 
Education Board, the Chairman-elect of the Southern States 
Energy Board, the National Board for Professional Teaching 
Standards, the National Assessment Governing Board, the 
National Board of Directors of Jobs for America's Graduates 
and the Executive Committee of the <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Democratic<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> Governor's 
Association. In addition, Governor Musgrove serves on the 
Executive Committee of the National Governors' Association. 
</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=2>Relentless. 
Determined. Persistent. These are the words used to describe 
Governor Musgrove's commitment to improving the quality 
of life for every Mississippian. By targeting education, 
health care, economic growth and public safety, Governor 
Musgrove is making a difference for <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=2>Governor 
Musgrove victoriously signed a bill in May 2000, which will 
raise teacher pay in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> to the Southeastern average. 
He created the Task Force on Classroom Technology, which 
will oversee the placement of an Internet-accessible computer 
in every classroom in the State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> by the end 
of 2002. </font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=2>Also 
in May 2000, Governor Musgrove unveiled a new plan of action 
to promote the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) 
to provide much needed insurance coverage to more <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> 
children of working families. Because of his leadership, 
more than 40,000 additional <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> children have access 
to healthcare, an increase of 70 times the number covered 
when the Governor took office. </font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=2>Governor 
Musgrove created a new economic development plan, the Advantage 
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Initiative. With the passage of supporting legislation, 
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> now has the advantage over our competing states. 
</font></p>
<p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=2>A graduate 
of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Northwest Community College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Mississippi<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> 
and the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Mississippi Law School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, Governor Musgrove 
is the proud father of two children <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jordan<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> (16) and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Carmen 
Rae<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> (13). </font></p>
<p align=center><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size=3><b><a href="index.html">Return 
to The Governor's Page</a></b></font><br>
</p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<br>
<font face=arial size=1><i>All rights are reserved to the Office 
of the Governor. Please view our full site <a href="../disclaimer.html">liability 
notice</a>. </i></font></div>
</td>
</tr>
</table></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC


<html><head><title>Biography</title>
</head>
<body bgcolor=#ffffff leftmargin=0 topmargin=0>
<div align=left>
<table border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 width="100%">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td align=right style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 5px; PADDING-LEFT: 5px; PADDING-TOP: 10px" valign=top><img alt="Lt. Governor Amy Tuck" height=157 src="biography_files/amytuckbio.gif" width=414></td></tr>
<tr>
<td align=left style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 10px; PADDING-LEFT: 10px; PADDING-TOP: 10px" valign=top>
<p align=left><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Amy Tuck<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is only the second woman ever elected to statewide 
office in the State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.</p>
<p>Since her swearing-in as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>Jan. 6, 2000<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, she has 
been recognized as the <i>2000 Outstanding <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Woman</i>by the 
President's Commission on the Status of Women and the <i><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Woman 
2000 Award</i>winner presented by <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> State University.</p>
<p align=left><img align=left alt="Amy with family" height=170 hspace=20 src="biography_files/family.gif" vspace=10 width=200>
<p align=left>During her first legislative session as Presiding Officer of the Senate, she successfully promoted:
<table width=438>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td valign=top width="11%"></td>
<td valign=top width="89%"><font face=Symbol size=2>
<p></font>&nbsp;&nbsp;A multi-year plan to raise teachers' salaries to the Southeastern average;<br><font face=Symbol size=2></font>&nbsp;&nbsp;Greater accountability by teachers and school officials for student performance; and<br><font face=Symbol size=2></font>&nbsp;&nbsp;Mandatory auto liability insurance.<br></p></td></tr></tbody></table></p>
<p align=left>Her interest in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s colorful political history 
began around her family's country store and on campaign outings she'd take 
with her family.</p>
<p align=left>She is a native of <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Maben<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> in Oktibbeha County and received 
her <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Bachelor's Degree in Political Science<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> and her <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Master's Degree in 
Public Policy &amp; Administration<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Mississippi State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.</p>
<p align=left>Her promising political future was heralded a few years 
later when she was awarded the Outstanding Woman Graduate Student by the 
President's Commission on the Status of Women. In 1989, she received her 
<TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Mississippi College School of Law<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.</p>
<p align=left>Lt. Gov. Tuck knows what it feels like to be in a classroom. 
From 1990 to 1995, she was a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>professor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Wood College<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in Mathiston.
And in 1990, she was elected to the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Senate to 
represent Choctaw, Montgomery, Oktibbeha and Webster counties.</p>
<p align=left>After serving in the Senate just one year, Tuck was selected to 
serve as Chair of the County Affairs Committee and gained wide support and praise for her leadership in the 
passage of a long-term program to repair and replace thousands of 
dangerous bridges throughout <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>. She also was a member of 
the Appropriations and Highways &amp; Transportation committees.
The <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Firefighters' Association recognized her with its Outstanding Legislator Award.</p>
<p align=left>In 1996, she was elected <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Secretary of the Senate<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> where she 
managed the legislative body's day-to-day operations.</p>
<p align=left>In March of 1999, she resigned that post to run for public 
office, and on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>Nov. 2, 1999<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, she was elected <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor of the 
State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>.</p>
<p align=left>A Methodist, she serves on the Board of Directors for the 
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Arts Fair for the Handicapped and is a member of the 
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Law Enforcement Officers Association, the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Business 
&amp; Professional Women's Club, the Golden Key National Honor Society and 
on the Advisory Board of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Mississippi<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Education Policy Fellowship 
Program. She also is an honorary member of the Civil Air 
Patrol.</p></td></tr></tbody></table></div></body></html>
ENDOFDOC

function init() {

  // Get width of window, need to account for scrollbar width in Netscape.

fullWidth = getWindowWidth() 
    - (isMinNS4 && getWindowHeight() < getPageHeight() ? 16 : 0);

  mainNavBar.resize(540);
  mainNavBar.create();
  mainNavBar.setzIndex(6);
  mainNavBar.moveTo(0,63);
}


function gotoText()
{
	var url = window.location.href;
	var loc = url.indexOf("css");
	var newurl = url.substring(0, loc) + "textonly" + url.substring(loc+3,url.length);

	window.location.href = newurl;
}
<!--
//Deal with Netscape Resize bug

    if(document.layers){
        pageWidth=innerWidth;
        pageHeight=innerHeight;

        function redraw(){
            if(pageWidth!=innerWidth || pageHeight!=innerHeight) {
                location.reload();
                }
            }
        window.onresize=redraw;
        }

//-->
</Script>

<table border="0" cellpadding="10" cellspacing="0" width="547"><tr><td>

<!-- start content here with standard HTML markup -->

<h1>
<IMG src="/gov2/css/images/state_icon.gif" align="middle">

Biography of <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Judy Martz<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></H1>

<P>
<IMG src="/gov2/css/images/martz.jpg" width="209" height="236" alt="Governor Judy Martz" border="0" align="right">Judy Martz was elected as Montana's first female <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 7, 2000<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>.  
Just four years earlier, she was elected as the state's first female <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> 
when she ran with Governor Marc Racicot. </P>
<P>As Lieutenant Governor, she was involved in policy development and problem solving 
across a wide range of issues.  She also served as Chair of the Governor's Drought 
Advisory Council; Co-chair of the Montana-Alberta Boundary Advisory Commission; Chair 
of Montana's Y2K Readiness Council; Chair of the Montana Census Council; Chair of the 
Governor's Council on Organ and Tissue Donor Awareness; and Chair of the Governor's 
Summit on Youth/Montana's Promise. During the wildfire season of 2000, she was a 
creator of the "I Care a Ton Program" to help agricultural producers in need of 
donated hay for their livestock.</P>
<P>Governor Martz was born <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>July 28, 1943<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Big Timber, Montana<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, to ranching parents. She 
graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Butte High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1961, and attended <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Eastern Montana College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. 
She was a member of the 1963 U.S. World Speed Skating Team, and a member of the U.S. 
Olympic Speed Skating Team at the 1964 Winter Games. She was the catalyst for the 
creation of U.S. High Altitude Speed Skating Center, located in Butte, and served 
as the Center's executive director from 1985 to 1989.</P>
<P>Governor Martz worked as a field representative for U.S. Senator Conrad Burns from 1989 
to 1995. She also served as President of the Butte Chamber of Commerce in the early 
1990's. For more than 30 years, she and her husband, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Harry Martz<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, have <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>owned and 
operated a commercial solid-waste business<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in Butte.  During these many years as 
a small business owner, she became actively involved in local and statewide 
economic development issues.</P>
<P>She and Harry, who were married in <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1965<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/>, have two grown children.</P>

<P><IMG src="../../css/images/camera1.gif" width="45" height="30" alt="Camera" border="0" align="right"><A href="/gov2/css/images/martz_hirez.jpg">This link will take you to a high resolution photo</A> of Gov. Judy Martz. 
Right click on the photo to download it to your computer. <I>The file is 1008 KB</I></P>


<P><CENTER>###</CENTER>


</TD></TR></TABLE>




<TABLE border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="600">
	<TR>
		<TD align="center"><H4><IMG src="/css/images/darkblue1px.gif" width="100%" height="3" vspace="8"><BR>
			<A href="/gov2/css/sitemap.asp#1" title="About Us">Biography</A>|
			<A href="/gov2/css/sitemap.asp#2" title="Category 2">Lt. Governor</A>|
			<A href="/gov2/css/sitemap.asp#3" title="Category 3">Goals & Objectives</A><BR>
			<A href="/gov2/css/sitemap.asp#4" title="Category 4">News Releases</A>|
			<A href="/gov2/css/sitemap.asp#5" title="Category 5">Speeches</A>|
			<A href="/gov2/css/sitemap.asp#6" title="Category 6">Staff</A></H4>
			<H4>
			<A href="/gov2/css/default.asp">Home</A> | 
			<A href="/gov2/css/search/default.asp" title="Search">Search</A>|
			<A href="javascript:gotoText();" title="Text Only Homepage">Text Only Website</A>|
			<A href="http://www2.state.mt.us/css/roads/default.asp" title="Roads &amp; Weather Information">Roads &Weather</A>|
			<A href="http://www.discoveringmontana.com/gov/contact.htm" title="Contact Us">Contact Us</A><BR>
			<A href="http://www.state.mt.us/" title="Discovering Montana" target="_top"><IMG src="http://www.discoveringmontana.com/banner/banner1.jpg" border="0" alt="Visit Discovering Montana" vspace="8"></A></H4><BR></TD>
	</TR>

	//Subcategory 2
	//Subcategory 3

  menu = new NavBarMenu(90, 180);
  menu.addItem(new NavBarMenuItem("<center>MORE LINKS<BR>&nbsp;</center>", "/gov2/css/sitemap.asp#7"));
  menu.addItem(new NavBarMenuItem("Boards and Commissions Scheduled Vacancies -- 2001", "/gov2/css/vacancies/vacancies.asp"));
  menu.addItem(new NavBarMenuItem("Executive Orders", "/gov2/css/eo/default.asp"));
  menu.addItem(new NavBarMenuItem("Northwest Power Planning Council", "http://www.nwcouncil.org/"));
  menu.addItem(new NavBarMenuItem("Office of Budget and Program Planning", "http://www2.state.mt.us/budget/"));
  menu.addItem(new NavBarMenuItem("Photos", "/gov2/css/gallery/photos.asp"));
  menu.addItem(new NavBarMenuItem("Public School Funding Study Advisory Council", "http://www2.state.mt.us/budget/Ed_Committee"));
  
  menu.addItem(new NavBarMenuItem("Former Governor Marc Racicot (1993-2001)", "http://www.discoveringmontana.com/racicot/governor.htm"));
 mainNavBar.addMenu(menu);

function init() {

  // Get width of window, need to account for scrollbar width in Netscape.

fullWidth = getWindowWidth() 
    - (isMinNS4 && getWindowHeight() < getPageHeight() ? 16 : 0);

  mainNavBar.resize(540);
  mainNavBar.create();
  mainNavBar.setzIndex(6);
  mainNavBar.moveTo(0,63);
}


function gotoText()
{
	var url = window.location.href;
	var loc = url.indexOf("css");
	var newurl = url.substring(0, loc) + "textonly" + url.substring(loc+3,url.length);

	window.location.href = newurl;
}
<!--
//Deal with Netscape Resize bug

    if(document.layers){
        pageWidth=innerWidth;
        pageHeight=innerHeight;

        function redraw(){
            if(pageWidth!=innerWidth || pageHeight!=innerHeight) {
                location.reload();
                }
            }
        window.onresize=redraw;
        }

//-->
</Script>

	left: 0px;
	width: 100%;
	height: auto;
	visibility: visible
	}

	</head>

<table border="0" cellpadding="10" cellspacing="0" width="547"><tr><td>

<!-- start content here with standard HTML markup -->

<h1>
<IMG src="/css/images/state_icon.gif" align="middle">

Biography of <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Karl Ohs<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></H1>



<IMG src="/gov2/css/images/ltgov.jpg" alt="Lt. Governor Karl Ohs" width="202" height="239" border="0" align="right">

<P>Lieutenant Governor Karl Ohs is widely known for his role in peacefully ending the Freeman standoff 
near Jordan, Montana. In 1996, at the request of the FBI, he served as principal negotiator, 
making 19 separate trips into the Freeman compound. His involvement earned him the 1998 Lou 
Peters Award given by the FBI for public service. Lieutenant Governor Ohs served in the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Montana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> 
<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>House of Representatives<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1995, 1997, and 1999 where he was majority whip in 1997 and 1999.</P>

<P>The son of a Swedish immigrant, Lieutenant Governor Ohs was born <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>November 18, 1946<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/> in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Havre<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> and grew up in 
<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Phillips County<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>, graduating from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Malta High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. He studied agricultural economics at <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Montana State 
University-Bozeman<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and left just months away from obtaining a degree to return to help on the family 
ranch when his father broke his leg. The family later moved the ranching operation to Harrison, 
where he and his wife Sherri still ranch today.</P>

<P>In 1988, Lieutenant Governor Ohs founded and became chairman of Montana Agricultural Producers Inc., 
a co-op for producing and marketing alternative crops. Since 1996, he has <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>owned and operated a 
small business<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, AAA Storage, in Helena. He served on the Harrison School Board from 1974 to 1983, 
including four years as chairman.</P> 

<P>He has four children:  <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Brad<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Eric<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Brian<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Elizabeth<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> from his previous marriage; his wife 
<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Sherri<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> has four children from her former marriage.</P>

<P><IMG src="../../css/images/camera1.gif" width="45" height="30" alt="Camera" border="0" align="right"><A href="/gov2/css/images/ohs_hirez.jpg">This link will take you to a high resolution photo</A> of Lt. Gov. Karl Ohs. 
Right click on the photo to download it to your computer. <I>The file is 782 KB</I></P>

<P><CENTER>###</CENTER>


</TD></TR></TABLE>



<TABLE border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="600">
	<TR>
		<TD align="center"><H4><IMG src="/css/images/darkblue1px.gif" width="100%" height="3" vspace="8"><BR>

			<A href="/gov2/css/sitemap.asp#6" title="Category 6">Staff</A></H4>

<title><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>John Hoeven<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></title>
<style>

<body lang=EN-US>
<basefont Face="Arial" size=2>
<div class=Section1>
<table width="100%"><tr><td align="right">
<p align="right"><font size="3">Biography<br>
</font><b><font size="4"><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>John Hoeven<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></font></b>

<div align="right" style='border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext .2pt;padding:0pt 3pt 3.0pt 0pt'></div>
<img src="/images/pixel.gif" height=5><br><font size="3">North Dakota</font></p>
</table>


<p style='text-align:justify'><a href="../mediacenter.htm"><img border="0" src="../images/hoeven.jpg" align="left" hspace="10" vspace="5" width="200" height="254"></a>In
his first run for public office, John Hoeven was elected the 31<sup>st</sup>
<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>North Dakota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 7, 2000<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, defeating the incumbent Democrat
attorney general with 55 percent of the vote.</p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>Governor
John Hoeven graduated with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelors degree in history and economics<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from
<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Dartmouth College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>masters degree in business administration<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from
the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>J.L. Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. After college he returned home to North
Dakota and joined the family business as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>executive vice president<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>First
Western Bank<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in Minot. In 1993, he was
appointed by the Industrial Commission to serve as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>president and CEO<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of the
nations only state-owned bank, <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Bank of North Dakota<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. Under his administration the bank grew from $900 million to $1.6
billion and the banks loan portfolio increased five-fold to more than $1
billion invested in agricultural, business, educational and residential loans
throughout North Dakota.</p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>Governor
Hoeven has a history of proven success in promoting economic growth and job
creation throughout North Dakota. He
received statewide and regional honors from the U.S. Small Business
Administration for his economic development leadership. He served as an economic advisor for North
Dakotas universities and also served as a trustee at Bismarck State College
and a regent at Minot State University.
His involvement in civic and charitable organizations includes serving
as director of the Minot Kiwanis Club, Souris Valley Humane Society and the
State Fair Advisory Committee. He was a
member of the board of directors for First Western Bank and Trust, North Dakota
Bankers Association, State Bank Board, North Dakota Small Business Investment
Company, Prairie Public Broadcasting, North Dakota Economic Developers
Association, Bismarck YMCA and the Harold Schafer Leadership Center. He chaired a task force that worked closely
with local and federal officials to prevent the shutdown of an Air Force base
in the state. He was the only person to serve two years as chairman of the
Minot Area Development Corporation and he pioneered The Magic Fund to help
bring in major new employers to the area.</p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>Proposing
an aggressive agenda for his first year as governor, Hoeven is focusing on
economic development, job creation, education, technology, agriculture, and
energy. His plans include strengthening
the state's economy through business recruitment and expansion, wiring the
state to a high-speed network and streamlining the state's economic development
structure. He is promoting value-added projects, agricultural research, and
substantial new investments in education to include additional spending for
teachers salaries, training
and technology.</p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>Governor
Hoeven and his wife <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Mical<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> (Mikey) have two children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Marcela<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jack<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>. </p>

</div>

<p style="text-align: justify">
<a href="../mediacenter.htm">High resolution photo of Governor John Hoeven available.</a><br>
<br>
<a href="/"><br>
<br>
Home</a></p>

</body>

</html>

   <title><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>North Dakota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Lieutenant Governor's Office</title>

   <meta name="GENERATOR" content="Microsoft FrontPage 4.0">
   <meta name="AUTHOR" content="ITD">
</head>
<body  background="/ndflagb.gif" text="#000000" bgcolor="#C0C0C0" link="#0000FF" vlink="#8000FF" alink="#8000FF">

<center><h1><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lt. Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jack Dalrymple<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></h1></center>

<a href="../mediacenter.htm">

<img border="0" src="../images/Dalrymple.jpg" width="200" height="275" align="right" hspace="15" vspace="5">
</a> Jack Dalrymple brings an outstanding record in farming, business and legislative
leadership to the lieutenant governors office. Born <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>Oct. 16, 1948<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, in
<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Minneapolis<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>,
he grew up in <a href="http://www.casselton.com/" target="_blank"><TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Casselton<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/></a> on the family farm, established in 1875 as
<a href="http://www.prairiepublic.org/features/BonanzaFarm/story/index3.htm" target="_blank">North
Dakotas first large-scale wheat farm</a>. Dalrymple graduated with honors
from <a href="http://www.yale.edu" target="_blank"><TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Yale University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/></a> in 1970 with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelors degree in American
Studies<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>, returning to North Dakota afterward to manage the farming operations.
He and <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Betsy Wood<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> were married in <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1971<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/>, and they have four daughters. Dalrymple
became active in the community serving on the Casselton Jobs Development
Commission and helping to found <a href="http://www.sharehouse.org" target="_blank">Share House, Inc</a>., a Fargo residential
treatment program for recovering alcoholics and drug dependents. Dalrymple came
to the <a href="http://www.state.nd.us/lr" target="_blank">North Dakota Legislature</a> in 1985, representing a rural Cass County
House district. He served eight terms, including four as chairman of the
influential House Appropriations Committee. In the 1999-2000 interim, he also
chaired the Budget Section, the legislative panel charged with reviewing
spending issues between sessions. Dalrymple is a nationally recognized leader in
value-added agriculture. He chairs the board of the Dakota Growers Pasta
Company, the
largest producer of non-branded pasta in the United States, headquartered in
Carrington, N.D. The company operates as a cooperative of more than 1,000 durum
growers. Dalrymple is also a national voice for agriculture as a member of the
board of the <a href="http://www.uschamber.com/" target="_blank">U.S. Chamber of
Commerce</a>. Elected in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 2000<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, Jack
Dalrymple is <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>North Dakota's 35th lieutenant governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>.
<p>
<a href="../mediacenter.htm">High resolution photo of Lt. Governor Dalrymple available.</a></p>
<p>
<a href="/" target="_top"><br>
<br>
Home</a></p>

-->06/12/2001<!--webbot bot="Timestamp" endspan i-checksum="12530"

</body>

is 402-471-6031.</font></font></td>

      <td> 
        <center>
          <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif" color="#000000" size="+2"><b><u><font size="+3">Mike 
            Johanns</font></u></b><br>
            <font size="+1"><i><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/><TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="start"/>Nebraska<TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/><TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></i></font></font></p>
        </center>
        <p><font face="Times New Roman,Times" color="#000099">Mike Johanns was 
          sworn into office as Nebraska's 38th Governor on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>January 7, 1999<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>. As 
          Governor, he has promoted an agenda of tax relief, less government, 
          building the economy, protecting families, and ensuring the health, 
          safety, and success of Nebraska's children. Mike Johanns is a <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/>.</font> 
        <p><font color="#000099">Mike Johanns was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Iowa<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> and raised on a 
          dairy farm. He graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>St. Mary's College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Winona, Minnesota 
          and earned his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Creighton University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Omaha. He then 
          <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>clerked<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for the Honorable Hale McCown at the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Nebraska Supreme Court<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>.</font> 
        <p><font color="#000099">Mike Johanns began <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>practicing law<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at the firm 
          of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Cronin &amp; Hannon<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in O'Neill, Nebraska, then moved to Lincoln where 
          he joined the law firm of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Nelson Johanns Morris Holdeman &amp; Titus<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. 
          He sought public office for the first time in 1982 and was elected to 
          a four-year term on the Lancaster County Board of Commissioners. After 
          deciding not to run for re-election to the County Board, Johanns was 
          elected to the Lincoln City Council in 1989. Two years later he successfully 
          challenged the incumbent <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>mayor of Lincoln<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. In 1995, Johanns was re-elected 
          mayor without opposition. As mayor he focused on public safety, economic 
          development, and holding the line on property taxes.</font> 
        <p><font color="#000099">During the first three years of his administration, 
          Governor Johanns has made property tax relief, reducing the size of 
          government, building the state's economy, protecting families, and ensuring 
          the health, safety, and success of Nebraska's children his priorities. 
          A list of his major enacted initiatives:</font> 
        <ul>
          <li><font color="#000099">$85 million dollars in surplus state sales 
            tax and state income tax dollars dedicated for direct property tax 
            relief over two years and an expanded homestead exemption for seniors, 
            veterans, and the disabled;</font></li>
          <li><font color="#000099">reductions in the size and cost of the Governor's 
            office staff, cost-saving restrictions on the use of state cars, an 
            emphasis on e-government and technology applications, and the merger 
            of the Department of Water Resources and Natural Resources Commission 
            into the new Department of Natural Resources; </font></li>
          <li><font color="#000099">incentives for business growth and job creation 
            in rural Nebraska and an emphasis on value-added agriculture;</font></li>
          <li><font color="#000099">tougher penalties for drug dealers, fourteen 
            additional state troopers, increased technology for law enforcement, 
            and settlement of a long-running labor disagreement between the state 
            troopers' union and the State; and</font></li>
          <li><font color="#000099">expanded incentives for adoption of state 
            wards, a record number of children covered by health insurance, increased 
            state funding for K-12 special education costs and technology in the 
            classroom, criminalized the offense of child enticement, and achieved 
            record child support collections.<br>
            </font> </li>
        </ul>
        <p><font color="#000099">Governor Johanns has led four delegations of 
          Nebraska government, business, and agriculture leaders on trade missions 
          to eight countries including Japan, Taiwan, China, Hong Kong, Australia, 
          Korea, Singapore, and Malaysia. He has also been a very strong advocate 
          for Nebraska agriculture producers during a period of depressed commodity 
          prices and severe drought.</font> 
        <p><font color="#000099">In his first year in office, Governor Johanns 
          was selected as the lead governor for re-authorization of the federal 
          farm bill for the Western Governors' Association. For 2000-2001, he 
          was selected to chair the National Governors' Association Committee 
          on Economic Development and Commerce. </font> 
        <p><font color="#000099">In 2001, Governor Johanns serves as chairman 
          of the 25-state Governors' Ethanol Coalition. The goals of the Coalition 
          are to increase ethanol's use, to decrease the nation's dependence on 
          imported energy resources, improve the environment, and stimulate the 
          national economy. He also has been selected as vice-chairman of the 
          Midwest Governors' Association for 2001 and serves as co-chair of the 
          Governors' Public Power Alliance and Governors' Bio-Tech Partnership.</font> 
        <p><font color="#000099">Mike Johanns has two children and one grandson 
          and is married to <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Stephanie Johanns<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, a former Lancaster County Commissioner 
          and former State Senator. Stephanie Johanns is Vice President-External 
          Relations for Alltel, a telecommunications company.</font> <font color="#000099"><br>
          </font> 
        <p><font color="#000000"> </font> 
        <div align=right><font color="#000099">&nbsp;<i><font size=-1>updated 
          July 6, 2001</font></i></font></div>
      </td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td COLSPAN="2">&nbsp;</td>
</tr>
</table></center>

<center>
<p><i><font size=-1><a href="mailto:jodee@mail.state.ne.us">Webmaster questions/comments?&nbsp;
e-mail:&nbsp; jodee@mail.state.ne.us</a></font></i></center>

</body>
</html>

<td>
<center><b><font size=+1><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>David I. Maurstad<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></font></b>
<br>Biographical Data</center>
</td>
</tr>
</table></center>

<center>
<hr WIDTH="85%">
<p><b>David I. Maurstad</b>
<br><b><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lt. Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></b></center>

<p>David Ingolf Maurstad was born in North Platte, Nebraska, on August
25, 1953.&nbsp; He and Karen Maurstad have been married for 26 years.&nbsp;
They have three children.&nbsp; Maurstad is a graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Beatrice High
School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, Platte Community College in Columbus, and the University of Nebraska-Lincoln
where he earned his bachelor degree in business in 1989 and his MBA with
distinction in 2000.&nbsp; He is a successful businessman and community
and civic leader in his hometown of Beatrice and has held public office
at both the local and state level.
<p>Maurstad was elected Lieutenant Governor of Nebraska in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> when he
won a five-way primary election and was paired with <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> gubernatorial
nominee Mike Johanns in a successful general election campaign.&nbsp; Governor
Mike Johanns has given Maurstad a number of key assignments and roles within
the administration.
<p>Maurstad serves as federal liaison and tribal liaison for the Johanns
administration and chairman of the Nebraska Information Technology Commission.&nbsp;
He has taken on several key assignments including: a review of working
conditions in meatpacking plants; chairman of a task force considering
the impacts of Immigration and Naturalization Service enforcement actions;
and chairman of a cooperative effort between the Department of Education
and the Health and Human Services System on child care issues.&nbsp; In
1999, Maurstad created the Spotlight on Youth program to recognize outstanding
young people from across Nebraska for their achievements, personal courage,
and positive outlook on life.
<p>In 1994, Maurstad was elected to the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Nebraska Unicameral Legislature
<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>representing District 30.&nbsp; He served on the budget-writing Appropriations
Committee for four years.&nbsp; Maurstads broad record of success in the
legislative arena includes changes to Nebraskas law enforcement pursuit
liability and domestic violence protection statutes.&nbsp; In his first
year in the Legislature, he successfully secured funding for the renovation
of living facilities for the developmentally disabled at the Beatrice State
Developmental Center.&nbsp; The funding was vetoed by the sitting governor
but Maurstad was able to secure enough support from his colleagues to override
the veto.
<p>In 1997, Maurstad sponsored legislation authorizing a new 960 bed maximum-mininmum
security prison to relieve overcrowding in the correctional system.&nbsp;
That year he also guided his priority bill, a ban on partial-birth abortion,
to passage.&nbsp; The abortion procedure ban resulted in litigation that
eventually reached the U.S. Supreme Court where the law was struck down
by a deeply divided court in a 5-4 decision.
<p>In 1988, Dave Maurstad was elected to the Beatrice School Board and
in 1990 he was elected mayor of Beatrice.&nbsp; As mayor, he increased
the size of the police force and spearheaded a successful ballot initiative
that allowed a new city sales tax to be used to cut property taxes in half
and boost economic development.
<p>Maurstad is a past president of the Beatrice YMCA, Gage County United
Way, and the Beatrice Education Foundation.&nbsp; He currently serves on
the board of directors for the Beatrice Public Library Foundation and Madonna
Rehabilitation Hospital Foundation in Lincoln.&nbsp; Maurstad has served
in leadership capacities in both county and state Republican organizations
and served as an at-large delegate to the 2000 Republican National Convention.&nbsp;
Dave and his family are members of St. John Lutheran Church in Beatrice.
<p>I. General Data
<p>Born <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>North Platte, Nebraska<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>August 25, 1953<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>. Lifelong <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/><TAG name="RESCITY" value="start"/>Beatrice, Nebraska<TAG name="RESCITY" value="end"/><TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>,
resident.&nbsp; Married to <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Karen Maurstad<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> for <TAG name="YRSMARR" value="start"/>26 years<TAG name="YRSMARR" value="end"/> with three children
including two sons (ages 24 and 21) and one daughter (age 19). Member of
St. John Lutheran Church.&nbsp; Education: Beatrice Public Schools, 1971;
<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Platte Community College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, 1973; <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Nebraska-Lincoln<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>B.S.
in Business Administration<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>, 1989; UNL, <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>MBA<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> with distinction, 2000.
<p>II. Professional and Business Affiliations
<blockquote><TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>President<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Maurstad Insurance Services, Inc<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. (1990-present)
<br><TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Office Manager<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, Maurstad Insurance Services, Inc. (1983-1990)
<br><TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Agent<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, Maurstad/Zimmerman Insurance (1978-1983)
<br>Head Golf Professional, Westward Ho Country Club, Sioux Falls, South
Dakota (1977)
<br>Assistant Golf Professional, Country Club of Lincoln, Lincoln, NE (1974-1976)
<br>Assistant Golf Professional, Beatrice Country Club, Beatrice, NE (1973)</blockquote>

<p><br>III. Public Office
<blockquote>Lieutenant Governor, <TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="start"/>State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Nebraska<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/>, 1999-present
<br><TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Nebraska State Senator<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, Legislative District No. 30, 1995-1999
<br><TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Mayor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>City of Beatrice<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, Nebraska, 1991-1994
<br>Board Member, Beatrice School District #15, 1989-1990</blockquote>

<p><br>IV. Civic Activities
<blockquote>Chair, Nebraska Information Technology Commission, 1999-Present
<br>Trustee, Beatrice Library Foundation, 1996-present
<br>Board of Directors, Madonna Foundation, 1997-present
<br>Trustee, Beatrice Educational Foundation, 1987-1997 (President, 1987-1990)
<br>Board of Directors, University of Nebraska - Lincoln, College of Business
Administration
<br>Alumni Association, 1989-1996 (President, 1994-1995)
<br>Chairman, Highway 77 Improvement Association, 1991-1994
<br>Member, Beatrice YMCA (President, Board of Directors, 1982-1983)
<br>Member, Beatrice Chamber of Commerce (Board of Directors, 1983-1986)
<br>Member, Gage County United Way (President, Board of Directors, 1985)
<br>Member, Blue Valley Life Underwriters (Board of Directors, 1988-1994)
<br>Member, Independent Insurance Agents of Nebraska
<br>Member, Rotary International
<br>At-Large Delegate, 2000 Republican National Convention
<br>Member, Gage County Republican Party (Vice-chairman, 1985-1986)
<br>Member, Nebraska Republican Party Central Committee (1985-1990)
<br>Member, Nebraska Republican Party Executive Committee (1995-1997)</blockquote>
V. Awards and Honors
<blockquote>Nebraska Community College System Distinguished Alumni, 2000
<br>League of Nebraska Municipalities 1998 Distinguished Service Award
<br>Central Community College Platte Campus, College Alumni Association,
Outstanding Alumnus Award, 1998
<br>The Arc of Nebraska 1998 Harold Sieck Public Official of the Year
<br>Trainer, International Republican Institute, Arkhangelsk, Russia, 1996
<br>Fellow, The Council of State Governments "Toll Fellows Program", 1996
<br>Darden Graduate School of Business, University of Virginia, Charlottesville,
1996 "Program for Emerging Leaders"
<br>Fellow, Midwestern Legislative Conference of The Council of State Governments
1995 Bowhay
<br>Institute for Legislative Leadership Development
<br>University of Nebraska - Lincoln College of Business Administration
Alumni Association 1994 Leadership Award
<br>University of Nebraska Alumni Association's 1993 Young Alumnus
<br>Beatrice Chamber of Commerce 1993 Citizen of the Year
<br>Nebraska Federation of Interscholastic Officials Association 1989 Distinguished
Service Award
<br>Independent Insurance Agents of Nebraska 1985 Young Agent of the Year
<br>Beatrice Jaycees 1985 Outstanding Young Man
<br>Nebraska Golf Association 1981 Outstanding Amateur Golfer</blockquote>

<div align=right>
<p><br>Updated 1/7/2001</div>

<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" text="#000000">
<table width="80%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" align="center">
  <tr>
    <td>
      <div align="center"><font size="+1"><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>NEBRASKA'S FIRST LADY<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></font> </div>
      <p align="center"><font size="+2"><b><font size="+3">Stephanie Johanns</font></b></font></p>
      <p align="center"><font size="+1">BIOGRAPHY</font><br>
      </p>
      <p align="left"><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Stephanie A. Johanns<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Glendale, Arizona<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>. She 
        graduated from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Minnesota<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1977 with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor's degree 
        in psychology<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> and has held a variety of <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>administrative and managerial 
        positions<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in the private and public sectors. Moving to Lincoln after graduation, 
        she <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>sold computers<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>IBM<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> for 3 1/2 years. Stephanie was executive director 
        of the Lincoln Private Industry Council for 4 1/2 years and Lancaster 
        County commissioner for four years, including two years as the board chair. 
        She was then appointed by former Nebraska Governor Kay Orr to serve as 
        a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Nebraska state senator<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> from May 1987 to January 1989, when she decided 
        not to seek a full term. </p>
      <p align="left">Stephanie is currently <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Vice President of External Relations<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> 
        for Nebraska, Kansas and Missouri, working for <TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="start"/>ALLTEL<TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/>, a communications 
        company. She has worked for the company, holding a variety of positions 
        in areas ranging from data processing to telephone directories to customer 
        service, for over 15 years.</p>
      <p align="left">Stephanie volunteers with numerous community organizations 
        and serves as a board member of the Lincoln Independent Business Association 
        (LIBA) Political Action Committee, Downtown Lincoln Association, Nebraska 
        Telephone Association, and Cornhusker State Games. She serves as a trustee 
        for Junior Achievement and has served as board president of Nebraskans 
        for Public Television, Junior Achievement, and Lancaster Manor Foundation. 
        Stephanie also participates in the Lincoln chapter of Mensa and is a Junior 
        League Sustainer.</p>
      <p align="left">She has received numerous awards including the LIBA Free 
        Enterprise Award and Junior Achievement's national bronze and silver leadership 
        awards. Stephanie was named Jaycee's Outstanding Young Individual in 1986.</p>
      <p align="left">Stephanie and <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Governor Johanns<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> were married in <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1986<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/> and 
        have two children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Justin<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Michaela<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>. In her free time, Stephanie enjoys 
        water skiing, snow skiing, bicycling, playing racquetball, walking, and 
        reading.</p>
      <p align="left"></p>
      <p align="left">(7/9/01)</p>
      <p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
    </td>
  </tr>
</table>

<html>
<head>
<title><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jeanne Shaheen<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></title>
<meta name="keywords" content="New Hampshire, NH, Jeanne Shaheen, information, speeches, agenda, biography, contact ">
<meta name="description" content="Governor Jeanne Shaheen's home page.">
</head>

<body bgcolor="#ffffef" link="#003399" vlink="#551A8B" alink="#ff0000" text="#000000">

<a href="index.html"><img src="images/govlogog.gif" alt="Governor Jeanne Shaheen" width=600 height=100 border=0></a></td>

<p>

<table width=600 border=0>
<tr>
<td>
<font face="arial"><strong><em>
"I stand before you as the thankful daughter of two hardworking and caring parents, as the
grateful wife of a loving and supporitve husband, as the proud mother of
three wonderful daughters - - and now, as the first elected woman <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> of the
<TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="start"/>state of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>New Hampshire<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/>."
</em></strong></font>
</td>
</tr>

	<tr>
	<td colspan=3 align=right>
        <font face="arial">-- Inaugural Address, January 1997</font>
	<p>&nbsp;
        </td>
        </tr>

<tr>
<td>
<font face="arial">
<img src="family4.jpg" align="right" alt="Governor & Family" width="247" height="213">
Elected New Hampshire's first female governor in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1996<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, Jeanne Shaheen has made her mark by crafting solutions to issues that matter to New Hampshire families: strengthening education from kindergarten through college; improving health care; building a high-tech and international economy; bringing competition to the state's electric industry; and maintaining a fiscally responsible state government. 

<p>Jeanne Shaheen was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>St. Charles, Mo.<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>1947<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, the second of Ivan and Belle Bowers' three daughters. She earned her <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor's degree in English<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Shippensburg University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Pennsylvania in 1969 and her <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>master's degree in political science<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Mississippi<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1973. 

<p>Before serving in public office, she <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>taught high school<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in New Hampshire and Mississippi, was the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>owner and manager<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of a small business, and managed several statewide campaigns.  

<p>In 1990, Jeanne Shaheen was elected to the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>state senate<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, where she served three terms. She quickly delved into some of the state's most complicated issues and demonstrated her ability to build bipartisan consensus. She was an early champion and expert on bringing electric competition to New Hampshire, reforming workers' compensation, improving the state's health care system and expanding the economy. 

<p>In 1996, she ran for governor, focusing on strengthening education, improving health care, building the state's economy and lowering electric rates. Jeanne Shaheen was the first Democrat elected governor in sixteen years, and she was reelected in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> and <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>2000<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>. Jeanne Shaheen is only the fourth governor in New Hampshire's history to be elected to a third term. 

<p>In her first six months as Governor, she fulfilled her promise to expand public kindergarten in New Hampshire. Gov. Shaheen increased the state's investment in local public schools, the university system and community technical colleges. In addition, the state is reforming its job training system to make it more responsive to the needs of employees and businesses. To help families meet the rising costs of higher education, the state has established a college savings program that is a model for the nation. 

<p>Recognizing that money alone does not improve the quality of schools, her administration began the testing of first-year teachers; toughened teacher recertification standards; created a program to put more computers into local schools; and developed a school report card so parents know how their children's schools measure up. She also launched the Best Schools Initiative, and its flagship program, the Best Schools Leadership Institute, to help communities achieve excellence in their schools. She has been recognized nationally for her work on education issues and is the chair of the Education Commission of the States, where she will focus her efforts on improving early education and child care. 

<p>She has led New Hampshire to the cutting edge of the new economy, taking advantage of new technologies and global opportunities. New Hampshire now has one of the highest concentrations of high-technology workers in the nation, one of the highest rates of growth in international trade, and has become a magnet for international investment. In addition, the state has increased its tourism marketing efforts, increased investment in its infrastructure and lowered workers' compensation premiums. 

<p>She has expanded health care coverage for children through an innovative public-private partnership, and is working to make prescription drugs more affordable for senior citizens. Gov. Shaheen successfully pushed through the legislature her HMO Accountability Act, which provides New Hampshire families with the information and tools to hold their HMO accountable for providing the health care families need. In addition, the legislature passed her proposal to allow small businesses to join together to purchase health insurance for their employees. 

<p>Gov. Shaheen has worked to make state government more efficient and effective, including creating a Kids Cabinet, which brings together the state's top officials to coordinate their efforts on children's issues, including child care, after-school care and substance abuse. 

<p>Under Gov. Shaheen's leadership, the state has made a number of significant advances toward lowering electric rates for all New Hampshire families and businesses and bringing electric competition to New Hampshire. 
 
<p>Gov. Shaheen and her husband of <TAG name="YRSMARR" value="start"/>thirty years<TAG name="YRSMARR" value="end"/>, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Bill<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, live in Madbury and have three daughters, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Stefany<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Stacey<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Molly<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>. Stefany and her husband, Craig Welch, have one daughter, Ellen Louise Shaheen.

</td>

</tr>

</table>

<p>
<hr>
<p>
<font size=-1><em>State of New Hampshire
<br>Office of the Governor
<br>State House
<br>Concord, New Hampshire  03301-4990
<br>(603) 271-2121
</em>
<p>http://www.state.nh.us/governor
</body>
</html>

<head>



<title><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Donald T. DiFrancesco<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> - <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Acting Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/><TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="start"/>New Jersey<TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/><TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></title>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<meta http-equiv="Content-Style-Type" content="text/css">
<link href="styles.css" rel=stylesheet  type="text/css">
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" leftmargin="0" topmargin="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0">
<table width="683" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" align="center">
  <tr> 
    <td width="683" align="left" valign="top"> 
      <map name="Map2"> <area shape="rect" coords="327,7,401,25" href="http://www.state.nj.us/government_info.html" alt="Government Information" title="Government Information"> <area shape="rect" coords="409,5,484,25" href="http://www.state.nj.us/deptserv.html" alt="Departments and Agencies" title="Departments and Agencies"> 
  <area shape="rect" coords="263,7,321,24" href="http://www.state.nj.us/njbiz/" alt="NJ Business Portal" title="NJ Business Portal"> <area shape="rect" coords="122,3,204,26" href="http://my.state.nj.us/" alt="MY New Jersey" title="MY New Jersey"> 
  <area shape="rect" coords="212,3,255,26" href="http://www.state.nj.us/government_info.html" alt="NJ people" title="NJ people"> <area shape="rect" coords="60,3,114,26" href="http://www.state.nj.us/" alt="NJ Home Page" title="NJ Home Page"> 
</map> <map name="Map"><area shape="rect" coords="12,2,79,10" href="index.shtml" alt="Governors Home" title="Governors Home"> <area shape="rect" coords="87,2,111,10" href="news/releases.shtml" alt="Newsline" title="Newsline"> 
  <area shape="rect" coords="120,1,165,10" href="speechesdtd.shtml" alt="Speeches" title="Speeches"><area shape="rect" coords="177,1,251,10" href="http://www.njleg.state.nj.us/html/difranc.htm" alt="Senate President" title="Senate President"> 
  <area shape="rect" coords="257,1,293,10" href="pictures/recent.shtml" alt="Recent Photos" title="Recent Photos"> <area shape="rect" coords="301,1,348,10" href="bio.shtml" alt="Biography" title="Biography"> 
  <area shape="rect" coords="356,1,398,10" href="news/schedule.shtml" alt="Governor's Schedule" title="Governor's Schedule"> <area shape="rect" coords="407,1,434,10" href="faqs.shtml" alt="FAQs" title="FAQs"> 
  <area shape="rect" coords="442,1,518,10" href="radiodtd.shtml" alt="Radio Addresses" title="Radio Addresses"> <area shape="rect" coords="525,1,599,10" href="directions.shtml" alt="Direction &amp; Maps to NJ Statehouse" title="Direction &amp; Maps to NJ Statehouse"><area shape="rect" coords="608,2,681,10" href="key_init.shtml" alt="Key Initiatives" title="Key Initiatives"></map> 
<table width="683" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" height="30">
        <tr bgcolor="#006699"> 
          
    <td align="left" valign="top" width="502" height="30"><img src="images/top_nav.gif" width="502" height="30" usemap="#Map2" border="0" alt="topbrandingbar"></td>
          <td height="30" align="center" valign="middle"> 
            <table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" height="30">

                <form name="seek" method="GET" action="http://search.state.nj.us/query.html">

  <tr>
    <td valign="top"><img src="images/secondary_nav.gif" width="683" height="12" usemap="#Map" border="0" alt="secondary_nav.gif"></td>
