      <table width="97%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" align="center">
        <tr> 
          <td height="122" align="left" valign="top" width="15%">&nbsp;</td>
          <td height="122" align="left" valign="top" width="85%"> 
            <p align="right"><a href="dtd3.pdf"><i><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman , Times, serif" size="2"> 
              Governor's Bio - Acrobat Version</font></i></a></p>
            <h3><font color="#003366"><b>Donald T. DiFrancesco</b></font><b><font face="Georgia, Georgia, Times New Roman , Times, serif" size="5" color="#990033"><font color="#990000" size="6" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"></font></font></b><br>
              <font color="#003366"><b>New Jersey Acting Governor</b></font><font size="3" color="#003366" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><br>
              </font><font color="#003366">Senate President</font><font size="4"> </font><b><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman , Times, serif" size="2"><br>
              </font></b></h3>
            </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td height="315" align="left" valign="top" width="15%"> 
            <p>
            <p><img src="images/difrancesco.jpg" width="96" height="137" align="left">
          </td>
          <td height="315" align="left" valign="top" width="85%"> 
            <div align="center"></div>
            <p><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman , Times, serif" size="2"><b><font size="4">N</font></b><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif">ew Jersey Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco 
              </font></font><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">became Acting Governor of New Jersey on January 31, 2001, when Gov. Christie Whitman resigned to become Administrator 
              of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. DiFrancesco retains his duties as Senate President, a post to which his Senate colleagues have elected him for an unprecedented five two-year terms.<br>
              <br>
              Acting Governor DiFrancesco has laid out an agenda that includes providing property tax relief, helping needy children, improving public schools and workplace basic skills, reforming health 
              care, protecting drinking water, promoting smart growth, and eliminating racial profiling.</font></p>
            <ul>
              <li><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2"><b>Providing Property Tax Relief Now!</b> DiFrancescos plan increases the maximum homestead rebate and adds an annual cost-of-living 
                increase for seniors. He proposes doubling the NJ SAVER property tax rebate and fully implementing the program a year ahead of schedule. DiFrancescos plan also increases municipal aid by 
                $100 million with a stipulation that this money be applied to property tax relief. </font></li>
              <li><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2"><b>Helping Children. </b>The Acting Governor is leading an effort, called KidsNeeds, to forge consensus among childrens advocates, 
                health care providers, parents, teachers, and community leaders about how to lift the states neediest children out of poverty and into a promising future.<br>
                </font></li>
              <li><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2"> <b>Improving Schools.</b> DiFrancesco has called on the Commissioner of Education and the Legislature to establish the nations 
                best system of teacher training, recruitment, and retention. He has also pledged timely disbursement of State funding for the historic statewide school construction program he sponsored.<br>
                </font></li>
              <li><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2"><b>Increasing Workplace Skill</b></font><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000066"><b>s.</b></font><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2"> 
                To enable more residents to succeed on the job and to provide employers with more qualified workers, Acting Governor DiFrancesco has directed the Commissioner of Labor to develop a workplace 
                basic skills program. <br>
                </font></li>
              <li><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2"><b>Reforming Health Care</b></font><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000066"><b>.</b></font><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2"> 
                The Acting Governors 24-point plan for reforming the health care industry includes granting patients the right to sue HMOs. It also includes the Senior Gold Prescription Plan, which would 
                provide prescription drug coverage to 100,000 moderate-income seniors and people with disabilities.<br>
                </font></li>
              <li><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2"><b>Protecting Drinking Water</b></font><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000066"><b>.</b></font><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2"> 
                DiFrancesco has put forth a 16-point plan of action to protect, conserve, test, and monitor New Jerseys drinking water supplies. The plan includes a fund to close abandoned landfills and 
                clean up contaminated drinking-water wells, and proposes banning the use of the gasoline additive MTBE.</font></li>
              <li><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2"><b>Ending Racial Profiling</b></font><b><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2" color="#000066">.</font></b><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2"> 
                Acting Governor DiFrancesco has endorsed legislative efforts to outlaw the practice of racial profiling by members of law enforcement on New Jerseys roadways.</font></li>
              <li><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2"><b>Promoting Smart Growth<font color="#000066">.</font></b> DiFrancesco called for new incentives to encourage &quot;smart 
                growth&quot; -- future development focused on areas where infrastructure, such as sewers and roads, is already in place to support that development.<br>
                <br>
                DiFrancesco began his legislative career in the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>General Assembly<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1976 and was first elected to the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>New Jersey Senate<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1979. A lifelong New Jersey resident, he represents District 22, 
                which includes parts of Middlesex, Morris, Somerset, and Union counties.<br>
                <br>
                DiFrancesco has led the effort to enact many landmark bills addressing critical New Jersey issues. </font> 
                <blockquote> 
                  <p><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">His <i><b>Congestion Relief and Transportation Trust Fund</b></i> <b><i>Renewal Act</i></b> helped secure billions of dollars 
                    for road improvements without a tax increase.<br>
                    <br>
                    Senate President DiFrancesco sponsored the <i><b>Garden State Preservation Trust Act</b></i>, which dedicated funding to preserve 1 million acres of open land.<br>
                    <br>
                    He also sponsored the <i><b>Dredging and Economic Development Bond Act</b></i>, protecting more than $20 billion in annual economic activity and more than 180,000 New Jersey port-related 
                    jobs.<br>
                    <br>
                    He played a key role in passing the <i><b>Educational Facilities Construction and Financing Act</b></i>, which commits the State to pay at least 40 percent of all eligible school construction 
                    costs in every district. <br>
                    <br>
                    A longtime advocate for families, DiFrancesco championed the Catastrophic Illness in Children Relief Fund, the Health Care Reform Act of 1992, the subsidized health insurance program 
                    KidCare, and the New Jersey Family Leave Act of 1989. </font></p>
                </blockquote>
              </li>
            </ul>
            <p><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, serif" size="2">Born in <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>1944<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/> and raised in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Scotch Plains<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>, Don DiFrancesco is a graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Penn State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Seton Hall School of Law<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> 
              and a former <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>partner<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in a Warren law firm. He and his wife, Diane, live in Scotch Plains and have three daughters, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Marie<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Tracy<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Marci<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/></font><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman , Times, serif" size="2">. 
              </font></p>
            <p align="right"><font face="Georgia, Times New Roman , Times, serif" size="2"><i>Updated May 2001</i></font></p>
          </td>
        </tr>
      </table>
       
<table width="683" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" align="center">
  <tr>
    <td align="left" valign="middle" width="355" bgcolor="#FFFFFF" height="27"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1" color="#006699"><b>State of New Jersey Governor's Office</b></font></td> 
    <td align="right" valign="top" width="*%" bgcolor="#FFFFFF"><img src="images/footer.gif" alt="footer.gif" width="291" height="27" usemap="#Map3" border="0"><map name="Map3"><area shape="rect" coords="2,4,67,23" href="contact.shtml" alt="Contact Us" title="Contact Us"><area shape="rect" coords="74,4,158,24" href="../privacy.html" alt="State Privacy Notice" title="State Privacy Notice"><area shape="rect" coords="169,4,259,22" href="../legal.html" alt="Legal Notice" title="Legal Notice"><area shape="circle" coords="276,12,13" href="../" alt="NJ Home" title="NJ Home"></map></td>
  </tr>

    </td>



  </tr>

</body>



</html>



ENDOFDOC

<HTML VERSION="2.0">
<HEAD>
<TITLE><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>George E. Pataki<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY BGCOLOR="#e6e6e6">


<blockquote>

<P><CENTER>
<FONT SIZE=5 color=000080><font face="verdana"><B>GEORGE E. PATAKI<BR>
	<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>GOVERNOR<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, <TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="start"/>STATE OF <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>NEW YORK<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
<TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/></b>
	
</FONT></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE=3 color=000080><font face="arial">Biography</FONT></FONT>
</CENTER>

<HR width=450 size=5>
<IMG border=0 SRC="images/george.jpg" align=left>
<P>
<center><B></B></center>
<font face="arial" size=2>
<P>
	George E. Pataki, the 53rd Governor of New York State, has shown that firm leadership and commitment to core principles can transform political and popular vision into government policies that position the Empire State for the 21st Century.  New York State's first Republican-Conservative chief executive, George Pataki was elected Governor on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 8, 1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>.  On <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 3, 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, he was re-elected by a margin of more than 1 million votes (20%), the largest landslide for a <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> Governor in New York history.
<P>
Governor Pataki has governed with a mandate to restore hope and opportunity to a state that had lost its luster.  Years of failed policies led to economic stagnation, high crime rates and a loss of optimism in the Empire State's future.  The Governor has reversed those failed policies and turned New York into, as the state's leading business group called it, "the comeback state."  New York is coming back because Governor Pataki has:  revitalized the state's economy by cutting personal, business and property taxes; reduced bureaucratic red tape; cut workers' compensation and unemployment insurance costs and freed the private sector to create jobs for New Yorkers.  Restored hope to those on welfare, by replacing welfare with workfare for the able-bodied while ensuring the truly needy will receive the help they need and deserve.  Renewed in honest people the belief that they can live in safety, by enacting the death penalty, lengthening prison terms and ending parole for violent felons.  Returned to New Yorkers confidence in the future, by improving the state's environment, improving health care for children and ensuring that education dollars go to the classroom.
<P>
	From education to the economy, from criminal justice to environmental conservation, the Pataki formula is working.  After leading the nation for so long in raising taxes, New York now leads the nation in cutting taxes and jobs are coming back; New York now has more private sector jobs than at any other time in its history.  Once saddled with America's worst welfare system, New York has now reduced the welfare rolls by 888,317 people.  New York's welfare rolls are at their lowest level since November 1966.  Once ridiculed for crime in the streets, New York now leads major states in reducing violent crime, and New York's streets are safer than they've been in nearly 30 years.  Fiscally responsible budgeting has turned chronic budget deficits into record surpluses.  New York is also a leader in reforming child support to ensure deadbeat parents meet their obligations.  For his work, Governor Pataki in 1997 was honored with the national Golden Heart Award from the Association for Children for Enforcement of Support.  "By replacing bigger government with smarter government, by better meeting the needs of the people, we have turned crisis into comeback," Governor Pataki says.  "Yet as good as these last six years have been, the best New York is yet to come."  
<P>
	Governor Pataki's philosophy of governing is simple: believe in people, not bureaucracy; pursue smart ideas that work; and commit to sweeping, fundamental change that prepares New York for the challenges ahead.  "I believe in a government that expands personal freedoms and allows honest and responsible citizens to enjoy the benefits of their hard work," Governor Pataki says.  "I believe New York is a place where private enterprise and entrepreneurial spirit can thrive and prosper; where those who need a helping hand not only receive it, but are permitted to lift themselves to a better life.  Above all, I believe in raising the government's standards to meet the greatness of its people."  Governor Pataki's vision centers on ensuring today's children have the same opportunities that he and others of his generation were given -- to receive a quality education and build a family and a life in New York; as he says, "to have their dreams come true in New York . . . New York was always the place where we knew that tomorrow would be better than today, that our children would have a better life than we did, and their children's lives would be even better than that," the Governor says.  "That is what New York has always represented to the country and the world, and what it represented to me as a kid growing up in Peekskill."
<P>
	<B>TAXES: </B> After years of leading the nation in raising taxes, New York, under Governor Pataki, leads the nation in cutting taxes.  New  York has cut taxes more than any other state since Governor Pataki  took office, and in 1996, cut taxes more than all of the other 49 states combined.  The historic income tax cut achieved by Governor Pataki in 1995 has reduced most New Yorkers' State income tax bills by more than 25 percent.  In fact, New York ranked 13th best in the nation in State taxes as a percentage of personal income in 1998.  But the Governor's efforts to cut New Yorkers taxes haven't stopped at the State level, they've extended to the local level as well.  Under the Governor's STAR program,  New Yorkers' school taxes have been reduced an average of 27 percent; 45 percent for seniors.  New York has also eliminated the sales tax on clothing under $110, eliminated the Estate Tax, and was the first state to declare Internet access fees off-limits from state sales tax.  In six years, Governor Pataki has cut 19 taxes 57 times, saving taxpayers a cumulative $40.6 billion.  When all of the enacted tax cuts become fully effective, these savings will grow to more than $100 billion.  This year alone, $1.8 billion in previously enacted tax cuts will be phased-in, and the Governor has called for an additional $530 million in tax cuts for 2001.  One newspaper has called Governor Pataki the "Tax-Relief Governor."  "Everyone knows high taxes threaten prosperity and limit freedom," Governor Pataki says.  "Today I am proud to say that New York leads the nation in cutting taxes."
<P>

	<B>FISCAL PRUDENCE: </b> Governor Pataki has reduced the size and cost of state government like never before.  In 2000, Standard and Poor's Rating Agency rewarded New York with its best credit rating in 22 years, the state's first ever two-step upgrade to AA.  Specifically, S&P cited New York's "consistent and successful efforts to improve its financial performance, definitively reversing a long standing pattern of imbalance."  The upgrade moves New York from 2nd to last to 23rd best in the nation -- the largest single improvement in State history.  Also in 2000, Governor Pataki targeted $500 million from the Debt Reduction Reserve Fund to eliminate State debt.  This action, the largest one-time effort to reduce debt in state history, will cut debt service costs by $800 million, and provide $300 million in interest savings to taxpayers.  State spending growth has been reduced, and the state workforce has been reduced by nearly 20,000 positions since 1995 (10 percent), largely by attrition.  Agencies have been consolidated, restructured and re-organized.  In 1995, spending was reduced for the first time in 50 years.  The State's "Rainy Day" fund, a buffer against bad economic times, is funded to one of its highest levels ever.  In contrast to the $5 billion deficit inherited by Governor Pataki -- a figure that by itself was larger than the total budgets of 31 states -- New York has run six consecutive budget surpluses.  Now, for the first time in history, New York has eliminated its accumulated deficit -- an accomplishment prominently noted by Comptroller Carl McCall and hailed by independent fiscal watchdogs.  In addition dangerous budget gimmicks have been stopped.  "Our fiscal prudence has turned chronic deficits into annual surpluses," Governor Pataki says.  "Conservative budgeting and smart economic policies have allowed us to devote our resources to ideas that work."
<P>
	<B>CRIME: </B>Governor Pataki restored the death penalty and ended parole for repeat violent felons, and violent crime dropped by 25 percent.  Then after ending parole for all violent felons, violent crime dropped by 39 percent.  In just six years, New York has seen across-the-board reductions in crime. Statewide, burglary is down 43 percent. Robbery is down 49 percent. Also the rate of murder has dropped by an astounding 55 percent.  Surveys show that New Yorkers feel safer than they have in years.  Last year, Governor Pataki  and the Legislature passed the most sweeping set of anti-gun violence laws in America -- common sense laws that protect the rights of honest gun owners while keeping guns out of the hands of children and criminals.  In 2000, the Governor enacted the landmark Hate Crimes legislation into law.  Governor Pataki has declared zero tolerance for child abuse and domestic abuse.  He signed Megan's Law to notify communities when convicted child molesters move into the neighborhoods, and other laws to help authorities investigate cases of child abuse.  The Governor has won the first comprehensive reform of the sexual assault laws in more than 30 years.  "The past six years have shown that there is an irrefutable cause and effect relationship in the crime rate.  We passed tougher laws for violent criminals, the number of arrests went up, and the number of violent crimes went down," Governor Pataki says.
<P>
	<B>WELFARE: </B> When Governor Pataki took office, one in 11 New Yorkers was on welfare.  Six years of fundamental reform have since reduced the welfare rolls by an astounding 888,317 -- a drop of  54 percent.  The current level is the lowest since November 1966 .  Workfare and anti-fraud measures such as finger-imaging and drug screening are restoring welfare to its original purpose as a temporary helping hand, not a permanent handout.  Smart, new child support enforcement initiatives, such as suspending the drivers' licenses of persistent deadbeats, are working to make New York a national leader in encouraging parental responsibility.  Child-support collections are up 63 percent, helping 227,274 families move off welfare.  As a result, Governor Pataki was honored with the 1997 Golden Heart Award from the national Association for Children for Enforcement of Support.  "It's simple to tout statistics," Governor Pataki says.  "It's better to celebrate the people's victory over dependency.  And in New York, hope is winning."
<P>
	<B>JOBS: </B> Before Governor Pataki was elected, New York led the nation in job losses and lost businesses.  Now, New York State is creating jobs once again, business confidence is higher than it has been in years, and private-sector jobs are at an all-time high.  New York's private-sector has created 786,600 new jobs since Governor Pataki took office. The rate of private sector growth outpaced the nation's rate of growth in 2000.  Recent data demonstrates that upstate New York's economic growth alone has beaten the growth rate of the other Northeast and Midwest industrial states for each of the last 22 months - the best performance since record keeping began in 1959.   In 1994, New York saw only 75 new or expanded businesses.  In 2000, there were 1,121 -- a nearly 15-fold increase.  Among the most recent good news, IBM announced plans to build the world's most technologically advanced chip-making plant in East Fishkill. The investment of $2.5 billion is the largest in State history and will bring 1,000 new, permanent jobs to the Hudson Valley.  "For the first time in a decade," says Chase Manhattan, "the Empire State's private economy is growing faster than Albany's ability to throttle it with more spending, more taxes and more regulations -- and ensuring that it stays this way is priority No. 1 at the Governor's Mansion."  "New York is coming back because jobs and opportunity are coming back," Governor Pataki says.  "No longer do we say no to jobs; we say 'yes.'  We say 'yes' to families, to wage earners, to homeowners, to young people deciding where to build their lives."
<P>
	<B>EDUCATION: </B> Governor Pataki has focused attention on rewarding excellence, giving schools the resources they need but also raising standards and expectations.  State funding for education has risen by record amounts under Governor Pataki, with greater emphasis being placed on classrooms instead of administration.  Today, total funding exceeds $13.6 billion, the highest level ever.  In 2000 state aid to public schools grew by $1.2 billion or 8.7%, the largest increase ever and the fourth consecutive year of record increases.  In 2000, Governor Pataki initiated a $25 million "Teachers of Tomorrow" program which will provide more than 50,000 new teachers.  Parents are also being given new tools.  In 1998, Governor Pataki won passage of a law allowing the creation of charter schools, which give parents real choices while freeing these schools of the bureaucratic rules that often cripple creativity and innovation.  This landmark law, acknowledged by experts as one of the strongest charter school laws in the country, puts New York on the cutting edge of education reform in America.  Governor Pataki has also won approval of School Report Cards, which give parents information they need to compare their children's schools against others in New York.  And his New York Wired for Education program has wired schools to the Internet, delivered new technology to the classroom, and has vaulted New York into a national leadership role.  And it's done so with Lottery funds, reinforcing Lottery's original purpose of helping education.  On higher education, the State University of New York enjoys a growing national reputation as one of the best public university systems in America, and SUNY campuses are regularly rated among the best and most affordable schools.  Through sound fiscal restraint New York held the line on tuition at SUNY and CUNY schools for five consecutive years.  "Nothing in our future holds more promise than the vivid dreams of a child," Governor Pataki says.  "And no obligation is more fundamental than the obligation to give them a clear path to those dreams."
<P>
	<B>THE ENVIRONMENT:</B> Like his hero, Theodore Roosevelt, Governor Pataki is taking bold steps to protect New York's precious natural resources for generations to come, while continuing to promote economic growth.  His Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act provides for the most ambitious environmental restoration program in state history.  Governor Pataki brought historic adversaries together to forge an agreement on the New York City watershed.  The plan ensures a reliable water supply for New York City while ensuring the rights of property owners upstate.  He has also strengthened New York's Environmental Protection Fund to preserve sensitive lands, close dangerous landfills, reduce waste and boost recycling, and he has taken bold steps to restore and protect the Hudson River.  In every measurable way, New York's environment is getting better.  Since 1995, emissions from large factories and utilities of three of the most important air pollutants have fallen by 23 to 50%, and average smog levels downstate have fallen more than 25%.  Not stopping there, New York adopted more stringent emission standards for all light and medium duty motor vehicles, starting in 2004. Governor Pataki has also freed $80 million to help close outdated landfills, an unprecedented investment in protecting water quality.    Fresh Kills, the world's biggest landfill, will be closed in 2001.  In the 2000-2001 budget, New York became the first state in the nation to adopt the green building tax credit.  In his 2000 State of the State, Governor Pataki announced the formation of the Henry Hudson Institute for Riverine and Estuarine Research.  Governor Pataki continued his commitment to open space with purchases of 8 new tracks,  bringing the total to over 300,000 acres of environmentally sensitive land being preserved for future generations.  When the Federal government ignored Midwestern air pollution that fouls New York's air, Governor Pataki went to court to end this environmental injustice.  In 2000 Governor Pataki enacted legislation to monitor and control the sale of sulfur dioxide emission allowances to out-of-state power plants and businesses, reaffirming New York's commitment to protect the environment from acid rain  pollution.  Governor Pataki also passed legislation to require schools and daycare centers to establish pesticide notification procedures to inform staff and parents of pesticide applications, and to authorize adoption of local pesticide notification laws.  When important environmental issues were deadlocked in bitter debate, Governor Pataki provided the personal leadership needed to produce solutions.
<P>
	<B>HEALTH CARE:</B>  Under Governor Pataki, major advancements have been achieved in improving the health care of New Yorkers, particularly in areas that have vexed the state government for years -- battling breast cancer, fighting teen smoking and finding ways to improve health care for uninsured children.  Governor Pataki has expanded health care for uninsured children, and made New York's Child Health Plus program a national model that will bring quality health care to more than 530,000 previously uninsured children.  And in 2000 Governor Pataki expanded pharmacy coverage through the EPIC program to an additional 80,000 seniors.  In December 1999, Governor George E. Pataki signed into law the most comprehensive health care    legislation in the nation which will build upon the Child Health Plus program to provide health coverage.  The program is aimed at lower income adults who do not have health insurance through their employers, yet have an income which disqualifies them for other public programs. Family Health Plus will help assure that the adult family members, as well as their children, are able to receive quality health care in New York.
Governor Pataki has also begun an unprecedented campaign to steer children and pregnant women away from tobacco, and the newborn HIV testing legislation has led to a significant reduction in the number of babies being born infected with the AIDS virus.  New York now has America's strongest Managed Care Bill of Rights, protecting patients and the medical professionals who treat them.  New York has given victims of breast cancer new rights, along with new research and detection tools that will help fight breast cancer.  Governor Pataki and the Legislature in 1996 solidified New York's reputation as a national leader in quality health care by transforming the state's centralized and highly bureaucratic system of reimbursing hospitals into a system more driven by natural market forces, such as competition.  This landmark change in the state's costly and cumbersome reimbursement plan will generate long-term health care savings, and preserves New York's historic commitment to charity care and public health.

	


<P>

	Governor Pataki was born on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>June 24, 1945<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, on his <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Peekskill, New York<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, family farm, which he still runs with his family.  He is a 1967 graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Yale University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and a 1970 graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Columbia Law School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, both of which he attended on academic scholarships.  The Governor, his wife, the former <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Elizabeth (Libby) Rowland<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, and their children <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Emily<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Teddy<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Allison<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>George Owen<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> reside in <TAG name="RESCITY" value="start"/>Garrison<TAG name="RESCITY" value="end"/>, New York, along the lower Hudson River.  Before being elected Governor, George Pataki served 10 years in the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>state Legislature<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and was <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Mayor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of his hometown.  He was the youngest mayor ever of the City of Peekskill, and was re-elected with the largest plurality in the city's history.
<P>
<HR width=450 size=5>
<B>
<A HREF="family.htm">Return to the First Family</A><BR>

</BLOCKQUOTE>

</BODY>
</HTML>
ENDOFDOC

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE> <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lt.Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Mary O. Donohue<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> </TITLE>
<TITLE> Lt.Governor Mary O. Donohue </TITLE>


</HEAD>
<BODY BACKGROUND="images/purpbk.jpg" BGCOLOR="#C0C0C0" TEXT="#000000" ALINK="#FF0000" VLINK="#FF00FF" LINK="#0000FF">                                                                                                                   
<IMG SRC="images/ltgovheader.gif" WIDTH="395" HEIGHT="82" BORDER="0" ALT="lt. governor mary o. donohue">
<P>
<HR WIDTH="50%" SIZE="5" align=left>

<table align=left cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0>
<P>
<table><tr><td>

<P>

<B>BIOGRAPHY OF MARY O. DONOHUE<BR>
LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR <BR>
<TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="start"/>STATE OF <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>NEW YORK<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/></B>
<P>
Elected to serve as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor of the State of New York<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 3, 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, Mary  Donohue was an integral part of Governor Pataki's reelection team. She traveled the state campaigning on the Governor's record of cutting taxes, reducing crime, reforming government, environmental protection and creating better opportunities for individuals on welfare.
<P>
	Mary Donohue's experience as a teacher, District Attorney and State Supreme Court Justice has proven invaluable to the Governor as he continues to implement policies that have given all New Yorkers more hope, more freedom and a better quality of life. 
<P>
	In 1996, Lieutenant Governor Donohue was elected to the State Supreme Court for the seven-county Third Judicial District by an impressive 20,000 vote margin in a six-way race.  Prior to her service as the first female <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>State Supreme Court Justice<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> from Rensselaer County, the Lieutenant Governor was elected as Rensselaer County's first female <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>District Attorney<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1992, and was reelected in 1995 with an unprecedented 70 percent of the vote.
<P>
	During her tenure as District Attorney, she compiled an impressive crime-fighting record and ran for reelection with a 98 percent felony conviction rate. As District Attorney, Donohue attained wide-ranging respect for her expertise in many criminal justice areas, including domestic violence, child abuse, the death penalty and juvenile justice. She personally tried cases ranging from murder and attempted murder to sexual abuse, all of which resulted in convictions. She oversaw nearly 5,000 criminal prosecutions each year.
<P>
	Prior to her service as Judge and District Attorney, the Lieutenant Governor was a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>teacher<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and an <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>attorney<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. A graduate of the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>College of New Rochelle<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, Donohue taught elementary and junior high school in <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Rensselaer and Albany County school districts<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. During her 10-year teaching career, Lieutenant Governor Donohue earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Master's of Science in Education<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Russell Sage College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.
<P>
	In 1980, the Lieutenant Governor entered law school at <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Albany Law School of Union University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, where she earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Juris Doctor degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> in 1983. During law school, she served as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>law clerk and intern<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>U.S. Attorney's Office<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in Albany and worked on the staff of Senator Joseph L. Bruno.
<P>
	After graduating from law school, Lieutenant Governor Donohue was admitted to the New York State bar and worked as an associate attorney with <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>O'Connell & Aronowitz, P.C.<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in Albany until 1988. From 1988 to 1992, she ran her own law practice in Troy. From 1990 to1992, the Lieutenant Governor also served as Assistant Rensselaer County Attorney, representing the county in civil litigation and in Family Court, thereby gaining invaluable experience in areas including juvenile justice and other issues affecting children.
<P>
	In January 1999, Governor Pataki appointed Donohue to chair the Governor's Task Force on School Violence. For more than one year, the Lieutenant Governor held public hearings, forums, and one-on-one meetings with students to get ideas and suggestions on how to address the school violence issue. In July 2000, Governor Pataki signed into law the Safe Schools Against Violence in Education Act, a comprehensive series of  Task Force recommendations aimed at reducing violence in schools. The law will be fully implemented by the start of the 2001-02 school year.    
<P>
	In January 2000, the Lt. Governor was appointed by the Governor to chair the Quality Communities Interagency Task Force. The Task Force has spent the year studying community growth throughout The Empire State and has worked to develop measures to assist those communities in implementing effective economic, land development, preservation and rehabilitation strategies.   
<P>
												12/00
    <P>

 <HR>
 
 
 

 
 
 

</td></tr></table>

</BODY>
</HTML>
ENDOFDOC

<HTML VERSION="2.0">
<HEAD>
<TITLE><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Libby Pataki<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY BGCOLOR="#e6e6e6">
<BLOCKQUOTE>
<P><CENTER>
<FONT SIZE=5 color=000080><font face="verdana"><B>Office of the Governor</font></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE=3 color=000080><font face="arial"><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> Libby Pataki</b></font></FONT>
</CENTER>

<HR width=450 size=5>
<IMG border=0 SRC="images/libby.jpg" align=left>
<font face="arial" size=2>
<P>
Libby Pataki has actively worked with her husband, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Governor George E. Pataki<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, to reinforce the Empire State's reputation as the best place to live, work and raise a family.  Her commitment to this goal is exemplified by the groups and organizations to which she devotes her time and energies.
<P>
	Libby Pataki traveled extensively throughout the world in her youth as the daughter of a military officer.  She attended the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>American College in Paris<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, and in 1973 received a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Bachelor of Arts in Political Science with a minor in French<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Clark University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Worcester, Massachusetts.  Mrs. Pataki's professional career began at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Warner Communications<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> and continued at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Paine Webber<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> where her responsibilities included overseas trading operations.  After her marriage and the birth of their first child, Mrs. Pataki turned her attention away from the international community and towards "her own backyard" by getting involved in organizations like the Northern Westchester Center for Abused Women.
<P>
	As First Lady, Mrs. Pataki has continued the work she started nearly twenty years ago as an advocate for victims of domestic violence.  Over the past three years, Mrs. Pataki has traveled across the State visiting shelters and speaking out against domestic violence.  She has been the annual keynote speaker at the New York Coalition Against Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault.  She has also been the featured speaker at conferences addressing domestic violence among law enforcement officials, New York's immigrant population, the elderly and the disabled.  Her expertise in this area has even led to her giving testimony before the New York State Office of the Prevention of Domestic Violence and the New York State Domestic Violence Fatality Review Board.  This hard work and dedication has paid off.  The Governor has signed into the law several pieces of legislation which protect women across the State.  The violation of an order of protection is now a felony; law enforcement officials now have the discretion to arrest the "primary aggressor,"  and domestic violence is now considered in child custody hearings.
<P>

	Mrs. Pataki is also deeply dedicated to her work relating to women's health issues.  Over the past three years, she has traveled the State working with breast cancer advocates to increase public awareness of this dreaded disease.  Mrs. Pataki has proclaimed October 19, New York State Mammography Day, visited numerous health clinics for the economically disadvantaged, promoting early detection and prevention.  She has traveled the State as a featured speaker at several breast cancer benefits and even hosted her own "Celebration of Survivorship" to raise money for the American Cancer Society.  Mrs. Pataki has received several distinguished service awards for her work from organizations like the American Cancer Society and 1 in 9, a breast cancer advocacy group based on Long Island.  Mrs. Pataki's efforts have had a statewide impact.  As First Lady, she brought the Mother's Day Mammography initiative to New York.  This statewide program encourages women to schedule early mammographies.  She also worked with the New York State Department of Health to promote mobile mammography units which reach out to under serve communities and serves as a national model.  Mrs. Pataki has combined these efforts with advocacy in Albany in legislation that end the practice of "drive through" mastectomies, requires insurance companies to pay for a second opinion in the case of a diagnosis and also requires insurance companies to pay for reconstructive surgery.  Mrs. Pataki, whose mother was diagnosed in 1996 with breast cancer and who lost two aunts to the disease, considers her work on behalf of those diagnosed with breast cancer as a personal crusade.
<P>
	Mrs. Pataki is also deeply committed to children's health issues.  She has traveled the State to raise public awareness of the benefits of Folic Acid for pregnant women as well as the dangers of cigarette smoking while pregnant.  Mrs. Pataki has served as New York State Spokesperson for an anti-smoking campaign, which targets New York's youth and for "Child Health Plus," which provides health insurance to under insured children and serves as a national model.  This work has earned Mrs. Pataki national attention.  She has been named "Mother of the Year" by the Coalition on Adoptable Children and the American Cancer Society.  In 1997, she was named "Woman of the Year" by the Police Athletic League and "Outstanding Mother" by the National Mother's Day Committee.  In 1998, she was named "Women of the Year" by the Ladies Auxiliary of the Columbus Citizens Foundation, and given a humanitarian award by United Cerebral Palsy.  Mrs. Pataki's dedication to New York State's children is the direct result of the experiences she had raising her own four children: Emily, Teddy, Allison and Owen.
<P>
	Besides her four children, Mrs. Pataki finds inspiration and support in her faith.  She belongs to a non-denominational women's prayer group.  As First Lady, she hosted the first official Prayer Breakfast in Albany after learning that New York was the last state to adopt this tradition.  Each year there is a national Prayer Breakfast in Washington, D.C. Mrs. Pataki's inaugural New York State Prayer Breakfast was held a the Executive Mansion and attended by a few hundred.  Today, the event has grown to nearly a thousand people and will likely require a stadium venue in the future.  The Prayer Group Movement throughout the Empire State has found Libby Pataki a source of strength and inspiration, as have many New Yorkers.
<P>



<HR width=450 size=5>
</BODY>

<HR>
<B>
<A HREF="family.htm">Return to the First Family</A><BR>

</BLOCKQUOTE>

</HTML>

  </TD>
  <TD WIDTH="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
  <TD WIDTH="97%">  
  <!--Begin Page Content -->

<font face="Arial" size=2>
<h1>Biography of <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Bob Taft<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></h1>

<img src="images/officialtaftsmall.jpg" align="right" hspace=10><p>Since being sworn in as Ohio's 67<sup>th</sup> Governor on January 11, 1999, Bob Taft has focused on rebuilding Ohio's schools, helping every child learn to read, attracting new jobs, positioning <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Ohio<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> as a leader in technology, improving services for seniors, and restoring cities and rural communities.</p>

<p>Since his first day in office, Governor Taft's top priority has been to enable every child to succeed.  Governor Taft is implementing his 12-year plan to provide $10 billion for new school buildings so every child has a good, safe place to learn.  He is working to revise statewide academic standards and hold schools accountable for results, and his OhioReads program has recruited more than 27,000 volunteer tutors to ensure every child can read at grade level by the end of the fourth grade.  He and his wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>First Lady Hope Taft<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, lead by example as reading tutors at a Columbus elementary school.</p>

<p>Governor Taft proposed The Clean Ohio Fund, which was approved by voters, to preserve green space, waterways and parklands, and revitalize urban centers through brownfield redevelopment. </p>

<p>The Governor has increased investments in research and technology to prepare Ohio to succeed in the New Economy.  He is putting more state services online so Ohioans don't have to wait in line.</p>

<p>He also has expanded programs to help seniors remain in their own homes and has increased access to health care for thousands of children and families.</p>

<p>Governor Taft began his career in public service as a volunteer for the Peace Corps in East Africa.  He has served Ohioans as a member of the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Ohio House of Representatives<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Hamilton County Commissioner<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and as Ohio's <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Secretary of State<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>  the chief elections officer.</p>

<p>He graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Yale University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor of arts degree in government<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>, received his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>master's degree in government<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Princeton University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and earned his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Cincinnati Law School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.</p> 

<p>Governor Taft's father and grandfather both served in the United States Senate, and his great-grandfather, William Howard Taft, served as the 27<sup>th</sup> President of the United States and Chief Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court.</p>

<p>The Governor and First Lady Hope Taft have one daughter, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Anna<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.</P>
<hr>
<ul>
<li><a href="images/officialcolor.jpg">Click here to view/download an official print-quality color photo of Governor Taft.</a><br><br>
<li><a href="images/officialbw.jpg">Click here to view/download an official print-quality black and white photo of Governor Taft.</a>
</ul>

    
 
  <!-- End Page Content -->
  </TD>
  </TR>
 </TABLE>

  </FONT></a></TD>

				<td width="1" height="38"></td>
				<td width="345" height="38" colspan="1" rowspan="1" valign="top" align="LEFT" xpos="207" content csheight="35"><font color="#666666" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular"><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>OHIO<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/><br>
					<TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>MAUREEN O'CONNOR<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></font></td>
				<td width="42" height="38"></td>
				<td width="12" height="38"></td>

				<td width="400" height="70" colspan="4" rowspan="1" valign="top" align="left" xpos="206"><img src="images/navbox.gif" width="400" height="58" align="BOTTOM" border="0" vspace="4" usemap="#mainmap"> 
<!-- usemap="#navboxB30AB5DC" ismap><map name="navboxB30AB5DC"><area shape="rect" coords="311,39,389,49" href="http://www.state.oh.us/"><area shape="rect" coords="142,40,291,52" href="http://www.drc.state.oh.us/"><area shape="rect" coords="10,40,135,52" href="http://www.ocjs.state.oh.us/"><area shape="rect" coords="307,24,388,32" href="http://www.state.oh.us/dys"><area shape="rect" coords="226,24,298,32" href="http://www.state.oh.us/odps/default.asp"><area shape="rect" coords="11,25,218,33" href="http://www.state.oh.us/slg/"><area shape="rect" coords="268,8,388,16" href="mailto://"><area shape="rect" coords="188,8,260,16" href="http://www.state.oh.us/gov/"><area shape="rect" coords="98,8,176,16" href="http://www.oplin.lib.oh.us/index.cfm?ID=3&section=Discover%2520Ohio"><area shape="rect" coords="10,6,88,14" href="http://www.oplin.lib.oh.us/index.cfm?ID=3&section=Discover%2520Ohio"></map>-->


</td>
			</tr>
			<tr height="90">
				<td width="1" height="90"><spacer type="block" width="1" height="90"></td>
				<td width="389" height="641" colspan="4" rowspan="3" valign="top" align="LEFT" xpos="205" content csheight="384"><img src="images/l.gif" width="21" height="29" align="LEFT" alt="L" border="0"><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">ieutenant Governor Maureen O'Connor began her legal career as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>private attorney<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1981. After serving as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>magistrate<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in the Summit County Probate Court and a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Judge<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in the Summit County Court of Common Pleas, she was appointed as the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Summit County Prosecutor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1995. As Prosecutor, she instituted strong anti-crime measures, including career criminal prosecution and direct indictment programs. In addition, she became a vocal advocate for disadvantaged children.</font>
					<p><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">Lieutenant Governor O'Connor has actively lobbied Ohio's General Assembly to strengthen criminal legislation. She has testified before the House and Senate Judiciary Committees in support of redefining sexual conduct in order to strengthen Ohio's rape laws, and she has also been a strong advocate for establishing mandatory jail time for violent offenses resulting from gang activity.</font></p>
					<p><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">As Lieutenant Governor, O'Connor is the Chair of the </font><a href="http://www.state.oh.us/slg/"><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">State and Local Government Commission of Ohio</font></a><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">. She is also a Cabinet Member as the </font><a href="http://www.state.oh.us/odps/default.htm"><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">Director of the Ohio Department of Public Safety</font></a><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">. This Department includes the Bureau of Motor Vehicles, the State Highway Patrol, Emergency Medical Services and the Emergency Management Agency. She also serves as Governor Bob Taft's chief policy advisor on all criminal justice issues. Consequently, during the administration, she will oversee many of the policy decisions for the </font><a href="http://www.drc.state.oh.us/"><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">Department of Rehabilitation and Corrections</font></a><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">, the </font><a href="http://www.state.oh.us/dys"><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">Department of Youth Services</font></a><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular"> and the </font><a href="http://www.ocjs.state.oh.us/"><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">Offices of Criminal Justice Services</font></a><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">.</font></p>
					<p><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">Lieutenant Governor O'Connor has received numerous civic and professional organization awards, inlcuding the 1997 MADD Law Enforcement Award and the 1997 Cleveland State Distinguished Alumnae Award for Civic Achievement.</font></p>
					<p><font size="2" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">Lieutenant Governor O'Connor lives with her two teenage sons, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Alex<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Ed<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.</font></p>
					<p><img src="images/bluelinepixel.gif" width="375" height="1" align="BOTTOM" border="0"><font size="1" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular"><br>
					<a href="http://www.state.oh.us/"><img src="images/sfpicon.gif" width="89" height="30" align="RIGHT" border="0"></a></font><font size="1" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">Date of last update: <csobj w="31" h="10" t="DateTime" format="ShortDate" region="0">9/05/00</csobj><br>
					</font><a href="mailto:webmaster@das.state.oh.us"><font size="1" face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">Contact the Webmaster</font></a></td>
				<td width="12" height="90"></td>
			</tr>
			<tr height="256">
				<td width="1" height="256"><spacer type="block" width="1" height="256"></td>
				<td csgroup="087F2FFC" width="205" height="256" colspan="2" rowspan="1" valign="top" align="left" xpos="0"><img height="249" width="180" src="images/montage4.gif" border="0" usemap="#agencymap"><!--<map name="montage4b312cccb"><area href="http://www.ocjs.state.oh.us/" coords="64,200,174,245" shape="rect"><area href="http://www.drc.state.oh.us/" coords="62,158,172,195" shape="rect"><area href="http://www.drc.state.oh.us/" coords="61,106,171,151" shape="rect"><area href="http://www.state.oh.us/slg/" coords="61,37,171,96" shape="rect"><area href="http://www.state.oh.us/odps/default.htm" coords="63,1,173,27" shape="rect"></map>--></td>

<!-- hide this script from non-javascript-enabled browsers


/* Function that swaps images. */

function di20(id, newSrc) {
    var theImage = FWFindImage(document, id, 0);
    if (theImage) {
        theImage.src = newSrc;
    }
}

/* Functions that track and set toggle group button states. */

function FWFindImage(doc, name, j) {
    var theImage = false;
    if (doc.images) {
        theImage = doc.images[name];
    }
    if (theImage) {
        return theImage;
    }
    if (doc.layers) {
        for (j = 0; j < doc.layers.length; j++) {
            theImage = FWFindImage(doc.layers[j].document, name, 0);
            if (theImage) {
                return (theImage);
            }
        }
    }
    return (false);
}
// stop hiding -->
</script>

	<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" width="90%">

	<tr>
		<td width="10" valign="top"><p><br>
			<img SRC="images/tabs/biography_tab.jpg" WIDTH="22" HEIGHT="209"></td>
		<td>
		<p><br>
		<font face="Verdana,Arial,Helvetica" size="1">
		<blockquote>
		
		<center>
		
			<table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" width="90%">

				<tr>
					<td align="right" valign="bottom"><img SRC="images/biography/Ltop1-1.gif" WIDTH="130" HEIGHT="32"></td>
					<td align="left" valign="bottom"><img SRC="images/biography/Ltop1-2.gif" WIDTH="139" HEIGHT="21"></td>
				</tr>
				<tr>
					<td align="right" valign="top">
					<img SRC="images/biography/Ltop2-1.gif" WIDTH="130" HEIGHT="133" valign="top"></td>
					<td bgcolor="#660099" rowspan="4" valign="top">
							
								<table cellpadding="8" cellspacing="3" width="100%" border="0">
							
								<tr>
									<td bgcolor="#CCCCFF" valign="middle">
			

	<font face="Verdana,Arial,Helvetica" size="1" color="#660099">
<TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Hope Taft<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, married to <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Ohio<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Governor Bob Taft<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, became <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on January 11, 1999.  As Ohios First Lady, she focuses on three basic areas:  mobilizing Ohio communities to promote positive youth development emphasizing drug and alcohol prevention, encouraging and recognizing volunteerism, and promoting Ohios Bicentennial through Ohios arts and history. <p>She is a co-founder of Ohio Parents for Drug-Free Youth, the Ohio Alcohol and Drug Policy Alliance, and Cincinnatis Citizens Against Substance Abuse.  She also is an Ohio Certified Prevention Specialist II.<p>Nationally, she serves on the Presidents Commission for Drug Free Communities and the Center for Substance Abuse Treatments National Advisory County.  She joins other Governors Spouses and co-chairs <i>Leadership to Keep Children Alcohol Free</i>, an initiative sponsored by the National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism and The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation dedicated to keeping children 9-15 alcohol free.<p>In 1999, she partnered with the Greater Canton Habitat for Humanity to volunteer and build the House of Hope as part of Habitats First Ladies Build.  In 2001, she will also partners with Habitat to build 25 homes around the state of Ohio that has been entitled Circle of Hope.<p>Mrs. Taft graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Southern Methodist University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1966 with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Bachelors Degree in Business Administration<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>.  In 1993, she received an <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>College of Mount Saint Joseph in Cincinnati<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and in 2001, was granted an <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Honorary Doctorate of Education<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Cleveland State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.<p>Over the past 25 years, Mrs. Taft has volunteered and served on numerous boards of arts, cultural, civic and service organizations.  She has also received numerous honors and both state and national recognition for her volunteer public service in the areas of mental health and substance abuse prevention and treatment.<p>Mrs. Taft was born and raised in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/><TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Camden, Arkansas<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/><TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>.  She and Governor Taft were married in <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1967<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/> after meeting in Guatemala.  They lived in Southeast Asia and Springfield, Illinois before moving to Cincinnati, Governor Tafts hometown.  The Tafts have one daughter, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Anna<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.
</font>
	<p><br>

<p>


<br><p>

								</td>

						<a href="http://www.state.oh.us/gov/" target="new">Ohio Governor: Bob Taft</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;
						</font>
					
								</td>
							</tr>
						</table>
					</td>
										</tr>
									</table>
					</td>
				</tr>
			</table>


		</center>
	</center>
</center>
	</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<!doctype html public "-//w3c//dtd html 4.0 transitional//en">
<html>

<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<meta name="GENERATOR" content="Microsoft FrontPage 3.0">
<title>Governor Keating</title>
</head>

<body>
<div align="center"><center>

<table border="0" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0" width="304" height="135">
  <tr>
    <td height="58" width="200"><p align="center"><img src="fak.jpg" border="3" width="186"
    height="202"></td>
    <td height="58" width="537"><img src="http://www.governor.state.ok.us/Sprite13.jpg"
    width="464" height="55"><font color="#FF0000"><font size="4"><b>&nbsp; 25th <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of
    the <TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="start"/>State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Oklahoma<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></b></font><big><big><big> </big></big></big></font></td>
  </tr>
</table>
</center></div><div align="center"><center>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="89%">
  <tr>
    <td width="100%"><br>
    <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Frank Keating<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is the second chief executive in Oklahoma history -- and the first
    <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> -- to win election to two consecutive terms. First elected in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> and
    re-elected by a landslide in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, Keating has been one of Oklahoma&#146;s most
    reform-minded and active governors. Under his leadership, Oklahoma has become a true
    two-party state and made significant progress in education reform, tax relief,
    roadbuilding, environmental protection, economic development and public safety. Beyond
    Oklahoma&#146;s borders, Frank Keating is widely recognized as one of America&#146;s most
    articulate and able political leaders.<p>Born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>St. Louis<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>February 10, 1944<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, Keating
    moved with his family to Tulsa before he was six months old. He graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Cascia Hall
    School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Tulsa and attended <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Georgetown University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, where he completed a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degree in history<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>
    and served as student body president. He earned his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of
    Oklahoma<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1969 and became a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Special Agent<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Federal Bureau of Investigation<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>,
    serving in west coast field offices in a variety of duties. Among his investigative
    targets were new left terrorists.</p>
    <p>Keating returned to Tulsa and became an <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>assistant district attorney<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. In 1972 he was
    elected to the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Oklahoma House of Representatives<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, and in 1974 he won a seat in the
    <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Oklahoma State Senate<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, where he served for seven years, ultimately rising to the position
    of minority leader.</p>
    <p>In 1981, President Ronald Reagan appointed Frank Keating as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>United States Attorney<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for
    the Northern District of Oklahoma. He was soon chosen chairman of all of the U. S.
    Attorneys, and in 1985 he was named <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Assistant Secretary of the Treasury<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, beginning seven
    years of Washington service that would make him the highest ranking Oklahoma in the Reagan
    and Bush administrations. Keating also held the positions of Associate Attorney General in
    the Department of Justice and General Counsel and Acting Deputy Secretary at the
    Department of Housing and Urban Development. In Washington, Keating oversaw the operations
    of virtually every federal law enforcement agency, including the Secret Service, U. S.
    Customs Service, ATF, the U. S. Marshals Service, the Federal Bureau of Prisons, the
    Immigration and Naturalization Service and all 94 U. S. Attorneys. He was also the
    American representative to Interpol and was chairman of the Federal Law Enforcement
    Training Center in Glynco, Georgia. </p>
    <p>At HUD, Keating joined Secretary Jack Kemp in cleaning up that troubled agency. Near
    the end of President George Bush&#146;s administration in 1992, the President appointed
    Keating to the federal appeals bench, but partisan wrangling in Congress delayed his
    confirmation until after the 1992 election, when it was scuttled by the incoming Clinton
    administration.</p>
    <p>Keating then returned to Oklahoma and ran for Governor in 1994, first capturing a
    multi-candidate Republican primary with no runoff and then winning a 17-point victory in a
    three-way race in the general election. He was sworn in as Oklahoma&#146;s 25th governor
    in January, 1995.</p>
    <p>The first Keating term was marked by significant achievement -- and by an overwhelming
    tragedy. On April 19, 1995, a terror bomb exploded in downtown Oklahoma City, and Keating
    led a state response that drew worldwide admiration. The Governor and <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>First Lady Cathy
    Keating<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> were instrumental in organizing rescue and recovery operations and in assuring
    that those affected by the bombing received prompt assistance. They also took the lead in
    creating a $6 million fund that will provide college scholarships for children who were
    injured or who lost parents in the bombing. The Keatings were honored by the Salvation
    Army with the prestigious William Booth Award as recognition for their outstanding
    contributions to the recovery effort.</p>
    <p>In state affairs, despite an often hostile Democratic majority in both houses of the
    Legislature, Keating succeeded in winning passage of a number of significant growth and
    reform measures. He led an effort to privatize the state&#146;s teaching hospital system,
    creating a unique public-private partnership that assured quality care for the indigent
    and a stronger medical education program. Oklahoma&#146;s welfare reform law, passed in
    1995, was one of the first of its kind in the nation; by 2001 it has resulted in
    reductions in the state welfare rolls of more than 70%. The Keating road program quickly
    became the largest highway improvement and construction effort in state history, with no
    additional taxes. A special task force appointed by Keating crafted model legislation to
    safely regulate the state&#146;s growing commercial hog and poultry industries and protect
    the environment. In 1998, Keating tax cut proposals led to the largest single-year tax
    reduction in state history and the first real cut in state income tax rates in 50 years.
    His tougher parole policies and landmark truth-in-sentencing legislation had already
    turned the corner on rising crime rates, which would begin to fall in the late 1990s. As
    his first term drew to a close, Keating had presided over a period of broad prosperity and
    the creation of more than 130,000 new Oklahoma jobs.</p>
    <p>In 1998, Keating was re-elected in a landslide. His second term agenda was even more
    successful. Capping significant progress in education, which had seen state spending for
    common, vo-tech and higher education reach all-time highs, Keating won passage of a
    historic school reform measure that introduced school choice and charter schools to
    Oklahoma and which strengthened the core high school curriculum. <i>Education Week</i>
    called this reform measure one of the most important in America, and within a year
    Oklahoma&#146;s ACT scores had increased dramatically. In 2000, he supported and signed a
    $3,000 annual teach pay raise, the largest in state history. As the new century
    approached, Keating also worked successfully to establish a major new higher education
    resource in Tulsa through cooperative efforts by several state colleges and universities. </p>
    <p>At his 1999 inaugural, Keating established a series of goals for Oklahoma, including
    reductions in divorce, out-of-wedlock births, substance abuse and child abuse during the
    first decade of the new century. With First Lady Cathy Keating he organized a statewide
    initiative designed to strengthen marriage, enlisting government, community groups and the
    faith community. Reorganizations of state agencies concerned with health issues, and a
    2000 cleanup of corruption and legislative patronage at the State Health Department, also
    lent support to the pursuit of these goals, all designed to make Oklahoma a healthier
    place to live.</p>
    <p>Keating tax cuts remained a central part of his economic growth agenda in his second
    term, along with sweeping reform of Oklahoma&#146;s antiquated workers&#146; compensation
    system and passage of a Right-to-Work law. While lawmakers debated these measures, Keating
    proceeded with appointments of new workers&#146; comp judges and other measures to control
    soaring workers&#146; comp costs. As he worked for reform and tax relief on a number of
    fronts, Keating also stood firm against wasteful spending. Through his first seven
    legislative sessions he had vetoed more than 250 measures, and all of those vetoes had
    been sustained.</p>
    <p>The 2001 legislative session was historic for a number of reasons. After Republicans
    made record gains in the House and Senate in the 2000 elections, both houses finally voted
    to submit Right-to-Work for a popular vote in the fall of 2001. Governor Keating also won
    passage of a second round of tax cuts -- a further reduction in the personal income tax
    rate and the creation of Oklahoma's first-ever earned income credit system to benefit the
    poor. Most significantly, legislative leaders from both parties launched studies designed
    to competely overhaul Oklahoma's tax system, including a proposal to eliminate the
    personal income tax. Also in 2001, the Governor signed a major criminal justice reform
    bill which extended the truth-in-sentencing reforms of previous years to assure that
    career, violent and repeat offenders would remain in jail. The results were clear: for the
    fourth year in a row, most major crimes declined in Oklahoma, and the state recorded a
    25-year low murder rate. The Governor also signed a measure repealing a 31-year-old
    vehicle inspection law that had outlived its usefulness, successfully pushed for long
    overdue pay raises for state correctional officers and moved aggressively through an
    appointed gubernatorial task force to address problems associated with the Tar Creek
    Superfund site in Ottawa County.<br>
    <br>
    The second Keating term also saw his growing emergence as a national leader. Keating
    served as chairman of the Interstate Oil and Gas Compact Commission, where he became a
    leading advocate for the creation of a national energy policy. He also served as chairman
    of the Republican Governors Association and was prominently mentioned, first as a
    potential vice presidential running mate, and later as a possible cabinet member, in the
    administration of President George W. Bush. In 1999, Governor and Mrs. Keating again
    represented Oklahoma with dignity and compassion when tragic tornadoes struck many areas
    of the state.</p>
    <p>At home, the Keatings led a long overdue effort to restore and refurbish the historic
    Oklahoma Governor&#146;s Mansion with private funds. As the new century began construction
    started on a dome for the State Capitol, also funded privately. Oklahoma's capitol is the
    only one in the nation which had original plans for a dome which were not completed.
    &nbsp; In preparation for Oklahoma&#146;s statehood centennial in 2007, Keating has also
    encouraged public and private development in the vicinity of the Capitol complex to
    revitalize that area. In all three cases, private funds have provided most of the
    improvements to the Mansion and the Capitol, saving taxpayers money.</p>
    <p>Frank and Cathy Keating have three children -- daughters <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Carrie<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Kelly<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and son <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Chip<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.
    </td>
  </tr>
</table>
</center></div>

<p align="left"><em><small><a href="http://www.governor.state.ok.us">Gov's Homepage </a></small></em><br>
</p>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

    <td height="60" colspan="4" valign="top"><img src="PICS/topnav0.jpg" width="600" height="60"></td>
