  <tr> 
    <td width="152" height="735" rowspan="2" valign="top"> 
      <p><img src="PICS/ltgov.jpg" width="150" height="138" alt="Lieutenant Governor Mary Fallin"><br>
        <img src="PICS/guys.jpg" width="128" height="81" alt="Lieutenant Governor Mary Fallin"><br>
        <a href="index.htm"><img src="PICS/home.jpg" width="152" height="41" border="0" alt="Home"></a><br>
        <a href="govphotos.htm"><img src="PICS/photos.jpg" width="152" height="27" border="0" alt="Current &amp; Past Photos"></a><br>
        <a href="govnews.htm"><img src="PICS/news.jpg" width="152" height="28" border="0" alt="News Releases"></a><br>
        <a href="govevents.htm"><img src="PICS/events.jpg" width="152" height="26" border="0" alt="Scheduling Request"></a><br>
        <img src="PICS/pastgov.jpg" width="152" height="28" border="0" alt="Past Lieutenant Governors"><br>
        <a href="govintern.htm"><img src="PICS/intern.jpg" width="152" height="28" border="0" alt="Internship"></a><br> 
        <a href="govrespons.htm"><img src="PICS/respons.jpg" width="152" height="27" border="0" alt="Responsibilities"></a><br>
        <a href="govcontact.htm"><img src="PICS/contactgov.jpg" width="152" height="28" border="0" alt="Contact Lieutenant Governor"></a><a href="govlinks.htm"><img src="PICS/links.jpg" width="152" height="41" border="0" alt="Lieutenant Governor's Favorite Links"></a><br>
        <br>
        <br>
        <br>
        <a href="mailto:Ltgovernor@ltgov.state.ok.us"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">E-mail 
        the Lt. Governor</font></a></p>
    </td>
    <td width="8" height="41" valign="top"></td>
    <td colspan="2" height="502" valign="top" rowspan="2"> 
      <div align="center"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="4"><br>
        Lieutenant Governor's Biography</font></div>
      <div align="left"> 
        <center>
          <p align="left"><font size="-1" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><font size="1"><br>
            <font size="2"> &nbsp;&nbsp;Oklahomans elected <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Mary Fallin<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> in 1994 
            to serve as the state's first woman and first <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant 
            Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>. She was re-elected in 1998 by a margin of nearly three votes 
            to one.</font></font></font></p>
          <p align="left"><font size="-1" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><font size="1"><font size="2"> 
            Since 1995, Fallin has made economic development and government reform 
            the cornerstones of her administration. Governor Frank Keating appointed 
            her as Oklahoma's Small Business Advocate in 1998. In this cabinet-level 
            role, Fallin champions the legislative and individual business issues 
            which concern this vital segment of the state's economy. She formed 
            a commission of 300 business owners that works to find solutions to 
            the obstacles facing small businesses. </font></font></font></p>
          <p align="left"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"> 
            &nbsp;&nbsp;In 1997 Fallin assembled a coalition to tackle Oklahoma's 
            skyrocketing workers' compensation costs. The Fallin Commission on 
            Workers' Compensation Reform successfully guided sweeping legal changes 
            through the Oklahoma Legislature. During her first term, Fallin served 
            as Chairman of the National Conference of Lieutenant Governors. She 
            presided over the association's State/Federal meeting in Washington 
            D.C. and hosted the group's 1998 summer meeting in Oklahoma City. 
            </font></p>
          <p align="left"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"> 
            &nbsp;&nbsp;The Lieutenant Governor has been honored by the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University 
            of Central Oklahoma<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> Alumni Association as a &quot;Distinguished Former 
            Student&quot;. She was the Red Lands Council of the Girl Scouts of 
            America's 1998 Woman of the Year in Government and is recognized in 
            the Who's Who in American Politics. As a state representative, Fallin 
            was named the American Legislative Exchange Council 1993 Legislator 
            of the Year. </font></p>
          <p align="left"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"> 
            &nbsp;&nbsp;In the aftermath of the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing, the 
            Lieutenant Governor formed a task force of state, local and private 
            sector organizations to rebuild the daycare center lost in the disaster. 
            The effort culminated in summer 1998, when the YMCA Heartland Child 
            Care Center opened its doors to the children of central Oklahoma. 
            As President of the Senate, the Lieutenant Governor serves on 13 boards 
            and commissions including the Tourism and Recreation Commission, Film 
            Office Advisory Commission, State Board of Equalization, Bond Oversight 
            Commission, State Insurance Fund, Oklahoma Futures and the School 
            Land Commission. </font></p>
          <p align="left"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"> 
            &nbsp;&nbsp;In April of 2000 Fallin took the unprecedented step of 
            taking over the state Senate when several Senators believed the right-to-work 
            issue was being discussed unfairly. Thanks to her leadership and determination, 
            the Senate had a roll call vote on this issue for the first time in 
            25 years. </font></p>
          <p align="left"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"> 
            Fallin's concern over gun violence and gun safety issues prompted 
            her to develop Project HomeSafe. Project HomeSafe distributed 23,000 
            free cable gun locks to Oklahomans. For her efforts, the National 
            Shooting Sports Foundation presented her with it's &quot; Gold Lock 
            Leadership Award.&quot; </font></p>
          <p align="left"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"> 
            &nbsp;&nbsp;Lieutenant Governor Fallin has also been closely involved 
            in the issue of literacy, hosting the annual &quot;Reach for the Stars&quot; 
            banquet for the Community Literacy Center. That center raises funds 
            for literacy efforts across the state. Raised in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Tecumseh<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>, she is 
            a graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Oklahoma State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. Public service is a family 
            tradition; her father, the late Joseph &quot;Newton&quot; Copeland, 
            served as Mayor of Tecumseh. Her mother, Mary Jo Copeland, served 
            as the town's first woman mayor.<br>
            <br>
            </font></p>
        </center>
      </div>
    </td>
  </tr>
  <tr> 
    <td width="8" height="461" valign="top"></td>
  </tr>
  <tr> 
    <td width="152" height="3" valign="top"><img width="152" height="1" src="transparent.gif"></td>
    <td width="8" height="3" valign="top"><img width="8" height="1" src="transparent.gif"></td>
    <td width="390" height="3" valign="top"><img width="390" height="1" src="transparent.gif"></td>
    <td width="40" height="3" valign="top"><img width="40" height="1" src="transparent.gif"></td>
  </tr>
</table>

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN">
<html>

<head>
<meta HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<meta NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Microsoft FrontPage 3.0">
<meta NAME="Microsoft Theme" CONTENT="none">
<title><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>CATHY KEATING<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>-<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>FIRST LADY OF <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>OKLAHOMA<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>&nbsp; </title>
</head>

<body>

<p align="center"><img src="cktitle.jpg" alt="cktitle.jpg (28402 bytes)" width="253"
height="313"> </p>
<font SIZE="3">

<p><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Cathy Keating<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is a native of <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Tulsa<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> and a descendant of land run pioneers. She graduated
from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Oklahoma<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>elementary education<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> and married <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Frank Keating<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1972<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/>.
In January, 1995, she became Oklahoma's 23rd First Lady when her husband was sworn in as
Governor.</p>

<p>In her hometown of Tulsa, Mrs. Keating was an active community volunteer in a variety
of causes; in 1984 she was nominated by the Junior League of Tulsa for the Good
Housekeeping Women of the Year award. She has also been a successful operator of her own
business. As First Lady, she has been active in a number of community efforts. She has
served as honorary state chair for the American Cancer Society's Project Woman, chaired
the annual Race for the Cure event for six years and helped organize numerous statewide
programs on women's health issues. She is also extremely active in the work of Habitat for
Humanity and has helped organize and lead a nationwide series of First Ladies Build
projects in all of the capital cities that&nbsp; involve women in constructing new homes
for the working poor. She also sits on the Habitat International Women's Build Steering
Committee. </p>

<p>Mrs. Keating served as a member of the National Trust for Historic Preservation and has
also been a prime mover in the state's Main Street effort to preserve and revitalize
historic downtown business districts in many Oklahoma communities. For her efforts in
historic preservation, she recently received the Shirk Memorial Award from the Oklahoma
Historical Society. She and Governor Keating served as co-leaders of Oklahoma's delegation
to the national America's Promise symposium. They then organized a statewide summit on
mentoring and volunteerism -- and put those principles to work as volunteer literacy
tutors for Oklahoma City school children. Mrs. Keating has also been a frequent guest
reader in hundreds of Oklahoma elementary schools, where she shares her enthusiasm for
reading and learning with young people. She was honored with the Champions for Children
Award by the Helping One Student To Succeed (HOSTS) Corporation.</p>

<p>Motivated by the importance of tradition, Mrs. Keating organized an annual holiday tree
lighting program at the State Capitol, adding live Christmas trees to the Capitol grounds;
her goal is to have one hundred trees planted on the grounds by the state's centennial
celebration in 2007. In 1997 she launched Septemberfest, a fall celebration of Oklahoma's
heritage and diverse culture that draws thousands of families to the Governor's Mansion
each year.</p>

<p>Shortly after she became First Lady, Mrs. Keating helped found Friends of the Mansion,
Inc., a non-profit foundation dedicated to restoring and preserving Oklahoma's historic
Governor's Mansion. She then led the most ambitious effort in state history to refurbish
and permanently furnish the mansion. By hosting a statewide open house, she involved
private groups and individual Oklahomans in this effort, which was later featured in an
article in <i>Architectural Digest</i> magazine. In 1998, Friends of the Mansion oversaw
construction of the new Phillips Pavilion on the Mansion grounds, the first major addition
to Oklahoma's executive residence since the 1920s. Mrs. Keating also oversaw the opening
of a Mansion Gift Shop that sells specialty items with an Oklahoma flair, and a gift cart
at the State Capitol; all proceeds benefit mansion preservation efforts. The Mansion is
once again &quot;Oklahoma's House,&quot; home to many special events each year.</p>

<p>The mansion restoration project led Mrs. Keating to publish <i>Our Governors' Mansions</i>,
a lavish pictorial and text tour of the executive residences of all of the states.<i> Our
Governors' Mansions</i>, published by Harry N. Abrams, Inc., and with a foreword by the
late Charles Kuralt, is in its fifth printing and is widely regarded as the definitive
work on the subject of the &quot;little White Houses&quot; of the states. All proceeds
from the book benefit Friends of the Mansion, Inc.</p>

<p>On two occasions, Mrs. Keating has joined Governor Keating and her fellow Oklahomans in
responding to crises. Following the April 19, 1995 terror bombing of the Murrah Federal
Building in Oklahoma City, she helped lead relief efforts and became an eloquent
spokesperson for Oklahoma. After the bombing, she coordinated the internationally
broadcast prayer service and publication of <i>In Their Name</i> with Random House. The
book, an oral history telling Oklahoma's stories from April 19, was a national best seller
and raised more than $1 million for bombing relief. Because of their effective and visible
efforts on behalf of bombing victims, Governor and Mrs. Keating were featured as NBC's
&quot;People of the Week&quot; and received the William Booth Award from the Salvation
Army. </p>

<p>In May, 1999, Mrs. Keating was again called upon to assist Oklahomans, following a
series of devastating tornadoes that struck many areas of the state. She helped raise
funds and material donations for those who suffered losses in the storms.</p>

<p>While she is the most publicly active First Lady in Oklahoma's history, Mrs. Keating is
first of all a wife and a mother. She and Governor Keating have three children -- daughter
<TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Carrie<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, a law student; daughter <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Kelly<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, a graduate of Southern Methodist University, and
son <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Chip<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, a college student.. </font></p>

<p><small><font color="#000000" face="Arial"><br>
&nbsp; <br>
<img SRC="bl_pin.gif" HEIGHT="21" WIDTH="21">E Mail Barby Jobe, First Lady's Chief of
Staff: <a HREF="mailto:barby.jobe@gov.state.ok.us">barby.jobe@gov.state.ok.us</a><a
HREF="firstladyphoto.htm"></a> </font></small></p>

<p><small><font color="#000000" face="Arial"><a href="firstladyphoto.jpg">For high
resolution picture of Mrs. Keating, click here&nbsp; (292k) .JPEG </a><br>
<a HREF="firstladyphoto.htm"></a>&nbsp; </font></small></p>

<p><font color="#000000" face="Arial" size="1"><a href="index.html">Governor's Homepage</a></font></p>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<HTML>

<HEAD>

<META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Internet Assistant for Word 1.0Z">
<META NAME="AUTHOR" CONTENT="Office of the Budget">
<TITLE><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Tom Ridge<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> - Biography</TITLE>
</HEAD>

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF">

<CENTER><H2><B>Governor Tom Ridge</B></H2>
<H3><B>Biography</B></H3></CENTER>

<P>
<CENTER><NOBR><IMG SRC="graphics/boy_T_Ridge.gif" ALIGN="BOTTOM">
              <IMG SRC="graphics/soldier_T_Ridge.gif" ALIGN="BOTTOM">
              <IMG SRC="graphics/governor_T_Ridge.gif" ALIGN="BOTTOM"></NOBR><BR>
As a boy in Erie, PA | As a soldier in Vietnam | As Governor of Pennsylvania</CENTER>

<P><CENTER><IMG SRC="/graphics/rwb_line.gif" ALIGN="BOTTOM"></CENTER></P>

<P>
<b>Career:</b><br>
Born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Pittsburgh's Steel Valley<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, Governor Ridge was raised in a working-class family in veterans' public housing in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Erie<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>.  He earned a scholarship to <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Harvard<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, graduating with honors in 1967.  After his first year at <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>The Dickinson School of Law<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, he was drafted into the U.S. Army, where he served as an <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>infantry staff sergeant<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in Vietnam, earning the Bronze Star for Valor.  After returning to Pennsylvania and earning his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>, he became an <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>assistant district attorney<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in Erie County.  He was elected to <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Congress<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1982, a <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> in a heavily Democratic district.  He was the first enlisted Vietnam combat veteran elected to the U.S. House, and was overwhelmingly re-elected six times.
<P>
<B>Election History:</B><br>
Governor Ridge was sworn in as Pennsylvania's 43rd governor on January 17, 1995. Ridge's performance was affirmed decisively on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 3, 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, when voters re-elected him with 57 percent of the vote in a four-way race.  Ridge's vote percentage was the highest for a Republican governor in Pennsylvania (where Democrats outnumber Republicans by almost 500,000) in more than half a century.  His 780,000-vote victory margin was the largest for a Republican governor in state history.
<P>
<B>Accomplishments:</B><br>
Governor Ridge has kept his promise to make <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Pennsylvania<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> "a leader among states and a competitor among nations."  In May 2000, he signed the largest tax cut in state history -- nearly $775 million.  Governor Ridge has cut taxes every year he's been in office.  Since 1995, Pennsylvania families and employers have saved nearly $15 billion through tax cuts, workers' compensation reform, reduced red tape and electric competition.  These savings helped to create more than 350,000 new jobs.  PA has one of the nation's lowest personal income tax rates and the most competitive utility markets -- the first state to enable consumers to shop competitively for both electricity and natural gas.  PA has been named the No. 1 state for electric deregulation.  And PA's tax-free Keystone Opportunity Zones were named the No. 1 statewide economic-development strategy.   Governor Ridge signed the nation's first model E-commerce law.  He eliminated the state tax on computer services.  And, to close PA's "Digital Divide," he created a first-in-the-nation "Tax-Free PC" holiday.
<P>
Education reform always will be Governor Ridge's top priority.  In May 2000, he signed into law the Education Empowerment Act, to help more than a quarter-million kids in PA's lowest-performing schools.  He won passage of charter public schools; alternative education for disruptive students; professional development for teachers; and new standards requiring future teachers to earn higher grades in harder courses.  He made an historic $125 million investment in reading and libraries, and he invested more than $200 million in education technology.  In all, state support of Pennsylvania public schools has increased at nearly twice the rate of inflation.  And Governor Ridge continues to fight for school choice for Pennsylvania parents and children.  
<P>
Pennsylvania also has become a national leader in developing a new environmental partnership.  Governor Ridge's common-sense Land Recycling Program is a national model; there now are more than 20,000 people working on nearly 800 formerly abandoned industrial sites.  In 1999, he won passage of "Growing Greener," to make PA's largest environmental investment ever, nearly $650 million.  In 2000, Governor Ridge won his "Growing Smarter" land-use plan, to give communities new land-use tools to control sprawl, while still respecting private property rights.  
<P>
More than 100,000 children now get free or low-cost health care through PA's nationally recognized Children's Health Insurance Program -- a 145 percent increase since Governor Ridge took office in 1995.  And Pennsylvania's welfare rolls are at their lowest point in three decades.  Since Governor Ridge and the General Assembly made sweeping changes to the state's welfare system in 1996, more than 210,000 families have left the welfare rolls and have not returned.
<P><CENTER><IMG SRC="/graphics/rwb_line.gif" ALIGN="BOTTOM"></CENTER></P>

<center>
<table border="0" bgcolor="#FFFFFF" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="604">
<tr><td valign="top" width="88"><img src="graphics/capitol-brightF2.jpg" border="0" alt="Capitol" width="88" height="463"></td>
<td valign="top" width="516"><img src="graphics/titletopbar.gif" USEMAP="#TopTileBar" alt="Title Bar" border="0" width="516" height="15">
 <BR><DL>
<font face="Verdana" size="2">
<DT></DT>
<DD><STRONG>Biography</STRONG>
<p>
Elected along with Tom Ridge in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, Mark Schweiker was sworn in as Pennsylvania's 28th Lieutenant Governor on January 17, 1995.  As <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, he Constitutionally presides over the state Senate and chairs the state's Board of Pardons.  The Constitution also provides that the Lieutenant Governor shall assume the powers and duties of Governor in certain circumstances of the governor being unable to.
<P>
As a trusted and valued partner of Governor Tom Ridge, Lieutenant Governor Mark Schweiker worked with the Governor to change <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Pennsylvania<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> - and they did!  Since their first day in office they have brought opportunities back to our communities, they brought safety to Pennsylvania's streets, they improved the state's jobs climate and they have strengthened Pennsylvania's education system.
<P><img src="graphics/personal.jpg" alt="LG's Photos" width="410" height="149" border="0"><p>
Through an unprecedented partnership, Governor Ridge and Lieutenant Governor Schweiker have successfully overhauled Pennsylvania's Office of the Lieutenant Governor to better serve all Pennsylvanians.  They've expanded the Lieutenant Governor's responsibilities far beyond the traditional and ceremonial areas into new, forward-thinking policy fronts relevant to Pennsylvanians' needs for the 21<sup>st</sup> Century.
<P>
What does all this mean for Pennsylvania?  Better service.  Better service for the Commonwealth's residents, employers and communities.  With the duties of the second highest office in the state being enhanced, Mark Schweiker has been able to accomplish more for Pennsylvania and its communities.
<p>
<center><b>WEED AND SEED</b></center>
<br>
              Making Pennsylvania's communities safer and more prosperous has 
              been a major focus for Governor Ridge and Lieutenant Governor Schweiker. 
              Among several key Ridge Administration community building initiatives, 
              Lieutenant Governor Schweiker leads the state's very successful<a href="http://www.weedseed.state.pa.us">  
              Pennsylvania Weed and Seed</a> initiative. The first state-sponsored 
              program of its kind in the nation, Pennsylvania Weed and Seed seeks 
              to "weed" out crime through a collaborative law enforcement partnership 
              between local and state police and "seed" in growth and opportunity 
              by rebuilding the community through citizen-driven change.<p> "There 
              are always doubters. What we have to do is create a few more believers 
              in our communities every day." <br> Lt. Governor Mark Schweiker, addressing 
              the Pennsylvania League of Cities and Municipalities, June 14, 2001. <p>
              Based on the concept of the Federal Weed and Seed program targeting 
              large metropolitan regions, the state model expands the seed effort 
              and delivers the program to smaller Pennsylvania towns and cities. 
              Currently the Pennsylvania Weed and Seed initiative is being utilized 
              in Chester, Easton, Lancaster, Norristown, York, Reading, and McKeesport.<br>
              The Pennsylvania Weed and Seed initiative is now a permanent part 
              of Pennsylvania's community building effort, enacted by Governor 
              Ridge's signing of<a href="http://www.legis.state.pa.us/WU01/LI/BI/ALL/2001/0/HB1048.HTM"> House Bill 1048 </a> as Act 30 of 2001. <p><br>
			  
			  <center><b>PRIME INITIATIVE</b></center><br>
              Promising to make state government more customer-centered, cost 
              efficient, and accountable to taxpayers, Governor Ridge and Lieutenant 
              Governor Schweiker launched the <a href="http://www.prime.state.pa.us">PRIME </a>initiative. This innovative 
              approach to serving citizens has saved Pennsylvanians over $650 
              million and has become a national model. Under the day-to-day leadership 
              of Lieutenant Governor Schweiker, PRIME is dramatically changing 
              the way state government does business. One example of this initiative 
              is that driver license and registration renewals are now available 
              online from PENNDOT. These documents can now be renewed in a few 
              days, rather than the several weeks it used to take. Ted Gaebler-the 
              father of government reinvention-highlighted PRIME in his most recent 
              book, "Positive Outcomes: Raising the Bar on Government Reinvention." 
              Citizens Against Government Waste honored Lieutenant Governor Schweiker 
              with its prestigious "Outstanding Achievement Award for Putting 
              Taxpayers First." 
            <p><br>
			<center><b>LOCAL GOVERNMENT</b></center><br>

	Tapping into his Lieutenant Governor's experience as a township supervisor and county commissioner, Governor Ridge tasked Lieutenant Governor Schweiker  formulating various policy initiatives concerning local governments and communities.  As chair of the state's Local Government Advisory Committee, which oversees the <a href="http://www.inventpa.com/default.asp?path=Communities%20in%20PA/Governor%27s%20Center%20for%20Local%20Government%20Services">Governor's Center for Local Government Services </a>, Lieutenant Governor Schweiker helped build the strong partnership that has emerged between state and local governments in the Commonwealth.<br>
	As an example of this leadership, the lieutenant governor worked closely with members of the General Assembly and local officials to craft and pass a new law to give local communities better ability to direct growth and development to areas suited for this.  

	<p>"The recent (June ,2001) flooding in southeastern Pennsylvania showed us dramatically that haphazard development, and the great increase in the amount of impervious surface that prevents absorption of rainfall upstream, can have a tremendous and potentially devastating impact on communities downstream.  Tropical storm Allison's "waterbomb" dropped on southeastern Pennsylvania shows us why our municipalities have to work together."  Lt. Governor Mark Schweiker, addressing the Pennsylvania Association of Township Commissioners, June 25, 2001
<p>
	Lieutenant Governor Schweiker is now leading efforts by the Governor's Center for Local Government Services to encourage regional cooperation among Pennsylvania's townships, boroughs and cities, in areas such as planning and zoning.   He is also actively supporting the sharing of services by neighboring municipalities, to help deliver better services to local governments' customers-their citizens-at a lower cost.  Under the lieutenant governor's leadership, the Governor's Center for Local Government Services is offering free studies and start up costs for regional police forces, and Shared Municipal Services Grants for communities that band together on everything from purchasing heavy equipment to hiring inspectors to enforce the state's new Uniform Construction Code for residential and commercial buildings.
 <p><br>
  <center><b>TECHNOLOGY</b></center><br>

	As the Governor's chief information technology advocate, Lt. Governor Schweiker interacts directly with the state's newly-devised "Technology Cabinet"-comprised of state agency heads with a keen focus on integrating new technologies throughout state government.  The cabinet's work is instrumental in the overall success of the key Ridge Administration initiative <a href="http://www.inventpa.com">Come Invent the Future</a>, which is geared to keeping the Commonwealth's best and brightest young people right here in Pennsylvania.

<p><br><center><b>EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT</b></center><br>

	As Chairman of the <a href="http://www.pema.state.pa.us">Pennsylvania Emergency Management Council</a>, Lieutenant Governor Schweiker directs the disaster response programs for the Commonwealth, a role highlighted during the blizzard/flood of 1996, and enhanced by the Lieutenant Governor's hands-on involvement with Pennsylvania's Counter-Terrorism initiative-considered a leading national model by the emergency response and law enforcement community.
<BR>
              As a Bucks County Commissioner, Schweiker pushed for and achieved 
              installation of the county's enhanced 911 emergency service, the 
              first such service in southeastern Pennsylvania. Under his direction, 
              the Emergency Management Council has advanced the effort between 
              the state, county, and local level emergency operating centers-resulting 
              in better service to the emergency responders, volunteers, and ultimately, 
              to all citizens of Pennsylvania. Recognizing the need to recruit 
              the next generation into the fire service, the lieutenant governor 
              is also actively supporting Pennsylvania's first-in-the-nation <a href="http://www.videopa.com/ramfiles/oa/firefighter.ram
			  ">Youth Firefighter Apprentice Program </a>, which helps local fire companies 
              establish and structure comprehensive training for young people 
              interested in joining the fire service. 
            <p><br><center><b>PERSONAL BIO</b></center><br>
		
		

	Mark Schweiker was born on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>January 31, 1953<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Levittown, Bucks County<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, the son of John and Mary Schweiker.  He is a graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Bishop Egan High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Bachelor of Science degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Bloomsburg University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1975.  He also holds a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>master's degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> in administration from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Rider University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.  After college, he entered the business world and advanced to executive positions at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Merrill Lynch<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>McGraw Hill<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, and his own management-consulting firm.  He served as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Middletown Township Supervisor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> from 1980-1987, and as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Bucks County Commissioner<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> from 1988-1994.
	<BR>He is married to the former <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Katherine (Kathy) Reichert<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, a native of Philadelphia and a graduate of John W. Hallahan Catholic Girls High School and the Philadelphia College of Textiles and Science.  They have three children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Brett<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Eric<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Kara<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.


		
			  
          </dd></font><dl><font face="Verdana" size="2">
</font>
</dl></dl></td>
</tr>
</table></center>
<P>

			<TR>
				<TD>
					<IMG SRC="../graphics/about.JPG" WIDTH="640" HEIGHT="105" BORDER="0">

			<TR>
				<TD><CENTER>
						<U><FONT SIZE="8" COLOR="NAVY">BIOGRAPHY</FONT></U>
					</CENTER> <BR>
					<IMG SRC="../graphics/pinkM.JPG" WIDTH="290" HEIGHT="38" BORDER="0">
					<Font SIZE="5">
						<BR>
							<B><EM>
								First Lady of the Commonwealth of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Pennsylvania<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
							</EM>
						</B> 
					</FONT>
					</P>
					As <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, Mrs. Ridge is dedicated to many family issues including the 
					prevention of youth violence and domestic abuse, education, literacy, breast 					 cancer awareness, child safety, and eradicating hunger. <P>
					
					Her signature project, the Governor's Community Partnership for Safe
					Children, is a community based initiative that seeks to curb 
					youth violence by reducing child abuse, drug and alcohol abuse, 
					academic failure, illiteracy, and other factors that make children
					more likely to commit crime.<P>
					
					In recognition of her commitment to Pennsylvania's children, the
					First Lady has addressed the U.S. House of Representative's
					Subcommittee on Housing and Community Opportunity and has been a 
					guest lecturer at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard
					University.<P>
					
					As Honorary Chair of the Pennsylvania Breast Cancer Coalition, 
					Mrs. Ridge has actively promoted breast cancer awareness through
					public service announcements, speaking engagements and educational
					conferences.  She has been instrumental in the expansion of the Rite Aid Corporation's
					Mother's Day Mammograms&copy Program, which offered free mammograms to women in twenty-four states and the District of Columbia in 1999. <p>
					<IMG SRC="../graphics/bio-1.JPG" WIDTH="165" HEIGHT="230" BORDER="2" ALIGN="RIGHT">
					Born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Erie, Pennsylvania<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>February 25, 1947<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Michele M. Ridge<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is the oldest child of the late Army Major Howard Moore and the late Margaret Nagle Moore.  Due to her father's military career, Mrs. Ridge, her brother William and her sister Maureen lived throughout the country and abroad, including a six-year residency in Europe.  She returned to Erie in her junior year of high school where she attended <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Strong Vincent High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, graduating in 1965.  Mrs. Ridge received her <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Bachelor's Degree in European History<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Seton Hill College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1969, and earned her <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Master's Degree in Library Science<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Pittsburgh<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1971.<p>
					
					Well-respected in the field of library science and literacy, Mrs. Ridge was <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>director of the Erie County Library System<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for nearly 16 years, where she managed a central library and six branches.<p>
					
					The Governor and Mrs.  Ridge have two children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Lesley<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and 
					<TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Tommy<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.  Three yellow labrador retrievers, "Allie," "Molly" 
					and "Gus," complete the family.
					<P>				
				</TD>		
			</TR>
		</TABLE>

<html>

<head>
<meta Name="GENERATOR" Content="Microsoft FrontPage 3.0">
<title>Almond Bio</title>
</head>

<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF">

<table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="6">
  <tr>
    <td align="left" valign="top"><p align="left"><img src="Images/anchor2.jpg" alt="State Seal" WIDTH="225" HEIGHT="170"><br clear="left">
    <br clear="left">
    <font face="Arial" size="3"><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <br>
    <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Lincoln Almond<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/><br>
    Office of the Governor<br>
    222 State House<br>
    Providence, RI 02903-1196<br>
    (ph) 401-222-2080<br>
    (fax) 401-861-5894</font><br>
    </td>
    <td align="left" valign="middle"><font size="5"><blockquote>
      <p align="center"></font><img src="Images/Home%20Page/linc_01.jpg" alt="linc_01.jpg (21300 bytes)" WIDTH="504" HEIGHT="86"></p>
    </blockquote>
    <hr>
    <p>In <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, Lincoln Almond was elected <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of the <TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="start"/>State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Rhode Island<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, making him
    the first Governor of Rhode Island to serve a four-year term.&nbsp;&nbsp; In 1998, Rhode
    Island voters re-elected Lincoln Almond to serve a second four-year term as Governor based
    on his pledge to govern with honesty and integrity, to restore Rhode Islanders' faith in
    their elected leaders, and to fight for quality jobs for all Rhode Islanders.</p>
    <p><em><img src="Images/Bio%20Page/almonds.jpg" align="right" border="0" alt="Photograph of Governor Lincoln Almond &amp; First Lady Marilyn Almond" width="199" height="272"></em> One of his first acts as Governor was to reorganize the state's
    Department of Economic Development, establishing a quasi-public agency charged with
    providing Rhode Island's employers with the tools needed to remain competitive and fuel
    job growth. </p>
    <p>As chairman of the board of directors of the RI Economic Development Corporation,
    Governor Almond has taken an active role in encouraging economic expansion in Rhode
    Island. In 1995, the Governor announced that Fidelity Investments, the multi-billion
    dollar mutual fund giant, would build a major facility in northern RI, leading to the
    creation of up to 2,500 quality jobs. In May 1997, the Governor joined Fleet Bank Chairman
    and CEO Terrence Murray to announce the bank's plan to build a Regional Service Center in
    northern RI, eventually employing up to 2,000 workers. The Governor continues his push for
    new job development, working aggressively to promote the port at Quonset Point/Davisville
    as one of the state's premier economic development assets that will fuel the state's
    economy in the next century.</p>
    <p>Economic development is not new to Governor Almond. He is the former President of the
    Blackstone Valley Development Foundation, Inc., considered the most successful private,
    non-profit land development organization in the state. He has also served as vice chairman
    of the Northern Rhode Island Economic Development Partnership.</p>
    <p>Almond is a member of the National Governors' Association (NGA) where he serves on the
    Economic Development Committee. He also serves on NGA's Legal Affairs Committee, which
    advises fellow governors on whether or not the NGA should take legal positions on matters
    pending before the U.S. Supreme Court.&nbsp; Almond was the 1998 Chair of the Coalition of
    Northeastern Governors (CONEG) and the 1997 Chair of the New England Governors'
    Conference.&nbsp; </p>
    <p>Prior to his election as Rhode Island's 56th Governor, Lincoln Almond served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>U.S.
    Attorney<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for over 20 years, receiving his original appointment to that post in 1969. He
    was reappointed by President Reagan in 1981 and served until 1993. He emphasized
    enforcement in the area of organized crime, drugs and white collar crime, including
    corruption.</p>
    <p>Prior to his service as U.S. Attorney, Almond was appointed <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Town Administrator<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of
    Lincoln, RI in 1963 and elected to full terms in 1963, 1965 and 1967. As administrator,
    Almond emphasized economic development, significant water system capital improvements to
    support development, and an ambitious school construction program. Concerned about
    conservation, he supported a program which today maintains a third of Lincoln as open
    space.</p>
    <p>Lincoln Almond earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Boston University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1961 and a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Bachelor of
    Science degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Rhode Island<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1959. A life-long Rhode Island
    resident, Almond is a graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Central Falls High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and was inducted into the
    Central Falls Hall of Fame in 1992--only the fourth person so honored. He is married to
    the former <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Marilyn Johnson<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> of Woonsocket, also a URI graduate, and they have two grown
    children and five grandchildren.</p>
    <div align="center"><center><table border="0" width="38%">
      <tr>
        <td width="100%"><p align="center"><img src="Images/Bio%20Page/firstfamily.jpg" alt="firstfamily.jpg (26252 bytes)" WIDTH="300" HEIGHT="220"></td>
      </tr>
    </table>
    </center></div><p align="center"><a href="Default.htm"><font face="Arial"><strong>Return
    to Home Page</strong></font></a></td>
  </tr>
</table>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<html>

<head>
<title>Lieutenant Governor Fogarty</title>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
</head>

<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
<div id="Layer1"
style="position:absolute; left:13px; top:182; width:174px; height:216px; z-index:1">

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">State House</font></p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">Room 116</font></p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">Providence, RI 02903 </font></p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">(401) 222-2371 </font></p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">(401) 222-2012 Fax</font></p>

<p><a href="mailto:riltgov@ltgov.state.ri.us"><font face="Arial" size="1">riltgov@ltgov.state.ri.us</font></a></p>
</div><div id="Layer2"
style="position:absolute; left:300px; top:205; width:400; height:277px; z-index:2"><font
face="Arial" size="1">

<p>The people of the <TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="start"/>State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Rhode Island<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/> elected <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Charles J. Fogarty<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> to the Office of
<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>. Prior to taking office on January 5, 1999, he served for
eight years as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>State Senator<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> representing the 27<sup>th</sup> District. His leadership
roles in the Senate included Majority Whip and most recently Senate President Pro Tempore.</font>
</p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">For 13 years, Mr. Fogarty served in <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>senior policy positions<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>
in the executive branch of state government, working for: Gov. J. Joseph Garrahy, the
Commissioner of Education and in the offices of General Treasurer and Lieutenant Governor
. He graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Providence College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and earned his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>MPA degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of
Rhode Island<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.</font></p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">Lieutenant Governor Fogarty is Chairman of the
Long-Term-Care Coordinating Council, Vice Co-Chair of the Governor&#146;s Advisory Council
on Health, Chair of the Small Business Advocacy Council and Chair of the Emergency
Management Advisory Council, Chair of Rhode Island Reads, and Chair of the
Intergovernmental Relations Council.. He is Treasurer of the National Conference of
Lieutenant Governors (NCLG), where he is also chairman of the finance committee and a
member of the executive committee.&nbsp; He also serves on the Executive Committee of the
Eastern Region Conference of State Governments (CSG).</font></p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">As a State Senator, Mr. Fogarty successfully authored and
sponsored legislation on health care, pension reform, education and environmental issues.
Some of his most notable bills passed into law include legislation requiring lifetime
supervision for child molesters; graduated licenses for teenage drivers; the Home Care
Client Bill of Rights; and the law that gives tax breaks to companies that suffer
disasters. For his Health Quality Performance Measurement and Reporting Law, Fogarty&nbsp;
was awarded the James E. Carney Public Health Legislation Award by the Department of
Health.</font></p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">A recognized leader in the area of public health ,
Fogarty&#146;s first act as Lieutenant Governor was to author legislation to create the
&quot;21<sup>st</sup> Century Health Care Fund&quot; which would have restricted all money
from the settlement with the tobacco companies to health care initiatives and tobacco
control efforts.&nbsp; He continues his fight on this issue today and has successfully
championed efforts to lower teen smoking.</font></p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">Through his role as chairman of the
Long-Term-Care-Coordinating Council, Fogarty is also a recognized leader and strong
advocate on many issues affecting senior citizens. He has repeatedly and successfully
fought to expand the state's RIPAE program, which provides pharmaceutical assistance to
low-income seniors, and is currently working to expand the program to cover all senior
citizens and to cover all FDA approved prescriptions.&nbsp; He is also&nbsp; a founding
member of the NortheastLegislative Conference on Prescription Drug Pricing which is
investigating&nbsp; ways to address the high price of pharmaceuticals.</font></p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">In 1998, Mr. Fogarty was honored by Save the Bay for
authoring what is recognized nationally as the toughest oil spill prevention legislation
in the country.&nbsp; He is the first and only elected official to receive Save the
Bay&#146;s Environmental Achievement Award.</font></p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">During his tenure in the Senate, Fogarty was named
&quot;Legislator of the Year&quot; by a number of groups, including the Rhode Island
Department of Health, the Rhode Island Council of Community Mental Health Centers, the
Rhode Island Chapter of the National Federation of the Blind and the Rhode Island Chapter
of the National Association of Social Workers. In 1996 he was named &quot;National
Legislator of the Year&quot; by the Biotechnology Industry Organization.</font></p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">He has also received awards from Rhode Island Housing, the
Rhode Island Home Care Partnership, the Alliance for Better Nursing Home Care, the AARP,
and the National Guard Association of the United States, the Rhode Island Academy of
Family Physicians &quot;Lucious Garvin Award&quot;, and the South County Hospital
Trustee's Award.</font></p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">Since becoming Lieutenant Governor he has also recieved
awards and honors from the American Legion of Rhode Island, the Disabled American Veterans
of Rhode Island, and Constantinian University, the Rhode Island Public Health Association,
and the American Cancer Society.</font></p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">Lieutenant Governor Fogarty serves on the Board of
Directors of the Rhode Island Chapter of the American Red Cross and the Northwest
Community Nursing and Health Services.</font></p>

<p><font face="Arial" size="1">For more information, please contact Susan Pegden,
Communications Director, at 401-222-3844.</font> </p>
</div>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><font face="Arial" color="#004080" size="+4">Biography</font></p>

<p>&nbsp; </p>

<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" BORDER="0">

    <TD><IMG SRC="images/sub_centercolumncap.gif" WIDTH=308 HEIGHT=41 BORDER=0 ALT="The South Carolina Governor's Office"></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><BR><DIV CLASS="bodytitle"><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>The Honorable<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jim Hodges<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></DIV>
		<DIV CLASS="body">Education has always been the top priority of Jim Hodges, the 114th <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>South Carolina<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>.<BR><BR>

As Governor, Jim Hodges has kept his promise to "focus like a laser-beam on improving our schools." South Carolina now leads the nation in SAT improvement. In fact, SAT scores have increased more over the last two years than in the past ten years combined. According to Education Week magazine, South Carolina now ranks fourth in the nation in improving teacher quality and sixth in promoting accountability. <BR><BR>

Last November, South Carolina voters overwhelmingly approved Hodges' education lottery initiative to fund college scholarships, free technical education and classroom technology.  The education lottery is the cornerstone of Governor Hodges' comprehensive education reform agenda, which also includes approval of $1 billion for school construction without raising taxes and the First Steps to School Readiness preschool initiative. This year, Hodges has launched an ambitious initiative to raise teacher pay to the national average within six years.<BR><BR>

Governor Hodges has advanced a number of other common-sense, conservative initiatives. Among these are the state's first sales tax holiday and the South Carolina SilverCard, offering prescription drug coverage for our state's senior citizens.<BR><BR>

As a young man in Lancaster, Jim Hodges continued his family's tradition of working summers in the textile mills to pay for his college education. He earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>business degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of South Carolina<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1979, and a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>USC School of Law<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1982. He is a member of Phi Beta Kappa.<BR><BR>

Governor Hodges was first elected to the South Carolina <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>House of Representatives<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1986. He served for 11 years, including two years as chairman of the House Judiciary Committee (1992-94) and two years as House Democratic Leader (1995-97). <BR><BR>

Born <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>November 19, 1956<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Lancaster<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, he is the son of George N. and Betty H. Hodges. He is married to the former <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Rachel A. Gardner<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> of Hartsville. They have two sons, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Luke<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Sam<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.
<BR><BR>
		</DIV>
	</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD><BR><DIV CLASS="copyr">copyright &copy; Office of the Governor, State of South Carolina
2001, all rights reserved</DIV></TD>

<html>

<head>
<title>Lieutenant Governor's Biography</title>
</head>

<body bbbbackground="bakstate.gif " stylesrc="index.htm" bgcolor="#0000FF" text="#FFFFFF" link="#FFFFFF" vlink="#FFFFFF" alink="#FFFFFF">

<p align="center"><img border="0" src="2000peeler.jpg" width="150" height="214"></p>

<p align="center">&nbsp;</p>

<p align="center">
<font face="Arial" size="5" color="#FFFFFF"><b>BIOGRAPHY OF LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR
PEELER</b></font></p>

<hr>
<p class="MsoBodyText" style="text-align:justify"><font size="4"><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Bob Peeler<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is
the first <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> elected to the Office of <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> since
Reconstruction and one of only a few non-legislators to hold the office in state
history.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;</span></font><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><font size="4">&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><font size="4">Peeler
was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Gaffney<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> where he grew up working side by side with his brothers in
the family milk business off Leadmine Road.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span>It was here, working in the converted white frame house he grew up in,
that Peeler developed the common sense, down-to-earth approach that he is widely
recognized for bringing to state government. &nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><font size="4">A
successful businessman, Peeler helped transform Peelers Milk into one of the
leading independent milk processing companies in the Southeast and currently
serves as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>President<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Peeler Brothers Dairy Cattle Company<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Peeler is a former President of the South Carolina Dairy Association.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><font size="4">A
dedicated familyman, Peeler is married to the former <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Bett Carter<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> of Sumter and
the proud father of daughter <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Caroline<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> 20 and son <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Robert, Jr.<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, 12.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>When Peeler isnt working in the statehouse or traveling the state in
his familiar red pickup truck, hes most likely with his family in Lexington
where Peeler is a fixture at Roberts little league baseball games.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><font size="4">Since
taking office in 1995, Peeler has set clear conservative priorities and worked
to make them happen.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>His first
official action eliminated the Lieutenant Governors security detail, personal
driver, and state vehicle while transferring valuable law enforcement officers
back to our streets to fight crime.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>All
told, Peeler has saved taxpayers well over a million dollars through cuts and
reforms in his own office.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><font size="4">As
Lt. Governor, Peeler has been a steady advocate for tax relief.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>As presiding officer of the Senate, Peeler blocked over $200 million
dollars in backdoor tax increases with his rulings.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Peeler also led the fight for car tax relief and delivered a referendum
that voters overwhelmingly approved to cut car taxes by nearly half. As a
result, the South Carolina Association of Taxpayers awarded Peeler, the <i style="mso-bidi-font-style:
normal">Friend of the Taxpayer </i>award in 1996, 1999, and 2000.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><font size="4">A
product of the public schools and the son of an elementary school principal,
Peeler has a long-standing commitment to education.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>He served both as Chairman of the Cherokee County School Board and as
Chairman of the State Board of Education.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>As
the states second highest official, Peeler has played key roles in a number
of education initiatives including charter school creation, higher teacher pay,
and statewide full-day kindergarten implementation, a cause which Peeler
championed throughout the state.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><font size="4">As
a successful businessman, Peeler believes government should only do a few
things, but do them well.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Thats
why Peeler led the fight to pass an independent performance audit of state
government.<span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">&nbsp; </span>Peelers performance audits spotlighted waste and
duplication leading to wholesale changes and reforms throughout state
government.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>To date, the
performance audit has reported tens of millions in taxpayer savings. &nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><font size="4">The
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>South Carolina<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Federation of Older Americans named Peeler <i style="mso-bidi-font-style:normal">Legislator
of the Year in 1997</i> for his commitment to seniors.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>The South Carolina Chapter of Mothers Against Drunk Driving named him <i style="mso-bidi-font-style:normal">Highway
Safety Hero for Year 2000</i> for his work promoting stronger drunk driving
legislation.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>And in 1998, Peeler
received <i style="mso-bidi-font-style:normal">the Ron Brown Export Enhancement
Award</i> from the National Small Business Exporters Association.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><font size="4">Peeler
has served his local community as President of the Cherokee County Chamber of
Commerce and as a member of the Cherokee County Boys and Girls Club Board of
Directors.<span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>During the 2000 Presidential Primary, Peeler
served as one of George W. Bushs original Co-Chairmen.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>He is also a member of the Gaffney Rotary Club, Sons of Confederate
Veterans, the Shriners, the Masons and a life member of Sertoma International.&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt"><font size="4">Viewed
as a political long shot by the experts, Peeler was elected in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> after
winning a three-way Republican Primary and tough General Election against a
former Congresswoman.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>In <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>,
Peeler was again underestimated by the political establishment and won
reelection handily against formidable opposition. &nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</font></span></p>
<span style="font-family: Times New Roman; mso-fareast-font-family: Times New Roman; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA"><font size="4">The
son of Smith and Sally Bratton Peeler, Bob is a 1970 graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Gaffney High
School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>He received a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>B.A. degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>
from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Limestone College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>B.S. degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Clemson University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;
</span>Bob, Bett and the children reside in Lexington and attend Washington
Street Methodist Church in Columbia.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Robert
attends public elementary school in Lexington and Caroline is at Clemson
University.</font></span>
<p>&nbsp;<o:p>
</o:p>
</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="center">&nbsp;<font color="#000000"><strong><font size="3" face="Arial">&nbsp;
<a href="mailto:ltgov@scstatehouse.net">E-Mail Lt.
Governor Peeler</a></font></strong></font></p>
<p align="center"><i><font size="3" face="Arial" color="#000000"><strong><a href="ltgtable.htm">Click
here to learn more about the Office of the Lieutenant Governor.</a></strong></font></i></p>

<hr>
<p align="left"><i><font size="3" face="Arial" color="#000000"><strong><a href="index.htm">Return
to Lieutenant Governor Peeler's Home page</a></strong></font></i></p>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

    <TD VALIGN="top">
<!-- CENTER COLUMN, content********** -->
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" BORDER="0">
<TR>
    <TD><IMG SRC="images/sub_centercolumncap.gif" WIDTH=308 HEIGHT=41 BORDER=0 ALT="The South Carolina Governor's Office"></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><BR><DIV CLASS="bodytitle"><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>South Carolina's First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></DIV>
		<DIV CLASS="body"><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Rachel Gardner Hodges<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, wife of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>South Carolina<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Governor Jim Hodges<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, is a native of <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Hartsville, South Carolina<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>.  She is a graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Columbia College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, where she earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degree in psychology<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>.  Before the election, Rachel and Jim lived in Lancaster, South Carolina.  They have been married for <TAG name="YRSMARR" value="start"/>13<TAG name="YRSMARR" value="end"/> years and have two young sons, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Luke<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, age eight, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Sam<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, age five.<BR><BR>

As First Lady, Rachel actively supports arts in the community and in education, community awareness of the American Red Cross, and her husband's initiatives to improve public education.  In April 1999, Rachel launched the "Reading with Rachel" literacy program to share her love of reading with South Carolina school children.  The program is designed to promote literacy, parental and community involvement in education, and a love of reading throughout <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>South Carolina<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.  <BR><BR>

Through "Reading with Rachel" the First Lady visits different elementary schools each month.  During her visits, Mrs. Hodges reads to students, talks about the joy of reading and presents the school with the "Reading with Rachel" Book of the Month.  In addition, she holds monthly "Reading with Rachel" events in the gardens of the Governor's Mansion, hosts a weekly radio program through the S.C. Educational Radio that is broadcast statewide, donates an average of 7,000 books each year to schools and organizations in need, holds at least four celebrity reading events each year, hosts a monthly television show on S.C. Educational Television, and collaborates with various other literacy organizations on their projects.<BR><BR>

Rachel is a member of several boards and commissions.  She is an active member of the Spoleto Festival USA Board, the Columbia College Board of Visitors, the A. C. Moore Elementary School Improvement Council, and the South Carolina Arts Commission.  Rachel also serves as the national honorary chairperson for Scholastic Publishing's READ FOR 2002, and as the honorary chair for the Governor's School of Science and Mathematics Board of Visitors, Edventure Museum Project Board, South Carolina Governor's School for Arts and Humanities Foundation Board, South Carolina Health Alliance Safe Kids Program, Columbia Museum of Art Board, and the Friends of the South Carolina Libraries. <BR><BR>

Before becoming First Lady, Rachel worked for <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Springs Industries<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> for eight years rising from a position as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>management trainee<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> to a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>production supervisor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and finally a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>customer service manager<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.  Later, she served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Director of Marketing and Community Relations<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Springs Memorial Hospital<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>.  After their youngest son was born, Mrs. Hodges made the decision to simplify her life professionally and spend more time with her family.<BR><BR>

		</DIV>
	</TD>
</TR>

2001, all rights reserved</DIV></TD>

<html>
<head>
<title>Governor Biography</title>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
</head>

<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" text="#000000" link="#663300" vlink="#003300" alink="#000066">
<img src="/gov_information/bio/gov_bio.png" width="741" height="156" alt="The Governor's Biography"> 
<table width="695" border="0" cellspacing="3" cellpadding="3">
  <tr> 
    <td width="9" valign="top" bgcolor="#FFFFFF" height="1386"><a href="#perry"><img src="/clear.gif" width="8" height="8" border="0" alt="skip to main"></a></td>
    <td width="161" valign="top" bordercolor="#990000" height="1386"> 
      <table width="150pxpx" border="3" cellspacing="3" cellpadding="3">
        <tr> 
          <td bordercolor="#990000" bgcolor="#FFFFCC"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><a href="/gov_information/responsi/responsibilities.htm"style="text-decoration:none">Governor's 
            Responsibilities</a></font></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td bgcolor="#FFFFCC" bordercolor="#990000"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><a href="/gov_information/bio/gov_bio.htm"style="text-decoration:none">Governor's 
            Biography</a></font></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td bgcolor="#FFFFCC" bordercolor="#990000"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><a href="/gov_information/frst_lady/firstlady.htm"style="text-decoration:none">The 
            First Lady</a></font></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td bgcolor="#FFFFCC" bordercolor="#990000" height="30"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><a href="/gov_information/mansion/mansion.htm"style="text-decoration:none">The 
            Mansion</a></font></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td bgcolor="#FFFFCC" bordercolor="#990000" height="30"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><a href="/current_events/news_info.htm"style="text-decoration:none">News 
            &amp; Information</a></font></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td bgcolor="#FFFFCC" bordercolor="#990000"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><a href="/the_office/the_office.htm"style="text-decoration:none">The 
            Office </a></font></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td bgcolor="#FFFFCC" bordercolor="#990000"><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2" color="#000000"><a href="/the_office/press/releases.htm"style="text-decoration:none"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Press 
            Releases</font></a></font></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td bgcolor="#FFFFCC" bordercolor="#990000" height="31"><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2" color="#000000"><a href="/index.htm"style="text-decoration:none"> 
            <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Return to Home </font></a></font></td>
        </tr>
      </table>
      <p>&nbsp;</p>
      </td>
    <td width="194" valign="top" height="1386"> 
      <p><img src="/images/perry02.jpg" width="160" height="210" alt="Photo of Governor Perry"></p>
      <div align="center"> 
        <center>
          <table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="3" cellpadding="0">
            <tr> 
              <td><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2" color="#990000"><b>Moving 
                Every Texan Forward -</b></font><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"> 
                <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Rick Perry<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> commits to the citizens of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Texas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> higher education 
                reform and expanded opportunities to succeed. </font></td>
            </tr>
          </table>
          <p align="left"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1"><font color="#333333"><br>
            <a href="#regulatory"><img src="/clear.gif" width="8" height="8" border="0" alt="skip to main"></a> 
            </font></font></p>
          <p align="left"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1"><font color="#333333"> 
            </font></font></p>
        </center>
      </div>
    </td>
    <td valign="top" bordercolor="#FFFFFF" width="292" height="1386"> 
      <p><font size="3" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" color="#663300"><b><font size="4" color="#990000">Governor 
        Perry </font></b></font><font size="2" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><a name="perry"></a><br>
        <br>
        <b>Rick Perry</b> was sworn in as the state&#146;s 47th <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on December 
        21, 2000.&nbsp;&nbsp; </font> <font size="2" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"> 
        </font> </p>
      <p><font size="2" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><b>Governor Perry 
        is focused on moving Texas forward by creating greater opportunities for 
        citizens across our state</b>. He is committed to continued reform in 
        our public schools, increasing attention to the critical fields of math 
        and science. <b>Governor Perry is also devoted to making our higher education 
        system the envy of the nation.</b> He appointed a special commission to 
        fully examine how we can make higher education more accessible and affordable, 
        how we can fully integrate technology into the college experience, and 
        how we can raise the bar of excellence while meeting the evolving workforce 
        needs of our state.</font></p>
      <p><font size="2" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><b>Governor Perry 
        is also committed to addressing the traffic congestion</b> that undermines 
        our quality of life; expanding opportunities for citizens of the border 
        region through better health care, infrastructure and educational opportunity; 
        and ensuring Texas is at the forefront of the digital revolution.</font></p>
      <p><font size="2" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><b>As <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, 
        Perry worked with legislators of both parties to pass a balanced state 
        budget that included record tax cuts, record teacher pay raises, and an 
        historic school funding increase.</b> He earned high marks as the president 
        of the senate for his bipartisan leadership. The Dallas Morning News wrote, 
        &quot;&#133;Rick Perry stands out as one of the session&#146;s brighter 
        lights. He draws almost universal praise for besting expectations and 
        for evenly running the Senate.&quot; The El Paso Times editorialized,<b> 
        &quot;Promises made, promises kept. That is the slogan by which Texas 
        Lt. Governor Rick Perry should be remembered&#133;&quot;</b></font></p>
      <p><font size="2" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Prior to being elected 
        Lieutenant Governor, Perry served two terms as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Texas Commissioner of Agriculture<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. 
        From 1985 to 1991, Perry served in the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Texas House of Representatives<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> 
        representing a rural West Texas district.</font></p>
      <p><font size="2" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><b>A fifth generation 
        Texan</b>, Governor Perry hails from the rolling plains of West Texas, 
        where farming, ranching and public service run in his family. His father, 
        Ray Perry, was a long-time Haskell County Commissioner and school board 
        member. First Lady Anita Perry served on the Haskell ISD School Board.</font></p>
      <p><font size="2" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Between 1972 and 1977, 
        <b>Governor Perry <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>served in the United States Air Force<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> flying C-130 tactical 
        airlift aircraft in the U.S., Europe and the Middle East. </b>Perry is 
        a 1972 graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Texas A&amp;M University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> where he was a member of the 
        Corps of Cadets, a junior and senior yell leader, and an animal science 
        major.</font></p>
      <p><font size="2" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><b>Governor Perry 
        grew up in the small community of Paint Creek, 60 miles north of Abilene, 
        on his family&#146;s farm and ranch. </b>The younger of two children, 
        Governor Perry was an active Boy Scout, Eagle Scout, and helped his father 
        and mother, Amelia, on the farm. Perry met Anita during their elementary 
        school years. Perry remains active in the Boy Scouts and is a lifetime 
        member of American Legion Post #75.</font></p>
      <p><font size="2" face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Rick and <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Anita<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> Perry 
        are the proud parents of two children &#150; <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Griffin<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, 17, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Sydney<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, 
        14. The Perry's are members of Tarrytown United Methodist Church.</font></p>
      <p align="center"><a href="/gov_information/bio/gov_bio.htm"><img src="/images/uparrow.gif" width="13" height="7" alt="top" border="0"></a></p>
      <table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="3" cellpadding="0">
        <tr>
          <td><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1"><a href="http://www.adobe.com/products/acrobat/readstep.html"><font color="#333333">Get 
            Acrobat </font></a><font color="#333333"><img src="images/spacer.png" width="1" height="10"><a href="http://www.state.tx.us"> 
            State of Texas</a> <img src="images/spacer.png" width="1" height="10"><a href="http://www.texasonline.state.tx.us/"> 
            TexasOnLine </a><img src="images/spacer.png" width="1" height="10"><a href="http://access.adobe.com"> 
            Access Adobe </a><img src="images/spacer.png" width="1" height="10"><a href="Disclaimer.htm"> 
            Privacy Policy</a><img src="images/spacer.png" width="1" height="10"> 
            Best viewed with Internet Explorer 4.+ or above<img src="images/spacer.png" width="1" height="10"> 
            &copy;Office of the Governor<img src="images/spacer.png" width="1" height="10"> 
            The images on the web site are copyrighted and may not be downloaded.</font></font></td>
        </tr>
      </table>
      
    </td>
  </tr>
</table>
</body>
