<IMG src="../../../../../Icons/75r/senate/members/large/Dist1_76BPW14.jpg" align="right" hspace="5" width="160" height="210" alt="Photograph: LtGov Bill Ratliff portrait"> 
<P class="pr"> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Bill Ratliff<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> holds a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degree in Civil Engineering<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Texas<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, and in 1990 was named a Distinguished Graduate of that university's School of Engineering. He has practiced as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>consulting engineer<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in Texas for more than 35 years. He owns his own firm in Mount Pleasant. Lieutenant Governor Ratliff is a graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Sonora High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Sonora, Texas. </P>
<P class="pr"> Ratliff is a past president of the American Consulting Engineers Council; has received state and national professional awards; has served as an <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>adjunct engineering professor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>; and has testified on a number of occasions before Congressional committees regarding the nation's infrastructure. Prior to becoming a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>consulting engineer<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, he served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>city manager<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of Copperas Cove, Texas. </P>
<P class="pr"> First elected to the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Texas Senate<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1988, <A href="http://www.senate.state.tx.us/75r/senate/members/dist1/dist1.htm">Ratliff represents the First Senatorial District</A> in northeast Texas. In December of 2000, Senator Bill Ratliff was elected by fellow members of the Texas Senate to fill the vacancy created when Rick Perry vacated the office of Lieutenant Governor. This marks the first time in Texas history that the Senate has elected one of its own members as Lieutenant Governor and President of the Senate. He served as Chair of the Senate Education Committee from 1992-1996, and served as Chair of the Senate Finance Committee from 1997 2000. Ratliff has been four times named one of Texas Best Legislators by Texas Monthly magazine. </P>
<P class="pr"> Ratliff received an honorable discharge as an <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Army Reserve Sergeant<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. He is active in Tennison Memorial United Methodist Church, serving as a Sunday school teacher, lay reader, chair of the church's finance committee, and member of the Board of Trustees. </P>
<P align="center"><A href="#top"><IMG src="http://www.senate.state.tx.us/Icons/75r/senate/Arrow.gif" border="0" width="13" height="7" alt="Top"></A></P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</BODY>
</HTML>
 
 
ENDOFDOC

<html>
<head>
<title>The First Lady</title>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
</head>

<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" text="#000000" link="#663300" vlink="#333300" alink="#000066">
<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td><img src="/gov_information/frst_lady/firstlady.png" width="741" height="156" border="0" alt="First Lady"></td>
  </tr>
</table>
<table width="714" border="0" cellspacing="3" cellpadding="3">
  <tr>
    <td width="3%" height="371" valign="top"><a href="#FirstLady"><img src="/clear.gif" width="8" height="8" alt="skip to main" border="0"></a></td>
    <td width="25%" height="371" valign="top"> 
      <table width="150px" border="2" cellspacing="3" cellpadding="3">
        <tr> 
          <td bordercolor="#990000" bgcolor="#FFFFCC"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><a href="/gov_information/responsi/responsibilities.htm"style="text-decoration:none">Governor's 
            Responsibilities</a></font></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td bgcolor="#FFFFCC" bordercolor="#990000"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><a href="/gov_information/bio/gov_bio.htm"style="text-decoration:none">Governor's 
            Biography</a></font></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td bgcolor="#FFFFCC" bordercolor="#990000"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><a href="/gov_information/frst_lady/firstlady.htm"style="text-decoration:none">The 
            First Lady</a></font></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td bgcolor="#FFFFCC" bordercolor="#990000" height="30"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><a href="/gov_information/mansion/mansion.htm"style="text-decoration:none">The 
            Mansion</a></font></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td bgcolor="#FFFFCC" bordercolor="#990000" height="30"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><a href="/current_events/news_info.htm"style="text-decoration:none">News 
            &amp; Information</a></font></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td bgcolor="#FFFFCC" bordercolor="#990000"><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2" color="#000000"><a href="/the_office/press/releases.htm"style="text-decoration:none">Press 
            Releases</a></font></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td bgcolor="#FFFFCC" bordercolor="#990000" height="26"><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2" color="#000000"><a href="/index.htm"style="text-decoration:none"> 
            Return to Home </a></font></td>
        </tr>
      </table>
    </td>
    <td width="36%" height="371"> 
      <p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="3" color="#990000"><b><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Texas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> 
        <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/><br>
        <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Anita Thigpen Perry<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></b><br>
        <a name="FirstLady"></a><br>
        <font size="2" color="#000000">Dedicated health care professional, committed 
        volunteer, loving wife and proud mother: these are just some of the descriptions 
        that aptly fit <b><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Anita Perry<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>. </b>Her friends also know her 
        to be intelligent, loyal and genuine.</font></font> </p>
      <p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2" color="#000000">In 
        1974, 22-year old <b>Anita Thigpen received a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Bachelor of Science degree in nursing<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> 
        from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>West Texas State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/></b>, beginning a 17-year career 
        in the health care profession that included numerous professional roles: 
        <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>supervisor of surgery<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>instructor and pediatric coordinator<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>staff nurse<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> 
        in an intensive care unit, <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>instructor in medical surgical nursing<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>in-service 
        director and childbirth education instructor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>area supervisor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of a home 
        health agency, <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>RN consultant<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>hospital director of nurses<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. Along the 
        way, she also received a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Master of Science degree in nursing<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the 
        <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Texas Health Science Center<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in San Antonio.</font></p>
    </td>
    <td width="36%" height="371" valign="top"><img src="/images/anita_rp.jpg" width="236" height="259" align="top" alt="Photo of Governor and Mrs. Perry"> 
      <table width="96%" border="0" cellspacing="3" cellpadding="4" height="79">
        <tr> 
          <td height="108"> 
            <div align="center"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><i>A 
              photo of Governor and Mrs. Perry taken at the Governor's Mansion</i></font><i>. 
              </i> </div>
          </td>
        </tr>
      </table>
    </td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td width="3%" height="493">&nbsp;</td>
    <td width="25%" height="493">&nbsp;</td>
    <td colspan="2" height="493"> 
      <p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2" color="#000000">Health 
        care has not just been a career, but a lifelong passion that began when 
        she was old enough to remember the work her father did for the rural community 
        of Haskell as a doctor. Dr. Joe Thigpen retired from his practice this 
        past year after practicing medicine for 50 years.</font></p>
      <p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2" color="#000000"><b>As 
        Texas&#146; newest <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></b>, <b>Anita Perry</b> will continue to 
        pursue her passion, focusing on efforts to improve health care for women 
        and children. She is also committed to opening doors of opportunity to 
        women. That&#146;s why she and Rick hosted the first annual Texas Conference 
        for Women in October of 2000. She will continue to host future conferences 
        that will address numerous issues of concern to women.</font><br>
        <br>
        <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2" color="#000000">The 
        daughter of Dr. Joe and Beunis Thigpen, <b>Anita Perry</b> grew up with 
        three siblings &#150; Joseph, Peggy and Emily. From her loving parents 
        she learned at an early age the importance of family. Anita credits her 
        parents with teaching their children the virtues of kindness, graciousness 
        and community service.</font></p>
      <p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2" color="#000000">After 
        a long courtship that began in their teens, and careers that found Rick 
        and Anita on different sides of the globe, the planets finally aligned 
        and they married in <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1982<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/>. They soon started a family in Haskell with the 
        birth of their son <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Griffin<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> in 1983. Their daughter <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Sydney<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> was born three 
        years later in 1986.</font></p>
      <p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2" color="#000000">After 
        six years in the Texas House, Rick was elected Texas Commissioner of Agriculture 
        in 1990, and the family moved to Austin in the summer of 1991. Anita worked 
        for several years for an Austin public relations firm, and worked the 
        last few years for the The Perryman Group.</font></p>
      <p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2" color="#000000">Anita 
        is involved with numerous charitable organizations and boards, and the 
        Perrys are members of the Tarrytown United Methodist Church.</font></p>
      <p align="center"><a href="/gov_information/frst_lady/firstlady.htm"><img src="/images/uparrow.png" width="13" height="7" border="0" alt="top"></a></p>
      <table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="3" cellpadding="0">
        <tr> 
          <td><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1"><a href="http://www.adobe.com/products/acrobat/readstep.html"><font color="#333333">Get 
            Acrobat </font></a><font color="#333333"><img src="images/spacer.png" width="1" height="10"><a href="http://www.state.tx.us"> 
            State of Texas</a> <img src="images/spacer.png" width="1" height="10"><a href="http://www.texasonline.state.tx.us/"> 
            Texas On Line </a><img src="images/spacer.png" width="1" height="10"><a href="http://access.adobe.com"> 
            AccessAdobe</a><img src="images/spacer.png" width="1" height="10"><a href="Disclaimer.htm"> 
            Privacy Policy</a><img src="images/spacer.png" width="1" height="10"> 
            Best viewed with Internet Explorer 4.+ or above<img src="images/spacer.png" width="1" height="10"> 
            &copy;Office of the Governor<img src="images/spacer.png" width="1" height="10"> 
            The images on the web site are copyrighted and may not be downloaded.</font></font></td>
        </tr>
      </table>
      <p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
    </td>
  </tr>

          <map name="menuFamilyMap">
            <area shape="rect" coords="0,6,150,21" href="../family/jim.cfm">

          name="contactButton" src="../images/buttonContactOff.gif" border=0 width=150 height=19 alt="Contact Gilmore"></a><br>
          
        
          
        <img src="../images/dot.gif" width=1 height=10>
      </td>
      
      
      
      
        
          <td width=6 background="../images/gutter.gif"><img src="../images/dot.gif" width=6 height=1></td>
        
      
      
      
      
      <td bgcolor=#ffffff valign=top>

      
      


  
  
<img src="../images/dot.gif" width=1 height=4><br>
<img src="../images/titles/jim.gif" width=174 height=16 alt="Governor Jim Gilmore">
  
  
<p><img src="../images/photos/gilmore200.jpg" width=200 height=244 align="left" vspace="10" hspace="14" border=2 style="border-color: #ffcc00; color: #ffcc00;"><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jim Gilmore<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was elected Virginia's 68th <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 1997<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> on a philosophy 
  of cutting taxes and providing all children in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Virginia<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> with quality education. 
  Since taking office, Governor Gilmore has provided steady, conservative leadership 
  that has resulted in the largest tax cut in Virginia history, implementation 
  of Virginia's nationally acclaimed Standards of Learning, and a safer, more 
  prosperous Commonwealth, leading to the creation of 175,000 new jobs.</p>
<p>Governor 
  Gilmore's principled vision focuses on the well being of Virginia's working 
  families. He believes all Virginians should have the opportunity to succeed 
  personally and in their work life. Through tax relief and quality education, 
  and by safeguarding individual liberties, the Governor is empowering people 
  to chart their own course for the future. Governor Gilmore's principal goal 
  is fostering unity among people within the state, leaving no citizen behind. 
  As Governor, he has been successful in expanding Virginia's economic reach by 
  leading trade delegations to Asia, Europe and South America. In Virginia, Governor 
  Gilmore has hosted Presidents Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Mary McAleese of Ireland</p>
<p> Governor Gilmore served as chairman of the federal Advisory Commission on 
  Electronic Commerce, a panel that reported directly to Congress on the future 
  of Internet taxation. The Governor heads the Congressional Advisory Panel to 
  Assess Preparedness for Weapons of Mass Destruction and is chairman of the Southern 
  States Energy Board. He serves on the Technology Committee of the National Governors' 
  Association. Governor Gilmore is the vice-chairman of the 30-member Republican 
  Governors Association and was recently appointed by Texas Governor George W. 
  Bush and the Republican National Committee to co-chair the Victory 2000 national 
  election effort</p>
<p> <b>Historic Tax Relief</b><br>
  Governor Gilmore is fulfilling his campaign promise to eliminate the onerous 
  property tax on the first $20,000 value of all personally owned cars and trucks 
  over a five-year period, 70 percent being eliminated by 2001. By the year 2002, 
  more than 90 percent of Virginians will pay no car taxes. In addition, the Governor 
  was successful in his drive to begin cutting the state sales tax on food by 
  more than half, alleviate the state tax burden on active military personnel, 
  reduce the sales tax on Internet software and hardware, and remove the state 
  sales tax on nonprescription drugs. Since taking office the Governor has cut 
  16 different taxes. By 2002, Virginians will receive more than $1.5 billion 
  in tax relief per year.</p>
<p><b>Quality Education</b><br>
  Educated in public schools, Governor Gilmore is working to provide the best 
  possible education for all of Virginia's children. The Governor has overseen 
  the implementation of Virginia's highly acclaimed Standards of Learning (SOLs) 
  -- a program designed to give students a solid academic foundation in core subjects 
  such as Math, Science, English and History. To assist schools in the implementation 
  of the SOLs, the Governor established Best Practice Centers throughout Virginia 
  that provide teacher training services, resource materials, and diagnostic assistance 
  to local school divisions that request assistance. Governor Gilmore is also 
  committed to overseeing the successful implementation of these rigorous new 
  academic standards to make sure students are learning and teachers and school 
  administrators are accountable.</p>
<p>This year, Governor Gilmore proposed and signed an Early Reading Initiative 
  designed to assess the literacy needs of children in kindergarten and first 
  grade and correct reading deficits by the end of the first grade. Furthermore, 
  the Governor has successfully passed and implemented legislation ensuring all 
  revenue raised from state lottery proceeds will be returned to localities for 
  public education, including aid for school construction and renovation, books, 
  additional teachers and teachers' salaries. Governor Gilmore continues to work 
  to provide 4,000 new classroom teachers in Virginia's elementary schools.</p>
<p>Governor Gilmore's goal is to ensure the state's public colleges and universities 
  are held accountable to the taxpayers who fund these public institutions. He 
  has cut tuition and fees at Virginia's public colleges and universities by 20 
  percent. He also continued the freeze on tuition costs at Virginia's colleges 
  and universities, and increased the maximum Tuition Assistance Grant award to 
  $3000 per student at Virginia's independent colleges by 2001.</p>
<p>This year, Governor Gilmore provided $26 million in new funding for Virginia's 
  historically black universities, Norfolk State University and Virginia State 
  University, to enhance the institutions' quality of education and attract the 
  best and brightest minds to Virginia.</p>
<p><b>Connecting to the Future</b><br>
  Virginia is the birthplace of the Internet and is a world leader in information 
  technology. With Virginia's global technology community expanding at a rapid 
  pace, Governor Gilmore is fostering a strong relationship between government 
  and the technology community. He appointed a Secretary of Technology -- the 
  nation's first cabinet-level technology post.</p>
<p>Governor Gilmore established the Governor's Commission on Information Technology, 
  a group that has already made recommendations on Internet policy, resulting 
  in the nation's first comprehensive state Internet policy. The seven pieces 
  of legislation comprising this policy: incorporate unsolicited bulk electronic 
  mail (spam) violations into the Computer Crimes Act; formally establish the 
  Secretary of Technology; extend the Privacy Protection Act to the Internet; 
  enhance penalties for the use of encryption in committing crimes; and extend 
  state law to allow requested information sought under Virginia's Freedom of 
  Information Act to be posted on the Internet or sent via electronic mail. As 
  the chairman of the federal Advisory Commission on Electronic Commerce, a Congressional 
  panel that studied e-commerce tax policy, Governor Gilmore submitted a report 
  urging Congress to keep the Internet tax-free, repeal the century old tax on 
  telecommunications and close the "digital divide".</p>
<p><b>Public Safety</b><br>
  Over the past six years, Virginia has led the nation in numerous public safety 
  reforms such as the abolition of parole, juvenile justice reform, habeas reform, 
  and "Three Strikes and You're Out." Through Governor Gilmore's leadership, Virginia 
  became the first state in the nation to implement a statewide version of "Project 
  Exile" -- a program that calls for mandatory minimum five-year sentences for 
  gun-wielding felons. Under Governor Gilmore's leadership, Virginia Exile has 
  become the national model for anti-gun crime efforts. To fight the drug crisis 
  in Virginia, Governor Gilmore has implemented the Substance Abuse Reduction 
  Effort (SABRE), a comprehensive initiative that strengthens enforcement, treatment 
  and prevention efforts.</p>
<p><b>Inclusiveness</b><br>
  Governor Gilmore has made reaching out to all Virginia's communities a top priority 
  of his administration. In addition to major funding increases for Virginia's 
  historically black colleges over the last two years, Governor Gilmore succeeded 
  this year in ensuring Martin Luther King, Jr. be honored on a holiday separate 
  from the day Virginia remembers its Civil War generals.</p>
<p>He has made black history a key to his Virginia tourism efforts, providing 
  funding for the African-American Heritage Trail and the National Slavery Museum 
  at Jamestown. Under the Governor's direction, Virginia is aggressively marketing 
  African-American tourist sites to make the Commonwealth one of the nation's 
  leading African-American tourist destinations.</p>
<p><b>Background</b><br>
  A native Virginian, Jim Gilmore was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Richmond<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>October 6, 1949<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>. The 
  son of working class parents, he grew up in Richmond's historic Fan District. 
  He attended <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>J.R. Tucker High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Henrico County and worked as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>grocery 
  store cashier<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> to help pay for his college education at the University of Virginia.</p>
<p>Governor Gilmore graduated from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Virginia<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1971 with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degree 
  in Foreign Policy<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>. He then volunteered for the U.S. Army. Upon graduating with 
  honors from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Army Intelligence School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and completing the Defense Language 
  Institute in Monterey, CA, where he learned to speak fluent German, he joined 
  the 650th <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Military Intelligence Group<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. Stationed in Mannheim, West Germany, 
  Governor Gilmore served his country in counterintelligence and was awarded the 
  Joint Service Commendation Medal for service to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.</p>
<p>After his Army tour was completed, Gilmore returned to Virginia and entered 
  the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Virginia Law School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. He graduated from UVA Law School in 1977. 
  After a decade of civic and community involvement as an attorney and small businessman, 
  Jim Gilmore was elected in 1987 as Commonwealth's Attorney for Henrico County. 
  He was overwhelmingly reelected in 1991.</p>
<p>After earning a solid reputation for fighting crime, he was elected Virginia's 
  <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Attorney General<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1993, receiving 56 percent of the vote in what was supposed 
  to be a close election. He served Virginians well as Attorney General and achievedreal 
  accomplishments in the areas of education, consumer protection, public safety, 
  and the environment. As Attorney General, he led a nationwide effort to stop 
  arson against African-American churches. </p>
<p>Governor Gilmore is married to <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Roxane Gatling Gilmore<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> of Suffolk. Roxane is 
  a teacher who has taught in public schools and currently teaches at Randolph-Macon 
  College in Ashland. The Gilmore's are the parents of two boys, 13-year-old <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Ashton<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, 
  and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jay<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, who is 17. They are members of River Road Methodist Church, located 
  in Richmond. </p>


        <br>
      </td>
      
      
      
      
      
      <td bgcolor=#ffffff width=5>
        <img src="../images/dot.gif" width=1 height=1></td>
      
      
      
      
    </tr>
    
    
    
    <tr>
      
      <td class="ltBlueBackground" colspan=4>
        <img src="../images/whiteFadeLineNarrow.gif" width=520 height=3></td>

<HTML>  
<HEAD>
  <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Adobe PageMill 3.0 Mac">
  <TITLE>About <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>John Hager<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> and the Office of the <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY BGCOLOR="#ffffff">

<TABLE WIDTH="570" HEIGHT="214" BORDER="0" CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0">
  <TR>
    <TD COLSPAN="2" VALIGN="BOTTOM" nowrap><IMG SRC="images/top.jpg"
      WIDTH="279" HEIGHT="64" ALIGN="BOTTOM" NATURALSIZEFLAG="0"><IMG 
      SRC="images/subhager.jpg" WIDTH="279" HEIGHT="64" ALIGN="BOTTOM"
      NATURALSIZEFLAG="0"></TD>
     
  </TR>
  <TR>
    <TD WIDTH="45%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT="135"><IMG SRC="images/side.jpg"
      WIDTH="69" HEIGHT="82" ALIGN="BOTTOM" NATURALSIZEFLAG="0"></TD> 
    <TD WIDTH="55%" VALIGN="TOP">
      <P><IMG SRC="images/whspacer.gif" WIDTH="480" HEIGHT="4" ALIGN="BOTTOM"
      NATURALSIZEFLAG="0"></P>

      <P><IMG SRC="images/hagersm.jpg" ALIGN="RIGHT" WIDTH="131" HEIGHT="175"
      NATURALSIZEFLAG="0"><B><FONT SIZE="+1">About John Hager</FONT></B><BR>
     <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Virginia<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> John Hager's election to the state's second highest office proves again that perseverance and determination in the face of daunting obstacles leads to victory, whether in an election or in one's life. His full-time work to benefit the people of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Virginia<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> has served to redefine the Office of Lieutenant Governor.</p>

<P>
Few pundits gave the Richmond business leader a great hope of victory when he began his campaign for Lieutenant Governor, but over a 34-month period, Hager traveled Virginia constantly, taking his message of fiscal conservatism and rethinking the role of government to the grassroots.  During just one two-month period (between July 4th and Labor Day week) he conducted a "Rolling across Virginia" tour that took him to each and every one of Virginia's 134 counties and independent cities.</P>

      <P>On November 4, 1997 Hager carried 88 of the state's 134 jurisdictions, winning 
        in all parts of the state. His final margin of victory for Lieutenant 
        Governor exceeded 80,000 votes. </P>

<P><IMG SRC="images/family.jpg" ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="250" HEIGHT="174" ALT="family photo" BORDER="0">
John Hager graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Purdue University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degree in Engineering<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> and from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Harvard University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> with an <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>MBA<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>.  He <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>served in the United States Army<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and the Army Reserve, rising to the rank of Captain.  A life-long athlete, John still competes in marathons and has won many first place medals.
</P>

<P>
John married the former <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Margaret Dickinson Chase<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1971<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/>.  A strong family man, Maggie and his two sons <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jack<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Henry<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> are often at his side as he continues to work full time for a better <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Virginia<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.
</P>

<P>
A business executive who started at the bottom of the career ladder loading boxcars in 1961, Mr. Hager quickly rose within the ranks of his corporation (<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>American Tobacco Company<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>) to <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Executive Vice President<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.  At the pinnacle of his career, however, he contracted polio in 1973 which robbed him of the use of his legs.  He uses a wheelchair for mobility.  Despite a near-death encounter at the on-set of polio, Mr. Hager quickly returned to work -- starting over as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Department Manager<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> -- and rose to the office of <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Senior Vice President<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Leaf and Specialty Products<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> for the parent company.  He did not miss a day's work until his retirement due to a corporate buyout in December 1994.
</P>

<P>
A long-term civic, charity and community leader, Hager has served as President or Chairman of more than 30 boards and commissions, including Children's Hospital, the Virginia Health Care Foundation, two-terms as Chairman of Leadership Metro Richmond. He serves as a Director of The Sorensen Institute of Political Leadership, American Red Cross and the Make-A-Wish Foundation.
</P>

<P>
Hager was Director of the Virginia Chamber of Commerce and the Partnership for Urban Virginia.  He works with local business leaders in all areas of our state to recruit new businesses for the Commonwealth, to create new jobs for the next generation, to promote technology and to protect Virginian's mature industries.
</P>

<P>
John participates in Regional and National activities with several organizations and his party.  He is Southern Sector Chairman for the National Conference of Lieutenant Governors, Vice Chairman of the Aerospace States Association and a member of the Southern Growth Policies Board.  These prominent leadership roles help boost Virginia's future.
</P>

<P>
He has been a leader in the war against drugs as a member of the Drug Task Force of the State Crime Commission and well recognized for his leadership roles in highway traffic safety.  In the position of Vice President of the Virginia Public Safety Foundation, he works to ensure that law enforcement officials are recognized for the tremendous role they play in keeping our neighborhoods and schools safe.
</P>

<P>
	Currently as Chairman of the Richmond Center Expansion project and Trustee of the Jamestown-Yorktown Foundation, Hager is heavily involved in the promotion of tourism and conventions and selling Virginia history, heritage and hospitality.
</P>

<P>
	In the role of the Chairman of the Disability Commission and Chairman of the VCU Charter Business Roundtable, John believes strongly in being sure that each and every Virginian has a level playing field and opportunity to achieve their full potential.  He serves as a strong role model for those seeking to achieve their American dreams.
</P>

      <P> Hager also serves as Vice Chairman of the Governor's Commission on Transportation 
        Policy, Chairman of the Commission on Educational Infrastructure and Technology and
        Chairman of the Faith Based Community Services Task Force.</P>

<P>
John Hager is a strong believer in the community-based approach to solving our problems, meeting our challenges and fostering new initiatives.  His philosophy of community, partnership and leadership is ever present in his presentations to many groups and organizations all over the Commonwealth. 
</P>

      <P><HR ALIGN=LEFT noshade>
    </TD>
  </TR>
  <TR>
    <TD COLSPAN="2" ALIGN="CENTER">
      <P ALIGN=RIGHT><MAP NAME="links">

      <td bgcolor=#ffffff valign=top>

      
      


  
  
  <img src="../images/dot.gif" width=1 height=4><br>
  <img src="../images/titles/roxane.gif" width=206 height=18 alt="First Lady Roxane Gilmore">
  
  
<p><img src="../images/photos/roxane.jpg" width="225" height="259" align="left" vspace="10" hspace="14"><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Roxane 
  Gatling Gilmore<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is a wife, mother and <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>college professor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> who understands the 
  daily complexities of modern family life. As the only <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in history 
  to continue her professional career while serving the citizens of Virginia, 
  Roxane's tenure promises to be one of achievement and success. </p>
<p>A 
  native Virginian, Roxane Gatling was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Suffolk<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> and graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Suffolk 
  High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. She is an alumna of the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Virginia<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. She earned her 
  <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>B.A. in history, classics and anthropology<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>, <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>M.A. in ancient history<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> in 1978, 
  and is currently completing her <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Ph.D. in ancient history<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>. </p>
<p>While a student and teaching assistant at the University of Virginia, Roxane 
  met and married <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Jim Gilmore<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>. In 1992, she began <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>teaching<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Henrico and Chesterfield 
  County Public Schools<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. Roxane is now a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>professor of classics<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at Randolph Macon 
  College. Her classes include Latin, Women in Ancient Literature, Roman History, 
  Greek History, Epic Poetry and Roman Britain. </p>
<p>As First Lady, Roxane created an Internet clearinghouse of resources for teachers, 
  parents, students and the business world. The Department of Technology and the 
  Department of Education continue to partner with Mrs. Gilmore in her efforts 
  to provide teachers with state-of-the-art educational resources. Roxane is also 
  proud to be a partner of the Virginia Literacy Foundation, sharing her love 
  of learning and passion for books with students of all ages. </p>
<p>She is working with the Virginia Tourism Corporation to promote Virginia's 
  historic, cultural and recreational treasures. Roxane was recently appointed 
  to the Jamestown-Yorktown Foundation, and is excited about serving as honorary 
  chair of Jamestown Celebration 2007steering committee. </p>
<p>Roxane also serves on the Board of Directors of the Virginia Museum of Fine 
  Arts. In 1994, Roxane was appointed to the Family and Children's Trust Fund 
  (FACT) where she continues to help raise funds to combat violence and sexual 
  assault aimed at children. </p>
<p>Roxane and Jim's greatest joy comes from raising their two sons, 13-year-old 
  <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Ashton<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jay<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, who is 17. Roxane and Jim are active supporters of their children's 
  school-related activities including youth football, Little League, youth basketball 
  and swim team. The Gilmores are active members of River Road Methodist Church.</p>

<hr>
<p>Visit the First Lady's <a href="http://www.knowledge.state.va.us">Commonwealth of Knowledge</a> Web site. The site is an innovative tool designed to assist teachers in implementing the Standards of Learning.</p>


<p>Learn how Roxane and the <a href="../press/news2000/roxy0524.htm">"First Ladies Build"</a> are helping to create Habitat homes across the United States.</p>



        <br>
      </td>
      
      
      
      
      
      <td bgcolor=#ffffff width=5>
        <img src="../images/dot.gif" width=1 height=1></td>

      </td>

<!--
function MM_reloadPage(init) {  //reloads the window if Nav4 resized
if (init==true) with (navigator) {if ((appName=="Netscape")&&(parseInt(appVersion)==4)) {
document.MM_pgW=innerWidth; document.MM_pgH=innerHeight; onresize=MM_reloadPage; }}
else if (innerWidth!=document.MM_pgW || innerHeight!=document.MM_pgH) location.reload();
}
MM_reloadPage(true);
// -->
</script>
</head>

<td width="98%" valign="top">
<!-- #BeginEditable "Body" -->
<!-- #BeginEditable "Body" -->
<table width="140" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="1" bgcolor="#000000" align="right">
<tr>
<td width="100%">
<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3" bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
<tr bgcolor="#FFFFCE">
<td width="100%">
<div align="right"><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><font size="1"><b><img src="images/spacer.gif" alt="spacer" width="160" height="1"><br>
<TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Howard Dean<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> MD<br>
109 State Street, Pavilion<br>
Montpelier, VT 05609-0101<br>
800 649-6825<br>
802 828-3333</b></font></font></div>
</td>
</tr>
<tr bgcolor="#FFFFCE">
<td width="100%">
<p align="center"><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1"><img src="images/spacer.gif" alt="spacer" width="160" height="1"><br></font><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><b>Recent Press Releases</b></font></p>
</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor="#FFFFCE"><td>
<p align="left">
<font face="VerDana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1">
<!-- Begin Press Releases -->
<p align="left"><a href=press_release.php3?display_num=9><img src="images/doc_icon.gif" width="17" height="17" border="0" alt="Document Icon"><b>Per pupil comparative ranking released today</b></a><br>Per pupil spending on education varies around Vermont from a high of $11,650.24 to a low of $5,415.33, according to a comparative ranking released today by Gov. Howard Dean.
<a href=press_release.php3?display_num=9><img src="images/read_more.gif" width="80" height="13" align="right" alt="Read More" border="0"></a></p><p align="left"><a href=press_release.php3?display_num=5><img src="images/doc_icon.gif" width="17" height="17" border="0" alt="Document Icon"><b>Blueprint for Reducing Substance Abuse in the Coming Decade</b></a><br>Gov. Howard Dean and Health Commissioner Jan Carney today released the state's blueprint for reducing substance abuse in the coming decade.<a href=press_release.php3?display_num=5><img src="images/read_more.gif" width="80" height="13" align="right" alt="Read More" border="0"></a></p><p align="left"><a href=press_release.php3?display_num=7><img src="images/doc_icon.gif" width="17" height="17" border="0" alt="Document Icon"><b>New Superior Justices Appointed</b></a><br>Gov. Howard Dean today named Karen Carroll of Vernon and Dennis R. Pearson of Jericho Center to serve as judges in Vermont's Superior Court. <a href=press_release.php3?display_num=7><img src="images/read_more.gif" width="80" height="13" align="right" alt="Read More" border="0"></a></p><!-- End Press Releases -->
</font>
</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr bgcolor="#FFFFCE">
<td width="100%">
<div align="center">
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="1"><b>Search Press Releases<br>
by Keyword<br><form method="post" action="search_press_release.php3">
<input type="text" name="search_string"><font size=1><br></font><img src="images/spacer.gif" width="1" height="7" alt="spacer"><br>
<input type="image" src="images/search.gif" width="80" height="13" alt="Search Button" border="0"></input>
<br><img src="images/spacer.gif" width="1" height="8" alt="spacer"><br>
<a href="search_press_release.php3"><img src="images/view_all.gif" width="80" height="13" alt="View All Button" border="0"></a></form></b></font></p> </div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><b><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><br>
<img src="images/gov_portrait2.jpg" width="110" height="150" align="left" alt="governors portrait">
Welcome to Vermont!</font></b> </p>
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/>
<TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Howard Dean<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>physician<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and has served as Vermont's governor
since 1991. Dean is a fiscal conservative whose priorities as governor
are improving the lives of Vermont's children, increasing access
to health care, preserving Vermont's natural resources, improving
public education, and creating jobs.</font></p>
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">Dean
received his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor's degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Yale University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1971 and
his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>medical degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Albert Einstein College of Medicine<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in New
York City in 1978. He then completed his residency at the Medical
Center Hospital of Vermont and opened an internal medicine practice
with his wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Judy Steinberg<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, M.D., in Shelburne, Vermont. </font></p>
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">During
his medical residency, Howard Dean began his political career as
a volunteer in Jimmy Carter's reelection campaign. He served in
the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Vermont House of Representatives<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> from 1982 to 1986, and was
elected assistant minority leader in 1985. He was elected lieutenant
governor in 1986 and reelected in 1988 and 1990. </font></p>
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">As
a legislator and lieutenant governor, Dean founded the Vermont Youth
Conservation Corps, championed protection of the Long Trail, and
created the Lieutenant Governor's Conference on Affordable Housing.
On August 14, 1991, Dr. Dean's political career took a sudden and
unexpected turn. Dean was treating a patient at his medical practice
when he received a call informing him that the governor had died
of a heart attack. Dr. Dean completed his patient's physical, called
his wife and children, and drove to Montpelier to take the oath
of office. </font></p>
<p><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><img src="images/gov_folsum.jpg" width="233" height="147" align="left" alt="governor with kids">He
was elected to a full term in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1992<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, and has been reelected by a
solid margin every two years . Over his decade as Governor, Gov.
Dean has retired the state's deficit and built comfortable budget
reserves, cut the income tax and the sales tax on most clothing,
improved the state&#146;s bond rating, and reduced the state debt.
In addition. Gov. Dean has established Vermont as a national leader
in the areas of children's prevention programs, health care reform,
and welfare reform. He has also focused on improving public schools,
and helping Vermont families meet the cost of sending their children
to college.</font></p>
<!-- #EndEditable -->

<p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
<font FACE="Arial" SIZE="2">
<p align="center"><b>&nbsp;<font FACE="Univers"><img border="0" src="_borders/ltgov10.jpg" width="199" height="251">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></b>
</font>
<b><font face="Univers" size="2">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
<p align="center"><b><i><font face="Book Antiqua" color="#800000" size="3">Doug Racine and his
Dad at the family business in S. Burlington</font></i></b></p>
<div style="position: absolute; top: 187255; left: 160; width: 299; height: 702; z-index: 1">
<b><font SIZE="2">
<p ALIGN="JUSTIFY">&nbsp;</font></b>
</div>
<p align="center"><b><font face="Arial" size="4" color="#800000">Biographical Sketch</font></b></p>
<p ALIGN="left" style="line-height: 100%"><font face="Univers" size="3"><b><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Douglas
A. Racine<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></b> was born on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>October 7, 1952<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>,
in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Burlington, Vermont<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>. He was educated in Burlington elementary and high
schools and graduated with honors from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Princeton University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1974. He is a
small business owner, serving as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Vice-president<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Willie Racine's Jeep/Isuzu,
Inc.<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, located in South Burlington.</font></p>
<p ALIGN="justify" style="line-height: 100%"><font face="Univers" size="3">Doug
served five terms in the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Vermont<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Senate<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> (1983-1992) and served as President <i>pro
tempore </i>for four years (1989-1992). He was sworn in as Vermont's Lieutenant Governor
on January 9, 1997. During his service as Chittenden County Senator, he served
on the Senate Appropriations Committee and was Chairman of the Senate Natural
Resources Committee.&nbsp;</font></p>
<p ALIGN="JUSTIFY"><font face="Univers" size="3">Doug Racine is currently serving a
third term as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Vermonts
Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>.</font></p>
&nbsp;<!--msnavigation--></td></tr><!--msnavigation--></table><!--msnavigation--><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%"><tr><td>

<p align="center">&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="default.htm">Home</a></p>

</td></tr><!--msnavigation--></table></body>

</html>
ENDOFDOC

<html>

<head>
<title>About Governor Locke</title>
</head>

<body background="../img/bkgrnd2.jpg" topmargin=-1 leftmargin=-1>
<a name="Top">

<p><img src="../img/govsbanner7.jpg" alt="About the Governor" WIDTH=620 HEIGHT=84 border=0><br><br>

     <p></p>
	 <font face="Arial,sans-serif"><font color="Navy">

	  <STRONG>
	  <P>&nbsp;&nbsp;<A href="monabio.htm" title="Mona Locke">Mona Locke</A>&nbsp; |&nbsp; 
&nbsp;&nbsp;<A href="family.htm" title="Family Moments">Family Moments</A>&nbsp; |&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;<A href="mansion/mansion.htm" title="Links">Tour the Executive Mansion</A></P>
     </STRONG>
	  </FONT> 
      <P></P>

<hr width="90%" align="left">
<div align="left">

<font face="Arial,sans-serif"><table border="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%">
  <tr>
    <td width="100%" height="1" valign="top"><p align="center"><font size="+1" color="Navy"><b><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> Gary Locke's Biography</b></font></p>
    <P><b>Making <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Washington<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> a better place to live, work, and raise a family</b></P>
	
	<p align="left">
	
	<FONT SIZE=2><P><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Gary Locke<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was elected Washington's 21st <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>Nov. 5, 1996<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, making him the first Chinese-American governor in U.S. history.  <img src="../img/gmed.jpg" alt="Gary Locke, Mona Lee Locke, Emily and Dylan Locke" align="left" border=0>As <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, he has worked to make Washington public schools the best in the nation, promote jobs and economic development in rural and urban areas, and fight juvenile crime.  On <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>Nov. 7, 2000<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, the governor was re-elected to his second term.</P>
<P><img
    src="../img/dad.jpg" alt="James Locke" align="right" WIDTH="144" HEIGHT="157">Born into an immigrant family on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>Jan.&nbsp;21,&nbsp;1950<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, Gary spent his first six years in Seattle's Yesler Terrace, a public housing project for families of World War II veterans.  His father, James Locke, served in the 5th Armored Division of the U.S. Army under General George Patton and landed on the beaches of Normandy shortly after D-Day.  Following the war, James Locke met his wife, Julie, in Hong Kong and settled in Seattle, where they raised their five children.</P>
<p>Gary worked in his father's grocery store.  He worked hard, became an Eagle Scout, and graduated with honors from Seattle's <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Franklin High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1968.  Then, through a combination of part-time jobs, financial aid and scholarships, Gary attended <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Yale University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, where he received his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor's degree in political science<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> in 1972.  After earning a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Boston University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1975, he worked for several years as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>deputy prosecutor<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in King County, prosecuting people for crimes such as robbery and murder.</p>
<P>In 1982, Gary was elected to the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Washington State House of Representatives<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, where he served on the House Judiciary and Appropriations committees, with his final five years as chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.  As chairman, Gary negotiated bi-partisan budgets that increased college and university enrollments, improved children's health-care services, and strengthened environmental protections.</P>
<P>Gary was elected <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>chief executive of King County<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1993 and took on all of the challenges facing Washington's most complex urban area.  During his term, he cut the budget, expanded transit services, established a program to reward county departments for saving money, and developed a nationally acclaimed growth management plan.</P>
<P>As governor, Gary has worked to make <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Washington<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> a better place to live, work, and raise a family.  Believing that education is the great equalizer, he has made it his top priority.  He created Washington's Promise Scholarships for top high school students from working, middle-class families. He has pushed to hire more teachers and to reduce class size in the K-12 system. He appointed an Academic Achievement and Accountability Commission to help identify and improve schools that are struggling in the effort to raise test scores. He also created the Washington Reading Corps to help students who are struggling as they learn to read.  And his Youth Safety Summit brought together educators, community leaders, students, and law enforcement leaders to begin addressing school violence.</P>
<P>In 1997, Gary signed into law a landmark welfare reform bill that puts work first and has reduced the number of families on welfare by almost a third.  He helped roll back business and occupation taxes for businesses, and in 1999 refunded $200 million in taxes from the injured workers fund.  He has also put forward a Rural Economic Development proposal to help rural economies grow by making vital funds available for infrastructure development and work force training.  Gary proposed a transportation plan in 1998 that provides strategic solutions for congested traffic corridors in urban areas, focusing on basics such as maintenance and highway improvements.  His Offender Accountability Act will increase the supervision of felons after they have served their time.</P>
<P>Gary and his wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Mona Lee Locke<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, a former reporter for <img
    src="../img/gamopic.jpg" alt="Locke Family Photo" align="left" WIDTH="136" HEIGHT="180">KING 5 television in Seattle, were married on <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>Oct. 15, 1994<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/>.  They are the parents of <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Emily Nicole<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, born on March 9, 1997, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Dylan James<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, born on March 13, 1999.</P>
	</FONT>
	
	</td>
    <td width="8" bgcolor="#E6E6E6" valign="top">&nbsp;</td>
    <td width="262" valign="top">&nbsp;<p align="center"><br>
    </p>
    <p align="center">&nbsp;<img src="../img/govbw1.jpg" alt="Govenror Gary Locke"></p>
<p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
    <p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
    <p align="center"><font face="Arial" color="#000080"><strong><br>
    </strong></font></p>
    
    <p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
    <p align="center"><img src="../img/kids.jpg" alt="With friends and relatives"
    WIDTH="144" HEIGHT="192"></p>
    <p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
    <p align="center"><br>
    </p>
    <p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
    <p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
    <p align="center"><img src="../img/gmem.jpg" alt="Locke Family Photo 1997" WIDTH="156"
    HEIGHT="250"></p>
    <p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
    <p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
        <p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
    <p align="center"><img src="../img/picfam.jpg" alt="The Lockes with Emily as a baby"
    WIDTH="146" HEIGHT="150"></td>
  </tr>
</table></font>
</div>

<html>

<head>
<title>WA STATE <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>BRAD OWEN<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></title>
</head>

<body BGCOLOR="#ffffff">

<p><img SRC="titltgov.jpg" ALT="icon" WIDTH="478" HEIGHT="59"></p>

<hr SIZE="3">

<p><img ALIGN="LEFT" hspace="20" SRC="owen.jpg" ALT="photo" WIDTH="195" HEIGHT="252"> </p>

<h2>LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR</h2>
<font size="+4"><strong>

<p>BRAD OWEN</strong></font> </p>

<h3>President of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Washington<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> State Senate</h3>

<p><br clear="left">
</p>

<hr SIZE="2">
<strong>

<p>Office:</strong><br>
304 Legislative Building<br>
P.O. Box 40400<br>
Olympia, WA 98504-0400<br>
Telephone: (360) 786-7700.<br>
<a href="mailto:owen_br@leg.wa.gov"><img border="0" SRC="ballgrn.gif" WIDTH="12" HEIGHT="12"> <strong>e-mail:</strong></a>
owen_br@leg.wa.gov </p>

<p><strong>Democrat:</strong> Term expires January 2005.</p>

<p><strong>Appointed Member:</strong> <a HREF="http://www.leg.wa.gov/senate/scs/rule/">Senate
Rules Committee, Chair</a></p>

<p><strong>Official Duties:</strong> <em>As excerpted from the</em> <a href="http://www.leg.wa.gov/pub/other/washington_constitution.txt"><em>Washington State
Constitution</em>: </a></p>

<blockquote>
  <blockquote>
    <p><strong>ARTICLE III, SECTION 16,</strong> <u>Lieutenant Governor, Duties...</u>
    &quot;The Lieutenant Governor shall be presiding officer of the State Senate, and shall
    discharge such other duties as may be prescribed by law...&quot;</p>
  </blockquote>
</blockquote>

<hr SIZE="3">

<p><font size="+1"><strong><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Brad Owen<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></strong></font> was elected Washington's fifteenth
<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1996<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, and again in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>2000<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>. </p>

<p>Prior to his election to the office of Lieutenant Governor he was a member of the
<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Washington State Senate<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, 1983-1996; <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>House of Representatives<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, 1976-1982; <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Shelton City
Finance Commissioner<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, 1976-1979.</p>

<p>Lieutenant Governor Owen serves on the following committees: The State Capitol
Committee; The State Finance Committee; The Washington Health Care Facilities Authority;
Washington Higher Education Facilities Authority; Chairman, Legislative Committee on
Economic Development; Public Deposit Protection Commission; The State Medal of Merit
Committee.</p>

<p>In addition to his public service, Lt. Governor Owen has participated in the Governor's
Council on Substance Abuse and the Washington State Substance Abuse Coalition, Board of
Trustees, Co-chair Youth Community Service.</p>

<p>He has also been a member in the Shelton Elks Club and Mason County Chapter, Trout
Unlimited.</p>

<p>Lt. Governor Owen has received the following awards: 1995 Legislator of the Year,
Washington State Patrol Troopers Assn.; 1995 Legislator of the Year, Washington State Farm
Bureau; Outstanding Male Non-Veteran 1994, Washington Department of Veterans Affairs.</p>

<p>Employment: President, Strategies for Youth, Drug/Alcohol Education Non-Profit
Corporation.</p>

<p>Lt. Governor Owen is an avid outdoorsman and sportsman. Brad and his wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Linda<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, live
in <TAG name="RESCITY" value="start"/>Shelton<TAG name="RESCITY" value="end"/>. They have six children: <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Shanie<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Dana<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Sherri<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Mark<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Adam<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Royce<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and eight
grandchildren, Elizabeth, Casey, Amanda, Savannah, Joshua, CammiAnn, Seth and Sophia. </p>

<hr SIZE="3">

<p align="center">[ <a href="../senate/default.htm">Senate Homepage</a> | <a href="../default.htm">Legislative Homepage</a> | <a href="ltgovhist.htm">Historical View
of Lt. Governors</a> ] </p>

<p><small><small><em>Last Update:<br>
<!--webbot bot="Timestamp" S-Type="EDITED" S-Format="%m/%d/%y %I:%M %p" startspan -->09/29/00 11:35 AM<!--webbot bot="Timestamp" endspan i-checksum="26129" --></em></small></small></p>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<html>

<head>
<title>Mona Lee Locke's Biography</title>
</head>

<body bgcolor="White" background="../img/bkgrnd2.jpg" topmargin=-1 leftmargin=-1>
<img src="../img/govsbanner7.jpg" width="620" height="84" alt="" border="0"><br><br>
<p align="center"><font face="Arial, sans-serif"><b>Washington's <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Mona Locke<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></b></font></p>
<a name="Top">

<hr>

<p align="left"><font face="Arial,sans-serif"><img src="../img/monapic2.jpg" width="200" height="286" border="0" hspace="10" align="left" alt="Photo of First Lady Mona Locke"><b><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Mona Locke<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></b>, wife of Washington Governor <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Gary Locke<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, became the state's twentieth <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on January 15, 1997.  Governor and Mrs. Locke are the proud parents of <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Emily Nicole<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, born in March 1997, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Dylan James<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, born in March 1999.</p>

<p>Mrs. Locke co-chaired the <a href="../early/home1.htm">Governor's Commission on Early Learning</a> which was charged with ensuring that every child in Washington state goes to school prepared to succeed.  It was comprised of leaders in education, child care, health, business and government.  </p>

<p>The commission primarily focused on helping all caregivers, whether parents, grandparents, or child care providers, get the tools they need to maximize the growth and development of children from birth to age five.  The commission launched a statewide public awareness campaign and established the non-profit <a href="http://www.welfoundation.org/">Foundation for Early Learning</a> to help reach this goal.  Mrs. Locke currently serves as the Board Chair.</p>

<p>The First Lady is an advocate for other issues related to children and education.  She is the honorary chair of the Washington state SAFEKIDS Coalition, and honorary co-chair of <a href="http://www.hmhbwa.org/">Healthy Mothers, Healthy Babies</a>.  She also is a member of the advisory board of <a href="http://mavia.org">Mothers Against Violence in America</a> (MAVIA).  Mona Locke says her proudest and most important role, however, is being a good mom.</p>

<p>Mrs. Locke, who left her career as a television reporter when her husband ran for Governor, is still a journalist at heart.  In 1999, she co-produced and narrated a local Public Broadcasting System documentary on early learning in China.  It was based on a cross-cultural exchange trip to China that she led.  Fifty teachers, child care providers and parent educators from five Northwest states participated.</p>

<p>Mrs. Locke earned her <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>bachelor's degree in English Literature<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of California, at Berkeley<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.  She has a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>master's degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.  She has worked as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>television news reporter<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in Washington DC, Green Bay, Wisconsin, and Seattle, Washington.</p></font>
</div><a name="Top">

<hr>
</a>

<p><font face="Trebuchet MS" size="2"><a href="../"><img alt="[HOME]"
border="0" src="../img/shome.gif" WIDTH="20" HEIGHT="20"></a> &nbsp; </font></p>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<head>

<link rel="stylesheet" href="governor.css" type="text/css">
<title>Meet the Governor</title>

<meta name="description" content="Welcome to the West Virginia Governor's online office. 
Here you can find information about Bob Wise' Economic Development Plan, PROMISE Scholarships,
his Blueprint for Technology and much more.">
<meta name="keywords" content="West Virginia Governor, Governor Bob Wise, State Governor's,
State Governor Web Sites, WV Scholarships, WV Government, West Virginia Government, 
Digital Government, WV Economic Development, Economic Development, Governor Wise">

</head>

<body marginheight="0" marginwidth="0" topmargin="0" leftmargin="0" background="images/sBg.gif">

<div align="left">
  <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%">
    <tr>
      <td width="1%" nowrap>
      <img border="0" src="images/s1Masthead1.jpg" alt="Robert E. Wise, Jr. took the Oath of Office to become West Virginias 33rd governor on January 15, 2001. Before becoming Governor, he served the citizens of West Virginias 2nd Congressional District for 18 years." width="165" height="114"><img border="0" src="images/s1Masthead2.jpg" alt="The West Virginia State Capitol Building was originally built in Wheeling, WV. It now sits on 16 acres of land in Charleston, WV at a height of 292 ft." width="172" height="114"><img border="0" src="images/s1Masthead3.jpg" alt="As the second tallest bridge in the United States, the New River Gorge Bridge was completed in 1978 and weighs 88 million pounds!" width="169" height="114"><img border="0" src="images/s1Masthead4.jpg" alt="June 20, 1863 is the day West Virginia became the 35th state in the union, the only state born out of the armed conflict of the Civil War." width="199" height="114"></td>
      <td width="99%" bgcolor="#323365" nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td width="1%" nowrap>
      <img border="0" src="images/s2Masthead1.gif" alt="West Virginia Governor Bob Wise" width="92" height="21"><a href="default.htm"><img border="0" src="images/s2Masthead2.gif" alt="Home" width="91" height="21"></a><a href="MeetGov.htm"><img border="0" src="images/sButtons3.gif" alt="Meet the Governor" width="154" height="21"></a><a href="appts.htm"><img border="0" src="images/sButtons4.gif" alt="Appointments" width="122" height="21"></a><a href="NewsRoom.htm"><img border="0" src="images/sButtons5.gif" alt="News Room" width="108" height="21"></a><a href="contact.htm"><img border="0" src="images/sButtons6.gif" alt="Contact Us" width="138" height="21"><br>
        </a><img border="0" src="images/tMeetGov.gif" alt="Meet the Governor" width="259" height="20"></td>
      <td width="99%" nowrap background="images/sCellBg.gif">&nbsp;</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td width="100%" colspan="2">
      <div align="center">
        <table border="0" cellpadding="2" width="75%">
          <tr>
            <td width="100%" valign="top" align="right">
              <p align="left"><b><font color="#996633"><br>
              </font></b><b><font color="#999966"><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Bob Wise<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/><br>
              <TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="start"/>State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>West Virginia<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/></font></b></p>
              <p align="left">&nbsp;</p>
              <p align="left"><font color="#323365"><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Bob Wise<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, West Virginia's 33rd
              governor, took office on January 15, 2001. He immediately launched
              a bold legislative agenda: funding the PROMISE Scholarships,
              stimulating economic development and increasing the availability
              of health insurance to the state's children.</font><font color="#323365">&nbsp;</font></p>
              <p align="left">&nbsp;</p>
              <p align="left">T<font color="#323365">he level of activity in Gov.
              Wise's first weeks in office was no shock to those who have
              followed his political career. West Virginia's senior statesman,
              Senator Robert C. Byrd, has described Wise as &quot;a steam engine
              in britches.&quot;
              
              </font></p>
              <p  align="left">&nbsp;
<span style="mso-tab-count:1"><font color="#323365">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
              </font></p>
              <p  align="left"><font color="#323365">Wise's victory in the 
              election of <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>2000<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> was the latest step in a career in public service. It was based on a spirited
              campaign that took the candidate repeatedly across the state,
              where he pledged to revive the state's stagnant economy, push for
              better schools and colleges and find a middle road between
              environmentalists and the energy industry.
              
              </font></p>
              <p  align="left"><span style="mso-tab-count:1"><font color="#323365">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
              </font></p>
              <p  align="left"><font color="#323365">Before becoming governor, he served
              the citizens of West Virginia's 2nd Congressional District for 18
              years, having first won his seat in 1982. The district - one of
              the largest in the east - stretches from the Ohio River on the
              west to the easternmost tip of the state at Harper's Ferry. As a
              representative, he traveled the district almost nonstop when
              Congress was not in session - a practice that made him very
              familiar with the potential and the problems of scores of West
              Virginia communities.
              
              </font></p>
              <p  align="left"><span style="mso-tab-count:1"><font color="#323365">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
              </font></p>
              <p  align="left"><font color="#323365">In Washington, he was a ranking
              member of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee
              and helped bring federal support to dozens of important road
              projects in West Virginia.
              
              </font></p>
              <p  align="left"><span style="mso-tab-count:1"><font color="#323365">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
              </font></p>
              <p  align="left"><font color="#323365">Wise first won elective office in
              1980 when he was elected to the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>West Virginia State Senate<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. Two
              years later, he ran for the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>U.S. House of Representatives<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and won
              the first of nine consecutive congressional elections. While in
              Congress, Wise served in his party's leadership as an at-large
              whip, a regional whip and parliamentarian.
              
              </font></p>
              <p  align="left"><span style="mso-tab-count:1"><font color="#323365">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
              </font></p>
              <p  align="left"><font color="#323365">Wise consistently voted against
              congressional pay raises and used a portion of his salary to fund
              scholarships at every college and university in his district.
              
              </font></p>
              <p  align="left"><span style="mso-tab-count:1"><font color="#323365">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
              </font></p>
              <p  align="left"><font color="#323365">Wise grew up in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Charleston<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>, where
              he attended public schools. He is a graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Duke University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>
              and the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Tulane University College of Law<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. Wise is married to <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Sandy
              Wise<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, and they have two children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Robert<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Alexandra<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>. </font></td>
            </tr>
          </table>
      </div>
      <p>&nbsp;
      </td>
    </tr>
  </table>
</div>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

</body>

</html>
ENDOFDOC

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jim Geringer<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF" BACKGROUND="/state/images/backgrounds/whiteseal2.gif">
<FONT FACE="Arial">
<CENTER>
<H1><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Jim Geringer<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></H1>
</CENTER>
<BR>
<IMG SRC="/governor/first_family/governor.jpg" HEIGHT="245" WIDTH="210"
BORDER=0 ALIGN="Left" ALT="Governor Jim Geringer">
<P>
  Born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Wheatland, Wyoming<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>April 24, 1944<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, Jim was the second oldest of seven children.  His
father had settled in Wheatland after emigrating from old German settlements in Russia in the
early part of this century.  Jim's mother's family came from Sweden.  Jim was reared on the family
farm and graduated from Wheatland High School.
<P>
  Jim holds a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Kansas State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> which
he received in 1967.
<BR>
<IMG SRC="/governor/first_family/family-1.jpg" HEIGHT="333"
WIDTH="278" ALIGN="RIGHT" BORDER=0 ALT="First Family">
<BR>
That same year Jim married his wife <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Sherri<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, was commissioned as an <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>officer
in the United States Air Force<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and assigned to space development programs in California.  He
participated in the development of a variety of Air Force and NASA space boosters, including
launches of reconnaissance satellites, the NASA Viking Mars lander, an upper stage booster for
the space shuttle, and the Global Positioning Satellite System.  Jim also served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>chief of
computer programming<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at a ground receiving station for early warning satellites.
<P>
  So that he and Sherri could bring up their young family in the quality environment of rural
Wyoming, Jim in 1977 gave up a promising career in the United States Air Force.  To facilitate
the transition back to farming, Jim accepted a position at the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Missouri Basin Power Project's
Laramie River Station<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>contract administrator<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and worked there during the peak construction
years from 1977 to 1979, after which he went into farming and cattle feeding full time.  The
Geringers started from scratch and by 1987 had bought their own farm.
<P>
<IMG SRC="/governor/first_family/family-ranch.jpg" HEIGHT="171" WIDTH="470" ALIGN="Left" BORDER=0 ALT="First Family's Ranch">  
<BR>
  Jim also continued his military service as an officer in the United States Air Force Reserve
including such assignments as activation of the Peacekeeper missiles at F. E. Warren Air Force
Base, Cheyenne.
<BR CLEAR="LefT">
<P>
<IMG SRC="/governor/first_family/gov-legislature.jpg" HEIGHT="269" 
WIDTH="431" BORDER=0 ALIGN="Right" ALT="Governor in Legislature">
 <BR>
First elected to the Legislature in 1982, Jim served six years each in the
House and Senate gaining valuable experience as a member of a number of
committees including terms as chairman of the Appropriations, Management
Audit and judiciary Committees. 
<P>
Jim's community activities include the Farm Bureau, Kiwanis, Farmer's
Union, Rotary, Lions, Ducks Unlimited, Pheasants Forever, National
Federation of Independent Business, Chamber of Commerce,
and the American Legion.  The Geringers are active members of the 
Lutheran Church.
<P>
<BR CLEAR="Right">
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
<CENTER>

<IMG SRC="/state/images/buttons/nav-home.jpg" HEIGHT="59" WIDTH="113" BORDER=0 ALT="Home"></A>

<IMG SRC="/state/images/buttons/nav-com.jpg" HEIGHT="59" WIDTH="113" BORDER=0 ALT="Comments"></A>

HEIGHT="59" WIDTH="113" BORDER=0 ALT="Search"></A>

Governor's Office<BR>
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Wyoming<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> State Capitol<BR>
