<img src="media/cat_patricia.gif" width=170 height=30 border=0 alt="Patricia"><br>
<a href="biography.html"><img src="media/btn_biography.gif" width=170 height=18 border=0 alt="Biography"></a><br>
<a href="photoalbum.html"><img src="media/btn_photoalbum.gif" width=170 height=18 border=0 alt="Photo Album"></a><br>
<a href="contact.html"><img src="media/btn_contact.gif" width=170 height=18 border=0 alt="Contact"></a><br>
<img src="media/children.jpg" border=0 alt=""></td>
<td colspan=2 class="flHeader"><br>Biography</td>
<td width=195 valign=top><img src="media/crn_patricia2.gif" border=0 alt="Patricia Kempthorne" width=195 height=32></td>
<tr>
<td colspan=3 width=410 valign=top>&nbsp;
<p><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Patricia Kempthorne<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, married to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Idaho<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Governor <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Dirk Kempthorne<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> for <TAG name="YRSMARR" value="start"/>23
years<TAG name="YRSMARR" value="end"/>, grew up in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Boise, Idaho<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> and graduated from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Idaho<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>
with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degree in business management<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>. The First Lady's interests encompass
issues concerning children, families and communities and finding solutions
to the specific challenges they face, including parenting, education,
healthy life choices and work-life balance. She helped to found the Family
and Workplace Consortium in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Idaho<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, which encourages and assists companies
in developing a family consciousness in practice and policy. In addition,
she has owned her own business consulting for employers on family and
work/life issues. In 2000 Mrs. Kempthorne joined Business Psychology
Associates, in Boise, as the Director of Work-Life Initiatives.</p>
<p>As part of the Governor's Generation of the Child initiative, she
serves as the co-chair of the Governor's Coordinating Council for Families
and Children and as a liaison for numerous boards and commissions.</p>
<p>Mrs. Kempthorne is a member of Leadership to Keep Children Alcohol
Free. The initiative has brought together 28 Governors' spouses in support
of a nationwide public education effort focused upon preventing underage
drinking, with a special focus on the 9-15 age group.</p>
<p>Mrs. Kempthorne serves on the University of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Idaho<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> College of Business
and Economics advisory board, is an honorary chair for the Boys and Girls
Club and the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Idaho<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> State Library Summer Reading Ambassador. She also
serves on the advisory councils of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Idaho<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Kids Count, St. Luke's Children's
Hospital and The Casey Family Foundation. She is on the board of directors
for the Boise Family YMCA and the World Sports Humanitarian Hall of Fame.
</td>
</tr>
<tr align=right>
<td colspan=5 width=600 class="flContent">&nbsp;<br>
<a href="index.html">Home</a>| <a href="http://www2.state.id.us/gov/govhmpg.htm">Governor Kempthorne</a>| <a href="http://www.accessidaho.org">Access <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Idaho<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></a><img src="media/stripe.gif" width=600 height=18 border=0 alt="---"></td>
</tr>
</table>
</body>
</html>

<html>
<head>


<title>GRAVES Biography</title>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" background="http://www.ink.org/public/governor/backgrounds/stone.jpg">
<center><img src="http://www.ink.org/public/governor/images/govframe.jpg" alt="Governor Bill Graves" border=0 naturalsizeflag=3 height=169 width=135 align=BOTTOM></center>
<center><table border=0 cellspacing=2 cellpadding=0 width="90%">
<tr>
<td>
<center><b><font size=+1><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>BILL GRAVES<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></font></b>
<br><i><font size=+1><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></font></i></center>
<p><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Bill Graves<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is the 43rd <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>.&nbsp; The Governor was re-elected 
to his second term with the largest percentage of votes of any Governor 
in the nation, and the largest percentage of votes in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> history.&nbsp; 
He is the first <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> re-elected in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> since 1962, 
and the states longest serving <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>.&nbsp; Governor Graves 
is a native of <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Salina<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>, where he grew up involved in the family business, 
Graves Truck Line. 
<p>He earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degree in Business Administration<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Kansas Wesleyan University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>
in Salina and attended graduate school at the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Kansas<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.&nbsp;
Prior to his election as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, he <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>served two terms as <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Secretary
of State<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.
<p>Governor Graves emphasis has been on sound fiscal management, lower
taxes, quality education, reducing the size of state government and common
sense regulation.
<p>He currently serves on the Jayhawk Area Council of the Boy Scouts of
America executive board, as well as the board of trustees for <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Wesleyan
University and the Sunflower State Games, and is an alumnus of the 1985
class of Leadership <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.&nbsp;
<p>The Governor and his wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Linda Richey Graves<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, are the very proud parents
of 4-year old daughter, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Katie<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.
<p>
<hr align=LEFT>
<center>
<h3>
The Governor at a Glance:</h3></center>
<li>
43rd <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, elected on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 8, 1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/></li>
<li>
Assumed office on January 9, 1995 (his 42nd birthday)</li>
<li>
Re-elected in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> with 73% of the vote, carrying all 105 counties in the
State</li>
<li>
Previously, Graves served eight years as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Secretary of State<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> -- first
elected in 1986 and re-elected in 1990</li>
<li>
Graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Kansas Wesleyan University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1975, with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degree in Business
Administration<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/></li>
&nbsp; 
<p>
<hr align=LEFT>
<center>
<h3>
Memberships and boards:</h3></center>
<li>
Executive committee of the Jayhawk Area Council of the Boy Scouts of America&nbsp;</li>
<li>
Board of the Sunflower State Games&nbsp;</li>
<li>
Member of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Chamber of Commerce &amp; Industry&nbsp;</li>
<li>
Graduate of the 1985 class of Leadership <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&nbsp;</li>
<li>
Commander in Chief of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Cavalry, a public sector-based recruitment
team&nbsp;</li>
<li>
Natural Resources Committee of the National Governor's Association&nbsp;</li>
<li>
Commander in Chief of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Army and Air National Guards</li>
<p>
<hr align=LEFT>
<p><a href="http://www.ink.org/public/governor/govmeet.html">Return to
the Meet the Governor Page</a>
<br><a href="http://www.ink.org/public/governor/duffrose.html">Picture
of the Governor and First Lady</a>
<p>
<hr align=LEFT></td>
</tr>
</table></center>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<td width=10 bgcolor="#FFFFFF" valign=top align=left><img src="images/topleft_arc.gif" width=6 height=7></td>
<td width=430 bgcolor="#FFFFFF" valign=top align=left class=bodytext>
<p><img src="images/bio.gif" width=106 height=32 border=0 alt="Biography"></p>
<p><b><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>GARY SHERRER<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></b></p>
<p><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> <br>
and SECRETARY OF COMMERCE AND HOUSING</p>
<p><b>The Lieutenant Governor At-a-Glance:<br>
</b>Family: Married; two children<br>
Spouse: <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Judy<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/><br>
Appointed: <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>July 18, 1996<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/><br>
Elected: <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November, 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/><br>
Term Expires: January, 2003</p>
<p><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Gary Sherrer<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was appointed <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> by Governor Bill Graves 
on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>July 18, 1996<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, and was elected to the office in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>. Sherrer is <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'
45th <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, and on July 21, 2000, he became the longest 
serving <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> history by serving 1,464 days in 
office. </p>
<p>In addition to his duties as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>, Sherrer also serves 
as the Secretary of <a href="http://www.kansascommerce.com"><font color="#0000cc">Commerce 
and Housing</font></a>. As Secretary, he oversees the agency charged with 
fostering and promoting economic development and enhancing the availability 
of affordable housing in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>. </p>
<p>As Chairman-Elect of the <a href="http://www.nclg.org/"><font color="#0000CC">National 
Conference of Lieutenant Governors</font></a>, Lieutenant Governor Sherrer 
helps lead the professional association which represents the elected officials 
who are next in line of succession to the governors in the 50 states and 
five territorial jurisdictions. </p>
<p>Lieutenant Governor Sherrer also serves as the Vice-Chair of the Governor's 
Cabinet, Co-Chair of the Midwest Economic Development Cooperation Council, 
and he recently served as the Chairman of the Governor's Vision 21st Century 
Task Force. As Chairman of the <a href="http://www.ink.org/public/governor/vision/index.html"><font color="#0000CC">Vision 
21st Century</font></a>Task Force, Sherrer directed a group of nearly 
100 well-respected Kansans who made recommendations to the Governor concerning 
the refocusing of policies and strategies as <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> enters the new millennium.</p>
<p>He was honored with the Emporia State University Distinguished Alumni 
Award in 1994 and the Emporia State University Award of Excellence in 
1995. In 1999, Lieutenant Governor Sherrer was selected for the national 
Henry Toll Fellowship Program, and in 2000, he received the Carl Perkins 
Humanitarian Award in recognition of his contributions to the improvement, 
promotion, development and progress of career and technical education.</p>
<p>Before beginning work for Governor Graves, Lieutenant Governor Sherrer 
spent the majority of his career in the financial industry and has always 
played an active role in the community. He is a founder of the Leadership 
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Program, and he created Leadership Wichita. </p>
<p>Lieutenant Governor Sherrer is a native Kansan who graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Topeka 
High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Emporia State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. In <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1965<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/>, he married <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Judy Waller<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> 
of El Dorado, Kansas. They have two grown children - <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Stuart<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> of Wichita, 
Kansas and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Nancy<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> of Prairie Village, Kansas. </p>
</td>
<td width=10 bgcolor="#FFFFFF" valign=top align=right class=bodytext>
<p><img src="images/topright_arc.gif" width=6 height=7><br>
</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width=162 class=leftnav valign=top>&nbsp;</td>
<td width=10>&nbsp;</td>
<td width=10 bgcolor="#FFFFFF" align=left valign=bottom><img src="images/lowleft_arc.gif" width=6 height=7></td>
<td width=430 bgcolor="#FFFFFF" class=bodytext>&nbsp;</td>
<td width=10 bgcolor="#FFFFFF" class=bodytext align=right valign=bottom><img src="images/lowright_arc.gif" width=6 height=7></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</body>
</html>

<head>


<title><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Linda Graves<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> Biography</title>
</head>
<body background="http://www.ink.org/public/governor/backgrounds/stone.jpg">
<center><img src="http://www.ink.org/public/governor/images/ladyframe.jpg" alt="Photo of First Lady Linda Graves" height=169 width=135>
<br><font color="#000000"><font size=+2><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Linda Graves<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></font></font></center>
<blockquote>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Linda Richey Graves<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, married to Governor
<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Bill Graves<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, has made the well-being of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> children and their families
the cornerstone of her work as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>.
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; She is the honorary chairman of Operation Immunize,
a nationally recognized, statewide effort to insure timely childhood immunizations,
and the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Breast and Cervical Cancer Initiative. Linda also is the
honorary co-chairman of the capital campaign for Exploration Place, a new
children's science and technology museum opening this spring in Wichita.
She served as co-chairman of the Governor's Task Force on Childhood Hunger
and is spokesman for K.I.D.S., the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Identification Sticker Program
promoting the use of safety seats.
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In addition, Linda is a member of the board
of directors of the Youth Entrepreneurs of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, the Shawnee Mission
Medical Center Foundation, KCPT public television and the Greater Community
Foundation of Johnson County. She serves as a director to the Unified Group
of Mutual Funds, Waddell &amp; Reed Funds, Inc., and Target Funds, Inc.
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Linda has led the effort to restore Cedar Crest,
the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> governor's residence, and has raised over $2 million in private
funds for the home. The <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Preservation Alliance honored her in March
2000 with their Award for Excellence, given annually to recognize exemplary
preservation projects in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Topeka<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, she is the daughter of Ronald
and Florence Richey. She earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degree in history<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>, graduating magna cum
laude from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Oklahoma State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. She is a member of Pi Beta Phi Sorority.
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Linda was awarded a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>, cum laude,
from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Washburn University School of Law<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Topeka. She then joined the
Kansas City law firm of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Levy and Craig, P.C.<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, an 80-year-old firm specializing
in business law.
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Linda was honored to be the first woman admitted
to <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>partner<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in the firm. She holds an <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>honorary Doctorate of Law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from
<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Baker University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. Linda met Governor Graves on a blind date in 1988 arranged
by mutual friends. They were married in <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1990<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/> and, in October 1995, welcomed
a daughter, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Katherine Preston Graves<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>..
<br>&nbsp;
<br>&nbsp;
<center>
<h3>
The First Lady at a Glance</h3></center>
<ul>
<li>
Became <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>January 9, 1995<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>.</li>
<li>
Was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Topeka<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, the daughter of Ron and Florence Richey.</li>
<li>
Earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Bachelor of Arts degree in History<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>, Magna Cum Laude, in 1975,
from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Oklahoma State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Law Degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>, Cum Laude, from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Washburn
University Law School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Topeka in 1978.</li>
<li>
Mrs. Graves is a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>partner<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Levy and Craig, P.C.<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, a 75-year-old firm that
specializes in the practice of business law.</li>
</ul>
</blockquote>
<center>
<p><b><font size=+1>Memberships and Boards:</font></b></center>
<blockquote>
<ul>
<li>
1993 graduate of Leadership <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></li>
<li>
Member of the Washburn Law School Year 2000 Committee</li>
<li>
First Vice-President and a member of the board of directors of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>
City Club.</li>
<li>
Member of the advisory board of the Johnson County Arts and Humanities
Council</li>
<li>
Serves with the Governor as Honorary Chairpersons of the 50th Anniversary
Season of the Topeka Symphony</li>
<li>
Director of the Board of Directors of the Ronald McDonald Children's Charities
of the Heart of America</li>
<li>
Recently completed her third term as director of the Camping Connection,
a <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> City area group that sponsors underprivileged children at summer
camp</li>
<li>
Honorary Chairperson for the "Think Ahead" campaign for healthier babies,
sponsored by the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Chapter of the March of Dimes</li>

Co-chairperson for the Governor's Task Force on Childhood Hunger</li>
<li>
Serves on the advisory board of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Kansas<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Specialty Dog Service, a non-profit

with children</li>
<li>
Official spokesperson for "Project Immunization," a statewide immunization
drive for children under 3 years old</li>

<html>
<head>
<title><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Mike Foster<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>'s Biography</title>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" background="../../images/seals/grayseal3.gif">
<table border=0 width="100%">
<tr>
<td width="24%"><img border=0 src="../../images/newgov.gif" width=169 height=185></td>
<td width="76%"><p align=center><font size=7>BIOGRAPHY</font></td>
</tr>
</table>
<div align=center>
<center>
<table border=0 cellpadding=0 width="94%">
<tr>
<td width="100%"><font face="Arial"><br>
<TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Murphy James &#147;Mike&#148;
Foster, Jr.<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was born on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>July 11, 1930<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Shreveport, Louisiana<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Shortly thereafter, his family moved to
<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Centerville<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> where he attended public school as a child.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
&nbsp;<br>
</span><br>
As a young man, he was involved in several extracurricular activities including the Boy
Scouts.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Attaining the highest honor and rank
of Eagle Scout is the one childhood accomplishment the Governor still cherishes and holds
dear.<br>
<br>
In 1948, he graduated from high school and enrolled at the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Virginia Military Institution<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>After one semester at the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Virginia
Military Institute<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, Governor Foster
transferred to <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Louisiana State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, where he was a member of the Delta Kappa
Epsilon fraternity and the National Order of the Scabbard and Blade.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>During his years at <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>LSU<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, he pursued a Chemical
Engineering degree; however, in 1952, he graduated in Chemistry.<br>
<br>
After graduating from the university, Governor Foster joined the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Air Force<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> and served in
the Korean War.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>After returning home to
Franklin from the war, he began farming sugar cane and soon after formed <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Bayou Sale
Contractors<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, primarily as a means to keep his farm crew together in the off-season.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Additionally, the Governor has been a board member
of several local banks, a junior warden of St. Mary&#146;s Episcopal Church, the president
of the St. Mary Parish Farm Bureau, and a member of the American Legion.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Over the years he has accumulated the following
licenses:<span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">&nbsp; </span>single engine, land and sea
multi-engine and instructor.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Also, he can fly
and is currently working towards his helicopter pilot&#146;s license.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>Governor Foster exemplifies a true modern day
renaissance man.<br>
<br>
A life in politics never appealed to Mike Foster; however, in 1986, after &#147;becoming
frustrated with the non-responsiveness of state government,&#148; he ran for a seat in the
State Senate.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>After fulfilling two very
active terms in the Senate, then Senator Foster decided that he could get more
accomplished as governor.<br>
<br>
On <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>January 8, 1996<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, after mounting a successful campaign as a <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> candidate,
<TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>M.J.
&#147;Mike&#148; Foster, Jr.<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, was inaugurated as <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Louisiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>&#146;s 49<sup>th</sup><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>
since the Louisiana Purchase in 1803.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>His
remarks in his inaugural address reflect a political philosophy that he still honors
today:</font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="100%">
<p align=center><font face="Arial"><br>
&#147;I
believe the people of our state must have the power to change
our state.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp;&nbsp;<br>
</span>I believe your values, your
voices, and<span style="mso-tab-count:1">&nbsp; </span>your
votes must lead the politicians&nbsp;<br>
rather than the politicians
<span style="mso-tab-count:1">
</span>leading
you.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>This is your state . . . now you must&nbsp;<br>
govern it.
<span style="mso-tab-count:1">
</span>My
job will be to see that you finally have the opportunity to
do so.&#148;<br>
<br>
</font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="100%"><font face="Arial">
After a very successful first term, Governor Foster ran for a 2<sup>nd</sup>term and won
in a landslide in the first primary.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>This was
the first time in many years that anyone has won the governorship outright without a
runoff election.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>He was inaugurated in
<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>January 2000<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> and this term will expire in 2004.<br>
<br>
When he is not running the state, Governor Foster enjoys spending his free time at his
home, <i>Oaklawn Manor</i>, in <TAG name="RESCITY" value="start"/>Franklin<TAG name="RESCITY" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>While
family, fishing and hunting occupy the bulk of his free time; his thirst for knowledge and
education has led him to take motorcycle and helicopter-flying lessons.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>He has even started taking courses part-time at
Southern University Law School in Baton Rouge.<br>
<br>
Governor Foster is happily married to <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Alice Cosner Foster<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
&nbsp; </span>He has two children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Murphy J. Foster, III.<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, who is an attorney in Baton
Rouge, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Ramelle Townley<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>He also has<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">&nbsp; </span>two stepchildren <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Paul<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Troy West<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, both
engineers, and many grandchildren.</font></td>
</tr>
</table>
</center>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify">
<span style="mso-tab-count:1">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><o:p></o:p></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">
&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><a href="../../default.htm" target=_top>[Home Page]</a><br>
<br>
</p>
</body>
</html>

<html>
<head>
<title>Biography of Lt. Governor Blanco</title>
</head>
<body bgcolor="White">
<img src="ltgovbig.gif" alt="Lt. Governor Kathleen Babineaux Blanco" align=right hspace=10 width=200 height=269 border=0><font size="+1" color="Navy"><b><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Kathleen Babineaux Blanco<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></b></font>is serving her second term as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor of the State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Louisiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>. She was re-elected by an overwhelming 80 percent of the state's electorate. As the state's second-highest official she oversees the Department of Culture, Recreation and Tourism, which encompasses the offices of State Parks, State Museums, State Libraries, Film and Video, and Cultural Development and Tourism. Also under her auspices is the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Louisiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Serve Commission and the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Louisiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Retirement Development Commission. <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Louisiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Serve oversees 64 national service projects across <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Louisiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, and involves more than 13,000 service volunteers. The Retirement Development Commission is dedicated to marketing <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Louisiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> as a premier retirement state.
<p>
<TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Kathleen Blanco<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> has served the state with distinction since 1984, when she became the first woman ever elected to represent the people of Lafayette in the State Legislature. She served two terms before being the first woman elected to the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Louisiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Public Service Commission. While on the PSC, she served as chairperson in 1993 and 1994. Then in 1996, she advanced to her current position. Since taking office, tourism in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Louisiana<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> has increased by 41 percent, representing growth not only in visitation, but in the hotel industry, air travel and in state park reservations as well. Her mission, along with many other economic initiatives, is to position Louisiana along with Paris, Rome and London as a top travel destination. 
<p>
The Lieutenant Governor has been married to her husband, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Raymond<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, since <TAG name="DOM" value="start"/>1964<TAG name="DOM" value="end"/>. They are the parents of six children and the proud grandparents of three. 
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<html>
<head>


<title>Bio</title>
</head>
<body bgcolor=white>
<div align=left>
<font face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular">
<table border=0 cellpadding=6 cellspacing=0 width=500>
<tr>
<td nowrap bgcolor="#cccc99"><font face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular" size=5><b><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Angus King<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> Biography</b></font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><font face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular" size=4><img height=205 width=300 src="../images/Family.jpg" align=right><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Angus S. King, Jr.<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is serving his second four-year term as <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maine<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s 71st <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>. Victorious in his
first bid for public office in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, King was reelected in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> by one of the largest margins of victory in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maine<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s history. He is one of the only two <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>independent<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> governors in the country.<br>
Born on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>March 31st, 1944<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, the Governor graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Dartmouth College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1966 and the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Virginia Law School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1969. He began his career in 1969 as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>staff attorney<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Pine Tree Legal Assistance<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in Skowhegan. In 1972 he became <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Chief Counsel to the U.S. Senate Subcommittee on Alcoholism and Narcotics<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in the office of then-Senator William D. Hathaway. In 1975 he returned to <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maine<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> to <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>practice law<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> with the firm of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Smith,
Loyd and King<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in Brunswick. In the same year he began his almost 20 year-stint as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>host of the television show &quot;<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maine<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Watch&quot;<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> on the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maine<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Public Broadcasting Network. In 1983 he became <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>vice-president and general counsel<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Swift River/Hafslund Company<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, an alternative energy development company based in Portland and Boston. Governor King founded and served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>President<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Northeast Energy Management, Inc.<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in 1989, a position he held for 5 years. The Brunswick-based company specialized in the development of large scale
energy conservation projects at commercial and industrial facilities in central and southern <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maine<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.<br>
Governor King is married to <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Mary J. Herman<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>. He is the father of four sons: <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Angus III<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Duncan<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>James<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Benjamin<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and a daughter, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Molly<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>.<br>
</font></td>
</tr>
</table>
</font></div>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<html>
<head>


<title>MARY J</title>

</head>
<body bgcolor=white>
<div align=left>
<table border=0 cellpadding=6 cellspacing=0 width=500>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#cccc99" nowrap><font size=5 face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular"><b><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Mary J. Herman<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>,</b></font><font face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular" size=5><b><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maine<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></b></font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<font size=7 face="Lucida Console">
<b>
<table border=0 cellpadding=3 cellspacing=0 width="100%">
<tr>
<td><img height=200 width=165 src="../images/Mary.jpg"></td>
<td valign=bottom><font face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular" size=4><b><a href="mailto:mary.herman@state.me.us"><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Mary
Herman<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></a></b></font></b></font><font face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular" size=3>, wife of Governor <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Angus King<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> and mother to <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Ben<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>,
10, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Molly<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>,
6, and three grown stepsons and a step
daughter-in-law, enjoys the challenge of balancing her time as mother, wife and <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>First Lady<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>.</font><font face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular" size=4><b><br>
</b>
</font>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<div align=left>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica,Geneva,Swiss,SunSans-Regular" size=3>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Mary's public priorities
focus on children, family literacy, community involvement in public education, women's health, and supporting and promoting <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maine<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> products and tourism,
<TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maine<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> artists and craftpersons.<br>
<br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Over the past five years, Mary has
served as honorary chair of the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maine<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Children's
Trust Fund, the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maine<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Women's Health Campaign, the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maine<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Breast Health Cooperative,
the Schools of Excellence for Health Education Committee, Safe Kids <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maine<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> and Well Suited, Inc.<br>
<br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Mary has also been an
active member of the Friends Board of her local library, the Board of the Portland Section of the Nation
Council of Jewish Women, and the Children's Museum of Maine Advisory
Board and the Advisory Board of Kits and Cases for
Kids and Arts are Elementary, a local school arts
program.<br>
<br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Her primary activities this year will continue to be chairing the
Statewide Family Literacy Task Force and serving as
an active member of the State Government Improvement
Committee for Child Protective Services.&nbsp; She most enjoys volunteering in her children's schools and
supporting community involvement in public education.<br>
<br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Mary Herman<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is a native of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, and
received her undergraduate degree from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Northwestern
University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.&nbsp; She received an <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Ed. M in Special Education<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Boston University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, and an <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>ADN<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Maine-Augusta<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>.&nbsp; Mary has been a
<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>teacher<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>; <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>special education teacher<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>; <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>family planning program
director<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>; <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>labor, delivery and nursery nurse<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>; and <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>substance abuse counselor/educator<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.&nbsp; Mary's &quot;initiation&quot; into public policy work began when she worked
for the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Maine<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Women's Lobby and continued when she
worked at and eventually owned a public policy consulting firm in
Augusta.&nbsp; She and <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Angus King<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> met 19 years ago.</font></div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<html>
<head>
<title><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Bob Holden<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></title>
<style type="text/css">
  TD { font-family: Arial, Helvetica; font size = 10pt; }
</style>
</head>
<body topmargin=0 leftmargin=0 marginwidth=0 marginheight=0>
<table border=0 bordercolor=red width=785 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0>
<tr>
<td valign=bottom width=229 height=192 background="back.jpg"><img src="gifs/spacer.gif"></td>
<td rowspan=2 valign=top>
<table border=0 bordercolor=yellow cellpadding=10 cellspacing=0 width=100%>
<td width="5%">
&nbsp;
</td>
<td>
<center><img border=0 src="header2.gif" width=393 height=97></center>
<hr width="100%" noshade size=5 color="#000080" align=center>
<table border=0 bordercolor=orange>
<tr>
<td colspan=2 align=left>
<p>&#9;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Bob Holden<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>s life is an affirmation of the American Dream.  Raised on a small rural farm and educated in a one-room schoolhouse, Holden fulfilled his lifelong aspiration on January 8, 2001, when he took the oath of office as <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s 5
3<sup>rd</sup><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>.  As the first <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> of this new century, Holden urged Missourians in his inaugural address to put aside their differences and unite to make the 21<sup>st</sup>century <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s century.   &quot;The goal of my adminis
tration is to unite all Missourians in forging a bright future that holds maximum opportunities for each of us,&quot; he said.  Holden believes that bright future can be found in a commitment to better education, improved health care access, a well-traine
d, highly skilled work force, and a strong multi-modal transportation system.</p>
</font>
<b>
<center>
<p>HISTORY OF PUBLIC SERVICE TO <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>MISSOURI<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/></p>
</b>
</center>
<font size=2>
<img height=222 src="index_files/govholden.jpg" width=173 align=right>
<p>&#9;Holden served two four-year terms as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>State Treasurer<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> before he was elected to the Governors Office in 2000.  During these years in the Treasurers Office, Holdens major responsibility was to manage the states $17 billion in annual revenues.  As 
<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>State Treasurer<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, Holden accomplished what no other chief financial officer of the state has ever done  earn <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> $1 billion in interest from investments.  Other major achievements include establishment of Dollar$ and Sense, <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>s first statewide
partnership between banks and schools to teach children wise money management practices, and MOST, a state and federal tax incentive program to help parents save for their childs post-high school education. </p>
<p>Holden began his career in public service in 1976 as an <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>assistant<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> to <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>State Treasurer Jim Spainhower<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>.  In 1983, he defeated an incumbent and was elected to the Missouri House of Representatives from the 136<sup>th</sup>District (Springfield).  He serve
d three terms, from 1983 to 1989.  During his tenure in the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> House, Holden served as chairman of the House General Administration Budget Committee, served on the House Budget Committee, and championed campaign finance reform.  He co-sponsored the 
Excellence in Education Act and was House co-sponsor of a bill that reorganized the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Department of Economic Development.  From 1989 to 1991, Holden served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>administrative assistant<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in the St. Louis <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>office of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Congressman Richard Gephardt<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>
.     </p>
<dir>
</font>
<b>
<center>
<p>FAMILY BACKGROUND</p>
</b>
</center>
<font size=2></dir>
<p>Born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Kansas City<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/> on <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>August 24, 1949<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Bob Holden<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> grew up on <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>a farm near Birch Tree<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> in south central <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.  In 1973, he graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Southwest Missouri State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> with a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degree in political science<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>.  </p>
<center>
<img src="index_files/fam.jpg" width=350 height=239 align=right>
</center>
<p>Holden met his wife <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Lori Hauser Holden<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> from Aurora when she volunteered to pour iced tea at a Jim Spainhower event in 1982 and the following year they were married.  They have two sons, 11-year-old <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Robert III<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, born in St. Louis, and 6-year-old <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>John D<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, 
born in Columbia and named for one of the Governors favorite teachers.  Holden is dean of the American Legion <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Boys State Legislative School, serves on the board of Boys and Girls Town of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> and the Parents as Teachers program.  He also ser
ved in the <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> National Guard.</p>
<p>Bobs parents, Lee and Wanda Holden, still work the Birch Tree family farm where Bob spent his boyhood. </p></font></body>
</body>
</table>
</td>
<td width="5%">
&nbsp;
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign=top bgcolor="#333949">

<html>
<head>
<title><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Joe Maxwell<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> Bio</title>
</head>
<body text="#000000" link="#0000AF" vlink="#0000AF" alink="#FFFFFF" bgcolor="#FFFFFF" background="JM%20images/backgrounds/capitol%20washout.jpg">
<div align=center><center>
<table width=500 border=0>
<tr>
<td><img src="JM%20images/staff%20photos/joe-color.jpg" alt="joe-color.jpg (10139 bytes)" width=227 height=285></td>
<td><p align=center><font face="AGaramond Bold"><font size=7><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Joe Maxwell<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></font><big><big>
</big><br>
<big><strong><em><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>'s Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></em></strong></big></font><br>
</big></td>
</tr>
</table>
</center></div>
<p align=center><img src="JM%20images/misc/feather_bar.gif" alt="feather bar" width=540 height=46></p>
<table border=0 width="100%">
<tr>
<td width="100%"><big><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Joe Maxwell<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> grew up on the family farm outside the small community
of <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Rush Hill<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/>. From a large family, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Joe Maxwell<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> understood at an early age the importance
of responsibility and obligation to one's family.</big><p><big>The farm crisis of the 70's
forced Joe and his brother from the farm into other vocations.&nbsp; As a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>rural mail
carrier<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, Joe continued his strong sense of responsibility and respect for
individuals.&nbsp; When he and his twin brother opened their own small business, Joe
treated each customer's problem the way he would want to be treated.&nbsp; It was the
right thing to do...the repeat business was just a welcome byproduct.</big></p>
<p><big>Service is the foundation of Joe Maxwell's philosophy.&nbsp; He served his country
in the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> National Guard<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> for twenty years and was called to active duty during the
great flood of 1993.</big></p>
<p><big>As a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>state representative<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, Joe earned the reputation for working long hours and
taking on tough issues, like welfare reform and health care.&nbsp; He served as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>senator<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of
the 18th District, representing an area that stretches across a dozen <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> counties in
the northeast region of the state.&nbsp; As <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>state senator<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Joe Maxwell<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> continued to fight
for issues vital to the whole state.</big></p>
<p><big>He sponsored the <u>Patients Bill of Rights</u>in <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>.&nbsp; Once more he
was ahead of the curve, and provided a blueprint for the nation to follow.&nbsp; This year
Joe again worked on HMO reform and small business health care.&nbsp; This past legislative
session he successfully passed the <u>Financial Exploitation Act</u>to safeguard our
senior citizens' financial savings.&nbsp; He also fought for tougher child protection laws
ensuring that <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> protects its most vulnerable citizens and saw the passage of his <u>Child
Protection Act</u>become law in July of this year.</big></p>
<p><big>Like most <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Missouri<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> families, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Sarah<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> and Joe Maxwell work hard to provide for their
children.&nbsp; Their two daughters, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Megan<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Shannen<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, serve as constant reminders that
<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Sarah<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> and Joe must strive every day to make this world a better place.</big></p>
<p><big>His vision of a better world for our children comes through in Joe's legendary
hard work, and his genuine love for people.</big></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p align=center><img src="JM%20images/misc/feather_bar.gif" alt="feather bar" width=540 height=46><big></big></p>
<font size=3><strong>
<p align=center><a href="homepage.htm">Home</a></strong></font></p>
</body>
</html>

'/images/Subpages/FocusLinkFirstLadyMessage.gif'" onmouseout="javascript:document.imgFLMessage.src = '/images/Subpages/UnselLinkFirstLadyMessage.gif'"><img border="0" name="imgFLMessage" id="imgFLMessage" src="/images/Subpages/UnselLinkFirstLadyMessage.gif" width="160" height="56" alt="A Message from First Lady Easley" /></a></td></tr></tr><tr><tr bgcolor="#333399" valign="top"><td valign="top"><a href="/MeetGov/MeetGov.asp" onmouseover="javascript:document.imgMeetGovl.src = '/images/Subpages/FocusLinkMeetGov.gif'" onmouseout="javascript:document.imgMeetGovl.src = '/images/Subpages/UnselLinkMeetGov.gif'"><img border="0" name="imgMeetGovl" id="imgMeetGovl" src="/images/Subpages/UnselLinkMeetGov.gif" width="160" height="42" alt="Meet Governor Easley" /></a></td></tr></tr><tr><tr bgcolor="#333399" valign="top"><td valign="top"><a href="/MeetGov/Biography.asp"><img border="0" name="imgBio" id="imgBio" src="/images/Subpages/FocusLinkMeetBio.gif" width="160" height="42" alt="Biographical Information About Governor Easley" /></a></td></tr></tr><tr><tr bgcolor="#333399" valign="top"><td valign="top"><a target="new" href="http://www.ah.dcr.state.nc.us/sections/capitol/exec/exectour.htm" onmouseover="javascript:document.imgTour.src = '/images/Subpages/FocusTourExecMans.gif'" onmouseout="javascript:document.imgTour.src = '/images/Subpages/UnselTourExecMans.gif'"><img border="0" name="imgTour" id="imgTour" src="/images/Subpages/UnselTourExecMans.gif" width="160" height="42" alt="Tour Executive Mansion" /></a></td></tr></tr><tr bgcolor="#333399" height="100%"><td valign="top" height="100%"></td></tr></table>
				</td>
				<td name="content" width="100%">
					<table width="500" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0">
						<tr>
							<td valign="top" width="500">
								<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" align="left">
									<tr>
										<td colspan="2"><br /><img src="/images/Subpages/TitleMeetBio.gif" alt="Biographical Information" width="478" height="54"></td>
									</tr>
									<tr>
										<td width="30"><img src="/images/SubPages/space.gif" height="1" width="30" alt=""></td>
										<td>
											<p><img src="/images/home/picbiogov.jpg" align="right" hspace="6" vspace="0" alt="Photo of Governor Easley" width="131" height="128">Michael F. Easley's inauguration as <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>North Carolina<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> follows nearly two decades of public service spent fighting crime, protecting children and the elderly, and standing up for working families. Easley, born in <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>1950<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>, is the first post-World War II &quot;baby boomer&quot; to be elected as Governor of North Carolina.</p>

											<p>Mike Easley was first elected to public office in 1982 when, at age 31, he became <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>District Attorney<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for the 13th Judicial District in Brunswick, Bladen, and Columbus counties. He was one of the state's youngest district attorneys, and he used his youthful energies to battle drug trafficking and public corruption along the district's coastline, achieving one of the highest drug conviction rates in the state. Easley prosecuted South American drug kingpins and was recognized as one of the nation's top &quot;Drug-Busters&quot; by USA Today.  While serving as a district attorney, Mike Easley boldly ignored political threats and directed the prosecution of numerous corrupt public officials in his district.</p>

											<p>As district attorney, he developed the first Rape and Child Abuse Victim Assistance program operated out of a district attorney's office. He also worked with the General Assembly to create investigative grand juries, a tool he then used to prosecute major drug traffickers. In addition, he also helped to create the Fair Treatment to Victims Act.</p>

											<p>Mike Easley was elected North Carolina's <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Attorney General<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1992, recording the highest-ever vote total for any candidate in North Carolina. When he was re-elected to the state's top law enforcement position in 1996, Easley was again the state's top vote-getter, receiving nearly 60% of votes cast.</p>

											<p>Soon after taking office as the Attorney General, Easley waged an aggressive and high-profile fight against consumer fraud, using the tools of litigation, legislation, and consumer education to prevent North Carolinians from falling prey to scam artists. His efforts have resulted in a dramatic decrease in fraudulent telemarketing calls in North Carolina. In the wake of Hurricanes Fran and Floyd, Easley quickly initiated the pursuit and prosecution of home-repair scam artists.</p>

											<p>One of Attorney General Easley's first priorities was to restore meaningful punishment to North Carolina's criminal justice system. Working closely with members of the General Assembly, prison officials, judges, prosecutors, and local law enforcement, he successfully challenged the federal court order that limited the state's prison population. The removal of this prison &quot;cap&quot; has kept thousands of violent criminals behind bars. Combined with the state's structured sentencing law, this action has resulted in a doubling of the average time served by violent felons. During Easley's eight years as Attorney General, North Carolina's violent crime rate fell by 15% and its murder rate dropped by 21%. Easley also worked to impose alternative punishments and establish drug treatment courts for non-violent offenders, to institute a statewide &quot;Safe Neighborhoods&quot; program, and to give law enforcement officers better tools to fight violent crime.</p>

											<p>In his role as leader of the North Carolina Department of Justice, Mike Easley spearheaded efforts to reach a national tobacco settlement and played a pivotal role in brokering the $206 billion dollar deal&#151;the largest financial recovery in history. His efforts will bring an unprecedented $5 billion in revenue to North Carolina over the coming years. The settlement also promises to be a giant step towards bringing stability to the state's tobacco industry and tobacco farmers.</p>
													        
											<p>Attorney General Easley's legislative achievements have included pushing new laws through the General Assembly that created &quot;weapon-free&quot; state school zones, removed the spousal defense for rape, ensured &quot;truth in sentencing,&#148; attacked telemarketing fraud and predatory lending, and prevented youth access to tobacco products. He was also a strong advocate for the Victim's Rights Amendment, ratified by North Carolina voters in November 1996.</p>

											<p>While Attorney General, Easley also led the successful effort to create the nation's first Business Court in North Carolina in an effort to better serve the legal needs of businesses and provide an incentive to attract industry and jobs to the state. He successfully argued before the North Carolina Supreme Court the case that established the right of governments to provide targeted economic incentives to companies, enabling the state and municipalities more effectively to recruit companies and increase the number of good jobs in North Carolina.</p>

											<p>With the support of the state's leading environmental organizations, Easley recently reached landmark agreements with major hog producers to develop environmentally superior technologies to treat hog waste and better protect the state's rivers and streams.</p>

											<p>In recognition of his professional accomplishments, Easley has received several awards including the North Carolina Association of Black County Officials' <i>Humanitarian Award</i> and the North Carolina Chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics' <i>Excellence in Public Service for Children Award</i>. Easley also received North Carolina Common Cause's <i>1999 Leadership in State Government Award</i> for his efforts to strengthen North Carolina's campaign finance reform laws and to maintain the state ban on corporate contributions to political candidates. In recognition of his public health initiatives, Easley received the <i>1998 Health Policy Award</i> from the state Heart and Lung Associations, and the Cancer Society.</p>

											<p>Mike Easley began his campaign for governor by vowing to continue his fight for working families: &quot;I am running for governor because I want to guarantee that the working men and women of this state&#151;the people who get up early, fight traffic, do the dishes, and pay the bills&#151;have a champion in Raleigh. They deserve someone who will speak frankly about the challenges facing this state and who will carry forward the progressive spirit that has been North Carolina's hallmark for the past 100 years.&quot;</p>
													        
											<p>Easley also pledged that his administration would be committed to uniting North Carolina and making sure every family can prosper in the New Economy: &quot;I am running for governor to make sure that North Carolina grows and that, as changes occur around us, our working families get a fair shake in the process and a fair share of the prosperity that comes our way. Every region and every citizen of North Carolina must be included.&quot;</p>
													                        
											<p>Born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Nash County<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>, just outside Rocky Mount, Easley was raised on a tobacco farm, the second of seven children. His parents, Huldah and Alex, instilled in their children the importance of a good education and hard work. After graduating from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Rocky Mount High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1968 Easley received his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>B.A. in Political Science<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of North Carolina<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1972 with honors.  In 1976, he earned his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>North Carolina Central University School of Law<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, where his wife Mary now serves as a professor of law. He graduated cum laude from law school and also served as Managing Editor of the Law Review.</p>

											<p>Easley is an avid hunter and sailor and an accomplished woodworker. He and his wife <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Mary<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> have one child, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Michael, Jr.<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, age 16.</p>
											<p>
										</td>
									</tr>
								</table>
							</td>	
						</tr>	
					</table>
					<br />
				</td>
			</tr>
			<tr>
				<td bgcolor="#333399">&nbsp;</td>
				<td align="right">
					<table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" width="100%"><tr valign="middle" nowrap><td align="right" name="bufferimage" height="27" width="100%" background="/images/SubPages/footerspan.gif" nowrap><span class="FooterText">2001 - North Carolina Office of the Governor</span></td><td background="/images/SubPages/footerspan.gif">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td></tr></table>
				</td>

						<tr>
							<td width="50">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
							<td valign="top" width="511" class="BodyText">
								<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2">
									<tr>
										<td colspan="1" valign="top">
											<img src="/images/title_bio1.gif" width="260" height="56" alt="Page Title">
										</td>
									</tr>
									<tr>		
										<td valign="top" align="left" class="BodyText">
											<img src="/images/biophoto.jpg" width="120" height="135" hspace="0" vspace="2" border="0" align="left" alt="Photo of Beverly Perdue">A  former  <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>public school teacher<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>health care  professional<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>, and   co-chair  of  the  Senate  Appropriations   Committee, <TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Beverly Perdue<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> has been a key figure  in shaping   our  states  successful  mainstream  agenda  for educational  excellence; affordable, accessible  healthcare; sustainable economic prosperity; and targeted tax relief for North Carolinas families.</p>
											<p>Lieutenant  Governor Perdue comes into  the  second  highest elected office in our state having <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>served five terms in the Senate  and two terms in the state House of Representatives<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. During  this time, she was consistently ranked  one  of  the most   effective  members  of  the  North  Carolina  General Assembly  and quickly gained a reputation for being  one  of the legislatures hardest workers. </p>
											<p>Her   successes  include  shepherding  through  the  General Assembly such innovative education measures as the Excellent Schools Act, the Safe Schools Act, and Governor Hunts Smart Start  initiative for early childhood development.  She  has also  worked tirelessly to improve the quality of  long-term care  for older adults and remains focused on expanding home health care opportunities.  Furthermore, having crafted  our states  balanced  budget since 1996,  she  has  earned  her designation as a fiscally responsible fighter for the  needs of our people.</p>
											<p>In  just  the  past  year,  Bev Perdue  received  the  North Carolina  Association  of Educators  President  Award,  the North  Carolina Nurses Associations Legislator of the  Year Award,  the National Association of Local Boards  of  Health Legislator  of the Year Award, the North Carolina  Community Colleges Faculty Association Legislator of the Year  Award, and  the  North Carolina Council of Womens Jean  H.  Nelson Distinguished Woman of the Year Award.</p>
											<p>Additionally, the North Carolina Division of Aging presented her  with the George L. Maddox Award given annually  to  the individual or organization in the state that has excelled in creative programming for older adults.</p>
											<p>As  Lieutenant  Governor, Bev Perdue will  continue  working hard on the issues that matter to North Carolinas families: prescription  drug cost relief for seniors,  more  effective schools  in every community, clean air and water, access  to technology, a government that treats businesses and citizens as  valued  customers, and ensuring that our law enforcement officers  have  the  tools necessary to  fight  crime  while making sure that our communities and schools remain safe.</p>
											<p>A  resident  of  Craven  County, Bev Perdue  has  two  sons, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Garrett<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Emmett<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>; two step-children, Robert and Charlotte. She  is married to <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Robert W. Eaves, Jr.<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>  The family home  is in <TAG name="RESCITY" value="start"/>New Bern<TAG name="RESCITY" value="end"/>.</p>
											<p>Lieutenant  Governor  Perdue holds a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Ph.D.<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>  and  a  <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>masters degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/>  from  the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Florida at Gainesville<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>,  and she  is ready to put her 14 years of experience in the state legislature to work fighting for an improved quality of life for all North Carolinians in this great 21st century.                              </p>
											<br />&nbsp;<br />
										</td>
									</tr>
								</table>
