<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML//EN">
<html>

<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<meta name="GENERATOR" content="Microsoft FrontPage 3.0">
<title>6-15-98 Governor's Biography</title>
</head>

<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF">

<p align="center"><font size="5" face="Wide Latin"><b>Governor Gary E. Johnson</b></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="5">State of New Mexico</font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2"><b>&quot;People Before Politics&quot;</b></font></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><b><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Gary E. Johnson<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>: First Governor in the history of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>New Mexico<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> to be elected to two
four-year consecutive terms. He is a successful, self-made businessman, family man and
accomplished triathlete.</b></p>

<p><b>The Johnson Administration Goal and Priorities:</b></p>

<p>Governor Gary E. Johnson&#146;s goal is to <b>improve the quality of life</b> of all
New Mexicans by concentrating on four major priorities: 

<ul>
  <li><b><u>Improving education</u></b> by making it more accountable; </li>
  <li><b><u>Bolstering economic development</u></b> by reducing taxes and by building roads
    and infrastructure; </li>
  <li><b><u>Reducing crime</u></b> by building prisons and expanding juvenile prevention
    programs; and </li>
  <li><b><u>Improving government efficiency</u></b> by holding the line on state government
    growth and on the number of state employees.</li>
</ul>

<p>Governor Johnson has made a commitment to the <TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="start"/>state of New Mexico<TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/> to offer the <b>best
product, best service at the lowest possible price </b>and he believes that his pledge of <b>&quot;People
before Politics&quot;</b> defines his administration. Governor Johnson is delivering on
that commitment and pledge. </p>

<p><b>Real Results Across the Board</b></p>

<p>Governor Johnson believes the highlight of his administration is the achievement of
what he calls, <b>&quot;Real results across the board.&quot;</b> He believes his
administration has taken a very balanced approach to improving state government and uses a<b>
&quot;common sense, business-like approach&quot;</b> to running state government.</p>

<p>Johnson went above and beyond his promises to stop any new tax increase and to prevent
the number of state employees from growing during his first term in office. Governor
Johnson signed legislation to actually <b><u>reduce taxes by more than $106 million
dollars</u></b> a year and he reduced the number of state employees by 6% or by around
1,300 employees.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><b>Economic Development</b></p>

<p>Governor Johnson believes that a business friendly state will benefit everyone.</p>

<p>In addition to cutting taxes to encourage economic development, Governor Johnson has
signed a $1.2 billion dollar highway improvement package to fix and four lane 500 miles of
roads throughout the entire state without raising taxes.</p>

<p><b>Government Efficiency</b></p>

<p>Governor Johnson believes one of his major legacies will be the implementation of
Managed Care for Medicaid during his administration. A Medicaid budget that had grown out
of control by approximately 600% over the past 12 years, was stopped in its tracks and was
reduced; and at the same time medical services for the poor were improved. </p>

<p>Governor Johnson has also held the line on the growth of state government to around 4%
after years and years of double digit growth prior to his taking office.</p>

<p>Under the Johnson Administration, Welfare Reform is taking place and that means those
who receive public assistance, yet <b>can work, will now be required to work.</b></p>

<p><b>Education</b></p>

<p><b>Governor Johnson&#146;s number one priority is to improve education in the state</b>.
While the governor signed legislation to give public school teachers their largest pay
raise in 16 years, and has invested over $300 million additional dollars a year to
education during his first term in office, the governor&#146;s <b>&quot;For the
Children&#146;s Sake&quot;</b> educational reform plan calls for: more accountability,
school choice through vouchers; and expansion of charter schools. Governor Johnson signed
an open enrollment bill intended to give students more choice. </p>

<p><b>Reducing Crime</b></p>

<p>Governor Johnson&#146;s leadership has resulted in the construction of two much needed
prisons in the state in order to help fight violent crime. The design, building, financing
and operations of the prisons are privatized and the daily costs per prisoner will be less
than in state run operations. Also, the costly federal Duran Consent Decree is in the
process of ending after 20 years of affecting the state&#146;s ability to run its prisons.
In the area of Juvenile Justice, prevention programs for children are being expanded and a
new juvenile corrections facility is being built.</p>

<p><b>Election History/Background:</b></p>

<p>Gary E. Johnson, a <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/>, was first elected to be the 26<sup>th</sup> <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of
New Mexico<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November of 1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> and was re-elected in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November of 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>. He says his
re-election is a <b>&quot;stick to your guns&quot;</b> affirmation of what his
administration has accomplished and of what more he wants to do to improve the quality of
life in New Mexico.</p>

<p>Prior to becoming governor, Johnson and his wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Dee<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, founded Big J Enterprises, a
successful, full-service commercial and industrial construction company still operating in
New Mexico.</p>

<p><b>Role Model/Athletic Firsts/Personal Goal</b></p>

<p>Governor Johnson, an accomplished triathlete, has enjoyed promoting physical fitness
while in office. He was the first governor to compete in the <b>&quot;Super Bowl of
triathlons- the Ironman in Hawaii.</b> Governor Johnson has also <b>ridden his bike five
times across the state of New Mexico</b> for over 2,500 miles in his effort to bring
awareness to fitness and litter clean- up during his annual &quot;Trek for Trash.&quot; He
has <b>run 25 miles in army boots and military fatigues</b> with a 35 pound pack on his
back through White Sands Missile Range to commemorate the Bataan Death March. And the
Governor has taken a<b> flying leap off a 10,000 foot mountain in New Mexico</b> to help
promote the World Hang-gliding Championships which were held in Albuquerque. </p>

<p>When he has completed his work for the state of New Mexico, Johnson has personal goals
to achieve that include <b>climbing Mount Everest.</b></p>

<p><b>Simple yet powerful rules for good living and principles of good government.</b> </p>

<p>Governor Johnson lives his life by simple yet powerful rules: <b>Treat others like you
would like to be treated; keep your word; always do more than you say you will; tell the
truth; and be on time.</b> Governor Johnson&#146;s principles of good government include:
Become reality-driven; always be honest; always do what is right and fair; determine goals
and a plan to reach them; those who ought to know what is happening -need to know;
don&#146;t hesitate to deliver bad news; be willing to do whatever it takes to get the job
done. </p>

<p>Birthdate: <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>January 1, 1953<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/></p>

<p>Spouse: <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Dee Simms Johnson<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/></p>

<p>Family: Married, one daughter- <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Seah<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, one son- <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Erik<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/></p>

<p>Education/Occupation: <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of New Mexico<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>B.S. Degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> (1976); <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Construction
Company Owner<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/></p>

<p>Elected: First governor in the history of the state to be elected to two consecutive
four-year terms. He was first elected to be the 26<sup>th</sup> governor of New Mexico in
November, 1994 and was re-elected in November, 1998. </p>

<p>Term Expires: January 2002</p>

<p>State Population: 1.7 million</p>

<p>State Budget: $3.1 Billion (General Fund)</p>

<p>Chief of Staff: Lou Gallegos</p>

<p>Media Contact: Diane Kinderwater</p>

<p>*11/98</p>

<p align="center">####</p>
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML//EN">

<html>



<head>



<title>Walter Bradley's Biography</title>



</head>



<body background="STOSeal2.jpg">
<a name="top"></a>

<table border="0" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0" align="left">

<tr valign="top">
<td align="center" bgcolor="#00bba8">
<a href="ltgovbio.htm"><img src="pw431.jpg" width="60" height="60" border="0"><br>
<font face="arial narrow">Biography</font>
</a></td>
<td rowspan=28 Valign="top"><img src="lt_gov.jpg" width="318" height="523" alt="" align="right">
<h1><strong><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>WALTER   D. BRADLEY<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/></strong></h1>

<h2><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>New Mexico's  25th Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/></h2>

<p>Walter Bradley grew up in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Eastern New Mexico<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> and is a graduate of <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Clovis High 

  School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and attended <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Eastern New Mexico University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. After leaving ENMU, Walter 

  started his career at <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Texas Instruments<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> moving to <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>National Chemsearch<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> both in 

  Dallas, Texas. He excelled in private business, receiving several awards and 

  quickly moved up the corporate ladder.</p>

<p>After coming home to New Mexico, Walter built from scratch a successful real 

  estate business. He is listed in both Who's Who of Finance and Industry, and 

  Who's Who in the West. His extensive business skills and success is due to his 

  strong beliefs in the entrepreneurial spirit. </p>

<p>Walter Bradley was elected Lieutenant Governor in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>. </p>

<p>As Lieutenant Governor Walter is &quot;President of the Senate&quot;. Walter 

  served in this same legislative body as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>State Senator<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> from Curry County from 

  1989 to 1992. Due to his success in the private sector, Walter was picked to 

  sit on the important Economic Development and the Education Committees. </p>

<p>While in the Senate, Senator Bradley was recognized by the New Mexico Association 

  of Commerce and Industry with their highest legislative rating.</p>

<p>The Lieutenant Governor's expertise continues to help <TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>New Mexico<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/>. He currently 

  serves on the New Mexico Space Commission Board, the New Mexico Border Authority, 

  NM Workforce Development Board and is Chairman of the Small Business Advocacy 

  Council.&nbsp; </p>

<p>As Chairman of the Small Business Advocacy Council, the Lieutenant Governor 

  has spearheaded legislative reform and eliminated regulatory roadblocks for 

  small businesses. </p>

<p>Walter's efforts to help New Mexicans have not gone unnoticed. He has received 

  numerous recognitions including:</p>

<ul type=disc>

  <li>2000 Leadership Beatification 

    Award, Keep New Mexico Beautiful</li>

  <li>2000 Mark Weidler Distinguish 

    Public Servant Award, New Mexico Petroleum Marketers Association. </li>

  <li>1998 Progressive Farmer Magazine 

    Man of the Year </li>

  <li>1997 Distinguished Leadership 

    Award, Albuquerque National Association for the Advancement of Colored People 

    (NAACP) </li>

  <li>1997 Distinguished Service Recipient, 

    New Mexico Farm &amp; Livestock Bureau </li>

  <li>1997 Outstanding New Mexico's 

    Small Business Supporter, New Mexico Small Business Development Center. </li>

</ul>

<p> Walter and his wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Deborah<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, were married in Clovis.  They lived and raised their four children, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Tige<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Lance<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Nicole<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, and <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Kristin<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> in Clovis until Walter's re-election in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1999<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> when they moved to Albuquerque. Lt. Governor Bradley and Debbie, are also the proud grandparents of their granddaughter, Alexis.</p>

<a href="#top"><img src="up.gif" width="41" height="41" border="0" alt="up button"></a>



</td>

</tr>

<HTML><HEAD><TITLE><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Kenny Guinn<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> - Biography</TITLE>
<META content="text/html; charset=windows-1252" http-equiv=Content-Type>
</HEAD>
<BODY background=images/bkg_redwhite.jpg bgColor=#FFFFFF link=#800000 
vLink=#800000>
<TABLE border=0 cellPadding=0 cellSpacing=0>
  <TBODY>
  <TR>
    <TD align=left vAlign=top width=185>
        <TABLE border=0 cellpadding=0>
           <TR><TD height=36 width=130></TD> </TR>
		</TABLE>
        
		<TABLE border=2 cellspacing=1 bordercolorlight="#000000" bordercolordark="#000000">
        <TR><TD>	
            <a href="http://gov.state.nv.us"><img src="images/governorspge.jpg" border="0" width="131" height="26" alt="Click here to visit Governor Kenny Guinn's Homepage!"></a>
		</td></tr>
		<tr><td>
            <a href="bio.htm"><img src="images/biography.jpg" border="0" width="131" height="27" alt="Governor Kenny Guinn"></a>
		</td></tr>
		<tr><td>					
            <a href="sos2001.html"><img src="images/stateofthestate.jpg" border="0" width="132" height="26" alt="Governor Kenny Guinn's 2001 State of the State Address!"></a>
		</td></tr>
		<tr><td>		
            <a href="pr.htm"><img src="images/pressreleases.jpg" border="0" width="131" height="28" alt="Governor Kenny Guinn's Press Releases!"></a>
		</td></tr>
		<tr><td>			
            <a href="contact.htm"><img src="images/contactinfo.jpg" border="0" width="131" height="28" alt="Contact Governor Kenny Guinn"></a>
		</td></tr>
		<tr><td>			
            <a href="http://silver.state.nv.us"><img src="images/nevadahome.jpg" border="0" width="132" height="25" alt="Click here to visit the Official State of Nevada's Homepage!"></a>
	     </TD></TR>
		 </TABLE>
	  
	</TD>
    <TD width=520>
      <p align="center">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
	<IMG alt="" border=0 src="images/guinn1.jpg" width="350" height="254" >&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
      <FONT face="Arial, helvetica, sans-serif" size=+1><B>Biography</B></FONT> 
      <P>

    <img src="images/spacer.jpg" width=15 height=5 border=0 alt="Space maker">
<p>
    Guinn, <TAG name="AGE" value="start"/>64<TAG name="AGE" value="end"/>, spent his boyhood in the small,
    Central Valley town of <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Exeter, California<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> where he met <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Dema<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, his wife of <TAG name="YRSMARR" value="start"/>42 years<TAG name="YRSMARR" value="end"/>. He
    earned undergraduate and graduate <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>degrees in Physical Education<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Fresno State
    University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and later obtained a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>doctorate in Education<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Utah State University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in
    Logan. The Guinns and their oldest son, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Jeff<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, moved to Las Vegas in 1964 where Guinn went
    to work for the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Clark County School District<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>planning specialist<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. Within five short
    years, he was named <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Superintendent of Schools<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in Clark County and served with distinction
    in that position until 1978. During Guinn's tenure with the school district, his second
    son, Steve was born.<p> <img src="images/kgdema.jpg" align="right" width="300"
    height="281" border="0"><p>

	<img src="images/spacer.jpg" width=15 height=5 border=0 alt="Space maker">
    In his work for the Clark County School
    District, Guinn was recognized as an effective administrator committed to educational
    excellence at a time when the county was experiencing exponential student growth. His
    service to Clark County students was honored when Kenny C. Guinn Junior High School was
    named for him.<p>

	<img src="images/spacer.jpg" width=15 height=5 border=0 alt="Space maker">	
    In 1978, Guinn began applying his management
    skills in business as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Administrative Vice President<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Nevada Savings and Loan<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> in Las
    Vegas, which later became <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>PriMerit Bank<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. At PriMerit, he quickly advanced through
    management ranks and, in 1987, was appointed as Chairman of the Board of Directors of the
    Las Vegas-based bank. Soon thereafter, Guinn was recruited to the energy business as the
    <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>President<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Southwest Gas Corporation<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> and eventually became Chairman of the Board of
    Directors of that utility in 1993.<p>

	<img src="images/reading.gif" align="left" width="230" height="309"
    border="0">
	<img src="images/spacer.jpg" width=15 height=5 border=0 alt="Space maker">
    In 1994, Guinn was recruited by the University of
    Nevada Board of Regents to serve as <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>interim president<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>University of Nevada-Las
    Vegas<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. During that challenging year, he restored credibility to the university's
    prestigious basketball program as well as instituting administrative and policy
    initiatives to enable the school to continue its growing success as an ever-expanding
    urban university. His compensation was $ 1.00 and he donated the remainder of his salary
    to UNLV's student scholarship fund and other student activities.<p>
	

	<img src="images/spacer.jpg" width=15 height=5 border=0 alt="Space maker">	
    In addition to his one-year term at UNLV,
    Guinn served the state in leadership roles on a variety of committees and commissions,
    including the Clark County Community College Advisory Committee, the UNLV Foundation Board
    of Trustees, the White House Conference on Children and Youth, the Las &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
    Vegas Citizens Advisory Committee on Downtown Development, the Governor's Commission on
    Government Reorganization,&nbsp; the Metropolitan Police Fiscal Affairs Committee, the
    Nevada Educational Development Council and the Advisory Group for Civil Justice Reform.
	<p>
	

	<img src="images/spacer.jpg" width=15 height=5 border=0 alt="Space maker">	
    Guinn has also worked in his community in a
    variety of volunteer roles, ranging from involvement in the Boy Scouts and Pop Warner
    Football to the United Way of Southern Nevada and the Southern Nevada Independent Youth
    Athletic Association.<p>

	
	<img src="images/spacer.jpg" width=15 height=5 border=0 alt="Space maker">	
    In addition to their two sons, the Guinns have six grandchildren.
	
	<br><img src="images/spacer.jpg" width=15 height=5 border=0 alt="Space maker">	
	<center><img src="images/family.jpg" width="400" height="218" border="0"></center>
			<p><center>
			<table border=0 cellpadding=10 width=400>
			<tr><th><hr noshade width=100% height=2>
                <STRONG><FONT size=2><a href="index.htm">Governor's Home Page</a> &nbsp;|&nbsp;

                <a href="sos2001.html">State of the State Address</a> &nbsp;|&nbsp;
                <a href="http://silver.state.nv.us">Nevada Home Page</a></FONT></STRONG>
                <FONT> 
			</th></tr>
			</table></center>		
	</TD></TR>	
	    </TBODY>
		</TABLE>

<HEAD>
<TITLE>State of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Nevada<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> - Office of the Lieutenant Governor</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY BACKGROUND="backgd8.gif" BGCOLOR="#ffffff" TEXT="#004080" LINK="#0000ff" VLINK="#800080" ALINK="#ff0000">

	<tr>
		<th>
	<IMG alt="" border=0 src="banner.gif" width="600" height="164">
		</th>
	</tr>
</table>
<table border=0 width=600>
  <TBODY>
	<tr>
		<td valign=top width=110>
			<a href="index.html"><IMG alt="This page" border=0 height=35 src ="home.gif" width=100 ></a>
			<p>
			<a href="report.html"><IMG alt="The Nevada Report" border=0 src="report.gif" width="100" height="35"></a>
			<p>
			<A href="spres.html"><IMG alt="Description of Duties - President of the Senate" border=0 height=35 src="spres.gif" width=100 ></A>
			<A href="cedchair.html"><IMG alt="Description of Duties - Economic Development Chairman" border=0 height=35 src="cedchair.gif" width=100 ></A>
			<A href="ncot.html"><IMG alt="Description of Duties - Commission on Tourism Chairman" border=0 height=35 src="ncot.gif" width=100 ></A>
			<A href="trans.html"><IMG alt="Description of Duties - Transportation Board Member" border=0 height=35 src="trans.gif" width=100 ></A>
			<A href="bio.html"><IMG alt="Biography - Lorraine T. Hunt" border=0 height=35 src="abio.gif" width=100 ></A>
			<p>
			<a href="http://www.state.nv.us"><IMG alt="Nevada State Home Page" border=0 height=35 src="nvhome.gif" width=100 ></a>
			<a href="http://sos.state.nv.us"><IMG alt="Secretary of State Home Page" border=0 height=35 src="soshome.gif" width=100 ></a>
			<a href="http://www.leg.state.nv.us"><IMG alt="Legislature Home Page" border=0 height  =35 src="leghome.gif" width=100 ></a></p>
<font size="-2"><b>
<CENTER>
This Page was updated on Tue 29 May 2001 10:38:2</CENTER>

</B></FONT>
		</TD>

		<TD valign=top>
			<TABLE border=1 align=right width=150>
	</TR>
      <TR>
		<TH>
		<IMG alt="Lorraine T. Hunt, Lt. Governor, State of Nevada" border =0 src="lhunt.jpg" width="150" height="200" >
		</TH></TR>
		</TABLE>		<H3><I>Biography</I></H3>
		<H5><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Lorraine T. Hunt<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/><BR>
		<TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/><BR>
		<TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="start"/>State of Nevada<TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/></H5>
		

		<P>
		<FONT size="-1"><B>
<TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> Lorraine T. Hunt moved to Henderson, Nevada in 1943 with her parents from Niagara Falls, New York.  Hunt graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Las Vegas High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and attended <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Westlake College of Music<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in Los Angeles, California.  She began her musical studies at the age of nine and embarked on her professional musical career at 19 when she started performing in Las Vegas, Reno and Lake Tahoe.
<P>
It was then that Hunt demonstrated her entrepreneurial ability by making her first real estate investment in a piece of desert land on the outskirts of Las Vegas.  Years later the investment led her into the world of business when she became <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>president<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>chief exective officer<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Perri, Inc.<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>, a real estate and restaurant management company.  
<P>
Hunt's business acumen led her into government and legislative affairs as a small business activist as well as into community service.    
<P>
Whether it is a personal or business-related endeavor, Hunt is committed to the state of Nevada because it has given so much back to her.  Throughout the years Hunt has acquired extensive experience in small business and was awarded with Nevada's first Governor's <I> Award for Excellence in Business </I> in 1987 as well as being named <I> U.S. Small Business Advocate of the Year </I> in 1989.
<P>
Throughout her years in Las Vegas, Hunt has maintained significant involvement in statewide economic development.  Her background in the entertainment industry and tenure as vice-chair of both the Nevada Motion Picture Foundation and Nevada Motion Picture Commission has been integral to the expansion of the film industry in Nevada.  Hunt was also a founder of Continental National Bank and is now on the Community Board of Wells Fargo Bank.
<P>
Along with her business expertise comes vast experience and knowledge of the gaming and tourism industries.  Hunt served as chair of the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority Board of Trustees, along with terms as commissioner and vice-chair of the Nevada Commission on Tourism.  Hunt also served as director of the Nevada Hotel/Motel Association. 
<P>
In addition to her ongoing commitment to a prosperous economy for Nevada, Hunt also participates extensively in community service.  Her involvement includes serving as president and Trustee of St. Jude's Ranch for Children, along with many other groups that she supports both financially and through volunteer activities.  
<P>
Prior to being elected lieutenant governor in 1998, Hunt served a four-year term as Clark County Commissioner.
<P>
Hunt and her husband, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Charles<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, have been married <TAG name="YRSMARR" value="start"/>33 years<TAG name="YRSMARR" value="end"/> and have three grown children, two grandsons and one granddaughter.
		</B></FONT>
		<TABLE border=1 align=center>
<TR>
<TD><IMG align=left src="4.gif" width="200" height="178">
<FONT size="-1"><I>    Lieutenant Governor Lorraine Hunt and her husband Charles (better known as "Blackie") Hunt.</I></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE> 
		<HR>
		<H3><I>To Reach Us...</I></H3>
		<P>
		<CENTER>
		<TABLE border=1>
        <TBODY>
			<TR>
				<TD valign=top width=205>
				<FONT size="-1"><B>
				In Carson City...
				<P>
				Capitol Building<BR>
				Carson City, Nevada 89701<BR>
				Phone: 775 684 5637<BR>
				Fax: 775 684 5782<BR>
				</FONT></B></P></TD>
				<TD valign=top width=205>
				<FONT size="-1"><B>
				In Las Vegas...<P>
				Grant Sawyer Building<BR>
				555 E. Washington Avenue<BR>
				Suite 5500<BR>
				Las Vegas, Nevada 89101<BR>
				Phone: 702 486 2400<BR>
				Fax: 702 486 2404<BR>
				</B></P></FONT></TD></TR>
			<TR>
				<TH colspan=2>
				<FONT size="-1"><B>
				Email: <A href="mailto:nvltgov@govmail.state.nv.us">
				nvltgov@govmail.state.nv.us</A>
				</B></FONT>
				</TH>
			</TR></TBODY></TABLE></CENTER></TD></TR></TBODY></TABLE>
<HR width=600 align=left>
<Susan Fink Office of the Lieutenant Governor, State of Nevada>
</BODY>

</HTML>
ENDOFDOC

<!doctype html public "-//w3c//dtd html 4.0 transitional//en">
<html>
<head>
   <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
   <meta name="GENERATOR" content="Mozilla/4.5 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">
   <title>Governor's Biography</title>
</head>
<body text="#000066" bgcolor="#FFFFFF" link="#800000" vlink="#808080" alink="#FFFF00">
&nbsp;
<br>&nbsp;
<center>
<h3>
<TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>John A. Kitzhaber<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/>, M.D. - Biography</h3></center>

<p><br><TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/><TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Oregon<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/> John Kitzhaber was born in <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>1947<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/> in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Colfax, Washington<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>.&nbsp;
He grew up in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Oregon<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> and graduated from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>South Eugene High School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1965.&nbsp;
After graduating from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Dartmouth College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 1969, he attended the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University
of Oregon Medical School<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, earning a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>medical degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> in 1973.&nbsp; He <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>practiced
emergency medicine<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in Roseburg, Oregon for 13 years.&nbsp; Kitzhaber is
married to the former <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Sharon LaCroix<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> of Saskatchewan, Canada.&nbsp; They
have one son, <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Logan<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/>, born in October 1997.
<p>Kitzhaber first ran for public office in 1978 and was elected to the
<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Oregon House of Representatives<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>.&nbsp; In 1980 he was elected to the first
of three terms in the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Oregon Senate<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> representing Douglas County and parts
of Jackson County.&nbsp; He was elected Senate President in 1985 and served
in that position until 1993.&nbsp; Kitzhaber was elected governor <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November
8, 1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, and was sworn into office January 9, 1995.&nbsp; He was re-elected
on <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>November 3, 1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> and inaugurated for a second term on January 11, 1999.
<p>As Senate President, Kitzhaber was recognized nationally for authoring
the ground-breaking Oregon Health Plan.&nbsp; He is credited both with
crafting the plan itself and for bringing together diverse interest groups
to pass the law, which took effect in February 1994.&nbsp; Kitzhaber also
received recognition for his many accomplishments in the field of environmental
stewardship, including the prestigious Neuberger Award given by the Oregon
Environmental Council.
<p>During his first term as governor, Kitzhaber oversaw the expansion of
the Oregon Health Plan, which reduced the rate of uninsured Oregon children
from 21 percent to eight percent.&nbsp; In addition, Kitzhaber's welfare
reform plan, known as the Oregon Option, has reduced the number of welfare
caseloads more than 50 percent, saved more than $200 million in the state
budget, and helped nearly 20,000 Oregonians find work.
<p>Preserving Oregon's environment remains a priority for Kitzhaber, and
during his first term he developed and implemented the Oregon Plan for
Salmon and Watersheds.&nbsp; This is a collaborative plan that encourages
federal, state and local government agencies to work with private landowners
to restore watershed health and recover endangered salmon species.
<p>Education and opportunity for Oregon's children also has been a centerpiece
of Kitzhaber's administration.&nbsp; He has fought for stable education
funding, implementing the Education Act for the 21st Century, increasing
investment in Oregon's colleges and universities, including freezing tuition,
and juvenile crime prevention.
<p>Kitzhaber is an accomplished fly fisherman and enjoys Oregon's wild
rivers.
<br>&nbsp;
<br>&nbsp;
<br>
<center>
<p><img SRC="images/fly.jpg" ALT="Fishing Fly" NOSAVE height=121 width=129 align=CENTER>
<p><img SRC="images/bluebar.jpg" ALT="Rule" NOSAVE height=5 width=90% align=CENTER></center>

<p><br>
<br>
<br>
<p><a href="../index.html">Return to Governor's Office</a>
<br>&nbsp;
</body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<HTML>
<HEAD>
   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">
   <TITLE>Governor's Personal Message</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY TEXT="#000066" BGCOLOR="#ffffff" LINK="#800000" VLINK="#808080" ALINK="#ffff00">

<CENTER><IMG align=center alt="State of Oregon Seal" height =123 src="../images/letter_head.gif" width=124  NOSAVE></CENTER>
&nbsp;

<P></P><B><FONT size=4>
<P align=center><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>SHARON KITZHABER<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> - BIOGRAPHY</P>
<P align=center></B>&nbsp;</P>
<P><FONT size=3>Sharon Kitzhaber grew up in <TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="start"/>Saskatchewan, 
Canada<TAG name="GREWPLACE" value="end"/> and graduated in <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>physical therapy<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of Saskatchewan<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> in 
1977.</FONT>           
       </P>
<P><FONT size=3>Sharon first worked in Hawaii as a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>physical 
therapist<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1977, then worked for a year in Geneva, Switzerland. She traveled 
Europe, the Middle and Far East, and the Mediterranean before returning to Maui 
in 1981. Sharon opened her first <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>private physical therapy practice<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in 1984, and 
over the next eight years, she developed, managed and sold a three-clinic 
physical therapy practice on Maui, Hawaii.</FONT>             
              
             
             
           
</P>
<P><FONT size=3>As the wife of <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Governor John Kitzhaber<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, 
Sharon has dedicated herself to working on behalf of Oregon&#8217;s children and 
youth. She is a founder and the honorary chairperson for the Oregon Safe Kids 
Coalition, which is part of a national organization aimed at reducing 
preventable childhood injury. She is also deeply involved in the prevention of 
teen pregnancy through an abstinence-based peer mentorship program called 
"STARS" (Students Today Aren&#8217;t Ready for Sex). Sharon is also a co-chair of a 
national initiative "Leadership To Keep Children Alcohol Free" aimed at reducing 
underage drinking.</FONT> </FONT>            
              
             
          
           
         
             
         </P>
<P><FONT size=3>Sharon is on the board of the Multiple Sclerosis Society 
of Oregon and also is a board member of the 
Oregon Ballet Theatre and the Oregon Health Sciences Foundation, and she 
serves on the Giving in Oregon Council. She is an outspoken advocate for the 
arts and is committed to enhancing young people&#8217;s access and experiences with 
the arts throughout the state.</FONT>   
              
             
               
           
</P>
<P></FONT><FONT size=3>In her private life, Sharon is an 
instrument-rated private pilot and the delighted mother of a son, 
Logan.</FONT></P>

<CENTER><FONT SIZE=+1></FONT>&nbsp;</CENTER>

<CENTER><FONT SIZE=+1></FONT></CENTER>

<html>

<head>
<title>Biography</title>


<meta name="Microsoft Theme" content="governor 111, default">
<meta name="Microsoft Border" content="l, default">

<body topmargin="0" leftmargin="0" background="_themes/governor/fullbg.jpg" bgcolor="#E0E0E0" text="#000000" link="#0000FF" vlink="#CC0000" alink="#00CC33"><!--msnavigation--><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%"><tr><td valign="top" width="1%"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img border="0" src="images/space.gif" width="158" height="10" alt=" ">
<p><script language="JavaScript"><!--

// --></script><script language="JavaScript"><!--

// --></script><a href="./" language="JavaScript" onmouseover="if(MSFPhover) document['MSFPnav1'].src=MSFPnav1h.src" onmouseout="if(MSFPhover) document['MSFPnav1'].src=MSFPnav1n.src"><img src="_derived/home_cmp_governor110_vbtn.gif" width="140" height="37" border="0" alt="GOV Home" name="MSFPnav1"></a>
</p>
<!--mstheme--></font></td><td valign="top" width="24"></td><!--msnavigation--><td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">

<p align="center"><img src="_themes/governor/alvrule.gif" alt="Horizontal Separator" WIDTH="300" HEIGHT="10"></p>

<h2 align="center"><!--mstheme--><font color="#330099"><img src="images/govtitle.gif" alt="govtitle.gif (16855 bytes)" WIDTH="210" HEIGHT="62"><br>
<img src="images/govname.gif" alt="govname.gif (14805 bytes)" WIDTH="452" HEIGHT="72"><br>
<em>Biography</em><!--mstheme--></font></h2>

<p align="center"><img src="_themes/governor/alvrule.gif" alt="Horizontal Separator" WIDTH="300" HEIGHT="10"></p>

<p><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>William J. Janklow<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was born in <TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="start"/>Chicago<TAG name="BIRTHPLACE" value="end"/>. His father was a prosecutor at the Nuremberg
war criminal trials, but when his father died, the Janklow family returned to mother
LouElla's hometown, Flandreau, South Dakota. At 16, Bill Janklow became a high school
dropout and joined the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>Marines<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. After serving in Asia during the Quemoy-Matsu crisis, he
returned home to South Dakota in 1960, married <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Mary Dean Thom<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, and enrolled for the fall
semester at the <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>University of South Dakota<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. When college officials discovered he didn't
have a high school diploma, they wanted him to leave, but he talked them into letting the
first semester be a test. His grades were good and they let him stay. </p>

<p>After earning his <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>law degree<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> in 1966, Janklow started working in the legal aid program
on the <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Rosebud Indian Reservation<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/>. Soon he was the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>director of all legal aid<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> for <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>South
Dakota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, winning court cases and national awards. He has argued and won more cases in the
United States Supreme Court than any lawyer in South Dakota's history. He also lectured at
Harvard, UCLA and other universities on Indian law and criminal law. </p>

<p>Republicans drafted Janklow as their 1974 Attorney General candidate and he won with
66.7 percent, the highest percentage for any South Dakota Attorney General's race. </p>

<p>During his one term as Attorney General (1974-1978), Governor Janklow: </p>

<blockquote>
  <div align="left"><!--mstheme--></font><table border="0">
    <tr>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Kept his campaign promise &quot;to be a trial lawyer, not a politician,&quot; <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Stopped the atmosphere of violence that began with the 1973 Custer riots, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Won landmark decisions before the U.S. Supreme Court on Indian law and criminal law, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Cracked down on welfare fraud, drug abuse and white collar crime, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Upgraded the state crime lab, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Improved the state's criminal investigation agency, and <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Had the best criminal conviction record of any previous SD Attorney General <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
  </table><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">
  </div>
</blockquote>

<p>His achievements as Attorney General caused many Republicans to urge him to run for
Governor in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1978<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>. He won with over 56 percent of the vote. In <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1982<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/>, he was re-elected with
71 percent of the vote, the highest margin of victory in the history of South Dakota
gubernatorial campaigns. </p>

<p>During his first two terms as Governor (1979-1987), Bill Janklow: </p>

<blockquote>
  <div align="left"><!--mstheme--></font><table border="0">
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Kept his campaign promise of &quot;Putting Taxpayers First,&quot; <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Reduced the state government bureaucracy by almost ten percent, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Managed state agencies so efficiently that over $50 million was returned to the state
      treasury, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Caused enough savings that he was able to fully fund a $40 million personal property
      tax repeal for the taxpayers with only $12 million in state sales tax broadening, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Saved SD's railroad system so farmers could have better access to Asian/European
      markets, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">More than doubled state aid to education to help hold down local property tax
      increases, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Prevented the budget crisis that occurred in over 30 other states in 1981 by seeing it
      coming and reducing state spending the previous August, 1980,<!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Won dramatic changes in state banking laws that caused a national revolution in
      financial services and created thousands of new jobs, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Accelerated development of Missouri River recreational and tourism opportunities, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Created more new plant expansions, more new industries and more new capital investment
      in South Dakota in his eight years than had been done in the previous twelve years at a
      time when federal policies were causing record-breaking years of high interest rates and
      inflation, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Started water development moving forward with the state's first water development plan
      and regular funding, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Dramatically increased the availability of capital for home loans so that the dream of
      home<br>
      ownership was realized by thousands of South Dakotans, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Implemented many joint agreements with Indian tribes so that they could have the
      opportunity<br>
      to manage their own affairs, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Creatively used prison labor for state fairgrounds rebuilding and many other projects,
      <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Implemented a rural renaissance program and computerized farm management courses, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Saved the Unemployment Insurance Tax fund from insolvency so that South Dakota became
      one of only 12 states who didn't need federal funding, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Transformed a small state college campus into a prison, thereby saving taxpayers $20
      to $40 million in new prison costs, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Reduced Medicaid fraud and abuse, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Substantially reduced alcohol-related accidents and deaths through tougher law
      enforcement, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Accelerated the transfer of children from foster care to adoption, <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Transformed a mismanaged state-owned cement plant from having lost over $70,000,000 in
      potential business and overspent $10 million in plant renovations to an efficient
      operation that deposited over $91 million in profits into the state treasury that didn't
      have to be raised in taxes, and <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica"><img src="_themes/governor/ablbull1.gif" alt="List Bullet" WIDTH="16" HEIGHT="16"><!--mstheme--></font></td>
      <td><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">Safeguarded the underground water supply of western South Dakota and received $5
      million from the ETSI Corporation for water development. <!--mstheme--></font></td>
    </tr>
  </table><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, Arial, Helvetica">
  </div>
</blockquote>

<p>After eight years in private life, Janklow was re-elected in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1994<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> to his third term as
Governor. He has often said that being Governor for the great people of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>South Dakota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> is
the best job, the most challenging job, and the most enjoyable job that anyone could ever
have.</p>

<p><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> Bill Janklow began 1995 by winning legislative approval for the largest tax
decrease in South Dakota history and the largest tax decrease of all fifty states for
1995. Property taxes on agricultural land and owner-occupied homes were reduced by twenty
percent. Instead of allowing property taxes to increase at the recent average rate of over
$40 million per year, Janklow reduced property taxes by $83 million in his first year.</p>

<p>To stop large property tax increases at the local level, Janklow's tax reduction plan
also limits local government and school spending to annual increases of only three percent
or inflation, whichever is lower. Janklow also put the same tight budget controls on state
government by keeping the state spending under the rate of inflation for the first time in
eight years. </p>

<p>In 1996, Janklow's budget for state government is the first one since the Great
Depression that actually spends less money than the previous year. It contains a reduction
of over 790 people and since the budget's approval, Janklow has eliminated another 250
jobs. Janklow has reduced the part of state government he supervises by over ten percent. </p>

<p>Janklow made state government more efficient by managing it like a business. He has
re-negotiated state contracts to make them less costly to the taxpayer, promoted joint
ventures with city and county governments to prevent local tax increases and eliminated
over 60 state government newsletters. He has also reduced the amount of overtime allowed,
consolidated state inspection programs, and privatized home health care. </p>

<p>Janklow also put state prison inmates to work on several building and remodeling
projects, saving millions of dollars for taxpayers. Janklow also created the only program
in America where prisoners build affordable homes for senior citizens who want to stay
independent and live in South Dakota's small towns. </p>

<p>Janklow's changes in law and administration have fixed workers' compensation problems.
He has also created hundreds of new higher paying jobs by bringing new companies to South
Dakota and helping the state's homegrown businesses grow even faster. </p>

<p>At the end of Janklow's eight years as Governor, one citizen told the Minneapolis
Tribune, &quot;We need someone as outspoken and animated as Janklow.&quot; State Senator
George Shanard told a Nebraska newspaper that Janklow's &quot;extremely aggressive,
extremely intelligent, extremely sincere. He's probably regarded as one of the best--if
not the best--governors in South Dakota history.&quot; </p>

<p>A daily newspaper editor wrote &quot;more often than not, he is a people's governor who
wants to make a difference for the people of his state.&quot; Another newspaper concluded,
&quot;The epitaph of his eight-year administration must read--what he did he did with the
honesty and courage of convictions. Call it dedication, call it sacrifice or call it
whatever you like, Governor Janklow has been good for South Dakota.&quot; 
<!--mstheme--></font><!--msnavigation--></td></tr><!--msnavigation--></table></body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

if(MSFPhover) { MSFPnav11n=MSFPpreload('_derived/special.htm_cmp_governor010_vbtn.gif'); MSFPnav11h=MSFPpreload('_derived/special.htm_cmp_governor010_vbtn_a.gif'); }

if(MSFPhover) { MSFPnav12n=MSFPpreload('_derived/newpage1.htm_cmp_governor010_vbtn.gif'); MSFPnav12h=MSFPpreload('_derived/newpage1.htm_cmp_governor010_vbtn_a.gif'); }
// --></script><a href="newpage1.htm" onmouseover="if(MSFPhover) document['MSFPnav12'].src=MSFPnav12h.src" onmouseout="if(MSFPhover) document['MSFPnav12'].src=MSFPnav12n.src"><img src="_derived/newpage1.htm_cmp_governor010_vbtn.gif" width="140" height="37" border="0" alt="Hobbies" name="MSFPnav12"></a> </p>
<!--mstheme--></font></td><td valign="top" width="24"></td><!--msnavigation--><td valign="top"><!--mstheme--><font face="arial, arial, helvetica">

<p align="center"><img src="images/bio.gif" alt="bio.jpg (11504 bytes)" WIDTH="275" HEIGHT="88"></p>

<p><TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Carole Hillard<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> is the first woman in the 106 year history of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>South Dakota<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> to serve as
the state's <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/>.<br>
<br>
But, public service at both the local and state level isn't new to her.<br>
<br>
Before serving in the <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>State House of Representatives<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> from 1991 through 1994, Carole
Hillard was a local and state leader in many different organizations.<br>
<br>
For seven years, she was a member of the City Council for Rapid City and served as its
first woman President. She has also been the president of the Rapid City Chamber of
Commerce and the Rapid City United Way Campaign.<br>
<br>
She has also served on the executive boards of the National Crime Prevention Council, the
South Dakota Municipal League, the West River Food Bank and Rapid City's Big Brothers I
Big Sisters organization. She has also been a member of the board of directors for the
National Crime Prevention Council, Heifer International, Michigan National Bank&nbsp; and
the Black Hills Eye Institute.<br>
<br>
In service to all South Dakotans, she has been the president or chairperson of several
statewide groups, including the Children's Home Society, the Corrections Commission, the
Governor's Crime Commission and the Board of Charities and Corrections.<br>
<br>
Lieutenant Governor Hillard has also been active as an organization officer for the Rapid
City Regional Hospital Steering Committee, Women Against Violence, the South Dakota
Commission on the Status of Women, National College, the Ellsworth Air Force Base Action
Committee, the Rapid City Downtown Development Foundation, the South Dakota Public
Assurance Alliance and the Rapid City Community Care Center and the Ninety-niners, an
organization of women pilots<br>
<br>
<TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Lieutenant Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Carole Hillard<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> has volunteered to be an Election Supervisor in Bosnia
for the Peace Corps, Election Supervisor in Cambodia for the International Republican
Institute, Livestock Supervisor for Heifer International in Bolivia and Peru, and Election
Trainer in Angola, Africa for the International Republican Institute, Livestock Inspector
in Costa Rica for Heifer International and New Governor's Trainer in Nigeria for the
National Republic Institute.<br>
<br>
In 1986, she was recognized as the state's United Way Outstanding Chairperson. In the next
two years, she earned the Public Service Award and the Governor's Outstanding Citizen
Award. In 1993, she was named one of South Dakota's Outstanding Women. In&nbsp; 1999, she
was given the SD <TAG name="PARTY" value="start"/>Republican<TAG name="PARTY" value="end"/> Party Abe Award.<br>
<br>
After earning a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Bachelor of Arts degree in Education<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> in 1957, Lt. Governor Hillard was a
<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>school teacher<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. She <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>operated a successful car dealership<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> and is a veteran member of the
South Dakota business community. The Lieutenant Governor also earned a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Master's Degree in
Education<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> in 1983 and a <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>Master's Degree in Political Science<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> in 1984.<br>
<br>
During legislative sessions, Lieutenant Governor Hillard is the presiding officer of the
South Dakota Senate. She also votes in the Senate whenever the votes cast are equally
divided. Outside the legislative sessions, she is concentrating her energies on global
concerns, elderly issues and improving child care opportunities in South Dakota.<br>
<!--mstheme--></font><!--msnavigation--></td></tr><!--msnavigation--></table></body>
</html>
ENDOFDOC

<TAG name="EMPLOYER" value="end"/>Don Sundquist


Don Sundquist


Don Sundquist

      <table width="93%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
        <tr> 
          <td valign="top"> 
            <div align="left"><img src="images/photos/photo5btm.gif" width="212" height="149"></div>
          </td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td valign="top"><a href="index.html" onMouseOut="MM_swapImgRestore()" onMouseOver="MM_swapImage('home','','images/nav/frame2/home2.gif',1)"><img src="images/nav/frame1/home2.gif" width="212" height="24" name="home" alt="Return to the Governor's Home Page" border="0"></a></td>

        <tr> 
          <td valign="top"><a href="initiatives.html" onMouseOut="MM_swapImgRestore()" onMouseOver="MM_swapImage('initiatives','','images/nav/frame2/initiatives2.gif',1)"><img src="images/nav/frame1/initiatives2.gif" width="212" height="18" alt="Governor's Initiatives" name="initiatives" border="0"></a></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td valign="top"><a href="media.html" onMouseOut="MM_swapImgRestore()" onMouseOver="MM_swapImage('media','','images/nav/frame2/media_center2.gif',1)"><img src="images/nav/frame1/media_center2.gif" width="212" height="18" alt="Governor's Media Center" name="media" border="0"></a></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td valign="top"><a href="calendar.html" onMouseOut="MM_swapImgRestore()" onMouseOver="MM_swapImage('calendar','','images/nav/frame2/calendar2.gif',1)"><img src="images/nav/frame1/calendar2.gif" width="212" height="18" name="calendar" alt="Governor's Calendar" border="0"></a></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td valign="top"><a href="history.html" onMouseOut="MM_swapImgRestore()" onMouseOver="MM_swapImage('history','','images/nav/frame2/history2.gif',1)"><img src="images/nav/frame2/history2.gif" width="212" height="30" name="history" alt="Governor's Biography &amp; History" border="0"></a></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td valign="top"><a href="residence.html" onMouseOut="MM_swapImgRestore()" onMouseOver="MM_swapImage('residence','','images/nav/frame2/residence2.gif',1)"><img src="images/nav/frame1/residence2.gif" width="212" height="23" alt="Executive Residence" name="residence" border="0"></a></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td valign="top"><a href="firstlady.html" onMouseOut="MM_swapImgRestore()" onMouseOver="MM_swapImage('first_lady','','images/nav/frame2/firstlady2.gif',1)"><img src="images/nav/frame1/firstlady2.gif" width="212" height="32" name="first_lady" alt="First Lady of Tennessee, Martha Sundquist" border="0"></a></td>
        </tr>
      </table>
    </td>
    <td valign="top" colspan="2">
      <p></p>
      <p><a href="http://www.tennesseeanytime.org"><img src="../images/TNAnytime_logo.gif" width="140" height="68" border="0"></a></p>
      <p><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Don Sundquist<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was inaugurated as Tennessee's 47th governor in 
        January 1995. He was elected to a second term in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> with a record 69 
        percent of the vote. Since being in office, he has initiated unprecedented 
        reforms in the areas of welfare, crime and government, while placing a 
        special emphasis on <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Tennessee<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/> children.</p>
      <p>Under his watch, the growth of state government spending has been more 
        than cut in half, allowing Governor Sundquist to invest in his administration's 
        priority areas:</p>
      <ul>
        <li>A safe, healthy start for children</li>
      </ul>
      <ul>
        <li>Excellence in education</li>
      </ul>
      <ul>
        <li>Economic opportunity</li>
      </ul>
      <ul>
        <li>Protecting public safety and health and the environment</li>
      </ul>
      <p>Governor Sundquist has worked on a bipartisan basis with the Tennessee 
        General Assembly to win approval for a wide array of programs that further 
        the priorities he has set.</p>
      <p>In 1996, Governor Sundquist won overwhelming bipartisan approval from 
        the General Assembly for Families First, a statewide welfare reform program 
        designed to move Tennesseans from welfare to work in 18 months. The program 
        offers job training and assistance with transportation and day care needs. 
        Since Families First took effect Sept. 1, 1996, Tennessee has seen a 60 
        percent reduction in the number of employable adults on welfare.</p>
      <p>Along with Families First, Governor Sundquist reformed the way Tennessee 
        cares for its children in need by consolidating all services under one 
        department. The move eliminates duplication of services, saves taxpayers 
        money and, most importantly, provides better care for needy and troubled 
        children.</p>
      <p>Governor Sundquist also hosted the first-ever Governor's Summit on Tennessee's 
        Children in June 1998 to bring together families, businesses, churches, 
        schools and volunteers to make a brighter future for Tennessee children. 
        His TNKids initiative, an outcome of the summit, stresses early intervention 
        and prevention services and coordination of services for families and 
        children at the state and local levels. </p>
      <p>In education, Governor Sundquist completed a six-year, $1 billion increase 
        in state funding to Tennessee schools through the Basic Education Program. 
        Through his ConnectTen project, Tennessee became the first state in the 
        nation to connect every public school and library to the Internet. To 
        protect school children from pornographic material on the Internet, Tennessee 
        also was the first state to implement software-filtering technology on 
        public school computers.</p>
      <p>Under Governor Sundquist's leadership, Tennessee has experienced four 
        consecutive record years of economic development, topping $5.4 billion 
        in capital investment in 1998. Since 1994, Tennessee has gained more than 
        186,000 jobs and personal income has increased by 13.3 percent.</p>
      <p>In health care, Tennessee led the nation by offering health insurance 
        to every child who otherwise has no access to coverage. The state's child 
        immunization rate is at an all-time high, while rates of teen pregnancy 
        and infant mortality are at record lows.</p>
      <p> </p>
      <p>A longtime advocate of strong law enforcement, Governor Sundquist promised 
        to work to make Tennessee safe. Keeping his word, he worked with the General 
        Assembly to win approval of four consecutive crime packages that crack 
        down on violent offenders, drunk drivers and juvenile delinquents.</p>
      <p>Governor Sundquist's environmental record captured headlines in 1998 
        when reports showed Tennessee's air, land and water were the cleanest 
        they've been in 25 years. The governor also has made protecting Tennessee's 
        pristine beauty a priority, adding 17 new state natural areas since taking 
        office.</p>
      <p>Governor Sundquist has appointed the most diverse Cabinet in history 
        and has named a record number of women to senior posts. He also has appointed 
        a record number of female judges. </p>
      <p>As a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>small businessman<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in Memphis, Governor Sundquist first ran for elected 
        office in 1982 after he and his wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Martha<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, had raised their three children. 
        Faced with an opponent who came from a famous Tennessee political family 
        and little name recognition of his own, Governor Sundquist defied the 
        odds and won the Seventh District congressional seat. He was re-elected 
        <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>congressman<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> five times by large margins of support from Republicans, Democrats 
        and independents.</p>
      <p>During his time in Congress, Governor Sundquist continually fought against 
        higher taxes and inefficient government. After a self-imposed term limit 
        of 12 years in Washington, he returned home to seek the governorship of 
        <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Tennessee<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/>, winning a hard-fought election that brought together Tennesseans 
        from all walks of life to support his &quot;In Touch with Tennessee&quot; 
        campaign. </p>
      <br>
      <hr>
      <font size="5">Don Sundquist<br>
      Governor of Tennessee</font><br>
      <p>Biographical information</p>
      <br>
      <p>Don Sundquist<br>
        <TAG name="POSITION" value="start"/>Governor of <TAG name="STATE" value="start"/>Tennessee<TAG name="STATE" value="end"/><TAG name="POSITION" value="end"/><br>
        Profile</p>
      <p><TAG name="TITLE" value="start"/>Governor<TAG name="TITLE" value="end"/> <TAG name="NAME" value="start"/>Don Sundquist<TAG name="NAME" value="end"/> was inaugurated as Tennessee's 47th governor in 
        January 1995. He was elected to a second term in <TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="start"/>1998<TAG name="DATEELECTED" value="end"/> with a record 69 
        percent of the vote. Since being in office, he has initiated unprecedented 
        reforms in the areas of welfare, crime and government, while placing a 
        special emphasis on Tennessee children.</p>
      <p>Under his watch, the growth of state government spending has been cut 
        in half, allowing Governor Sundquist to invest in his administration's 
        priority areas:</p>
      <p>A safe, healthy start for children<br>
        Excellence in education<br>
        Economic opportunity<br>
        Protecting public safety and health and the environment</p>
      <p>Governor Sundquist has worked on a bipartisan basis with the Tennessee 
        General Assembly to win approval for a wide array of programs that further 
        the priorities he has set.</p>
      <p>In 1996, Governor Sundquist won overwhelming bipartisan approval from 
        the General Assembly for Families First, a statewide welfare reform program 
        designed to move Tennesseans from welfare to work in 18 months. The program 
        offers job training and assistance with transportation and day care needs. 
        Since Families First took effect Sept. 1, 1996, Tennessee has seen a 60 
        percent reduction in the number of employable adults on welfare.</p>
      <p>Along with Families First, Governor Sundquist reformed the way Tennessee 
        cares for its children in need by consolidating all services under one 
        department. The move eliminates duplication of services, saves taxpayers 
        money and, most importantly, provides better care for needy and troubled 
        children.</p>
      <p>Governor Sundquist also hosted the first-ever Governor's Summit on Tennessee's 
        Children in June 1998 to bring together families, businesses, churches, 
        schools and volunteers to make a brighter future for Tennessee children. 
        His TNKids initiative, an outcome of the summit, stresses early intervention 
        and prevention services and coordination of services for families and 
        children at the state and local levels. </p>
      <p>In education, Governor Sundquist completed a six-year, $1 billion increase 
        in state funding to Tennessee schools through the Basic Education Program. 
        Through his ConnectTen project, Tennessee became the first state in the 
        nation to connect every<br>
        public school and library to the Internet. To protect school children 
        from pornographic material on the Internet, Tennessee also was the first 
        state to implement software-filtering technology on public school computers.<br>
        This year, Governor Sundquist has proposed a statewide reading initiative 
        to ensure that Tennessee children learn to read by the end of the third 
        grade. </p>
      <p>Under Governor Sundquist's leadership, Tennessee has experienced five 
        consecutive record years of economic development, topping $7 billion in 
        capital investment in 2000. Since 1994, Tennessee has gained more than 
        196,000 jobs and personal income has increased by 23.6 percent.</p>
      <p>In health care, Tennessee led the nation by offering health insurance 
        to every child who otherwise has no access to coverage. The state's child 
        immunization rate is at an all-time high, while rates of teen pregnancy 
        and infant mortality are at record lows.<br>
        <br>
        A longtime advocate of strong law enforcement, Governor Sundquist promised 
        to work to make Tennessee safe. Keeping his word, he worked with the General 
        Assembly to win approval of four consecutive crime packages that crack 
        down on violent offenders, drunk drivers and juvenile delinquents.</p>
      <p>Governor Sundquist's environmental record captured headlines in 1998 
        when reports showed Tennessee's air, land and water were the cleanest 
        they've been in 25 years. The governor also has made protecting Tennessee's 
        pristine beauty a priority, adding 23 new state natural areas since taking 
        office. </p>
      <p>In the new millennium, Governor Sundquist announced that for the first 
        time in over 50 years, Tennessee has a new State Forest, the Gulf Tract 
        in Cocke County. </p>
      <p>Governor Sundquist has appointed the most diverse Cabinet in history 
        and has named a record number of women to senior posts. He also has appointed 
        a record number of female judges. </p>
      <p>As a <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>small businessman<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> in Memphis, Governor Sundquist first ran for elected 
        office in 1982 after he and his wife, <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Martha<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/>, had raised their three children. 
        Faced with an opponent who came from a famous Tennessee political family 
        and little name recognition of his own, Governor Sundquist defied the 
        odds and won the Seventh District congressional seat. He was re-elected 
        <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>congressman<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> five times by large margins of support from Republicans, Democrats 
        and independents.</p>
      <p>During his time in Congress, Governor Sundquist continually fought against 
        higher taxes and inefficient government. After a self-imposed term limit 
        of 12 years in Washington, he returned home to seek the governorship of 
        Tennessee, winning a hard-fought election that brought together Tennesseans 
        from all walks of life to support his &quot;In Touch with Tennessee&quot; 
        campaign. </p>
      <p></p>
      <p align="center">###</p>
      <p></p>
      <p></p>
      <p></p>
      <p></p>
      <p><br>
        Don Sundquist<br>
        Governor of Tennessee<br>
        Biographical Information</p>
      <p>Tennessee's 47th governor was born <TAG name="DOB" value="start"/>March 15, 1936<TAG name="DOB" value="end"/>. He married <TAG name="SPOUSE" value="start"/>Martha 
        Swanson<TAG name="SPOUSE" value="end"/> in 1959, and they have three children and two granddaughters: 
        <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Tania (Mrs. David) Williamson<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> of Montgomery, Alabama; <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Andrea (Mrs. Art) 
        Jeannet<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> of Phoenix, Arizona; <TAG name="CHILD" value="start"/>Donald Jr. (Deke)<TAG name="CHILD" value="end"/> of Nashville; Gabrielle 
        Renee Jeannet of Phoenix; and Alexandra Grace Jeannet of Pheonix. </p>
      <p>After graduating from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Augustana College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, he <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>served two years in the U.S. 
        Navy<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/>. In 1962, he joined <TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="start"/>Josten's<TAG name="PREVEMPL" value="end"/> and rose quickly to <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>plant manager<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> at 
        the scholastic products company's Shelbyville plant. Ten years later, 
        he struck out on his own, becoming <TAG name="PREVPOS" value="start"/>president and partner<TAG name="PREVPOS" value="end"/> of Graphic Sales 
        of America, a Memphis printing and advertising firm. </p>
      <p>His political experience includes: National Federation of Young Republicans 
        chairman 1971-1973; Shelby County Republican chairman, 1976-1978; manager, 
        Howard Baker for President, 1979; first elected to U.S. Congress in 1982; 
        member, Ways and Means Committee, Subcommittee on Trade, Subcommittee 
        on Select Revenue Measures; vice chairman, Congressional Technology Assessment 
        Board; past chairman, House Republican Task Force on Trade; former member, 
        House Republican Task Force on Ethics Reform. He has received <TAG name="DEGREE" value="start"/>honorary 
        doctorates<TAG name="DEGREE" value="end"/> from <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Lincoln Memorial University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>, <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Union University<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/> and <TAG name="SCHOOL" value="start"/>Newberry 
        College<TAG name="SCHOOL" value="end"/>. He is a member of the Lutheran church.</p>
      <p><br>
      </p>
      <p align="center"><cite>Send comments to <a href="mailto:dsundquist@mail.state.tn.us">Governor 
        Don Sundquist</a></cite></p>
      <hr>
      <p align="center"><a href="http://www.tennesseeanytime.org">TennesseeAnytime 
        Home</a> | <a href="http://www.tennesseeanytime.org/main/supplements/privacy.html">Privacy 
        Statement</a> | <a href="http://www.tennesseeanytime.org/main/supplements/survey.html">User 
        Survey</a> | <a href="http://www.tennesseeanytime.org/main/help/contact.html">Contact 
        Us</a></p>
      <hr>
      <p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
      <p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
    </td>
  </tr>
</table>
</body>
</html>

          <td valign="top"><a href="firstlady.html" onMouseOut="MM_swapImgRestore()" onMouseOver="MM_swapImage('first_lady','','images/nav/frame2/firstlady2.gif',1)"><img src="images/nav/frame2/firstlady2.gif" width="212" height="32" name="first_lady" alt="First Lady of Tennessee, Martha Sundquist" border="0"></a></td>
